Title: Go clean and green in 2020, say no to toxic beauty products
Content: The year 2019 witnessed conversations and discussions around what we consume and how it affects the environment and what’s sustainable and what’s not. Surprisingly, these conversations were not just restricted to food and clothing, but also took over the beauty and cosmetics industry. The term ‘clean beauty’ took center stage. Here’s everything you should know about the buzzword.As the term suggests, clean beauty refers to products that are mindfully created and produced without any proven or suspected toxic ingredients. Most of the products curated and created are said to have been sourced ethically and do not have side effects on your skin and the environment. “It is all about using the original source in its natural form and using that to the best of its capacity,” says Rubeina Karachiwalla, a beauty entrepreneur.Dermatologist and aesthetician Dr Anil Abraham says, “Patients have been wanting to know more about the trend and its benefits. As doctors, we are realising that it’s not a fad and is going to be the direction that skincare and health are going to take.” Deep Lalvani, a clean beauty curator, explains, “Increased exposure to pollution, stress and toxins in skincare has resulted in a more sensitive skin. Hence, this is building a stronger case towards clean beauty products.”“Products impact the environment through two main components — the product itself and product packaging. Product packaging includes several components that negatively impact the environment, namely plastic. A clean beauty approach focuses on sustainable packaging, recycling and using a supply chain that reduces carbon footprint,” says Deep. “Clean and green beauty should go hand-in-hand. The consumer must take their power back by demanding clean beauty products with sustainable packaging,” he adds.Experts advise that one should exercise caution and not follow a label that says ‘clean’. “There is a risk that these labels — natural, organic, preservative-free — may not actually be reflected in the contents of the product. It could be a clever marketing ploy to sell more expensive products to niche consumers who are aware of environmental damage,” says Dr Anil. “Some times, manufacturers use cheaper substitutes for natural materials and claim that it is clean, natural or vegan. Hence, consumers need to be informed and educate about the ingredients that are being used in products,” says Rubeina. Desiree Pereira, owner of a clean beauty line adds, “Manufacturers may use ingredients that may actually be worse than the ingredients they are trying to avoid in order to meet the ‘organic or natural’ criteria, and get similarefficacy. I would advise people to not go by labels, especially if they are not sure about how some of them can bemisleading.”For those who think clean beauty is the answer to glowing skin, experts advise otherwise. “A healthy lifestyle is the best beauty care. It is best to avoid harsh treatments and products on the skin. Products need to be genuine and manufacturers should ensure that the labels are not misleading and are within the reach of the common consumer in terms of price,” sums up Dr Anil.

Title: Rishi spends 10 days with cops to play a police officer
Content: After making his debut as a gangster in Attu, Rishi Rithvik will now be donning khakhi in his next, Marijuana. The film, directed by debutant MD Anand , will be a thriller that talks about how drug addiction is leading to crimes.Says Anand, “We generally blame parents for their children turning into monsters. This film will show how parents should be vigilant and ensure their kids don’t stray into a dangerous path. The film’s antagonist commits crimes under the influence of marijuana, and the story is about how the hero and heroine, who are both cops, nab him.”Rishi reveals that he spent 10 days with cops to prepare for this role. “I didn’t want any shades of Attu to come into this role. One of my brothers is a police officer, so I tagged along with him for 10 days to study the body language of cops to get into this role,” elaborates the actor.

Title: Mayakkum Margazhi: I usually don’t go past 5 minutes for an RTP, says Mahathi
Content: Performing a Ragam Tanam Pallavi (RTP) is an essential part of most Carnatic concerts, but there’s no denying that its inclusion increases the duration of the performance. Holding the audience’s attention and making them connect with the verses are some of the challenges artistes face. That’s one of the reasons why Mahathi S has chosen to do RTPs differently this year. The singer has been choosing general topics that relate to the audience for this segment.“Until last year, my RTPs were about God, but this year, I’ve been trying to sing on general subjects as well,” says Mahathi, “Usually in kutcheris, the songs are all about a particular God or a spiritual element. So, I decided to take up general subjects, like flowers, animals, Tamizh and Thirukkural, which Sanjay sir (Sanjay Subrahmanyan) generally does. For instance, one of my pallavis was —Kattravarai rasikka vaipathu kalaiya, rasiganai karka vaipathum kalaiye. It was in the ragam Rasali. Another one was, aanam pola vaazhkai undu, vaazhndu parka vaa, padi aadi maghizha, in ragam Shanmukhapriya. I usually don’t go beyond 25 minutes for an RTP and try to keep it energetic by choosing brisk ragams. This year, there have been a few occasions when we, as artistes, clapped for our audience from the stage because they have been attentive and sat for the entire duration. I think this kind of appreciative gestures help build relationships.”It has been 18 years since Mahathi started performing during the Margazhi season. Reminiscing about her first concert, she says, “In 2001, I performed for Karthik Fine Arts, at Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan Mini Hall for an audience of 20. But long ago, when I was three-and-a-half-years old, I had once sung during the season. In that sense, my first Margazhi concert was on December 25, 1988. Though my dad is from Thiruvaiyaru, he worked in a private company in Kerala, and I spent my childhood there.”Mahathi continues, “So, every December, he’d bring me to Chennai so that I could attend concerts. It was Mandolin Shrinivas sir’s kutcheri at Mylapore Fine Arts. I was sitting on my mother’s lap and was loudly blurting out the ragas in which he was performing. When he started Madhyamavathi, I said the concert was over. Those who were seated next to my mom were quite surprised. They insisted that I do a live demo after Shrinivas sir finished his concert. The sabha secretary, Venkatraman mama, arranged for it, and my mom coaxed me to get on the dais. Shrinivas sir and Kanyakumari amma (A Kanyakumari, violinist) were on stage, playing different ragas, and I was spelling out the ragas using a stage mic. That was such a big exposure for me.”Coming from a family of musicians, it was but natural for Mahathi to develop a deep passion for the performing arts. “My appa (Thiruvaiyaru P Sekar) is a disciple of Balamurali sir and my mom is a flautist. My great grandfather, Pazhamaneri Swaminatha Iyer, is the fourth Sangita Kalanidhi of Madras Music Academy. Our house in Thiruvaiyaru is a stone’s throw away from Thyagaraja’s sannidhi. So, I was heavily influenced by music in my growing up years,” she says.But why did it take her so many years to perform during Margazhi? “That’s because I was based out of Kerala, where I was doing my schooling. It was actually after I got an opportunity to sing for Ilaiyaraaja sir that I shifted to Chennai. I sang for him during my Class 11 vacation and shifted to Chennai for my next academic year. In a way, it was because of my playback singing career that I could perform during Margazhi,” she states.But the singer admits her career in films also stopped people from taking her seriously as a classical musician. “I had big hits as a playback singer till 2011. During those few years, people thought I was taking Carnatic music lightly, even though I wasn’t. The problem is, if you appear on a TV show, people think you are more into light music. Even if you maintain your film and Carnatic music career separately, it’s difficult to change this mindset of people.”But now that she’s established herself as a Carnatic musician as well, is there any advice that she’d like to give aspiring Carnatic musicians? “It takes a lot of preparation to sing during Margazhi. I was 17 when I gave my first Margazhi concert, and I remember how much of planning I did to finalise the ragam and kalpanaswaram. When we start, we by-heart a lot of stuff, and are not very confident about going extempore on stage. We try to render whatever we have practised to near perfection. If we forget even one swaram, then the flow completely stops. But as you evolve, you stop rehearsing. You gain confidence as you perform. The other problem that we generally face is with our voice — we don’t know how to manage our voice and get stressed out. We learn that too as we grow. But beyond all that, I think it’s also a sheer blessing to be able to perform well on stage. There are times when you have gone over a song a thousand times, but it will not work out that day. That’s the superpower controlling you.”

Title: Ushering in New Year, Tolly style!
Content: The New Year’s Eve party at the Tollygunge Club was probably one of the most rocking ones in the city on Tuesday night. The club members and their guests turned up in hordes to enjoy the night. “This is a very special New Year’s Eve for Tolly Club. It is the curtain-raiser for the celebration of the club’s 125 years,” said Anil Mukerji, CEO and managing member of the club.The party had an enviable lineup of artistes like Louis Banks, Shayne Hyrapiet, Michelle and Sonia Teresa Saigal, who enthralled the crowd with their amazing performances. As the clock struck 12, everyone thronged the dance floor and wished each other a very happy New Year. We spotted percussionist Bickram Ghosh with wife Jaya Seal Ghosh at the do. Bickram told us, “It’s always lovely to be present at the club’s New Year’s Eve bash. Jaya, our elder son, Adit, and I are having a super time. The music is great. Louis Banks and his team are simply phenomenal. I am ringing in the New Year in a relaxed manner with my family.”The celebrations rounded off with everyone digging into a lavish spread of Indian and continental dishes.

Title: 2020 is going to be all about pop revolution and indie music: Akasa
Content: Akasa had a whirlwind 2019 with her songs being played at music festivals in Mauritius, the singer collaborating with international artistes like Lauv and her track Naagin becoming a chartbuster. She was recently in Bengaluru for a performance. In a quick chat with us, Akasa spoke about her work with Ricky Martin, how Thug Ranjha propelled her into the music industry, how she believes in being authentic and more, Excerpts:It was a great year. In fact, the last few months of 2019 were more eventful for me than ever. Thug Ranjha was a really good start to my career, then there was a brief gap before my next project. Meanwhile, I had also been dubbing for film songs, but two of the songs that I sang last November were included in films only recently. But, overall, yes it has been an eventful year for me.Ricky and I are managed by the same music label. The team behind the label told me that he was looking for an Indian voice for his track, Vente Pa Ca, and they asked if I would like to go for it. So, I just dubbed the scratch vocals and sent it across, and the next thing I know is that I was in the song. Even my latest track, Dil Naa Janeya, was scratch vocals. But I was pleasantly surprised when I heard the final track recently. In my head, I was only hoping for it to work out well. But it not only worked out, it also had someone like Lauv being part of it.I don’t think reality shows help everybody, because, right now, there are so many of them. But it definitely helped me. It gave me a push and that is how I bagged the song, Tu Kheech Meri Photo. Even though, I was only a small part of it, it gave me an identity. It was the only thing I had to my credit for a long time. Reality shows give you a platform to reach out to a wider audience. But only a few lucky ones go viral. It’s a platform that prepares you for what you will experience once you enter the industry.Being versatile and doing things that others probably struggle to do helps. I have worked really hard on my dancing skills and my fitness, which, in turn, helped me be the face of Thug Ranjha, and not just the voice behind it. I saw my father, Arvinder Singh, on stage and the kind of fan following he had, and I wanted the same. The ‘popstar’ aura that Beyoncé has created around herself is a true inspiration. Being authentic helps you stand out from the rest.Absolutely. I feel the ’90s were cool, because pop music was above Bollywood at that time. If you compare KK or Lucky Ali’s fan following at that time, it was way more than that of a playback singer. Thankfully, it’s making a comeback. Everyone is receiving singles very well, so much so that many tracks are now being used in films as well. I feel the pop revolution is here, and 2020 will be all about indie music.I’m one of the least trained singers in my family. As a child, I was taught the basics of classical music. But since my father is a singer, I think I’ve got his genes and I’m making use if that to the fullest. Learning classical music helps you so much. If you learn the base of classical music, your voice gets so well rounded that you can sing anything. My brother is a good example of that. Woh English gaane sun sun ke shayad mujhe gaana nahi aata.I’m at a point now where I would love to work with anyone and everyone. So far, I’ve dubbed for many music composers, but there’s no one who I don’t want to work with. Collaborating with AR Rahman, however, would be a dream come true. I have also been obsessed with Diljit Dosanj and hope that I would get to work with him too in the near future.

Title: After his solo act, Parthiban to make a single-shot film next
Content: After directing Oththa Seruppu Size 7 , a solo act film that also featured him, Parthiban has announced his next. The actor-filmmaker will be directing Iravin Nizhal , which will be a single-shot film. “There have been a few single-shot films made across the world, like Victoria and Russian Ark, but this will be a full-fledged feature film, which will be filmed in a single shot,” says Parthiban.The first-look poster of the film was released yesterday by Bharathirajaa. “I’d written Oththa Seruppu 15 years ago, and Iravin Nizhal five years ago. I’d almost gone on floor with this one a few years ago, but had to put the idea on the backburner because of some issues. But now, I’m starting work on this with renewed vigour because of the love people of Tamil Nadu have given me. They made my Oththa Seruppu a success and that has given me confidence,” says Parthiban.The director has started the pre-production work. “There will be multiple characters, and we are working towards finalising the cast and crew. Alfred Hitchcock had made a film called Rope, which people acknowledge as a single-shot film. But he had shot the film by brilliantly blending to make it look like one. But we won’t be joining or stitching together scenes at all. It will be a challenge to shoot a full-length film in a single shot, and we will rehearse it before shooting. It’s a challenge I’m game for,” he signs off.

Title: My Favourite Raga: One raga I have circled back to often is Begada, says Rithvik Raja
Content: As musicians, we learn new compositions and we keep exploring different ragas. There are different periods during which we lean towards one raga. In 10 concerts, a raga might be featured five or six times invariably. Then, once that phase passes, you probably will not hear it in the next 15 or 20 concerts. And then, it will pop back. That, I think, is the beauty of the options that are available wide and plenty. All of them have amazing scope for exploration.One raga I have circled back to often is Begada. In fact, when I was around 12 years old, I remember telling my friends that one thing I wanted to probably learn was every composition in Begada. That raga continues to fascinate me. Incidentally, in my concert this Monday, that was the raga I sang as the main piece.If someone put a gun to my head and said I had to pick one raga, it would be Begada. The melody of this raga is stuck in my head. I remember hanging around my mother’s classes with her teacher as a toddler. Her teacher made her learn one line in this raga over and over again across three or four classes. That was the one line I kept hearing. She was also my teacher between 2000 and 2003. The first ever composition that she taught me was the Begada varnam. That is my earliest memory of any raga or any class.

Title: Tovino to play a triple role in a multi-genre film
Content: If 2019 was about Tovino Thomas proving he can handle any role with ease, 2020 seems to be about him showing that he belongs in the big league. The actor, who is currently busy with the superhero film Minnal Murali, has signed another big-budget entertainer titled Ajayante Randam Moshanam that will have him in a triple role.The movie’s director Jithin Lal , who has worked as the chief associate director of films such as Godha , Kalki and Ennu Ninte Moideen, tells us, “The movie has portions set in 1900, 1950 and 1990. Tovino plays characters named Maniyan, Kunjikelu and Ajayan, respectively, in these three generations. The main storyline though will be set in the 90s.”Ask him if it’s an adventure-fantasy and Jithin says, “It has multiple genres. But at its core, it’s an entertainer. The movie would remind the audience of the stories that they have read in Malayalam comic magazines.”Jithin, who had recently helmed a trilingual music video titled Pragathi featuring Wamiqa Gabbi, Lena and Nyla Usha, also informs us that the work on the script and its pre-production has been on for two years now. Sujith Nambiar has penned the screenplay while Dhibu Ninan Thomas, who composed for the Tamil movie Kanaa, will handle the music department.“We are now in the process of finalising the cast. As it’s a big project, there is some more work to be done before we can start shooting. We expect the movie to go on floors by mid 2020,” says the filmmaker.The team has zeroed in on Kannur, Kasaragod and Wayanad as the main locations for Ajayante Randam Moshanam. Like Tovino-Basil Joseph team’s Minnal Murali, this film too is set to be dubbed and released in several languages apart from Malayalam.

Title: Shimla witnessed coldest December in 20 years
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Youngsters welcome the New Year in Shimla. Himachal Pradesh experienced dry and cold weather on Wednesday.<... Read More SHIMLA: The month gone by, December, was the coldest during day time in Shimla in the last two decades. Average monthly minimum temperature in Shimla during December was 3.8 degrees Celsius, which was the second lowest average minimum temperature after 1997, when it was 3.1 degrees Celsius. Meanwhile, there appears no immediate relief from freezing cold in Himachal Pradesh as cold conditions have intensified and the meteorological department has predicted chances of snow from January 2 to 4. Shimla meteorological centre director Manmohan Singh said that total monthly snowfall in December in Shimla was recorded as 20.3 cm, after 2014 when it was 38.1 cm. Even, average monthly maximum temperature of Shimla during December was 13.4 degrees Celsius, which is the lowest average maximum temperature in the last 20 years. The lowest maximum average temperature was 10.5 degrees Celsius in 1986. He said Keylong in Lahaul-Spiti district recorded the lowest minus 16.4 degrees Celsius on December 17, which was the lowest minimum temperature since 2009, when minus 13.2 degrees Celsius was recorded on December 25. Monthly average minimum temperature recorded in Keylong was minus 9.9 degrees Celsius, which was the lowest monthly temperature after 2009 when minus 8.4 degrees Celsius was recorded. The met centre director said that November and December months last year were colder at few places in Himachal Pradesh as compared to last few years. He said that there were four spells of precipitation in November and one significant spell in the December last year. He said that period from October 1 to December 31 is known as "Post-monsoon season" or "North-east Monsoon Season" and during this period overall precipitation over the state was 33% above normal. He said this was highest precipitation in Himachal Pradesh since 2004. Previous highest precipitation was 5% above normal during Post-Monsoon Season in 2004. On account of three spells of rainfall and snowfall in November last year and one significant spell of precipitation in December, both day temperature and night were below normal. Rain and snow has been predicted for tourist town of Shimla for Thursday and Friday. On Saturday, hill town is likely to receive light rain and snow but after that moderate rain and snow has been predicted for Monday and Tuesday.

Title: Sitting pretty on top, will this new year be a happy one for FC Goa?
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: Not that FC Goa haven’t been here before, but this time around, there is added pressure.

Goa finished the last year and the first leg at the top of the Indian Super League table. That doesn’t mean much; all that matters is how they will end. Finishing in the top four and then going on to win their first ISL title, and a purse of Rs 8 crore, would be fine with plenty of fans. But for a club that aims to make a name for itself at the continental level, the joy of finishing at the top of the table and booking a rare spot – the first for anyone from India – in the AFC Champions League (ACL) should be unmatched.

Can Goa hold on to the top spot? Of course, they can. Will it be easy? No chance.

Whether Goa are ready for the big challenge should be known when they take on the might of Bengaluru FC in their next game on Friday. The defending champions are five points behind and have been unexpectedly sluggish all through the season. They have won only four of their 10 games and scored just 11 goals, the least among the top six teams. Yet, Goa will still dread a side they have always found too hot to handle.

Sergio Lobera’s boys have won just once against Bengaluru, and that came in 2017. In all other matches, they have been second best, including last season’s final. In fact, the last time Goa visited the Sree Kanteerava Stadium in Bengaluru, the hosts won 3-0, despite having Nishu Kumar sent off and playing an astonishing 50 minutes with a numerical disadvantage.

Should Goa get the better of Bengaluru, they will open an eight-point gap between the two favourites. That should prove to be a major boost, although given the nature of the league, nothing can be taken for granted.

Goa are without coach Lobera for the Bengaluru clash. His assistant and most trusted hand, assistant coach Jesus Tato, will be calling the shots from the sidelines.

“You can see that we have a very strong defence, have quick wingers who have great quality and Coro in front. This makes our squad very strong. We also have other players on the bench who are waiting for an opportunity. All of them possess enough quality and skills to make the starting XI. We are very lucky to have these players with us,” said Tato.

Tato will need all of them to punch above their weight against Bengaluru.

Lobera will return for the home clash against NorthEast United on January 8, but there are fears that it may be time for some Goa players to watch from the sidelines. With five players now on three yellow cards -- Ahmed Jahouh, Edu Bedia, Brandon Fernandes, Seriton Fernandes and Lenny Rodrigues – they are in danger of missing a game, if they pick up another booking.

Then there are some really difficult games. Goa still have to play three of the top five teams away. ATK, Jamshedpur FC and even Odisha FC will make it hard, but first Goa must show they mean business against Bengaluru.

Title: Maharashtra Police get custody of human trafficking victim
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

YAMUNANAGAR: A fourmember team of the Maharashtra Police took the custody of the woman, who had been rescued from the clutches of a human trafficking gang from Yamunanagar last week. The victim, who belonged to Chandrapur district , had been kidnapped when she was just 13 years old from a temple in Ram Nagar in 2010. She will meet her family after nine years.

The police team under sub-inspector Pradeep Nitavane from Ram Nagar police station of Chandrapur district got her custody and left for Maharashtra on Wednesday morning.

During the years that she spent in captivity, the woman was gang-raped, sold, married, raped, and even gave birth to two children in Fatehabad district , where she lived for around seven years with one Dharamvir.

The woman was rescued with the efforts of a Yamunanagar-based NGO when she disclosed her ordeals to one of its members last week. Afterwards, the NGO approached the Yamunanagar women police station (PS), which registered a zero FIR on the complaint of the survivor and transferred the case to the Ram Nagar police station of Chandrapur district.

“Maharashtra Police took the custody of the woman and took her along,” inspector Seema, in charge of Yamunanagar women police station, said. “She will be able to meet her mother once we reach Maharashtra. Meanwhile, her cousin brother and uncle met us in New Delhi on Wednesday and they have identified her,” said SI Nitavane.

Nitavane said, “In 2010, she was kidnapped from Ram Nagar police station area and her family members had lost hope of finding her again. Thanks to the NGO and social activists, who made efforts to report the case to the police station, the woman will finally reunite with her mother after nine long years.”

‘Adopt, don’t shop’

Braving a record breaking winter, Delhi’s furry friends came out in their best attires as India’s biggest pet festival, Pet Fed, was back for its sixth edition at Okhla NSIC ground. With dedicated play areas for pets and food and drinks stalls for pet parents, the two-day event was a treat for everyone.The carnival featured a number of events, such as Temptation Alley, Pet Cosplay, International Cat Show, Pet’s Got Talent and, of course, the crowd favourite – Pet Fashion Show. Pet parent Shruti Mittal, who came with her pug buddy Rocky to the event, said, “This is my first time here and it feels amazing. My pet is a little scared as it is his first time also but I am loving this initiative. There are not a lot of places for pets to socialise. I know of only one pet-friendly cafe.”A police dog show organised in association with Delhi Police crime dog squad saw 10 talented police dogs perform various tasks, such as sniffing out hidden suspicious objects. In a bid to expand further and make this edition stand out from the previous ones, the International Cat Show was also held in association with the World Cat Federation . “Many people attending the previous editions had pointed out that cats get left out with so many dogs being here. That’s why we have arranged for the International Cat Show this year,” said Akshay Gupta, founder of Pet Fed. International experts were present at the show to guide pet parents on how to take care of their cats.While the pet talent show saw a lot of skilled pets, like a singing husky and a paneer-catching Dalmatian, many four-legged buddies felt too lazy to perform due to the evening chill. The fashion show saw a lot of unique participants. Some pooches dressed up as cowboys and minions, others went traditional and set the ramp on fire in dhoti and kurta . From India’s most followed cat on Instagram to a chow chow dog with 1,054 followers on social media, pet celebs stole the show as pet lovers queued up to click photos with them.Raising awareness among pet lovers to adopt indigenous dogs instead of shopping for exotic breeds was one of the initiatives taken up at the event. To encourage the same, desi pets were allowed free entry. Animal rights activist Ambika Shukla, who was also one of the judges of the fashion show, urged the audience to adopt desi dogs instead of an exotic one. “If you want a pet, adopt an Indian dog. Every shelter is overloaded with dogs. You would be getting a best friend for free,” she said.-- Imana.Bhattacharya@timesgroup.comIn Video: Delhi's furry friends have a paw-some time at Pet Fed 2-019

Title: Riva Kishan: I feel the most fashionable during winters
Content: Priyaank and Riva get candid about their Delhi connection and express their love for the city’s winter and delicaciesWith their debut film hitting the theatres this weekend, Priyaank Sharma and Riva Kishan have been very busy. But when the two came to town to promote their upcoming film, ' Sab Kushal Mangal ', they simply couldn’t resist pausing in the neighbourhood to experience the Delhi winter. “I am freezing,” said Priyaank Sharma as he walked on the streets of Delhi on the cold winter morning. Talking about his Delhi connection, he shared, “It’s not the first time that I am here. In fact, I have a family in Sainik Farms and I have come to Delhi after three years. I used to roam around GK 1 and GK 2 and would often go on long drives with my friends. I have partied a lot in south Delhi and that’s a very comfortable setting for me.”For Riva, too, coming to Delhi is not new. She told us, “Since my dad ( Ravi Kishan ) is now a politician, mera Dilli aana laga hi rehta hai. Pehle itna zyada nahi hota tha but in the past few years, it has increased.” The actress added, “The best time to visit Delhi is in the winters. I absolutely love winters as I feel the most fashionable during this time. I was born and brought up in Mumbai, so wahan toh sardi hoti nahin hai. We cannot wear nice jackets there.” Echoing the sentiment, Priyaank said, “Not just the weather, the food is amazing too. Kisi bhi restaurant ke Delhi outlet ka khaana hamesha zyada achcha hoga.”Since both the actors belong to filmi families, there is a certain pressure of expectations they face. Priyaank, who is the son of Padmini Kolhapure , said, “Neither do I take pressure nor do I want to because if I do, then I will not be able to perform well. If I start comparing myself with my mom or my cousins ( Shraddha Kapoor and Siddhanth Kapoor ) then I will never be able to truly devote myself to work. Having said that, I think if I can become half the actor my mom is, then I think I am good.” Riva added, “This debate has been ongoing but I don’t think I am gonna let it affect me. I am here to entertain the audience and that’s all I am going to do. I might be a star kid in the eyes of the people but in reality I am just an actor doing my job. I am just taking my baby steps and I hope the audience will love my work.”

Title: Prasad Jawade: I feel blessed to play Dr BR Ambedkar on screen: Actor Prasad Jawade
Content: Well-known Marathi actor Prasad Jawade is on cloud nine these day. Reason being the actor has bagged his first show as a lead in the serial Ek Mahanayak, Dr BR Ambedkar in which he will be playing the lead role. Ask Prasad, who was recently in Lucknow to promote the show, on how it feels to play an iconic character like that of BR Ambedkar, and he says “Since childhood I have been reading about Dr BR Ambedkar. I also saw Marathi film director Jabbar Patel ’s film Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar in which Mammootty had acted. All I know before doing this serial about Ambedkar sahab was that he wrote the constitution, he was ‘the’ mahanayak, who was fighting for the rights of other castes. But today I have realised that his work is so big that it is beyond our imagination. I feel blessed to play an iconic character like Dr BR Ambedkar.”Prasad Jawade (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Ask Prasad on how acting happened for him and he shares, “This all started when I was doing theatre for a theatre group in a town 30 kilometres from Pune. This I am talking when I was very young. Soon after I completed my high school, I realised that I should do something in theatre only, though I did my class XII from Science stream and then a diploma from Information Technology. At one time, I also wanted to pursue law, but that could not happen because I was also doing theatre. But luckily because of Baba Sahab Bhimrao Ambedkar ji, today I am getting to play such a role in which I am getting to read all the things related to law. And very soon, as a part of the research work for my character, I will be going to a law school to study Baba Sahab Bhimrao Ambedkar ji’s subject constitution of India. So this way I will be studying Law indirectly.”He adds, “My acting journey started when I participated in a talent hunt show Maharashtracha Superstar. I was among the top 12 contestants and this competition changed everything for me. After this reality show, I auditioned for films and serial and have done four Marathi serials, out of which I also played the role of a blind guy in a serial. This was one of the most challenging roles for me because I had to move blindfolded for almost two months.”Having Bollywood aspirations, Prasad says he also keep auditioning for films. “Ever since I came to this field, I only want to do the best work possible. I never wanted to be a hero because I wasn’t the filmy-filmy guy ever. I always wanted to do good and some meaningful work. I also did a small role in Chhichhore,” he says.– Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui

Title: Alistair Petrie’s India vacay with wife & kids
Content: Popular Hollywood actor Alistair Petrie , who has featured in films such as The Bank Job and Rogue One : A Star Wars Story, was recently in Udaipur on a vacation with his family. Alistair, his wife Lucy Scott and three children came to Udaipur on December 26 and returned to Delhi on December 29, from where they headed to Agra to visit Taj Mahal. Before coming to Udaipur, Alistair and his family had visited the Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur and the Kumbhalgarh Ranakpur Temple.Alistair Petrie (second from left) visited The Bungalow Udaipur, a multi-cuisine restaurant in Udaipur“He kept his trip to Udaipur very low profile. He didn’t want anyone to know about it. In fact, he didn’t even stay at a fancy hotel. The family was in Udaipur for two-and-a-half days. On the first day, they went on a tour of the city and visited the City Palace and Saheliyon Ki Bari. Then they enjoyed a boat ride at Lake Pichola . In the evening, they did a 25km bicycle tour in Udaipur,” a source said.Alistair Petrie (third from right) enjoying a bicycle ride in Udaipur“The next day, the family went on a 10km trek from the Morvanya village to Ubeshwarji in Udaipur, taking in the scenic landscape. After exploring Udaipur, they left for Delhi. They will be leaving India on January 2,” the source added.Alistair Petrie visits Taj Mahal in Agra

Title: #MentalHealthMatters: It’s time for digital detox
Content: In a technology and social media obsessed world, digital detox is one of the crucial steps you can take for your mental well-beingIt’s that time of the year again when New Year resolutions are made. Gyms are flooded with membership requests, while some vow to pursue a sport. Atthe corner paanwala’s, one can hear many well-intentioned souls declare, ‘Bas, yeh mera aakhri sutta hai’. While focus on physical health and being fit is one of the most common (and, of course, important) resolutions that one can make in a new year, there’s a new addition to the list – mental well-being. And in a technology and social media-obsessed world, it seems that digital detox is one of the crucial steps one can take to ensure mental well-being.People give a wide range of reasons for taking a break from social media – ranging from breakup, sleep disorder to depression. While reasons vary, most people agree on one thing – digital detox is essential for mental well-being. Even if it is for few hours a day, it definitely helps in dealing with anxiety. Several studies have also confirmed that disengaging from social media can make one happier and less stressed out.In mid-2019, Chennai-based digital marketer Sorav Jain posted a survey on his blog to determine whether people were digital addicts. His survey showed that 80% of the 2,500 respondents looked at their mobile phones the last thing at night and first thing in the morning, while 70% scrolled through their social media feed to put themselves to sleep.When he decided to go for a digital fast, 512 of the survey respondents, who found they couldn’t do without their phones, decided to go on a fast with him. But a majority of them crashed and burned, several tweeting a couple of hours into the upwaas that they just couldn’t do it.Jain was one of those who succeeded and spent the day playing with his son. He even managed to read an entire book. The survey also showed 40% said they could not live without their phone for even a day. “Most of those who took the survey were in the 18-30 years age group,” Sorav was quoted as saying in a report.In November 2019, a teenager from Bengaluru, Tanvi overcame her Instagram addiction and inspired people to take a #1HrChallenge to stay away from gadgets every day. Tanvi herself was addicted to Instagram. “I used to post pictures regularly and started accepting requests of random people to get more followers and likes on social media. I had over 400 followers in a short time,” Tanvi was quoted as saying in a TOI report. When Tanvi’s academic score fell from 80% to 50%, she realised that there was a problem. She decided to stay away from gadgets. She began organising board game competitions and painting contests for people in her residential complex.In seven months, Tanvi said over 200 people told her how her challenge helped them ‘disconnect from gadgets and connect back to life’. There are many like Sorav and Tanvi who realised that they are ‘digital addicts’ and tried to overcome their addiction, but it wasn’t easy.“We were having a discussion in our office once about who is always online and who is not after work. Turned out that I was the one who was always on social media. So a colleague challenged me that I have to spend a day without looking at any of my phone apps. I took the challenge and thought it would be easy, but that was the first time I realised that I am an addict. I could survive only half a day without checking my phone. But after that experience, I tried taking half-day break from phone one day on the weekend. I succeeded after six weeks and now, I take a day off every week from my phone,” says Sujata Bisht, a 29-year-old resident of Lajpat Nagar.Saloni Singh, a life coach, underwent digital detox classes for 15-20 days twice last year. Her intent was to learn to take a break from social media and ultimately she decided to quit it. “Once you start disengaging from social media platforms, you realise that you end up spending your time more productively and that has a positive impact on your mind,” says Saloni, who is now helping people fight digital addiction. “Different people consume content on social media differently. Some young people tend to believe everything they see on social media. They sometimes set goals inspired by someone else’s life as they see on social media or aspire to be like someone else. When they realise they can’t be like that other person, it results in low self-esteem and depression,” adds Saloni.Writer Advaita Kala was not on any social media platform for a long time while she was in the process of writing. “I was not using any social media platform to use my time productively. Also, I realised that social media is so full of poorly formed opinions that at the end of the day, it just exhausts you. Digital detox is essential for one’s mental well-being,” says Advaita. Shreya Gyawali, a student, shares, “I had just passed out of school and was having a tough time adjusting in Mumbai after living in Hisar for years. Whenever I would log on to Facebook and Instagram, I would see people having a great time. But when I personally interacted with them, I realised that was not the case. Everyone seems to be under pressure to showcase a perfect life on social media and that made me uncomfortable. It made me realise that everyone was filtering their lives and I did not want to do that.”Shreya went off social media for two years and admits that it did have a positive impact on her mental health.– Inputs from Tanya Kundu

Title: Murder accused out on bail slits throat of nurse in hotel
Content:
Cops take away the body of the woman from the hotel.

Cops hunt for nurse killer in Hry, Punjab

CHANDIGARH: A 29-year-old nurse working in a private hospital in Mohali was found murdered in a room of a hotel in Industrial Area, Phase II, on Wednesday in a gory start to the New Year in the city.Sarabjit Kaur's throat had been slit with a sharp-edged weapon. Her killer is suspected to be her 31-year-old friend Maninder Singh, a resident of Sector 30 who is out on bail in a 10-year-old murder case. He had allegedly stabbed a woman to death in a park at Karna Lake, a tourist attraction, in Karnal in 2010.Sarabjit, who belonged to Sangrur in Punjab and was residing in Gracier hostel in Sector 69 of Mohali, had booked the room at Hotel Sky for two days on December 30. She had checked in with Maninder. She was to check out at 12 noon on January 1. Police said the staff noticed that she had not stepped out till 1.30pm. When she did not respond to repeated knocks, an employee opened the door with a master key and found her lying in a pool of blood.Police suspect Maninder killed her on December 30 night. CCTV footage of the hotel showed Maninder going out of the premises alone at 11.55 pm on December 30. Nobody had visited the room in the last two days, according to the hotel staff.Sarabjit was the youngest among four siblings. Police said she wanted to marry Maninder but her parents were against the relationship. Their main objection was that he belongs to a different caste, police said. The victim and Maninder had stayed in the hotel on several occasions, sources in the police department said. They had been seeing each other for the last two years. Sources said Maninder was a drug addict and had been arrested by the UT police under NDPS Act eight months ago. He had spent two months in jail and then got out on bail.Maninder had been working in a factory in Industrial Area, Phase I, but left the job around three months ago. Sector 31 police booked Maninder for murder. Police teams have been sent to parts of Haryana and Punjab to nab him. Earlier, senior superintendent of police Nilambari Vijay Jagadale, SP (city) Vineet Kumar, and Sector 31 police station house officer along with other cops inspected the crime site.A Central Forensic Science Laboratory (CFSL) team collected fingerprints and other samples for examination. Police said no weapon was recovered. Charanjit Singh, deputy superintendent of police, PRO, said the Sector 31 police registered a murder case on the statement of hotel staff. CCTV footage and hotel records have been seized for investigation.Police kept the body for post-mortem at Government Medical College and Hospital, Sector 32. Cops informed the parents of the victim in Sangrur. The autopsy would be conducted on Thursday.

Title: With 6 training centres, Bhopal is water sports hub
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The waters of Upper and Lower Lakes have produced outstanding sportspersons

BHOPAL: Bhopal is a prominent name when it comes to water sports in India. With six water sports centres, Bhopal is fast becoming the water sports hub in the country. At the recently concluded All-India Police Water Sports Meet, a majority of the medallists from the police teams from across the country who participated were trained in Bhopal only. The waters of Upper and Lower Lakes have produced outstanding sportspersons, who are challenging established champions at national and international meets. In both lakes, water sports centres are being run by the sports department (one each at Upper Lake and Lower Lake), ITBP (Upper Lake), EME (Khanu Gaon Upper Lake), SSB (Lower lake), MP Kayaking and Canoeing Association (MPKCA) and a private boat club (Lower Lake). Asked about the reason for so many water sports centres, senior coach Mayank Thakur cited the example of Lower Lake. He said water sports centres at the Lower Lake is the only centre in the country providing practice facility on all kinds of boats. "The water sports centre at Lower Lake is the only centre in the country providing facility of practising on plastic, melo, wazda and other such international boats. It would help players to acclimatize on all kinds of boats," said Thakur. Currently, the centre has over 500 boats costing around Rs 7-8 crore. He added that the water body is very balanced and ideal for water sports events. "Our centre can host events round-the-year and organize camps in all seasons. Due to this reason, players from across the country are keen to practise in Bhopal," said Mayank. The centre conducts around 7-8 campd every year, where the country's best players practise before participating in any big event. Besides, good geographical conditions have made the state capital the best venue in the country for water sports. "Upper Lake and Lower Lake has still water, which is best for conducting water sports events. Other places in the country where such water bodies are available are not blessed with the facilities of slow moving wind, peaceful city and world-class facilities," claimed secretary general, Indian Kayaking and Canoeing Association (IKCA) Prashant Singh Kushwaha. Calling their centre the best in the country, former IKCA secretary BS Kushwaha said, "It is because of excellent infrastructure in Bhopal that Madhya Pradesh has been the national champion in water sports for the past several years." Notably, MP won the title of both boys and girls categories in the recently concluded junior kayaking and canoeing championship. "The centre has made it possible for the country to think of medals in water sports in the next two Olympics," claimed Prashant. The director of sports, department, SL Thaosen said, "National sailing school and other centres have made Bhopal an attractive centre in the country."

Title: CAA protests in UP: In India’s long history of protests, UP first to make ‘vandals’ pay price
Content:
Thousands of Muslims hit the streets of Kochi on Wednesday demanding that the Citizenship (Amendment) Act be w... Read More

HARYANA:

DELHI:

GUJARAT:

WEST BENGAL:

ODISHA:

KARNATAKA:

KERALA:

ASSAM:

RAJASTHAN

The UP government’s attempt to identify and make rioters pay for the damage caused to public property during the recent anti-citizenship law protests is without precedent in a country where many states have, at one time or another, endured destruction on the streets in the name of agitation. The only other instance of strong punitive action being ordered for vandalising public property is against the Dera Sacha Sauda in Punjab, albeit on court orders.While the jury is out on whether the Yogi Adityanath government’s move will stand legal scrutiny, TOI takes stock of the number of occasions over the past five years that individuals and outfits appear to have got away with destroying public property worth crores of rupees during protests.The Jat quota stir in February 2016 was a destructive one, resulting in 30 deaths and widespread damage to public and private property. Assocham estimated the loss in monetary terms to be Rs 1,800-2,000 crore. Around 2,100 cases were filed and hundreds arrested. The then BJP government told the Punjab and Haryana high court that the cost of the damage would be recovered from the perpetrators, but it was never done.In August 2017, vandalism returned to the state after a special CBI court convicted Dera Sacha Sauda chief Gurmeet Ram Rahim in multiple rape cases. Property worth Rs 126 crore was damaged in Panchkula alone. The high court ordered that properties belonging to Dera Sacha Sauda be frozen till such time “liability” for the losses caused during the violence was decided. The case continues.On August 22 last year, thousands of protesting Dalits led by Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad damaged 14 cars at Govindpuri. In November, lawyers at Tis Hazari damaged 13 police vehicles and set fire to several bikes while clashing with the cops over a parking dispute. Similar violence was reported at Saket. Nobody was even arrested.But after the arson during anti-CAA protests at Jamia Nagar and Mathura Road on December 15, Police approached the HC to appoint a claims commissioner who would assess the damage and “establish liability”.Within just three days of the Patidar quota movement in August 2015, mobs torched 660 government vehicles and 1,822 public buildings. A week after the riots, a PIL was filed in the Gujarat HC, seeking an inquiry commission to assess the damage. The PIL was withdrawn two weeks later.The railways bore the brunt of the vandalism and arson that marred the anti-citizenship law protests last month, losing an estimated Rs 80 crore worth of property in just four days. According to the state government, 64 FIRs were lodged and 931 people arrested. The Calcutta high court is hearing six PILs on fixing responsibility for the damage.Property worth Rs 20 crore was damaged after violence erupted in Puri on October 3, 2018, during a bandh called by an outfit called Jagannath Sena. Police subsequently made it mandatory for organisations to sign an indemnity bond while seeking permission to hold rallies.Around 15 vehicles, including police vans and buses, were set ablaze in Bengaluru in April 2016 by garments factory workers protesting against the Centre’s decision to amend the Employees Provident Fund Act. On September 12 the same year, the Cauvery riots ravaged public property, with more than 30 buses being damaged. No attempt was made by the government to recover damages in either of these cases.In 2018, as many as 49 state-owned buses were damaged in Pathanamthitta district and several more across other districts during protests that greeted the Supreme Court’s verdict on entry of women into the Sabarimala shrine. Many were arrested under the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984, but the loss due to damage of public property was never recovered.In October 2011, the Kerala HC had ordered that in the event of public property being damaged, an amount equivalent to the loss must be deposited by the accused as a condition for bail.The first few days of the anti-citizenship law protests that broke out last month saw public property being vandalised in Guwahati and Dibrugarh . The BJP-led government plans to initiate “proper legal action against the instigators of violence” after collecting more evidence.: There have been multiple instances of vandalism and arson, including during the agitation against the film Padmaavat in November 2017 and the Gujjar community’s quota stir in February 2019. In none of these instances did the state even calculate the extent of damage to public property.

Title: New Year Wishes: PM Modi greets neighbourhood leaders on New Year, skips Pakistan
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NEW DELHI: On the first day of the new year , PM Narendra Modi reiterated India’s commitment to its “neighbourhood first” policy and a “vision of shared peace and prosperity” in telephonic conversations with leaders of all countries in the region except Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan.

The Prime Minister spelled out a commitment to prosperity and progress for all of India’s “friends and partners in the region”. Sources said the current circumstances in India-Pakistan bilateral ties didn’t lend themselves to a similar call to Khan though they didn't rule out an exchange of greetings in some form later.

The already stuttering ties with Pakistan further dipped after the abrogation of Jammu & Kashmir’s special status last August that led to Islamabad launching a diplomatic offensive. Khan attacked India for the “anti-Muslim” measure and spoke of nuclear conflict in an effort to attract global attention and India’s counter-offensive sent bilateral ties into a deep freeze.

One of the first leaders Modi spoke to was Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina , whom he congratulated on being re-elected as president of the Awami League for the next three years. Modi also expressed his condolences on the untimely demise of former high commissioner of Bangladesh to India Syed Muazzem Ali.

“He also mentioned the upcoming birth centenary of Bangabandhu and 50 years of the liberation of Bangladesh and establishment of bilateral diplomatic ties besides important milestones to further the progress in close India-Bangladesh ties, a priority of his government,” said an official statement.

The conversation is important in the context of heated politics over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act which has seen frequent references to illegal migrants from Bangladesh and the “persecution” of Hindus in that country.

In his conversation with Prime Minister K P Oli of Nepal, Modi expressed satisfaction at the progress of relations in 2019, with the completion of several projects. He specifically noted the completion of the Motihari (India)-Amlekhgunj (Nepal) petroleum product pipeline in record time. Both leaders also agreed on early inauguration of the integrated checkpost in Biratnagar and the housing reconstruction project in Nepal through video-conference. Oli later tweeted about his conversation in which he said there was mention of the need to address pending issues.

Modi also spoke to Bhutan King Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck, PM Lotay Tshering, and Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and PM Mahinda Rajapaksa, as also Maldives President Ibrahim Solih.

“The Prime Minister conveyed to the leaders his New Year greetings and good wishes on behalf of the people of India and on his own behalf,” added the statement. In his conversation with the Bhutan king, Modi spoke of important achievements that led to further consolidation of special ties between India and Bhutan.

"The Prime Minister fondly recalled his last visit to Bhutan and the love and affection he received from the people there. He also emphasised the need to enhance youth exchanges between the two countries. The Prime Minister also mentioned that he was looking forward to forthcoming visit of the king to India,” said the government.

Gotabaya was said to have warmly reciprocated Modi’s wishes and expressed confidence that India and Sri Lanka would further enhance friendly ties in 2020. The two leaders reiterated their commitment to closely work together towards this end.

With Mahinda, Modi reiterated India’s commitment to further expand close and extensive cooperation with Sri Lanka. PM Rajapaksa reciprocated the wishes warmly and expressed a keen desire to further enhance relations between the two countries.

Title: India will work out its own model of theatre commands: CDS Rawat
Content:
Chief of Defense Staff (CDS) Bipin Rawat

NEW DELHI: India will work out its own mechanisms for theatre commands, says the chief of defence staff (CDS) General Bipin Rawat , in the backdrop of the urgent need to build an integrated land-air-sea war-fighting machinery for a greater combat punch despite the ongoing fund crunch for military modernisation.“There are methods of doing ‘theaterisation’. We don’t have to copy from western methods or others. We can have our own systems. We will jointly work out mechanisms…I think it will work,” said Gen Rawat, after taking the tri-service guard of honour at South Block on Wednesday. Though Gen Rawat did not spell out the details, sources said he has been tasked by the government to initiate and spearhead doctrinal and transformational changes as well as prepare a roadmap for the first new theatre command to be set up in four to five years.This, of course, will take some doing because the Army, Navy and IAF zealously guard their turfs. India’s only theatre or geographical command in the strategically-located Andaman and Nicobar archipelago, which places all the assets and manpower of the three services under one operational commander, has largely failed to realise its potential due to inter-service rivalry, general politico-bureaucratic apathy and funding problems since it was set up in 2001.The PMO and defence establishment have discussed the need to have integrated commands over the last few years. There was even a proposal to establish theatre commands in the shape of one or two (one each for west and east of Nepal ) for the “northern borders” with China, a western command for Pakistan , a counter-insurgency operations command and one southern or two peninsular commands for the maritime borders. A strategic air command, in turn, could be handled by the IAF.But the IAF had strongly opposed the move, stressing it would be operationally unwise to divide the country’s “limited air assets” among different theatre commands. The force, after all, has just 30 fighter squadrons when at least 42 are needed for requisite deterrence against any collusive threat from Pakistan and China.Similar is the case with other critical platforms like AWACS (airborne warning and control systems) and mid-air refuelling aircraft. “The entire country should be treated as one theatre. We have shown through ‘Gagan Shakti’ and other exercises that the IAF can swiftly switch its assets from the western to eastern front, and vice-versa, if the need arises,” said a senior IAF officer.But the dominant opinion in the defence establishment is that the time has come for India — which has as many as 17 single-service commands — to move towards integrated commands to save resources and prepare for wars of the future.Gen Rawat, on his part, said, “The task is cut out for the CDS to integrate the three services and enhance their capabilities through teamwork. We must ensure the 1+1+1 combine of the three services adds up to 5 or 7, and not 3. Synergy is needed. The whole should be more than the sum of the parts.” He added he would strive to achieve jointness in operations, planning, procurements, logistics, transport, training and the like within the three-year deadline set by the government.

Title: Appointment of CDS ‘momentous reform’: PM Modi
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

CDS General Bipin Rawat

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday described creation of the department of military affairs and institutionalisation of the post of chief of defence staff as “momentous reforms” and said the first CDS, Gen Bipin Rawat , is an “outstanding officer” who has served India with great zeal.

“Creation of the Department of Military Affairs with requisite military expertise and institutionalisation of the post of CDS is a momentous and comprehensive reform that will help our country face the ever-changing challenges of modern warfare,” Modi tweeted.

“As the first CDS takes charge, I pay homage to all those who have served and laid down their lives for our nation. I recall the valiant personnel who fought in Kargil, after which many discussions on reforming our military began, leading to today’s historic development,” he said.

“This institution carries tremendous responsibility of modernising our military forces. It would also reflect the hopes and aspirations of 1.3 billion Indians,” Modi said.

A key mandate of the CDS will be to facilitate restructuring of military commands for optimal utilisation of resources by bringing about jointness in operations, through establishment of joint and theatre commands.

Title: Amid chill, India and Pakistan exchange customary list of prisoners, N-facilities
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: India and Pakistan exchanged through diplomatic channels the customary list of nuclear installations and facilities covered under the agreement on prohibition of attack against nuclear installations between India and Pakistan. Though routine and a well established practice, the adherence to protocol comes after worsening India-Pakistan ties that have seen Prime Minister Imran Khan and other ministers in Pakistan raise the nuclear bogey several times in 2019 over incidents like the air strike on Balakot and the abrogation of J&K’s special status.

India and Pakistan also exchanged list of prisoners under their 2008 agreement and asked Islamabad to expedite grant of visas to Indian medical experts to allow them to assess the mental condition of Indian prisoners. India also called for early visit of the Joint Judicial Committee to Pakistan. The exchange of information on nuclear facilities is in keeping with the 1988 agreement which calls for the two countries to inform each other of nuclear installations and facilities to be covered under the same agreement on the first of January of every calendar year. This is the 29th consecutive exchange of such a list between the two countries, the first one having taken place on 1st January, 1992. On the prisoner issue, India handed over a list of 267 Pakistan civilian prisoners and 99 fishermen to Pakistan who are in India’s custody. Similarly, Pakistan shared lists of 55 civilian prisoners and 227 fishermen in its custody, who are Indians or believed to be.

“In this context Pakistan was asked to expedite the release and repatriation of four Indian civilian prisoners and 126 Indian fishermen to India whose nationality has been confirmed and conveyed to Pakistan. In addition, Pakistan has been asked to provide immediate consular access to 14 believed-to-be Indian civilian prisoners and 100 Indian fishermen who are in Pakistan’s custody,” the government said in a statement.

Title: Nine more infants die in Kota hospital, December toll hits 100
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

J K Lon hospital (file photo)

KOTA/JAIPUR: At least nine more infants have died at Kota’s J K Lon Hospital in the last two days, taking the toll to 100 in December 2019.

The number of infant deaths in the same hospital in December 2018 was 77, the hospital authorities confirmed on Wednesday.

“At least nine newborns and infants have died in J K Lon Hospital on December 30 and 31. The number of kids’ deaths in December has reached 100,” the hospital superintendent, Dr Suresh Dulara, said on Wednesday.

He added, “On December 30, four kids died and on December 31 five kids died. All of them died mainly due to low birth weight and birth weight hypothesis.”

The Rajasthan government on Tuesday ordered hospitals attached to medical colleges to check the functional status of all medical equipment and send reports.

Last week, Rajasthan chief minister Ashok Gehlot and health minister Raghu Sharma had claimed that that most of the children who died were referred to the hospital in critical condition from nearby districts, including regions of neighbouring Madhya Pradesh .

The hospital superintendent claimed on Wednesday that the number of infant deaths at the hospital in 2019 was lower than 2018 and the lowest in last six years. “At least 1,005 kids died in 2018 in the hospital, while 963 died in 2019,” said Dulara.

The number of infant deaths at J K Lon Hospital has witnessed a constant decline since 2014 when 1,198 deaths were recorded, which was 7.6% of the 15,719 admitted, according to data from Kota district collector Om Kasera and the hospital superintendent. The percentage declined to 7.2% in 2015, 6.6% in 2016, 5.9% in 2017, 6.1% in 2018 and 5.7 %, the lowest, in 2019, the hospital superintendent said.

Following the controversy over the high number of infant deaths in December 2019 alone, the hospital has put in efforts for the upgradation and maintenance of its medical equipment, as well as reconstruction of paediatric units and deputations to make up the insufficiency of medical and nursing staff in the hospital.

The principal of Medical College Kota, Dr Vijay Sardana, said, “The units of the paediatric department have been subdivided into three units. The HOD’s office will be in J K Lon Hospital and the non-teaching unit will be working on the New Medical College Hospital premises.”

He added, “A work order for installation of a central oxygen supply line in the hospital has been issued and work would be completed within 15 days. Proposals for new OPD and emergency wards for the paediatric and gynecology departments have been incorporated in the proposed OPD block under the Smart City Project.”

Taking serious note of TOI’s report on December 30 headlined “Over 50% of gadgets in Kota hospital where kids died defunct”, the medical education department wrote to the principals and controllers of all medical colleges saying: “An immediate stock-taking of all the equipment should be carried out to make sure that all the gadgets are in use and their annual maintenance contracts (AMCs) are in place.”

“For equipment whose AMCs have not been done, the process should be immediately initiated after stock-taking,” wrote Vaibhav Galriya, principal secretary, medical education.

While pointing out that some equipment might be lying in hospital stores after purchase, he directed that a physical verification of the stores be done to ensure that such machines are identified and put to use immediately.

Galriya has also pulled up doctors while pointing out that hospitals are not properly maintaining IPD bed tickets. “It has also been observed in some hospitals that IPD bed tickets are not being properly maintained. History and clinical notes of the patients are incomplete. All departments and treating doctors must be instructed to make sure that proper recording of patients’ medical information is done after their admission to the IPD,” he said in the circular.

Also, proper counselling of patients and their attendants should be done. “They should be briefed regarding the disease and health of the patients,” he wrote.

To prevent infection from spreading, he pointed out that microbiological surveillance of operation theatres (OTs) and ICUs must be regularly done at least once a month and samples taken from all relevant portions of OTs and ICUs.

The hospitals attached to medical colleges will also ensure that bacteriological reports of the samples should detail the bacteria for which the culture is positive or negative and take curative action. Standard infection control practices, including hand hygiene, should be ensured in all OTs, ICUs, labour and procedure rooms, said Galriya’s directions to all medical colleges.

Title: Bank robber fled by city bus: Police
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

PATNA: It may be unbelievable but the criminal who robbed Rs9.12 lakh from the United Bank of India (UBI) branch near Patna Junction on Tuesday had fled by a city bus after committing the crime, according to police sources.

The lone robber, who pretended to be armed with a pistol after wrapping his right palm and wrist with a towel, had barged into the bank branch at 3.04pm and escaped with the cash from the counter within two minutes. The UBI branch is 50 years’ old.

When asked, a senior police officer preferring anonymity said the criminal after looting the money had used a public transport to escape. “He had boarded a city bus which runs on the Station Road route of the state capital. His movements had been caught in the CCTV cameras installed near the bank,” he said.

Meanwhile, another IPS officer preferring anonymity said the criminal, after coming out of the bank with looted cash, first crossed the busy Station Road near Patna Junction and then boarded a bus. “That bus had stopped finally near auto stand roundabout under Kankarbagh police station area where Patna Municipal Corporation’s office is located,” he said.

The officer said the bus had stopped at four different places along the route. “The criminal had alighted from the bus at one of these places only. The bus driver has been interrogated and police could get some details about the criminal from him,” he said, adding that police were trying to pinpoint the location where the criminal had alighted from the bus.

He said technical investigation was going on to gather further clue for arresting the criminal.

Meanwhile, outgoing SSP Garima Malik said it was clear that the criminal had reached the branch alone. “Investigations were going on to ascertain his identity and arrest him,” she said.

Title: Three more arrested in Phulwari murder case
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

PATNA: The decomposed body of 18-year-old Amir Hanjla was found in a water body on the Phulwarisharif block office premises on Tuesday. Amir had gone missing during the violent protests for and against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) during Bihar Bandh at Tamtam Padav under Phulwarisharif police station area in western Patna on December 21.

Altogether five persons, mostly having criminal antecedents, were arrested till now in connection with Amir’s murder.

Phulwarisharif SHO Rafique-ur-Rahman on Wednesday said Amir was beaten to death by a few residents with criminal antecedents of Uttari Sangat locality. Rahman said Chaitu Kumar, Sanoj Kumar alias Dhelwa and one Deepak Mahto were arrested from their residences at Uttari Sangat on Tuesday and the body was recovered on their confession. He said all three work as autorickshaw driver.

The SHO said a semi-automatic country-made pistol with five live cartridges of 7.65mm were recovered from Deepak’s residence. The weapon was also used by him during the riot. “The body was dumped in dense vegetation. It took almost six hours to search and recover the body even though the criminals had told the police about the place where they had dumped Amir’s body,” he said, adding that police also seized a small two-wheel garbage cart which was used to carry the body after the murder.

Rahman said Chaitu and Sanoj had been to jail in 2012 in a double murder case while Deepak is also involved in liquor smuggling. “Chaitu had been to jail for liquor smuggling during Holi last year,” he said.

“Earlier, police had arrested Ravish Paswan and Manoj Paswan on December 29. Several others are yet to be arrested for Amir’s murder,” he added.

“Most of the Uttari Sangat residents have been to jail on multiple occasions,” he said.

Title: Teenager killed over suspicion of being a gang member
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A grab from the video of the crime

Surat: Three persons were arrested for allegedly murdering a 17-year-old boy suspecting him to be member of a notorious gang of historysheeters in Katargam area of the city on Wednesday. However, police investigation revealed that the deceased Chandrakant alias Chirag Patel, a resident of Ved Road , was not associated with the gang and was killed because of mistaken identity.

Police arrested Hitendra alias Bhuriyo Chhagan Mevada, Abhishek alias Shikhdo Varma and Meet alias Montu for the murder of Patel. They have issued look out notice for the four persons involved in the attack on the deceased.

According to police, the accused attacked Patel outside Dhruv Tarak Society in Katargam at around 12 midnight on Tuesday. Patel succumbed to injuries in wee hours of Wednesday. Police said that all the accused are residents of Dhruv Tarak Society and they were hanging out in group when Patel came there with his five friends.

The accused suspected Patel to be part of the notorious gang of Surya Marathi and attacked him, added police.

“The deceased was stabbed several times in the thigh and died due to heavy blood loss. He was not associated with any gang but lived in the same locality as the members of alleged gang in the past. Hence the suspicion,” said a police officer.

The accused was in contact with Manu Dahya Bariya gang and after murder of Bariya in April 2016 many gang members were trying to replace him. Surya Marathi, another gang leader on Ved Road was involved in Bariya’s murder and was arrested few days after the killing. Since then Marathi is in jail.

Meanwhile, some members of Marathi gang used to come to Dhruv Tarak Society and harassed former close aids of Bariya frequently in an attempt to prove their dominance in the area.

Title: PSI held for role in bootlegging racket
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ahmedabad: While the state police claims to be cracking down on the liquor mafias, three persons including an police sub-inspector, S I Gadhvi of Jambughoda, were held by the state monitoring cell (SMC) on Tuesday, for allegedly helping a bootlegger, Hiesh Bariya, smuggle in and stash Indian-made foreign liquor (IMFL) at a storeroom built on a field near Jambughoda in Panchmahal.

SMC sources said that they got a tip-off that Hitesh Bariya has been smuggling IMFL in to the state and supplying various bootleggers.

“We formed a team and raided the field in Jambughoda on Tuesday. We found 494 IMFL bottles stored in a small room built in the middle of the field. We also seized a car from the spot, which we suspect was used to carry the IMFL to the place,” said a SMC official.

SMC officials said that during their investigation they found that PSI S I Gadhvi of Jambughoda police station was in touch with Bariya and used to help him smuggle the IMFL to the field. “As his role in helping the bootlegger emerged during the investigation, we have held him and are questioning him to learn if other policemen are involved in the racket,” a senior SMC official said.

Man, 3 women held during booze party

Ahmedabad: A 23-year-old man, executive of a leading corporate house in Mundra in Kutch, along with three women, all executives of private firms, were caught by Anandnagar police when they were allegedly drinking liquor and making obscene gestures in public. A police official said that a resident of their society had called police saying that a man and three women were making obscene gestures on the road. An Anandnagar police official said they went to the spot and found a man and three women playing loud music at Krishna Tower in Satellite. They were drunkl and were arrested.

Title: Surat cops break 5 years’ record in nabbing tipplers
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Those caught drunk included three traffic brigade jawans in Umara Police Station

Surat: Arresting 281 drunk persons on Tuesday and Wednesday, Surat cops outdid their own five years’ record in nabbing Prohibition Act violators. Majority of the accused arrested in the city were released on bail.

Among the police stations, Amroli caught 112, the highest in city. Being the bordering police station, Amroli cops raided the huge number of labour colonies located under its jurisdiction and arrested a large number of drunk people.

Three traffic brigade jawans were also arrested by the police for being drunk during the checking on Udhna Magdalla Road on Tuesday night.

Police arrested Paresh Pargi, 39, Dahrmedra Baria, 35, and Manish Chaudhary, 34, after senior traffic police official initiated actions.

A senior traffic police officer on duty spotted the jawans at an eatery instead of being at their point of duty. When he talked to them he found they were drunk and later they were taken to Umra police station.

Long queues were witnessed at hospitals where the accused were taken for medical examination.

In Surat district total 2,072 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 2.45 lakh were seized by the police. In Valsad 7,751 bottles of IMFL worth Rs 5.82 lakh, 164 bottles of IMFL worth Rs 10,660 in Navsari and 78 litres of country liquor worth Rs 17,860 were seized by the cops.

“People do not respect law when it comes to drinking. The problem can be tackled only through better awareness,” said a senior Alcoholic Anonymous member.

Title: India-Sri Lanka T20: Tickets for disabled on sale only for today
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Indore: The ticket window for specially-abled spectators for India- Sri Lanka T20I match will open on Thursday.

The spectators will have to purchase tickets from Satish Malhotra gate of Holkar Stadium.

The ticket window will open at 11 am and will shut till the end of the quota or till 4 pm. Although this ticket window is for one day, in case the tickets remain unsold, the ticket window will again open on December 3.

The price of South Pavilion (lower) wing is Rs 2153 and west stand (lower) wing is Rs 250.

India and Sri Lankan team will arrive in the city on January 6. While the Indian team will stay at Radisson Hotel, Sri Lankan team will be accommodated at Marriott.

“Though the teams will reach here on Monday, we’ll be informed about their practice schedule on January 4,” said Madhya Pradesh Cricket Association (MPCA) CEO Rohit Pandit.

As the second match of India-Sri Lanka T20I will be held in night, the association is working on the logistics. The floodlights have been tested and are in functional condition and MPCA has spoken with the administration regarding the security during the match.

“We are totally prepared and on a regular basis we have been conducting meetings regarding the match. As the stadium has already hosted a match in November, most of the things are in place,” MPCA secretary Sanjeev Rao told TOI.

Title: Light showers in south Bihar, rain forecast till Sunday: Weatherman
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Patna in central Bihar and most places in north Bihar witnessed partly cloudy skies.

PATNA: As predicted by weathermen, several places in south Bihar witnessed showers, though light in intensity, on the first day of 2020 on Wednesday. Patna in central Bihar and most places in north Bihar witnessed partly cloudy skies.

India Meteorological Department (IMD) maintained its forecast for showers across the state over the next four days with comparatively higher intensity on Friday and Saturday. IMD has also issued warning for thunderstorm, lightning and squall in the state on Friday and Saturday. Nevertheless, generally cloudy skies with light rain have been forecast for Patna till Sunday.

Meanwhile, Patna meteorological centre’s bulletin stated that light rainfall occurred at one or two places in Bihar during the past 24 hours. The showers in Gaya town and Dehri in Rohtas were measured at 1.4mm and 0.8mm, respectively.

Meteorologists have attributed the showers to a western disturbance , the weather systems originating from Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea and Caspian Sea, which cause snow and winter rainfall in northwestern Indian subcontinent.

Rain, however, has brought a slight respite from the biting cold conditions as the IMD stated in its all India evening bulletin issued on Wednesday that cold day conditions abated from entire Bihar. Cold day condition is declared when the minimum temperature touches 10 degrees C or low and there is a departure of 4.5-6.4 degrees C in maximum temperature on two consecutive days. Many parts of the state, including in Patna and Gaya, have been reeling under cold day and even severe cold day conditions for around a week now.

There was a tad rise in mercury column owing to change in wind direction and cloud cover. Minimum temperature in Patna increased from 5 degrees C on Tuesday to 8.4 degrees C on Wednesday. Maximum temperature, on the other hand, increased from 18.6 degrees C on Tuesday to 21.4 degrees C on Wednesday. The IMD has predicted minimum and maximum temperature in Patna in the range of 9 and 18 degrees C respectively till Sunday.

Title: Prakashotsava celebrations: 3,000 police personnel deployed for security in Patna
