Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Sikh devotees at a procession on the occasion of Prakashotsava in Patna on Wednesday.

PATNA: At least 3,600 police personnel have been deployed at different locations in Patna City for the security of pilgrims arriving for the Prakashotsava celebrations .

The celebrations began on Wednesday and the main event of the celebration will take place on Thursday. Patna SSP Garima Malik said, “Over 3000 policemen have been deployed for security of the pilgrims and the spots. In addition, there are around 600 police officers. Around 500 officers have been allotted by the state police headquarters along with 1500 police personnel from different districts.”

“Rest of the deployment is from Patna police. Heavy security arrangements have been made around the Takhat Shri Harmandir Sahib Ji, Bal Lila, Guru Ka Bagh and the tent city. As the tent city falls under the jurisdiction of Vaishali police and they are also involved in looking after its security arrangements along with the Patna police,” she said.

Malik said that apart from these, at least 150 CCTV cameras had been installed for round-the-clock monitoring of movements in the areas. The SSP said that in addition to police personnel, four bomb detection and disposal squads (BDDS) have been also deployed in the area.

“Besides two teams of Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) consisting of trained commandos from Anti-terrorism Squad (ATS) and eight Quick Response Teams (QRT) have been also deployed at vantage points,” she said adding that each QRT has around 15 members.

The SSP said that on foot patrolling parties and canine units are active to look after security along with maintaining law and order. “The event will conclude on January 2, but deployment would continue till all the pilgrims return,” Malik said adding, “Deployments were made on December 27.”

Title: Bihar: Three trains cancelled, many others delayed
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Passengers waiting for their trains at Patna Junction on Wednesday.

PATNA: Foggy weather conditions continued to affect the movement of passenger trains in all the five divisions under East Central Railway (ECR). While 93 passenger trains were delayed due to fog on Tuesday, several mail and express trains were running late by four to five hours on Wednesday.

According to an ECR official, at least 30 passenger trains reaching the Danapur division were delayed on Tuesday followed by 33 in Mughalsarai, 20 in Sonepur, 6 in Dhanbad and 4 in Samastipur division. “The dense fog prevailing in the entire northern region on the New Delhi-Kanpur-Allahabad-Pt Deendayal Upadhaya Junction-Patna Junction route was badly affected,” the official said, adding that the stretch between Tundala and Allahabad was the bottleneck causing slow traffic movement due to poor visibility on tracks.

Danapur railway official told this newspaper on Wednesday that New Delhi-Rajendra Nagar Terminal Rajdhani Express (12310) reached Patna Junction about 90 minutes late, while New Delhi-Patna Sampoorna Kranti Express (12392) was delayed by 210 minutes and New Delhi-Rajgir Shramjeevi Express (12394) by about 180 minutes on Wednesday.

Similarly, the Yesvantpur-Patliputra Sanghamitra Express (22352) reached 180 minutes late while New Delhi-Islampur Magadh Express (20802) was delayed by 300 minutes and Surat-Bhagalpur Express (22947) by 60 minutes followed by Udhna-Danapur Express (19063) by 70 minutes and Brahmaputra Mail (15956) by 160 minutes. “The railways also cancelled Anand Vihar-Sealdah Expres (13120), Kumbha Express (12370) and Mokama-Howrah fast passenger (53050) trains on Wednesday,” the Danapur official said.

According to sources, long distance passenger trains were running at full caution speed of 60km per hour on the mainline section of Danapur division at night. Extra alertness is being maintained on bridges where night track patrolling is being carried out under the supervision of senior safety officers.

“Loco pilots have been directed not to take risk and follow winter safety measures on the Delhi-Kanpur-Allahabad route due to zero visibility on the tracks during night,” sources said.

Title: Retail demand for cars, SUVs positive from Sept-Nov ‘19
Content:
File photo

CHENNAI: Riding on heavy discounts particularly for BS4 models, retail sales of cars and SUVs have shown an increase for three consecutive months. According to the Vahan vehicle registration data shared by the government, passenger vehicle registrations were up 6.25% in November, 14% in October and 8% in September (see chart). This three-month on-the-trot sales increase comes after five months of continuous sales slump (see chart). The Federation of Automobile Dealers Associations (FADA), the industry apex body for auto dealers, says December too should see positive retail numbers for passenger vehicles though the bloodbath continues for the trucks and buses segment.“In December, dealers are expecting a small increase in sales. October saw positive retail due to festival demand, November the trend continued as the discounts continued and December too should see some uptick. The inventory levels are now very normal at 4 weeks countrywide and around 3 weeks in some markets and the liquidity situation is also improving with banks increasing their working capital and other financing,” said FADA president Ashish Harsharaj Kale. What has helped the situation, he added, are planned production cuts by car companies in the run up to the BS6 shift.“What’s happening is less a turnaround than a bottoming out with passenger vehicle numbers looking stronger month-on-month. The used car trade has also been quite active which is another indicator,” explained Kumar Kandaswami, partner, Deloitte .Used car marketers agree that the sector has been both strong demand and supply right through calendar 2019. “We were expecting a slightly softer December compared to October and November but used vehicle sales continue to be strong,” said Droom founder-CEO Sandeep Aggarwal. Online marketplace Droom, he said, sold used vehicles worth Rs 636 crore in October and Rs 604 crore in November and is looking to close December with around Rs 625 crore worth of business.The total passenger vehicle market (used and new) is currently 9 million units strong (used 5 million units, new 4 million units) and worth $77 billion (new $39 billion and used $38 billion).Auto financiers however say that December retails of some OEMS could be impacted by the production cuts taken to clean up the BS4 stocks. “December has seen some supply issues with a few OEMs that have been discontinuing their BS4 models. The aggressive discounting means customers are interested but in many markets they are not getting the model, variant, colour or powertrain of their choice,” said Vyomesh Kapasi, MD, Kotak Mahindra Prime.

Title: Patnaites throng parks, zoo to soak in festive spirit
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

New Year visitors at Patna Zoo on Wednesday.

PATNA: The city parks and major hotspots teemed with revellers who celebrated the first day of 2020 with their families, relatives and friends with gusto and fervour.

Eco Park, Gandhi Maidan and Patna zoo among other places were buzzing with crowd, as residents preferred to spend the cold day under bright sunshine. Kids enjoyed playing at children’s park zone while people gorged on street food, reminiscing the best moments of year 2019 and taking the New Year resolutions while releasing balloons, taking selfies or groupies and listening music.

Hemlata Kumari, an entrepreneur, spent the day at Eco Park and enjoyed the double-cycle ride with her son and husband. “I like skating but lose balance. So, I have taken the resolution to learn skating and devote more time to my family this year,” she said.

Patnaites enjoyed zorbing , boating, cycling, zipline, trampoline , skating, rope course set-up and rope climbing at Eco Park.

For young girls, picnic at zoo, movies and luncheon at cafés is what the New Year celebration was all about. Monica Singh, a student of Patna Women’s College, said she planned the outing in daytime with her friends and dinner with her family. “I watched a movie and spent the noon at zoo. The restaurant at the zoo was overcrowded, so we had lunch at nearby café,” she said.

Many people were seen buying balloon and releasing it in the air after making New Year resolution. Shailendra Tiwari, a resident of Nasriganj , said he enjoyed boating at Gandhi Ghat with his family and friends. “We made a joint resolution to indulge more in charity work and distributed warm clothes to less privileged people on this occasion,” he said.

Women were seen playing antakshri, housie and dumb charades at the Ganga riverfront. Many couples were sitting at cosy kiosks and planning their future course of action.

Swati Pandey (24), a resident of Agamkuan said, “This is the first day of the year and I wanted to make it memorable. I spent the whole night baking cakes and muffins and sent it to my friends and relatives. I have also planned late night movie with my family following a dinner party,” she said.

There were long queues outside the Patna Museum and Bihar Museum and people were seen jostling to get entry tickets even though most of such places had doubled their entry fees.

Outdoor places like Gandhi Maidan and other parks were perfect picnic spots where revellers enjoyed games like badminton, cricket and football besides playing cards, snakes and ladders, carrom and ludo.

For some people, partying at home was the best idea to spend the first day of the year. Minakshi Sinha and Tushar, who were recently got married, spent their time together with their family and cooked exquisite delicacies. “Earlier, we had decided to spend the New Year at Goa. However, due to some unavoidable reasons, we stayed back and spent the day with my family,” Tushar said.

Ayesha Khanum, a student of Magadh Mahila College and resident of Alamganj, said New Year celebrations were incomplete without sharing sweets, exchanging cards and calendars. “I organized a lunch party at my home for my friends and shared cards and gifts,” she said.

Shopaholics spent their day on buying dresses and other accessories as many markets, shopping plazas and malls offered exclusive offers. Movie buffs watched shows at theatres and gorged on food at nearby restaurants.

Title: ‘Akhand path’ and ‘nagar kirtan’ mark Guru Gobind Singh’s birth anniversary
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Sikh devotees at a procession on the occasion of Prakashotsava in Patna on Wednesday.

PATNA: Thousands of Sikh devotees on Wednesday participated in the ‘akhand path’ and ‘Nagar Kirtan’ at Gai Ghat gurdwara, which was followed by a ‘Shobha Yatra’ on the second day of three-day 353rd Prakashotsava celebrations to mark the birth anniversary of Guru Gobind Singh.

The ‘Shobha Yatra’ which started from the Gai Ghat gurdwara at 2.30pm converged at Takht Shri Harmandir Sahib in Patna City late evening. During the yatra, devotees recited ‘Gurbaani’ from the Guru Granth Sahib on the beats of drums.

The band members of several schools including Guru Gobind Girl’s Middle and High School, Guru Gobind Boy’s Middle and High School, Guru Tegh Bahadur Academy and Guru Nanak School as well as orchestra members from Punjab enthralled the audience with their scintillating performances. Gatka (martial arts of Sikh) was also performed by the youths during the yatra.

Members of the gurdwara committee and locals put up stalls of refreshment between Gai Ghat gurdwara and Takhat Sri Harmandir Patna Sahib gurdwara to provide snacks, juice and water to the devotees. Horses, camels and elephants were also included in the procession.

On the occasion of Prakashotsava, all the gurdwaras in the city, including the Takhat Sri Harmandir Patna Sahib gurdwara, Gurdwara Sri Gai-ghat Sahib, Guru Ka Bagh gurdwara and Bal Leela gurdwara have been decked up with flowers and illuminated with lights.

A rush of devotees from India, Canada and Australia was witnessed at various locations in Patna City, including the Kangan Ghat and other gurdwaras. Many devotees also showed active participation in serving ‘langar’ to the people.

Manpreet Singh from Punjab said he along with his family will contribute their best during the three-day Prakashotsava. Another devotee Mahinder Singh, who, after celebrating the birth anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev in Rajgir, arrived in the city to attend Guru Gobind Singh’s birth anniversary said, “Since I am a retired man, my wife and I have decided to participate in all such events.”

Daljeet Singh, superintendent of Takhat Sri Harmandir Ji Prabandhak Committee said, “Langar was also arranged at Gai Ghat gurdwara for devotees. People of all religious groups have come out on streets to mark the Prakashotsava celebrations. The celebrations will continue till midnight of January 2,” he said.

Title: Patna air quality very poor, Muzaffarpur AQI worst in country
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A boy protects himself from air pollution in Patna on Wednesday.

PATNA: The state capital and Muzaffarpur ushered in the New Year with very poor air quality. The air quality index (AQI) of Muzaffarpur remained ‘severe’ on Wednesday, whereas that of Patna was in ‘very poor’ category.

According to the figures released by Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the AQI of Muzaffarpur was recorded at 465 on Wednesday, which was the worst in the country. Patna’s AQI, on the other hand, was recorded at 365.

Track the pollution level in your city

Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) officials stated that the overall AQI of 365 for Patna was the average of AQI level at planetarium (439), BIT-Mesra, Patna (372), Eco Park (312) and SK Memorial Hall (321).

BSPCB chairman Ashok Ghosh told this newspaper on Wednesday that the air quality of Patna and Muzaffarpur deteriorated because of three weather conditions — low wind velocity, increase in moisture level and decline in temperature. “Vehicle movement even at night on December 31 was another factor for the increase in AQI level at Patna and Muzaffarpur,” he said.

“The overall AQI level of the city has increased drastically. If we had only one air quality monitoring station at the planetarium, then Patna’s AQI level could also have been in severe category,” he added.

The BSPCB chairman further said one more air quality station would soon come up at Muzaffarpur and another at Gaya. “The data of one monitoring station in a city is not sufficient at all. I personally think that at least four stations are needed in any city to get a broader scenario with regard to air pollution, but for bigger cities like Patna, 10 air monitoring stations are must,” Ghosh said.

BSPCB is, in fact, in the process of installing two more air quality monitoring stations near DRM office at Danapur and Government Boy’s High School in Patna City by January 15.

Pradhan Parth Sarthi, professor at Department of Environmental Science of Central University of South Bihar (CUSB), said weather factors like low wind velocity, foggy conditions and low temperature have led to thermal inversion phenomenon in the atmosphere, which, in turn, has trapped the suspended particulate matter in the lower level of atmosphere. “The conditions can improve only with northwesterly wind and rainfall,” he added.

Title: Security concerns: President’s visit to Sabarimala cancelled
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With his security team denying clearance, President Ram Nath Kovind will not be visiting Sabarimala during his visit to the state on Sunday, it is learnt.

The Pathanamthitta district police chief is learnt to have submitted a report to the district collector flagging concerns over security that can be provided to the President. The police chief had expressed concern over the safety of landing a helicopter on the water tank at Pandithavalam as per a plan. In his report the district police chief had also raised concerns on providing security to the President at the temple due to the heavy rush of pilgrims at Sannidhanam.

Earlier, the engineering division of the Travancore Devaswom Board (TDB) had assessed that small helicopters could land on top of the water tank.

“That is the preliminary assessment and we have informed the Rashtrapathi Bhavan. Our engineers are of the view that the water tank is strong enough for small choppers. Now Rashtrapathi Bhavan has to take the final call,” TDB president N Vasu had said.

Devaswom minister Kadakampally Surendran said earlier on Wednesday that the state government was awaiting official confirmation from Rashtrapathi Bhavan over his visit to the temple. “The government has informed about the facilities we can provide for his visit,” he said.

The Rashtrapathi Bhavan had enquired about the facilities that can be arranged if the President comes for a darshan. He is scheduled to arrive in Kochi on Sunday enroute to Lakshadweep .

Title: Bihar: Governor celebrates birthday, CM Nitish Kumar, deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi greet people
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar with his deputy Sushil Kumar Modi in Patna.

PATNA: Prominent personalities offered prayer and extended greetings to people on New Year on Wednesday.

It was a day for double celebrations at Raj Bhavan as governor Phagu Chauhan had his birthday on the New Year day. PM Narendra Modi and President Ram Nath Kovind greeted him on the occasion. Politicians, officials, members of civil society and representatives of non-government organizations visited Raj Bhavan to greet him on the occasion. “I wish people would maintain peace and brotherhood across the country. People should come forward for the success and growth of Bihar in 2020,” the governor stated in a message.

Chief minister Nitish Kumar started the New Year by paying floral tributes to her mother late Parmeshwari Devi on her death anniversary at his native village, Kalyan Bigha, in Nalanda district. He returned to Patna around 12 noon and met ministers, legislators, political workers, officials and hundreds of common people and party workers, who visited his 1, Aney Marg residence in the afternoon. Later, he unveiled Bihar Diary and the official calendar of the state government along with information and public department minister Neeraj Kumar.

Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi celebrated the first day of the year with BJP ministers, officials of environment, forest and climate change department, party workers and representatives of business firms at his official Desh Ratan Marg residence here. He also cut a cake and wished the guests a happy New Year. Many party workers from several districts greeted him with bouquets, roses and cards. SuMo said the NDA would register grand success in the upcoming state assembly elections, just like the general elections in 2019. “Under the leadership of PM Narendra Modi and CM Nitish Kumar, the NDA will get more seats than previous year,” he told media persons. In the evening, he met CM Nitish and extended New Year greetings.

But there was no celebration at the official residence of former CM Rabri Devi, the wife of incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad, at 10 Circular Road. Although several RJD workers reached there from different districts to greet Rabri and her son Tejashwi Prasad Yadav, but they returned disappointed. RJD worker Manju Singh said she comes here every year on January 1. “Had Lalu been here, a huge crowd would have gathered at his residence. The poor used to visit him from every corner of Bihar. This is the first time that we could not meet anyone here. But I have no complaints,” she said.

The New Year celebrations started at St Joseph’s Pro Cathedral, Bankipore since Tuesday evening with Thanksgiving prayer service attended by over 400 people. On Wednesday morning, around 300 people attended the Mass led by Patna Archbishop William D’Souza at 7.30am. “I ask people to count the blessings they received from God last year because there are so many blessings that we never noticed in the form of success, health and prosperity. God has been blessing us continuously and, in return, we need to thank him. In the midst of all violence, protest and unrest in the country, we need to work together for communal peace and harmony and place trust in God,” the Archbishop said.

Title: City schools hail CBSE’s anger-free zone initiative
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

PATNA: The schools in Patna have welcomed the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) initiative to make schools anger-free zones. The board believes that this will improve the mental health of students and make their learning environment prosperous.

CBSE, on December 23, sent a letter to all its affiliated schools instructing them to reserve one period everyday for health and physical education. The board suggests that students should be encouraged to involve themselves in sports activities and yoga as it will decrease anger issues.

St Karen’s Secondary School principal KK Kunjachan said the CBSE has suggested some initiatives, including smiling at each other, talking to students calmly and practising breathing exercises. “This will help the students in developing affective skills. It is a welcome step,” Kunjachan said.

Baldwin Academy principal Rajiv Ranjan Sinha appreciated the Board’s initiative and considers it beneficial for the healthy growth of students. Ranjan, who is also the city coordinator of CBSE, said, “Our aim is to talk to students calmly and listen to their problems. We hope to find out solutions to their problems by cooperating with them. Besides, the school will also be taking steps to counsel teachers and parents so that they can reach out to the students and help them in anger management.”

Principal of Litera Valley School, Sharat Kumar Singh, considers its as a noble intention of CBSE, which will help students in channelizing their energy in constructive way. “The teachers will be directed to take this initiative further by talking to students composedly. I will personally urge the teachers to make good choice of words while dealing with the students,” he said.

CB Singh, director of Dr DY Patil Pushpalata Patil International School, said they are preparing a ‘Teacher-Guardian’ scheme to make school no-anger zone. “The teachers will prepare a list of shot-tempered students and they will be managed by happy-go-luck teachers. Besides, we have already put up happy quotes and smiles across the school campus,” he said.

Title: Further shortage of IAS officers likely as 22 will retire this year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

PATNA: There will be further shortage of IAS officers in Bihar as altogether 22 officers of the state cadre, including chief secretary Deepak Kumar, are scheduled to retire this year.

As per the Centre’s department of personnel and training’s (DoPT) notification, the total authorized cadre strength of IAS officers in Bihar is 342. But only 237 officers were available on the state government’s roll on January 1, creating a shortage of 105.

“The retirement of 22 more officers in 2020 will only add up to the existing shortage, unless the Centre takes necessary steps to fill the vacancies by granting promotion to the state civil service (SCS) officers or sends more direct recruits to the state,” an official of general administration department (GAD), who didn’t want to be identified, told TOI on Wednesday.

“If new officers are not added to the state’s roll, the total shortage will reach up to 127 by the end of 2020,” the officer said.

Besides Deepak (1984-batch), who is now scheduled to retire on August 31 after getting six months’ service extension, four more officers of chief secretary-rank from the Bihar cadre are retiring this year. They are C K Mishra (1983-batch), Ajay Kumar (1984), Rabindra Pawar (1985) and RK Mahajan (1987 batch). While Mishra, Kumar and Pawar are currently on the central deputation, Mahajan is serving as additional chief secretary in education department with the additional charge of vigilance department.

Two officers in the principal secretary rank — Deepak Prasad (1989-batch) and S M Raju (1991-batch) — are also scheduled to retire on August 31 and July 31 this year, respectively. While Prasad is currently on leave, Raju is suspended on the charges of corruption with effect from January 12, 2017.

Other IAS officers holding key posts and retiring this year are the district magistrates (DMs) of Khagaria and Lakhisarai. While Khagaria DM Aniruddh Kumar will be superannuating on May 31, his Lakhisarai counterpart Shobhendra Kumar Choudhary is to retire on October 31.

Sources in the GAD said out of the total cadre strength of 342, altogether 74 posts are meant for central deputation. It means 74 IAS officers from Bihar cadre can be sent on the central deputation at a time. But currently, only 36 officers (less than 50%) from Bihar cadre are on the central deputation.

Title: Curbs on plastic: Traders seek affordable alternatives
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The statewide plastic ban , which came into effect on Wednesday, has put traders across the district in distress as they now face a crisis in delivery of products.

The unused stock of plastic carry bags which were bought in bulk by paying a minimal sum as low as Rs 1 per bag, and having to pay Rs 12 or more per piece of alternatives have resulted in huge loss to most of the traders.

While several of the traders are ready to accept the ban on plastic bags , they unanimously called for a need to introduce alternatives at similar prices to that of plastic products.

Krishnan K, a vegetable vendor of Chalai market said that it is the vegetable, fruit and grocery vendors who are the worst hit. “We used to buy carry bags in bulk, which cost Rs 50-100 for 100-120 carry bags. But it costs more than Rs 10 to buy a single cloth bag. We need affordable alternatives,” he said.

Vijaya Kumar, who runs a grocery shop, shared a similar opinion. “Regular customers who come to buy dairy products now bring carry bags with them but as our shop is in the heart of a busy market, we cannot expect everyone to do the same. How many people will be willing to pay an additional Rs 10 for a carry bag?” he asks.

Flower merchants too are concerned about alternative options. According to Jayan G of Omkaram Flowers, it is impossible to find an alternative to transport flowers in bulk. “For small orders, we can use leaf bundles but for festival orders of 6-10kg, we require giant carry bags. With plastic carry bags, we had such flexibility but alternative materials suggested do not provide such an option. We still don’t think this ruling will stay for long and things will revert back to normal before Onam,” he said.

City corporation, which is determined to carry forward the initiative, is pushing sales of cloth bags. Mayor K Sreekumar inaugurated a cloth bag counter at Gandhi Park on Wednesday. The counter which will be functioning at corporation office from Thursday will accept all banned carry bags and also sell cloth bags.

According to cloth bag project implementation officer R Sasikumar, the tailor-made bags will come in various sizes as required.

“We have included 100 Kudumbhashree members in the project, who will make the cloth bags at our centres at Muttada, Vallakadavu, Pongumoodu, Valiyavila and Kunnampara. A bag of normal size, which cost us Rs 25 to prepare, has been given 50% subsidy and will come at a rate of Rs 12.50 per bag. Also, bags will come in various sizes and we will take orders as required,” Sasikumar said.

Title: Seven-year-old boy attacked by leopard in Areth, survives
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Surat: A seven-year-old boy was attacked by a leopard when he was playing in sugar cane farm in Areth village of Mandvi taluka of Surat district on Tuesday evening. The boy Lalsinh Keshar Malche, a resident of Navapur suffered minor injuries after alert labourers in the farm chased the leopard away.

Lalsinh was brought to New Civil Hospital in Surat and is currently under treatment.

According to forest officials, Lalsinh was attacked at around 7 pm when he was playing in the field with other children. The leopard tried to catch the child but before it could grab the child labourers spotted it and started shouting. The leopard disappeared in the thick sugar cane field.

“Some hair and skin on head of the child had come off during the attack. Besides this there was not major injury. We have started awareness drive around Areth among sugar cane labourers so that they can remain safe,” said Puneet Nayyar, deputy conservator of forest, Surat.

Forest department also placed cages in the area to nab the leopard before it attacks another human.

A suspected man eater leopard was shot dead by a professional shooter in December 2010 after forest department ordered its killing. The leopard was involved in multiple attacks on humans.

Title: Drunken revellery leaves four youngsters dead
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Two men on bike had rammed into the parked earth mover in Diu

Rajkot: Four youngsters , celebrating the New Year completely sozzled , died and as many were injured in two separate accidents reported from union territory Diu and Morbi district on Tuesday night.

In Diu, two from Una, crashed their bike into an earth mover on Jalandar beach which they failed to see as they were heavily drunk, police said. “Rahul Bambhania (24), Kalpesh Solanki (23) and Kalpesh Maiya (23), had gone to Diu to celebrate the New Year. On their way back, the trio was riding on one bike with no headlights. As a result they could not see the parked earth mover rand rammed into it,” said an official from Diu police.

Of the victims, Bambhania and Solanki were killed on the spot, while Maiya was injured in the accident.

In Wankaner, two persons were killed and three injured when the car they were travelling in overturned by the roadside while negotiating a turn. Four beer cans were found in their car.

“The car lost control while negotiating a turn on the road between Wankaner and Thangadh. While Dharmendra Makwana (29), who was driving the car, and Chetan Nimawat (32) were killed on the spot, Kalpesh Nimavat (26), Vipul Rawaldev (20) and Alpesh Dholakia (25) were injured in the accident. ,” said an official from Wankaner city police station.

Ajay Nimawat (30), brother of Chetan and Kalpesh, who lodged the complaint told the cops that the victims had gone to a farmhouse near Thangadh to celebrate the New Year. “When Ajay made a video call to his brothers, all of them looked heavily drunk,” added the official.

An official of the Rajkot police control room said, “Five persons who were heavily drunk in a car lost control over their vehicle, following which their car broke the BRTS railings and turned turtle. The five, who received injuries, were arrested for violating the Prohibition Act.”

Title: Surat hospital performs city’s first kidney transplant
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Surat: In a first-ever kidney transplant operation in South Gujarat region, a father donated kidney to his ailing 19-year-old son, the surgical procedure of which was done at city-based Kiran Hospital on December 22.

Both father and son were discharged in healthy condition on Wednesday. Experts opine this will open the door for many more transplant operations in Surat and the region.

Hospital administrator, Dr Snehal Dungrani said, “Samarth Nilesh Maisuriya, 19, a college student was suffering from kidney failure for the past three years. His father, a 43-year-old Nilesh Hasmukh Maisuriya, who owns a saloon in old city, decided to donate his kidney to save his son’s life.”

After required tests and premedical preparations Transplant team of eight doctors decided to perform the transplant procedure on December 22, Dr Dungrani added.

CEO of hospital Dr Ravindra Karenjekar said, “We have a transplant ICU facility of six beds. Therefore, we can carry out three transplant procedures at a time. Hospital is equipped with 36 modern Dialysis machines and till now more than 90,000 dialysis have been performed in the hospital.”

Run by the Patidar Samaj Trust, Kiran hospital started nearly three years ago in Sumul dairy road in Surat and has treated more than 7.5 lakh patients for various ailments till now. It functions on no-profit no-loss basis.

Title: Women-led startups still a distant dream
Content: Chennai: A mere 5.9% of the participating startups were founded by ‘only females’, as compared to 55.5% by their male counterparts, showing a long road ahead for women entrepreneurs to catch up.A pilot survey conducted by the banking regulator RBI on the Indian Startup Sector, showed even among a majority of startups (57.5%) which have at least a minimum of two co-founders, the presence of at least one female founder is only 45%.“Lack of trust in female entrepreneurs, especially in the technology space, is a never-ending challenge,” said Kanika Tekriwal, founder and CEO of JetSetGo. Tekriwal runs a female-only led plane aggregator start-up that operates, manages, and flies planes for owners.Though there are many funds to invest and encourage female entrepreneurs, they are still on papers.“Besides funds, the government must set up dedicated start-up incubation centres solely for women. These centres should hear out our challenges and help find legal, financial and technical solutions. I know a couple young and enthusiastic girls with craving for fashion technology, but investors feel women can’t be good with tech,” Tekriwal added.On the other hand, Saha Fund chief executive officer (CEO) and co-founder, Ankita Vashistha, which funds female entrepreneurs, said, “There is no shortage of appetite among women entrepreneurs, as we saw a 15% growth in applications or enquiries for investment in 2019.”“Since, the market has seen slowdown this year, we have not seen much investment. There is a larger share of 30% from business models around women health and wellness, unlike last year,” she added. The survey also showed, about 39% of the participating startups had both male and female as co-founders.When questioned if there is a constant battle to prove seriousness in a board meeting, Swati Bhargava of CashKaro, with over five-year experience as Goldman Sachs in London said, “Been a banker myself, I still struggle with investors looking away from me and towards my (male) business partner, as they discuss numbers or negotiate deals. This is the same with manufacturers too.”Dipali Mathur Dayal, co-founder of Super Smelly, “My partner and I are both from economics background (academically), yet investors turn to him to discuss topics on tech, while they presumed I am the right fit for topics on human resource, marketing and sales.”Addressing challenges faced by female entrepreneurs on networking front, Dayal adds, “I have never shied away from raising a point, neither being the only women in board meetings, yet late night informal meetings are still difficult to crack, as that space is still dominated by men.”

Title: Liquor laws: Gujarat courts temper justice with mercy
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The prohibition laws made stringent more than two years ago have not brought about the feared severity in punishment for boozing and bootlegging, thanks to Gujarat ’s courts which believe in tempering justice with mercy.Sahil Vegda was caught loitering on a public street in an inebriated condition in Kagdapith police station last year. A local court took up his case last month. He immediately admitted his guilt and was convicted under the amended Gujarat Prohibition Act, which prescribes a jail term of up to one year and a fine. However, the court imposed a fine of Rs 500 on Vegda and ordered him to sit in the courtroom for a day as his punishment.There were various reasons put forth by the court for showing leniency to Vegda. It cited a judgment of Gujarat high court passed by Justice J N Bhatt and said that the courts are still governed by the law laid down by the high court so far as punishment is concerned upon the accused confessing his crime.The court also said that it was Vegda’s first offence and that he had responsibility of his family. His financial situation is weak. Vegda promised not to repeat the offence.The court said that if he was sent to jail, his family would starve. If huge fine is imposed, his family will suffer. Hence it was not proper to slap a heavy penalty on Vegda, the court said.Moreover, the court also said that the courts are flooded with “such types of cases” and the high court has been striving to reduce the number of pending cases.For this, special sittings are organized in courts and the high court has suggested spotting such cases and disposing them quickly.There were many more offenders like Girish Solanki, Ramchandra Banjetri and others, who accepted that they had consumed liquor, and were fined Rs 500 by courts in the city.For those who were charged with bootlegging country liquor, the metropolitan courts have imposed fines of Rs 200 on each of the accused and ordered them to sit in the courtroom for a day as their punishment.Anil Chunara, Suryaben Chunara and many others confessed their crimes before courts and were shown leniency.Salem Sheikh was caught drunk driving. He was booked under Section 185 of the Motor Vehicles Act. He admitted his crime and was let off with a fine of Rs 1,000.For an offence committed in 2015 under the prohibition laws, before the law was made stringent, a court at the Mirzapur rural court campus had fined one Yogendrasinh Harbhajansinh with Rs 100 for drinking liquor.

Title: Key infrastructure projects in three districts may be completed this year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

KHAGARIA/ SITAMARHI/ ARARIA: This new year is expected to witness completion of many key infrastructure projects in several districts in the state which are aimed at benefiting the people in manifold ways.

Khagaria: The district is soon expected to have a four-lane RCC cable-stayed 3,160 metre-long bridge to be built utilizing an estimated outlay of Rs 1,710,77crore across the Ganga at Aguwani Ghat under Parbatta block. The bridge will link NH-31 and 107, thus reducing the distance between Khagaria and Sultanganj in Bhagalpur district besides Supaul, Saharsa and Madhepura districts.

In Araria, an ambitious ‘Prestine Mega Food Park’, an agro-based project entailing an outlay of Rs127 crore, at Ekaniya village under Mansi block is also expected to be commissioned this year. The project is expected to generate employment opportunities to 5,000 people and benefit about 25,000 farmers. Similarly, Khagaria-Alouligarh rail project under the Samastipur division of East Central Railway (ECR) with a cost of Rs 162 crore is expected to be completed in coming few months.

With regard to key railway projects, Araria is set to get a new railway line from Supaul-Araria upto Galgalia as work on Araria-Galgalia railway line is already underway. Besides, the bidding process for construction of the first phase of railway line from Supaul to Pipra entailing an estimated outlay of Rs 1,725438963 stands completed.

Railways apart, construction of an engineering college at Renu Ban at Simraha, the birth place of late Phanishwar Nath ‘Renu’, entailing an estimated outlay of Rs 83crore, construction of a civil court at Forbesganj, construction of a ITI College at Araria, and an art centre-cum-gymkhana are few other projects in the pipeline in Araria.

Besides, work on construction of NH- 57 connecting India with Nepal with a cost of Rs 270 crore along with construction of ANM and GNM training centres with a cost of Rs 29.6 crore are also likely to be completed in 2020.

Also, upgradation of Araria sadar hospital into a full-fledged district hospital has necessitated addition of 300 beds and opening of a health and wellness centre. An amount of Rs 82 crore is estimated to be spent on upgradation of the sadar hospital. Moreover, several new announcements for Araria are likely to be made on January 6 when CM Nitish Kumar is likely to visit the district under his ‘Jal Jivan Hariyali Yatra.’

Sitamarhi: The projects likely to be completed in 2020 in Sitamarhi district include opening of a new Kendriya Vidyalaya, a medical college at Muradpur village near Sitamarhi town and making Sitamarhi Nagar Parishad, a municipal corporation. District magistrate Abhilasha Kumari Sharma said that river Lakhandei and Manushamara would be channelised in their old courses. This will give relief from flood and boost cultivation in several districts including Sitamarhi.

Title: VTR’s lone tigress found dead
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

BAGAHA: The lone tigress of Valmiki Tiger Reserve (VTR) in West Champaran was found dead on Tuesday evening.

The carcass of the two-year-old tigress was found in Raghiya forest sector near Ghoradih under the Gobardhana police station area. Forest officials said the tigress was killed after suspected fight with another tiger.

Deputy director-cum-divisional forest officer of VTR Ambrish Kumar Mall said, “Prima facie territorial fight seems to be the reason for the death of the tigress. The autopsy on the body of the tigress is being done and some samples will be sent to advance veterinary laboratory to find out the exact cause of the death.”

Veterinary doctor of Bagaha- II block, SB Ranjan, who performed the autopsy on Wednesday morning said the throat vein of the tigress was found fractured. “Blood stains and injury marks of nails were also found on the body of the tigress,” he said.

The body of the tigress was consigned to flames at Gobardhana rage office headquarters. Sources said that the with the death of lone tigress, the number of tigers in VTR came down from 31 to 30.

Title: Style meets substance in calendar brought out by budding designers
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Tirupur: To usher in the New Year in style , students of the NIFT-TEA College of Knitwear Fashion here have released a calendar for the fifth consecutive year.

The students concentrated on five fashion trends bridal, casual, contemporary, party and wearable art. They not only designed the garments but also created the props in the background and also handled photography and editing.

“Fashion is not just about garments and fabrics but also about the properties in the background, makeup, aesthetics, styling, art and layout. Our students created everything to give life to the calendar, which has come out very well,” said G Boopathy Vijay, an assistant professor.

“As themes, they chose history for August, as the month is associated with the country’s independence. A knitted garment with prints has the background with newspaper headlines on the death of Mahatma Gandhi, twin bombs destroying Hiroshima and Nagasaki, death of Hitler and sinking of the Titanic,” Boopathy told TOI.

The students created a mini chariot using cardboards to suit an Indian ethnic wear for November, the month of Diwali, said S Sabarissh, a second-year student of the apparel fashion designing department, one of the six students, who made the calendar. “For the month of December, our theme has dew falling in the background, to denote the Christmas season.”

“We created retro fashion concepts using a large-size guitar, toothed wheels and radio as background,” said P Gnana Prakash Raj, who took the photos and edited them. The other four students who contributed were P Manish, N L Aabash Kumar, S Ragu Prasanth and A Kavin.

Five girl students modelled for the calendar, Boopathy said. “Usually, April Fool’s Day is associated with pranks. So, we designed a fashion wear inspired by the Joker, the character played by Heath Ledger in The Dark Knight.”

Title: New Year begins on foggy note, temp may rise in coming days
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Indore: The city may heave a sigh of relief as temperate is likely to rise despite chances of rain in next 48 hours, as per Met forecast.

“An upper air circulation system has formed in south Gujarat and a trough in north west Madhya Pradesh till south Gujarat. Both the systems has brought cloudy weather in the city. Light rain may also occur due to them,” Met official Ajay Shukla told TOI.

There will also be a rise in both minimum and maximum temperatures for a couple of days from Thursday, he added.

On Wednesday, residents of Indore woke up to a foggy morning with a dip in temperature. While Jabalpur, Pachmarhi and Betul received rainfall, Indore, Ujjain and Ratlam witnessed fog along with cold waves throughout the day.

The maximum temperature recorded in the city on Wednesday was 22.4 degrees Celsius with a drop of four degrees. However, the minimum temperature rose to three degrees at 11.6 degrees Celsius. The relative humidity percentage in the morning reached 95% and in the evening it came down to 82% with 13 per cent decrease.

At 5 degrees Celsius, the lowest minimum temperature was recorded in Gwalior.

Both western and eastern parts of Madhya Pradesh witnessed severe cold day along with dense to very dense fog and thunderstorm at isolated places on Wednesday. The department has issued a warning of light rain in Bhopal, Ujjain, Rewa, Sagar, Hoshangabad and Shahdol divisions along with Neemuch, Mandsaur, Guna, Gwalior, Datia, Morena and Bhind districts.

Title: 35 get challans in Nainital on New Year’s Eve
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nainital: Nainital police issued challans to 35 people, including five Thailand nationals studying at Aligarh Muslim University (AMU), for violating traffic rules on New Year ’s Eve.

Speaking to TOI, Mallital station house officer, Ashok Kumar, said, “The students had come to Nainital with their friends to celebrate New Year’s Eve but they were not wearing helmets and therefore were violating traffic rules. We caught them near Mallital rickshaw stand and fined them Rs 500 each,” he said. The foreign students paid the fines on the spot after which they were let off by the police. However, the entire area got blocked to witness these foreign students riding colourful bikes being fined by the police.

These challans were issued by the police in the Mallital area since the Tallital police station was busy managing traffic arrangements. “Our main task was to manage the flow of traffic since Mallital is the entry point for tourists to Tallital. However, we did carry out a drive on Monday when we challaned over 60 people and even seized a vehicle. Most of these people were tourists and hadcome from places such as Delhi and other nearby areas. We have also seized a vehicle of a tourist which will be returned after proper procedure,” police said. While the cause-wise breakup of the challans issued wasn’t available yet, police said that most were issued for driving without helmets and some for drunk driving.

Title: Steps taken by police ensure no major accidents during revelry
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: Except for a few road accidents , the city welcomed the New Year with special prayers at religious places, revelry on roads and parties at hotels.

The city police ensured fatal accident-free New Year celebrations that went on till 2am on Wednesday with fun and frolic.

The city police made extensive arrangements to curtail speeding, drag racing and drunk driving.

As many as 25 check points were set up on Avinashi Road and Race Course to detain traffic violators. To tighten the security, 1,500 police personnel were deployed across the city and patrolling was carried out in 44 two-wheelers and 26 four-wheelers. Certain entry points from Avinashi Road and Race Couse were temporarily blocked with barricades to prevent untoward incidents.

However, 14 people sustained minor injuries in road accidents in the city.

A police officer said hundreds of bikers were detained for speeding or drunk driving ahead of the celebrations and were let off only after the celebrations were over. Cases were not registered against them, he added. The bikers were given a piece of cake to mark the New Year celebrations.

Hours after celebrations were wound up, B Ansaruddin, 20, a resident of GM Nagar in Karumbukadai, died in road accident after he lost control of his vehicle and dashed a tree at Ukkadam by-pass road around 4.30am on Wednesday. He died on the spot. His body was sent to the Coimbatore Medical College Medical (CMCH) for post-mortem.

Similarly, N Chandru, 25, a resident of Nammakal, died after he fell from his vehicle near Kovilpalayam on the city outskirts around 10pm on Tuesday. As he did not wear helmet, he sustained severe injuries on head. Commuters took him to a nearly private hospital where he died without responding to the treatment.

Last year, three people died in road accidents on Thadagam Road and Sundakamuthur bypass during the celebrations, thus crushing the police’s hope of having a fatal-free New Year celebration for the third consecutive year.

Title: Over 16,000 beneficiaries skip mustering process
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Over 16,000 beneficiaries of social welfare pension did not turn up for mustering process, which was conducted by city corporation as part of statewide verification of the identities of pension recipients and to filter out ineligible beneficiaries.

As per data with the corporation, as on Tuesday, which was the last date for mustering process, 70,975 beneficiaries completed mustering process while 16,222 beneficiaries skipped it. There are a total of 87,197 beneficiaries for five types of social welfare pension. The two-month long process was conducted by the corporation after the state government mandated that mustering is essential for all kinds of pension, in addition to furnishing relevant certificates.

The mustering process is mainly aimed at verifying life certificates of pension beneficiaries and linking these certificates with Aadhaar cards. The separate list of beneficiaries who attended mustering process shows that nearly 10,000 beneficiaries who receive old age pension did not attend mustering.

“They may not be alive, some of them may be bed-ridden and there could even be cases in which their relatives would be receiving the pension. We have to verify why these many beneficiaries did not attend the mustering process. We would try to make sure by all means that whoever is eligible for welfare pension do not get omitted from the list,” said S S Sindhu, chairperson, welfare standing committee.

In case of disbursal of widow pension, 24,191 beneficiaries completed mustering process out of the total of 28,277 beneficiaries. Owing to the presence of ineligible beneficiaries under widow pension, the state government has recently mandated beneficiaries to produce self-attested certificates annually, proving that they haven’t got remarried. The condition was also made applicable for beneficiaries of pension for unmarried women below the age of 60.

With 16,222 beneficiaries not turning up for mustering, corporation could redirect over Rs 1 crore as pension amount for eligible beneficiaries. The officials said that even for the bed-ridden patients who were receiving welfare pension, provisions were made for conducting mustering at their homes. Those who were not able to register their bio-metric data due to old age were issued forms certifying that mustering had failed and alternative arrangements were done for such people, said Sindhu.

“The beneficiaries who did not attend mustering process could also include persons who are ineligible for welfare pension. That might be the reason why they skipped the process,” said an official.

Title: Miyapur Crossroads: Activists record 120 violations of wrong-side driving
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Violations recorded during awareness drive at Miyapur

HYDERABAD: Activists noticed about 120 violations of wrong side driving at Miyapur Crossroads during an awareness drive on the first day of New Year. They said they recorded all the offenders and would be handing over the data to traffic cops . “We were at the site for under an hour but recorded at least 120 violations of just wrong-side driving,” said Jayachandra Oleti, an activist. He said besides wrong side drivers, triple riding was another common offence.

“We did not even count motorists not wearing helmets, otherwise the number of violations would have crossed 300,” said Oleti. A traffic volunteer himself, he said he would report the violations to the cops.

Another activist at the site, Vinay Vangala, said, “Lot of educated residents were seen behaving irresponsibly at Miyapur area.”

Anumod Thomas, also part of the drive, said, “This year we plan to carry out more awareness drives to ensure that people understand and adhere to traffic laws.”

Title: Despite high rates, limited supply, dry fruits demand up
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Indore: The plunge in temperature has lifted demand for dry fruits in local markets negating the impact of higher prices with traders anticipating a growth of over 5 -8 per cent in sales in coming months.

The rates have risen by around Rs 50 per kg to Rs 100 per kg for past a month owing to a jump in demand in winters, the peak season for dry fruits consumption, said traders.

Amongst all, prices of dry dates have shot up the most by close to 50 per cent due to encouraging demand amid restricted supplies. Dry dates are being sold at Rs 140 per kg to Rs 150 per kg as against Rs 40 per kg to Rs 70 per kg earlier.

Dry dates were originally imported from Pakistan to cater to the local needs but after restriction on imports, supplies have been limited from alternative origins such as Iran and Afghanistan.

Prateek Tiwari, a date seller from the wholesale Siyaganj market said, “Prices of dry dates have jumped multi-fold this winter because supplies are not as smooth as earlier besides demand has also grown mainly amongst lower income class.”

The daily arrivals of dry dates from Pakistan were about 320 quintals in Siyaganj Wholesale Kirana Market which has reduced to negligible.

Demand for dates have also gone up and the premium variety from Saudi Arab is being sold in the range of Rs 1,500 per kg to Rs 3,000 per kg.

Ramesh Khandelwal, president, Siyaganj Wholesale Kirana Merchant Association said, “This winter looks good as most dry fruits and species are doing good business. Prices have gone up and demand is rising with the dip in temperature.”

Figs, raisins, apricot, pistachio, and cashews are most in demand this season, traders said.

Title: Coimbatore: Man dupes elderly woman of gold, mobile phone, held
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police arrested a 43-year-old man after he robbed a 65-year-old woman of her gold ornaments weighing 7.5 sovereign and other belongings at the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) on Tuesday.

Police identified the accused as M Krishnakumar, a resident of Sundarapuram. “The accused noticed G Palaniammal alone at the hospital. He initiated a conversation with her and told her that the government is assisting senior citizens to meet out their medical expenses upon submitting an application form. Before meeting a doctor to get a form, he told her to remove her ornaments as the doctor may suspect her to be wealthy,” a police officer said.

Believing the accused, Palaniammal handed over her ornaments, a mobile phone and Rs 200 to him and went to see the doctor, the officer said. “When she came back, the accused had escaped with the items.”

Realising that she had been duped, Palaniammal informed her son G Mohanasundaram. He came to the hospital, took her to the Race Course police station and lodged a complaint.

Based on the complaint, the police traced the accused and arrested him on the same day. Later, he was produced before a judicial magistrate, who remanded him in judicial custody.

In another incident, the Bazaar police arrested S Suresh, 38, a resident of Kollam district in Kerala for stealing a gold chain weighing three sovereign from a man while travelling in a town bus near Podhanur. Police made the arrest based on a complaint from M Pradiponnu Gurus, who lost the Rs 75,000 worth chain. The accused was later lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Chief minister defends slapping of UAPA
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Dismissing the stand of CPM central leadership, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan defended the slapping of UAPA against the two college students of Pantheerankavu in Kozhikode on alleged Maoist links . He told reporters on Wednesday that Allan Shuhaib and Thwaha Fasal were not arrested by police when they were having a cup of tea.

Asserting that he doesn’t have the opinion that they (Allan and Thwaha) were saints, Vijayan said, “You might be wishing that under normal circumstances I would say slapping UAPA (on them) was a big mistake. I am not saying that. I stand by my earlier position that I don’t have the opinion that they were not involved in such activities.”

When reminded of his earlier promise to the party that the case would be reviewed by Justice P S Gopinathan commission constituted by the state government, the CM said such a situation hasn’t arisen in this case.

“That is during filing of chargesheet. Here, we didn’t reach that phase. They (NIA) have taken over before that. They can take over the case at any phase. That is what the law suggests,” said the CM, who didn’t forget to claim that like his party he also is a critic of UAPA.

In further defence of the police under the home department which he himself handles, Vijayan said there were several other instances under the LDF rule when UAPA was invoked against the accused.

Meanwhile, Sabitha Shekhar, mother of Allan Shuhaib, penned a touching note for her son on New Year’s day. After mentioning about the moderate New Year celebrations she had with her friends and students, Sabitha tells Allan that no government can jail his thoughts though they can incarcerate him physically. “All regimes create dictators. Their egos incarcerate innocents. If we examine history, (we will find that) the end of all dictators was tragic. So, Allan, wait patiently. Our time will come,” said Sabitha in the note shared on her Facebook page.

Title: After 3 defeats, Unmukt Chand stripped of captaincy, his deputy Tanmay Srivastava now new skipper
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Dehradun: After losing all three games in the ongoing Ranji Trophy tournament, the Cricket Association of Uttarakhand (CAU) has made some major changes in the Uttarakhand squad.

Team captain Unmukt Chand has been relieved from his captaincy duties and his deputy Tanmay Srivastava will now lead the side for the remaining season.

The Uttarakhand team is having a bad time in the current Ranji season. In the three matches that the team has played till now, Uttarakhand lost by 253 runs against Jammu and Kashmir while the team lost an innings against Chhattisgarh. In the last game of the year, Uttarakhand lost by 10 wickets against Odisha.

Apart from not winning the games, Chand had a poor outing with the bat in the first-class games this season. The 26-year old batsman scored only 70 runs from six innings. Chand had the highest score of 24 against Chhattisgarh and got dismissed thrice in single-digits. The former India U-19 captain hasn’t had a smooth domestic season as he missed out the entire Syed Mushtaq Ali T20 Trophy due to an injury.

The newly-appointed captain Srivastava hasn’t had a great outing with the bat either but has scored more runs than Chand in the three Ranji Trophy matches. Srivastava scored 116 runs in three games and scored a half-century in the second innings against Chhattisgarh. Srivastava also got dismissed thrice at single-digit scores in the six innings he played.

Meanwhile, the selectors have dropped batsmen Karanveer Kaushal and Avneesh Sudha from the squad. Both of them have been replaced by stand-by players Piyush Joshi and Harshit Bisht.

Uttarakhand’s next game is against Assam starting from January 3 at the Rajiv Gandhi International Cricket Stadium in Raipur.

Title: Ist transgender adalat on Jan 10
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: In an attempt to resolve the issues faced by members of the transgender community such as violation of rights and denial of justice, the Kerala state youth commission will organize a state-level adalat on January 10.

The special hearing, exclusively for transgender community, is a first of its kind initiative in the state. The aim of the adalat is to find solutions to the complaints of transgender persons regarding exploitation they face at home, workplace and in the society.

The adalat will be led by youth commission chairperson Chintha Jerome and will begin at 11am on January 10 at the conference hall of Government Guest House in Thycaud.

The aim of the adalat is to provide a platform where they can express their concerns without fear.

Complaints and suggestions are invited from transgender persons aged between 18 and 40 years. For further details contact: 0471-2308630.

Officials in youth commission said that many transgender persons keep away from filing complaints fearing the hostile environment in police stations. The initiative by the commission is to address this gap.

“Despite having legal protection and support of the government, a section of transgender people still complain about ill treatment from the society. There are complaints that transgender people are treated as second grade citizens even in government offices where they approach for different services,” said an official.

Title: Pension for seafarers via social welfare
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: The disbursal of pension for retired seafarers under the Goa welfare/pension scheme for seafarers will soon be implemented through the social welfare department.

“We have already transferred all the data to the social welfare department. Earlier, there used to be cases where people would draw pension from the social welfare scheme as well as from the seafarers scheme which is not permissible,” director for NRI affairs Anthony D'Souza stated.

This integration of the scheme with the DSSS will streamline the process, D’Souza said.

The scheme introduced in 2012 provides financial assistance in the form of gross monthly pension of Rs 2,500 to retired Goan Seamen on completion of 60 years of age who were employed on lowly paid jobs on board the ship and retired, including seamen invalidated from sea service on medical grounds before retirement and widows of deceased seamen on compassionate grounds, provided the annual income from all sources does not exceed Rs 1.2 lakh.

Title: ‘CAA won’t affect Portuguese citizens registered as OCIs’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: The NRI commission of Goa has not received any cases from Portuguese citizens over their citizenship status in the wake of the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), commissioner for NRI affairs Narendra Sawaikar said on Wednesday.

“Most of them are registered as overseas citizens of India (OCI), which give them all the rights. In fact they should not worry. CAA will not have any effect on those people because they’re registered as OCIs. Therefore there should not be any problem,” he told reporters.

A large number of Goans have voluntarily surrendered their Indian citizenship for Portuguese citizenship for better job and educational prospects abroad. The Portuguese passport became all the more alluring after Portugal joined the European Union (EU), giving citizens easy access to EU countries, especially the UK .

Title: Industrial estate projects to make headway this year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: Industrial associations in the district have decided to expedite industrial estate projects in 2020.

While the Coimbatore Gold Jewellery Cluster, which will have modern facilities to make gold jewellery, is expected to be operational by August, other industrial associations are also getting ready to start construction and finish their projects this year.

Members of the Coimbatore Sidco Industrial Estate Manufacturers Welfare Association (Cosiema) are working on land registration process for the industrial estate at Kinathukkadavu. Representatives said they have completed the process for the 42-acre plot. Land survey is under way.

“Once the survey is complete and the boundaries are marked, we would approach the State and the Centre for infrastructure subsidy,” said S Surulivel, former president of Cosiema and current state vice-president of Lagu Udhyog Bharati. “We hope to get Rs 10crore fund and also infrastructure subsidy from the State. Construction is likely to start by March or April. The estate will focus on expansion projects of the industrial units at the Sidco Industrial Estate in Kurichi.”

Meanwhile, work on the Nethaji Industrial Estate at Devanampalayam village at Sarkar Samakulam is also progressing fast. Representatives have decided to handover the land to the members this year.

Secretary of the Nethaji Industrial Estate Society P Soundararajan said they had applied for infrastructure subsidy six months ago. “The procedure is yet to be completed. We are also planning to start the project by our own if it gets more delayed,” he added.

Title: Med students ask govt to cancel exam
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The third-year MBBS students of SR Medical College and Research Centre at Akathumuri near Varkala have requested the state government to cancel the university examinations of the third-year regular batch, which is scheduled to be commence on January 10.

In a news conference called by the SR Medical College Action Council on Wednesday, the students and their parents alleged that even after the Union ministry of health directed the state government to withdraw the essentiality certificate (EC) of the college and directed to shift the students to other medical colleges across the state, the Kerala University of Health Sciences (KUHS) is turning a blind eye to the order.

It was on December 27, citing poor facilities and lack of faculties and patients at the SR Medical College, that the medical education wing of ministry of health and family welfare issued an order directing the state government to cancel the EC and to send a proposal for shifting the students.

Simi B, a parent said that though the Centre’s intervention was a relief to the students, the silence of KUHS is a reason for worry.

“At a time when the ministry had asked the government to take immediate steps to shift the students, KUHS has announced the examination dates for the regular batch and asked to pay the examination fee and the management started collecting fees. The management also threatens the students that there won’t be any shifting and also announced that Rs 300 will be imposed as fine if they refuse to pay the examination fee. It seems that the university is supporting the college management by conducting the examination which is not a right move,” said Simi.

The students have sought immediate intervention of the state government in this regard. “We have not received a single class for third-year subjects that include ophthalmology and ENT. We have not seen any patient this year. There is another group of students who support the management and is ready to write the exams. How can we call one a doctor if he/she lacks practical knowledge? KUHS should take immediate steps in shifting us to other medical colleges and cancel the announced examinations,” said Shehin S S, a third-year student.

Title: Passengers say nominal train fare hike no cause for worry
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: Effective from January 1 , any ticket to Chennai on an airconditioned coach from the city will cost Rs 20 more. Tickets on non-AC coaches will costRs 10 more.

This comes after the Indian Railways announced a blanket increase in fares of four paise per kilometre for the AC class, one paisa for ordinary non-suburban classes and two paise for non-AC mail/express trains.

Those who travel to Chennai from Coimbatore on the Nilgiris Express’ sleeper class spending Rs 265 will have to shell out Rs 10 more from now on. The fares for the AC classes, which ranges from Rs 815 to Rs 1,940, will increase by Rs Rs 20. “For a family of six, the total fare will go up by Rs 60 to Rs 120,” said a railway official.

Fares from Coimbatore to Delhi, which range from Rs Rs 820 on a sleeper class to Rs 3,245 on an AC second class, will increase by Rs 53.5 and Rs 107 respectively. “For a six-member family, the increase will be Rs 300 to Rs Rs 600,” the official said.

Frequent rail passengers, who were initially worried about the impending increase in fares, heaved a sigh of relief after the announcement on Sunday. “The fact that it does not apply to season tickets and suburban rail travellers is a relief,” said T Arunachalam, a regular traveller. “ I think with the cost of so many essentials, including vegetables increasing, a hike of Rs 4 to Rs 6 for a train I take every week is reasonable.”

Rail activists said the hike is justified, especially after five years. “No doubt, it may affect a poor family, but overall, the increase is reasonable and hardly costs Rs 10 to Rs 15 for most trains within South India and the state,” said B Mohanraj of the Pollachi Rail passengers Welfare Association.

However, former division rail users committee member and member of Parliament P R Natrajan said the hike is an additional burden on the people, who are already reeling under job losses and a bad economy. “We are further burdening the poor, who are facing inflation in all other streams and job losses. So, every paisa counts. The hike should be withdrawn,” he added.

Title: R K Singh new finance secretary
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The government has appointed Rajesh Kumar Singh , an officer from 1989 batch, as the principal secretary (finance). He replaces Manoj Joshi, who is leaving the state on central deputation.

Singh, who had recently come back from the Centre, has been serving as principal secretary (public works department). He will continue to hold the charge of principal secretary of animal husbandry and dairy development department as well.

As he moves to finance, Ishitha Roy, who also recently came back to the cadre after her central deputation, will hold the charge of public works department. The cabinet also gave additional charge of secretary of food and public distribution and civil supplies to P Venugopal. He is currently holding the charge of information and public relations department. The cabinet also appointed Haritha V Kumar, who is back after leave, as deputy secretary in the general administration department.

The government also promoted two IPS officers from 1995 batch to the rank of additional director general of police. While Suresh Rajpurohit has been conferred pro-forma promotion as he is currently on central deputation as IG in the special protection group, M R Ajith Kumar has been posted as ADGP (armed police battalion). He was serving as city police commissioner in Thiruvananthapuram. TNN

Title: PWD strengthens bund wall of lake after breach
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Erode: Public works department officials and residents of Perumugai village near Gobichettipalayam in Erode district stopped seepage from a lake after an eight-hour operation.

Around 9pm on Tuesday, a few residents of the village noticed water seeping from Sanjeevirayan lake spread over 100 acres. “The flow was increasing continously. If it had continued, five villages including Anna Nagar, Varapallam and Sybanpudur as well as 200 acres of fertile lands would be submerged,” C Mathivanan, a villager, said.

The lake was recently desilted under the Kudimaramathu scheme. “It was about 36ft deep. Water reaching the lake was already diverted to nearby canals for irrigation purposes,” a PWD official said.

After being alerted, the PWD officials reached the spot and tried to place sand bags to prevent seepage at the breached spot. They used earthmovers to fill sand to strengthen the bund wall. Andhiyur legislator Rajam Krishnan also reached the spot and monitored the work. After eight hours, water seepage was finally stopped.

Title: Got a complaint? Use Rail Madad app, 139 helpline
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: Borrowing a page from the police department , which introduced apps like Kavalan SOS and Police-E-Eye to seek assistance, the railway has introduced Rail Madad , an app for train passengers .

Whether it is a stinking toilet, stained sheet or a troublesome co-passenger, all you need to do is to register a complaint on the app or dial139, which has been made an integrated railway helpline.

From Wednesday morning,139 took over all existing helpline numbers like 138, for General Complaints, 1800111321 for Catering Services, 1072 for accidents and safety, 152210 for Vigilance, 58888 / 138 for Clean my coach and 9717630982 for SMS Complaints. Only 139 and 182 will function along with Rail Madad, a grievance redressal mechanism developed in July last year.

Madad, which stands for Mobile Application for Desired Assistance During travel, can be downloaded from Google Play. Using the app, you can register a complaint with minimum inputs and can upload a photograph also.

The minute the complaint is registered, the app will issue a unique ID and relay the complaint to the relevant official for action. Once the complaint is acted on, the passenger will receive an SMS update, fast tracking the entire process of redressal.

The app also displays security helpline numbers and has a provision for a complainant to directly make a call for immediate assistance. It is expected to generate data, which can present an overall picture of weak and deficient areas in railway operation that can corrected, said an official.

Data analysis will also generate trends on various performance parameters of a selected train or station like cleanliness and amenities among others making managerial decisions more precise and effective. Dashboard and reports will also be available for management at division /zonal/ railway board level and sent through auto email to every officer concerned.

Customer care number 044 – 25351621 for UTS ON MOBILE will continue to function for promoting paperless booking.

Title: Man pushed down in petty quarrel, dies
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Tirupur: A 49-year-old man was killed near Avinashi in the district on Tuesday after one of his neighbours pushed him down during a quarrel.

Rajendran R of S Mettupalayam in Avinashi taluk was working as a painter and his 15-year-old son was studying Class XI in a school nearby. On Tuesday, the boy was riding Rajendran’s motorcycle. He lost control of it when he was speeding and hit his neighbour’s dog, which was killed on the spot, a policer officer said.

When M Saminathan, 42, a driver, was informed of his pet’s death, he confronted the boy and scolded him. Irked Rajendran intervened on his son side and an argument ensued. At a point, Saminathan pushed Rajendran down. Rajendran suffered severe head injuries and lost his consciousness, the officer said.

Rajendran was rushed to the Avinashi government hospital, where doctors declared him brought dead. The Avinashi police registered a case and arrested Saminathan. He was later lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Congress to speaker: Decide on disqualification plea
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

10 former Congress MLAs had joined BJP mid-2019

PANAJI: Congress on Wednesday requested speaker Rajesh Patnekar to decide on the disqualification petition filed against 10 former Congress MLAs who joined BJP mid-2019.

State Congress president Girish Chodankar said the delay in deciding the disqualification petition defeats the purpose of the anti-defection law. “It is submitted that justice delayed is justice denied, and in the present case, the delay caused in delivery of justice is giving undue and undeserving benefit to the respondents to illegally continue as members of the legislative assembly,” said Chodankar in his application for expeditious disposal of the disqualification petition.

Former opposition leader Chandrakant Kavalekar, Isidore Fernandes, Nilkanth Halarnkar, Jennifer Monserrate, Antonio Fernandes, Francisco Silveira, Wilfred Dsa, Clafasio Dias, Filipe Rodrigues and Antanasio Monserrate broke away from Congress and joined BJP en masse without resigning as MLAs.

Subsequently, Congress filed disqualification petitions before the speaker of the House under Article 191(2) of the Constitution of India and Schedule X, seeking that the 10 MLAs had incurred disqualification by joining the BJP.

Patnekar held a preliminary hearing on October 15, where the Congress put forth its stand. Since then, Patnekar has not held any other hearings on the matter.

Chodankar says that there has been no “meaningful progress” in the disqualification proceedings and “adjudication in the matter is being unreasonably delayed” by Patnekar, who is from the BJP camp.

Title: Tableau plan rejected, Bihar out of Delhi Republic Day parade
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

ITBP personnel during their rehearsal for Republic Day Parade 2020 at Rajpath in New Delhi on Tuesday. (Photo:... Read More

PATNA: Bihar will not be represented in the Republic Day parade at Janpath in New Delhi on January 26. Officials at Bihar Information Centre in Delhi said though the Centre appreciated the state government’s theme of Jal-Jivan-Hariyali Mission proposed for its tableau, but refused to showcase it in the Republic Day parade because “it does not fulfil the criteria for that”. Bihar was not included in the R-Day parade in 2019 as well.

“As the state government is working on the ambitious JJH Mission, which is one of a kind initiative to tackle climate change and water conservation, it was proposed as our theme for Bihar’s tableau in national R-Day parade. We had submitted a proposal in this regard to the defence ministry in September. But the ministry later claimed that as per the set criteria for Republic Day parade, state governments cannot make their tableaux on such a theme,” a senior official at Bihar Information Centre said.

Sources said the selection committee under the defence ministry has set stringent criteria for selecting tableaux for R-Day parade. According to sources, the entries sent by states have to pass three rounds of scrutiny by the selection committee. The broad parameters for evaluating the themes proposed by the states include international branding, national integration and aesthetic value.

“Even though the selection committee appreciated our theme and the state government’s endeavours under the JJH Mission, it turned down our proposal for showcasing the same in the R-Day parade,” he said and added that Bihar government had proposed prohibition as the theme for its tableau in 2019 but it was also rejected for similar reasons.

Officials said the last time Bihar featured in the R-Day parade in Delhi was in 2015 when its tableau was based on the celebrations of 100 years of Mahatma Gandhi’s Champaran Satyagraha.
