Prior to that, the theme for Bihar’s tableau in 2013 was ‘Mithila ka Sikki art’. Sikki is a traditional folk craft of Mithila region. In 2012, the theme for Bihar’s tableau was ‘Dharhara Ki Beti’. Dharhara is a village in Bhagalpur district. It is famous for its tradition of planting of trees by families on the birth of a girl child.

Title: KSHRC seeks report on surveillance cameras
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

T’puram: The failure of police in identifying the car involved a hit-and-run case at Vellayambalam three days ago has invited the criticism of the Kerala state human rights commission (KSHRC).

Commission chairman Justice Antony Dominic on Wednesday directed the city police commissioner to file a report on conditions of the cameras in the surveillance camera network of the police in the city within four weeks.

On Sunday night, an online food delivery executive, Abdul Rahim, was killed after he was knocked down by a speeding car. Another person, who sustained serious injuries in the accident, is still under treatment. The police are yet to identify the car. They claim that the cameras in the proximity could not capture visuals that could help identify the car that caused the accident.

KSHRC has intervened in the issue after receiving a petition in this regard from a city resident, Ajithkumar of Vazhuthacaud. The petitioner alleged that the accident occurred near high security zone that housed the official residences of the governor and ministers. Hence it is highly unlikely for the cameras in the zone to be dysfunctional. tnn

Title: Sunshine comes as welcome relief on New Year eve
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A kid wrapped in a blanket to beat the chilling cold on Tuesday. The minimum temperature was recorded at 5.8 d... Read More

Allahabad: Bright sunshine on the last day of the year brought much-needed relief to city residents who have been bearing the brunt of winter chill for last two days.

The city woke up to a hazy and foggy skyline on Tuesday but sunshine later in the day brought smiles to the faces of people who came out to enjoy the New Year eve at restaurants and public places.

The minimum temperature was recorded at 5.8 degrees Celsius while maximum temperature stood at 13.8 degrees Celsius, up by 2.9 degrees and 5.2 degrees Celsius, respectively.

The coldest day of the season was recorded at 2.9 degrees Celsius on Monday.

Met officials, however, said people would not get much relief from the chill for next few days as existing weather conditions could be attributed to rising relative humidity and icy winds coming from western region.

Meanwhile, fog continued to affect railway operations on Tuesday as many trains arrived and departed late.

Kunal Sharma, a resident of Civil Lines said, “Bright sunshine brought a major relief for people after a gap of two days. We enjoyed the last day of the year with our families.”

Anjali of Rajapur area said, “After I saw bright sunshine during afternoon hours, I decided to take my children to park and enjoy the last day of the year.”

Title: Bipin Rawat’s village celebrates his CDS appointment
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Dehradun: Residents of the sparsely populated Saina village, the native village of General Bipin Singh Rawat, rejoiced after the Union government appointed him as the country’s first Chief of Defence Staff (CDS).

On Wednesday morning, the villagers woke up to celebratory drum beating. “We are all proud of Bipin’s achievement and celebrated his appointment with great joy and happiness. Everyone participated in the special prayer. Later, we had lunch in our house,” said Gen Rawat’s uncle Bharat Singh Rawat, who is also a retired Army personnel.

The villagers expressed hope that General Rawat will continue to excel in his role as the first CDS of the country. “During his last visit to the village, Gen Rawat had promised to do things for the school and hospital here. We hope that those things would get materialised now,” said Ravindra Bisht, aresident of Saina village. Villagers are also expecting that Gen Rawat would visit his native place soon.

Gen Rawat had last visited the village in 2018 after taking over as Army Chief in 2016. Saina village is located approximately 80 km from Pauri district’s headquarter Kotdwar.

Earlier on Monday, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat had also congratulated Gen Rawat on his appointment as Chief of Defence Staff. “It is a matter of pride and honour for Uttarakhand,” the chief minister had said.

Notably, Gen Rawat has been appointed India'’s first CDS with a mandate to bring in convergence in functioning of the Army, the Navy and the Indian Air Force and bolster the country’s military prowess.

Title: Drink-driving cases on VIP Road, Sector V exceed Kolkata’s
Content:
Cops carry out breathalyzer tests on bikers in Kolkata

KOLKATA: The number of people caught driving drunk on VIP Road and at Chinar Park and Sector V far exceeded the figure in entire Kolkata on the intervening night of December 31 and January 1 with cops from the Bidhannagar commissionerate booking 317 motorists and bikers. In Kolkata, 188 were booked on the night of revelry.“This year, we were determined to ensure no accident took place on the year-end festive night, especially owing to drink-driving. Hence, we had set up checkpoints and nakas at all major entry and exit points, along with main junctions near party zones and bars in our jurisdiction. The move yielded results and we booked 317 people just for driving or riding drunk. This strict checking ensured that not even a single accident took place in our area,” said Kunal Agarwal, joint commissioner (headquarters) of Bidhannagar commissionerate.More than 2,000 cops from the Bidhannagar City Police got down on the roads around 8pm on Tuesday and their drive continued till 4am on Wednesday. Not only senior officers in the rank of deputy commissioner and additional commissioner but also Agarwal himself and even Bidhannagar commissioner L N Meena patrolled the roads. The only instance of trouble was recorded at a private party for which, a venue at Eco Park was rented. The organisers reportedly ran out of food and liquor, leading to a brawl. Cops had to intervene and bring the situation under control.Last year, the crackdown figures in Bidhannagar were much lower, with 169 people being booked for drink-driving and a total of 274 people were booked for different offences. This year, the total number of offenders jumped to 544. In Kolkata last year, 267 people were arrested for different offences, 182 for drink-driving. This year in Kolkata, the total number of people arrested for drink driving remained almost the same, but the total number shot up to 1,305. Of them, 863 people were booked for disorderly conduct. Lalbazar officers pointed out the number of people arrested for disorderly conduct, which included teasing, molestation, brawl, unruly behaviour and creating disturbance in a drunken state, increased almost three times the count of 267 recorded on December 31, 2018.“Most of the incidents of disorderly conduct were reported in pockets of south Kolkata. But none of the incidents was serious enough to attract specific charges. The only serious incident was that of a molestation at Dorina crossing, for which we have started a case at the New Market police station,” said an officer. He explained they arrested people when they either received a complaint or to prevent a brawl from flaring up. Several arrests were also made in Narkeldanga, Entally, Phoolbagan and Maniktala , followed by port and south west division, including Watgunge, Ekbalpore, Behala, Parnasree and Taratala.The rise in booking and arrests hinted at tighter vigilance, said a senior Kolkata Police officer. “We set up multiple checkpoints and our officers were everywhere, be it among the crowd or on buses and Metros,” said a senior officer at Lalbazar.

Title: Mumbai: Schools start weekly mental health classes
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: As mental health gains focus in schools and counsellors become a part of staff rooms, some schools are going a step ahead to break the stigma attached to it.

To ensure students do not feel akward walking into the counsellor's office, a few schools in the city now dedicate a session each week where the counsellor, like any other subject teacher, comes to a classroom to discuss issues which are otherwise are often brushed under the carpet.

Five schools in the city and Thane managed by Goenka and Associate Educational Trust have a weekly period called classroom counselling. “Professionally qualified psychologists go to a class and discuss age-appropriate mental health topics with students. Topics could range from eating healthy for a healthy mind to suicide, sexuality and relationships. We now have a lot more students speaking to our counsellors about their troubles in personal life as well. It helps identify a problem and helps the child at the right time,” said Meera Kothari, counselling director at the schools. The schools have a counselling centre and have dedicated personnel for each section.

A similar model has been highly successful at Aditya Birla Education Trust’s institutions, said child and adolescent psychiatrist Zirak Marker, who is attached to the school. “There is a need to normalise mental health issues. There is still a fear of being labelled if a student is seen going to the counsellor’s office. So why not bring the counsellors to the classroom? There must be a few periods each week when like all other subjects, the counsellor speaks to the children and teaches them coping mechanisms, resilience or emotions. Then it would not be difficult for students to approach the counsellor,” he said at a recent panel discussion.

While not all have inhouse counselling available for students, schools look at professionals to outsource demand. iCall, the helpline run by the Tata Institute of Social Sciences, recently tied up with Billabong High International Schools. “It can often be difficult to open up about thoughts because of the fear of being judged or isolated. We provide a supportive and non-judgemental space for anyone who is feeling vulnerable and suicidal,” said Tanuja Babre, programme coordinator, iCall. The helpline can be accessed post-school hours by students and the service can be availed anonymously.

Title: Relevance of cooperative banks has increased: Min
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Cooperation minister Kadakampally Surendran has said that the relevance of cooperative banking sector has increased at a time when commercial banking sector shows symptoms of weakness.

He said the cooperative sector of the state has shown its strength when the country witnessed severe crisis after demonetization. The minister was inaugurating the deposit mobilization campaign and Navakeraleeyam default settlement schemes in cooperative banks in the state.

He said the government aims to strengthen the cooperative sector with the setting up of the Kerala Bank. The aim of Kerala Bank is to mobilize Rs 3 lakh crore in two years. This money will be utilized for the development of the cooperative sector in the state.

The deposit mobilization drive will continue till February last across the state. Through this campaign, the government aims to mobilize at least Rs 6,000 crore from across the state.

Navakeraleeyam scheme provides an opportunity for defaulters to settle the loan arrears by making one-time payment. Loans given by all cooperative banks and societies under cooperation registrar will be covered by the scheme. There will be special concessions for loans availed for medical treatment. MLA V Joy, cooperation department secretary Mini Antony and cooperation registrar P K Jayasree spoke at the event.

Title: Woman hailing cab after Park Street revelry molested by men in car
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The incident took place at Dorina crossing in Esplanade despite cops being deployed nearby

Title: All set for counting of votes in local body elections today
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Salem: Three-tier security arrangements are put in place at counting centers across Salem region before the counting of votes polled for the rural local body election held on December 27 and 30. The counting would begin at 8am on Thursday.

After inspecting counting centres in Salem district, collector Raman said the process will start at 8am. “First round results will be available around 10.30am. We hope the entire process would be completed by 9pm.”

CCTV cameras were installed in all 20 counting centres in the district. “A total of 14,500 government employees will be involved in the process. Only booth agents with valid pass which was issued by the district administration will be allowed inside the counting hall,” the collector said.

In Erode district, collector C Kathiravan directed the officials to complete the counting process by evening.

The 20 counting centres in the district were installed with CCTV cameras. “A total of 14,500 government employees will be involved in counting process,” the collector said. He strictly informed that, only booth agents, those who have valid pass, issued by the district administration will be allowed inside the counting hall. Erode SP Sakthi Ganesan said 500 police personnel were deployed to safeguard ballot boxes.

The district collectors of Krishnagiri, Namakkal and Dharmapuri also reviewed the arrangements for the counting on Wednesday

Title: 66-year-old nature lover to cycle 800km to attend meet
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: 66-year-old Kishor Wankhade and his three young friends of nature from Wardha will cycle over 800km to attend the 33rd ‘pakshimitra sammelan’ (birders’ meet) at Revdanda in Alibagh district.

Wankhade and his likes could have preferred a vehicle to attend the two-day state level meet beginning January 11, but the bird watchers have a message to save environment in birding interest.

The sammelan will be opened by well-known bird expert and author Raju Kasambe. It will be attended by many experts, bird lovers and amateur bird watchers from the country.

“Even at 66, I’ve not left the ground. I’m still into cycling, playing sports, running, walking and all sorts of physical activities that keep me fit,” says Wankhade, who is also president of Bahar Nature Foundation (BNF), Wardha.

Other three members of Bahar — Dilip Virkhade, Deepak Gudhekar and Darshan Dudhane — will join Wankhade. The group will leave Wardha on January 4 and reach Alibagh in 7 days on January 10, which means they will cover a distance of over 100km every day.

Wankhade said, “Last year too, I rode 850km to attend a similar state-level birders’ meet in Karad. I started attending these meets on cycle three years ago, basically to send a message that cycle was the most environment-friendly mode of transport and clean substitute for fossil fuels.”

Earlier, Wankhade has attended similar meets in Vidarbha on cycle. The group will also meet forest minister in Mumbai and demand to declare November 5 to 12, as ‘Pakshi Saptah’ (bird week) to commemorate the birthdays of two renowned ornithologists from India — Dr Salim Ali (November 12) and Maruti Chitampalli (November 5).

To a question how cycling will help conserve birds, Virkhade said, “The message is to save nature. If it is saved, birds will automatically be. Not only this, cycling has many health benefits. On way, many people including media men meet us and help promote the message of saving environment by promoting cycling.”

Title: Two motorists killed in separate road accidents
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Two men were killed in separate accidents in the district on Wednesday.

Santhosh Kumar (39) of Santhosh Bhavan, Keezhpaloor, Aryanad, was found dead in a pit near the road at Chayam under Vithura police station limits on Wednesday around 5.30am.

It appeared that his motorcycle skidded off the road and eventually fell into the pit. Kumar was a civil police officer attached to the Vithura police station. The station officials said that Santhosh Kumar had left the station around 10.30pm on Tuesday night after completing his shift. Passers-by spotted him lying unconscious beside the road. Though he was rushed to the hospital, the doctors declared him dead on arrival.

Kumar leaves behind wife, Sreeja, and three children. Though he failed to reach home on time, his family did not bother to enquire as they were under the impression that he might be on special patrolling duty in connection with the New Year celebrations, the police said.

The police also said that primary evidence collected from the scene did not suggest involvement of any other vehicles in the accident.

His body was released to the family for funeral after conducting post-mortem examination.

The second accident was reported around 3pm near Vembayam under Venjarammoodu police station limits on Wednesday. Thulasi (35) of Kanjirammoodu House, Eettimmoodu near Manickal is the deceased. He was a daily-wages labourer.

According to Venjarammoodu police, Thulasi succumbed to injuries suffered in a vehicle accident involving his motorcycle and a tipper truck. Thulasi’s bike collided head on with a tipper truck that was going in the opposite direction. Though he was rushed to the government hospital at Kanyakulangara near Vembayam, the doctors declared him dead on arrival.

Thulasi leaves behind wife Savithri and children, Sajeev and Aswathy. His body will be released to the family for funeral after conducting post-mortem examination on Thursday.

Title: Malkajgiri to turn model railway station with more trains, facilities
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: South Central Railway (SCR) is aiming to increase the number of Diesel Electric Multiple Unit trains and passenger trains from and to the Malkajgiri railway station . The vision is to develop it as a model railway station on the lines of Lingampalli railway station, said officials. The move would also help in decongesting the Secunderabad-Kacheguda stations, they said.

The new facilities at the Malkajgiri railway station that will make it more passenger-friendly include booking offices, waiting halls, foot over bridge and a circulating area.

“A number of trains travelling to Maharashtran and other parts of Telangana halt here. Over the time, we have observed a rise in demand and need for more trains to be halted at Malkajgiri such as Rayalaseema Express, Sampark Kranthi and Devagiri Expresses. Though close to 20 express trains pass through the station, only 10 halt here," said an SCR official.

Meanwhile, citizens on Twitter under the hashtag #AskKTR are demanding to know when the MMTS trains between Bolarum and Secunderabad will start running.

This request for MMTS service also found support from railway unions and suburban train and bus travellers association who have requested railway authorities to run MMTS trains on the said route.

Despite electrification work being completed in the Bolarum and Secunderabad MMTS section in February last year, SCR is unable to run MMTS trains as the fund share by the state government is still pending.

“The extended train services from the station will provide direct rail connectivity to Malkajgiri residents and its surrounding areas to reach Hitec City, Lingampalli, Patancheru , Falaknuma and other suburban areas at an economical price,” an SCR official added.

Title: Goan diaspora youth to trace roots through history, culture
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: One of the eight Goan diaspora youth scheduled to attend the 12th edition of Know Goa Programme beginning this week is awaiting clearance from the ministry of home affairs, foreigners division, government of India.

The issue has arisen for M Monteiro, an Australian citizen, because he was born in Karachi, Pakistan.

The rest of the participants will arrive from Canada, UK and Portugal for the special programme formulated for the benefit of the Goan Diaspora youth who are born abroad and are foreign nationals, but whose parents or ancestors are of Goan origin.

The 12th edition of the KGP scheduled between January 4 and 15 will give the youth of Goan origin who haven’t had an opportunity to discover their roots, a chance to immerse themselves in Goan history and culture, commissioner of NRI affairs Narendra Sawaikar told reporters on Wednesday.

They will visit educational, cultural and historical places, including Goa Shipyard amd Goa University as well as interact with local Goans, elected representatives at all levels and government dignitaries.

An opportunity to see world heritage monuments like the Red Fort, Taj Mahal in Delhi is also on their itinerary.

The Goa government is bearing 90% of the total cost of the lowest economy air fare from their country to India and back, besides the entire cost of local travel, accommodation and meals, director of NRI affairs Anthony D’Souza stated.

The NRI commissioner has also proposed to have a global convention for Goans, the last edition of which was held in 2007.

“We will try to have this by the end of this year. There are a lot of preparations involved, and we will be inviting eminent Goan Diaspora from throughout the world to the state,” D'Souza said.

Title: Amrut elixir to dry taps and clogged drains in Cantt wards
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: Issues such as water shortage and improper drainage may well be a thing of the past in Secunderabad cantonment area with the Atal Mission for Rejuvenation and Urban Transformation (Amrut), now being extended to civilian areas under the Secunderabad Cantonment Board .

The central government sponsored scheme focuses on providing basic amenities such as water supply, sanitation, sewerage and development of green cover and open spaces in urban areas in the country.

According to official communiqué from the ministry of urban development ( MUD ), the Amrut scheme has been extended to all Cantonment Boards, including civilian areas, apart from cities, towns and notified municipalities in the country.

“The corresponding state share shall be borne by the Cantonments out of their own resources,” the official communiqué read.

Cantonment residents are hopeful that with the advent of this scheme, issues related to water supply will be solved as supply of potable water to every household is a salient feature of Amrut scheme. Residents said that only 55 per cent of Cantonment area receives adequate water at an average of five days a week.

The inclusion of residential areas under the scheme is a good sign as every household will be able to get potable water, said a senior SCB official from the water department. Officials are also hopeful that the Amrut scheme will provide much-needed relief to the areas with poor drainage system. As the sewage system in SCB is several decades-old, the low-lying areas are inundated every year drying monsoon .

“As the scheme focuses on infrastructure creation there is a direct link to provision of better services to citizens”, an official said.

Welcoming the move a senior BJP leader in Secunderabad Cantonment said, “It is unfortunate that the SCB stands as the worst performer among cantonment boards in the latest results of Swachh Survekshan League 2020 by the central government. Hopefully this central scheme may help to improve the situation.”

Title: Goa: Power department moots tariff hike, may stop slab-billing
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Your power bills are likely to get heftier in April, with the electricity department proposing a tariff hike of 3.84 %.

"The electricity department has proposed a tariff hike of 3.84 % for FY 2020-2021," the department stated in its tariff petition submitted to the Joint Electricity Regulatory Commission.

After a public hearing, the commission will decide on the government's proposal.

The department, in its proposed tariff structure is looking at cumulatively billing low-tension consumers at a uniform rate for their entire power consumption, instead of the present staggered slab rate billing. The new tariff structure has been proposed for low-tension domestic, commercial and industries categories of consumers.

All low-tension domestic consumers, whose consumption is more than 200 units, shall lose the benefit of the cheaper unit fares of the first two slabs (0-100 and 101-200 units). Total monthly consumption of more than 200 units shall fall in the respective slab and accordingly, applicable energy charges for that respective slab will be levied," the department has stated.

Currently, low-tension domestic consumers are charged Rs 1.40 per unit for consumption up to 100 units, Rs 2.20 per unit for consumption up to 200 units, Rs 2.65 per unit for consumption up to 300 units and Rs 3.45 per unit up to 400 units and Rs 4 per unit for above units.

Similarly, the department has proposed that low-tension commercial consumers, whose consumption is beyond 100 units lose the benefit of the first slab and low-tension industries whose consumption is beyond 500 units lose the benefit of the first 500 units for the energy charges.

"Along with the above non- telescopic approach for categories of consumers where slab-wise tariff is applicable, the power department proposed to meet their partial revenue gap through a tariff hike, and the remaining through budgetary support," the department stated.

The department has computed a revenue gap of Rs 242.68 crore for the financial year 2020-2021.

There was no power tariff hike proposed by the department for the financial year 2019-2020, where the department informed JERC that it would meet the revenue gap of Rs 308 crore through the state government’s budgetary support. JERC had highlighted the department’s “over-reliance” on budgetary support at the time.

Title: Graduate social science teachers seek ‘fair play’ in PG promotions
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: Graduate social science teachers from government and government-aided schools, who teach for students up to Class X, say those of them who have studied both UG and PG in history or geography, have been losing out PG promotions to those teachers who have done cross majors.

They said as PG courses in history and geography do not insist that candidates should be from social science backgrounds, teachers who have completed UG in other subjects such as language or science do PG in social sciences. It is to these candidates that those who have done purely social sciences have been losing out, they said.

Graduate social science teachers said about 3,000 of them have been affected due to this across the state.

K P Sekar, a graduate social science teacher at a government-aide school from the district, said they have not been getting proper promotions for around 4 to 5 years now. “Graduate social science teachers have not been getting proper promotions. Cross major people are eating away into our opportunities,” he said and added that the issue was also represented in the court.

T Arulanandam, a representative of the Tamil Nadu High and Higher Secondary School Graduate Teachers Association, said the state should fix a ratio for PG promotions in social science teachers. “There should be a ratio of say, 1:1, meaning if there are 50 PG promotion posts for social sciences, the state should give opportunity for 25 pure social science graduates and equal number of cross majors, so that there would be fair play,” he said.

Graduate social science teachers also said at present they have only five classes per week for Class X. But the new syllabus had 27 chapters across history, geography, civics and economics. They said this calls for more hours and sought seven social science hours per week.

The association members had represented these issues to the commissioner of school education recently.

Title: Manuu launches new web portal
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Hyderabad : The Instructional Media Centre (IMC) of The Maulana Azad National Urdu University ( Manuu ) has developed a new web portal to present the Centre’s activities in well-structured manner. The web site will improve its online presence through intuitively designed interfaces.

The website was launched by Dr. Mohammad Aslam Parvaiz, vice chancellor, Mannu, at the preview theatre at IMC.

“The screen is equally important as pen in this new age. IMC has potential and strong infrastructure to disseminate knowledge to the world through screen,” Dr Aslam Parvaiz said.

Rizwan Ahmad, director, IMC said that the new website is a welcome addition in this era of internet and added that an online presence was imperative to establish a global reach.

“This website will open a new window to the world and anybody from any corner of the globe can connect to us through this website. It will add a new vision in terms of dissemination of knowledge and Urdu culture," Ahmad said, adding that he hope the IMC would help generate revenue for Manuu in future,

Ayub Khan, pro vice-chancellor, S. M. Rahmatullah, registrar, M. G. Gunasekaran, finance officer, deans and faculty were present at the ceremony. Omar Azmi was credited with playing an important role in designing and developing the portal.

Title: West Bengal: Two youths leave for picnic, their bodies found by tracks
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The tracks near Lake Town, where the bodies were found

KOLKATA: Two drivers of small goods carriers were found dead on two sides of the railway tracks near their homes at Gazidanga bustee near Lake Town on Wednesday morning. Police found grievous injuries on Sajal Paswan and Swapan Karmakar’s heads and legs.

The two 23-year-olds reportedly went on a picnic on New Year’s Eve organised by a local club. A witness said the two hurried out after one of them got a call in the middle of the night. They did not return and their bodies were found the next morning, police said. Locals said their mobiles were buried nearby. “He was our only bread-earner,” said Anita Paswan, Sajal’s mother. Swapan’s sister, Dipa Sarkar, said, “The picnic was organised by their drivers’ association. At the picnic, they had a brawl with some youths from Chingriahata.”

A case has been started by the Dum Dum GRP. “We have sent the body for post-mortem. It will show whether it was a murder or an accident,” said an officer.

Title: New Year celebrations: Hyderabad tops in drunk driving cases, over 3,000 booked in Telangana
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The DCP added that those caught for drunk driving might face a penalty of up to Rs 10,000 or imprisonment alon... Read More

HYDERABAD: As police fanned out across the state with breath analysers, 3,158 drunk driving cases were booked in Telangana on the intervening night of December 31 and January 1. Madhapur police station in the IT corridor logged maximum number of drunk driving cases (192) in the state. Only two women were booked for drunk driving in the state and both were caught in Cyberabad limits.

Among the three commissionerates, maximum drunk driving cases were booked in Hyderabad (980), followed by Cyberabad (868) and Rachakonda (281), taking the total to 2,129. Last year, 2,091 were booked in the three commissionerates.

Though no fatal accidents were reported, two people suffered injuries as their bike skid due to rash driving in Raidurgam at around 2am on Wednesday. “The rider, who was visibly drunk, fell unconscious. We could not conduct breath analyser test, but pillion rider’s BAC level was almost 300mg/100ml,” said Madhapur traffic inspector, Rajagopal Reddy.

“Though people were requested not to resort to drunk driving, it is disappointing to see that highly-educated and employees of reputed organisations were found violating the traffic rule,” said M Vijay Kumar, DCP (Traffic) Cyberabad.

The DCP added that those caught for drunk driving might face a penalty of up to Rs 10,000 or imprisonment along with community service as punishment.

About 71 people were caught with Blood Alcohol Content (BAC) level above 300mg/100ml. Police also caught nine minors for drunk driving across the state, of which four were caught in Cyberabad. The maximum number of people (1,039) caught for drunk driving were found to be in the age group of 18 to 25 years. Police also caught nine senior citizens for drunk driving.

Title: Anti-CAA protests hit power loom units
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Erode: The owners of power loom units across the district have shut down their business since Monday as they were not able to send cloth material for dyeing process to Surat, Ahmedabad, Faizabad and Jaipur due to ongoing protests and violence against CAA and NRC in north India.

The owners have decided to keep the units shut for a few weeks until normalcy resumes in north India.

“Due to continuous protests and violence in north India, we could not send our cloth materials for dyeing. This has resulted in piling up of huge stock of cloth materials in power loom units across the district,” spokesperson of Erode district power loom owners association (EPOA) B Kandavel told TOI.

More than 60,000 power looms are functioning in Chithode, Lakkapuram, Modakkuruchi, Chennimalai, Vellode in Erode district. Nearly 50 lakh metres of cloth materials are produced by these looms every day. More than 20,000 weavers are employed directly in these units while thousands get jobs indirectly.

Dyeing units in Surat, Ahmedabad, Faizabad and Jaipur charge less for dyeing process when compared with units in Namakkal, Erode and surrounding districts.

“We get Rs 30 profit per metre if we send our cloths to these north Indian cities for dyeing after transportation and loading and unloading expenses,” Kandavel said.

Four weeks ago, the power loom unit owners had sent 16 lakh metres of cloth materials to these cities for dyeing process. “We have not received information about the status of 7 lakh metres of materials. We don’t know whether the material is safe or damaged in the violence,” Kandavel said.

Fearing over this, the owners have started to halt their business to avoid loss.

Sarath Yadav of Aditya Dyeing and Printing Mills Private Limited, Surat in Gujarat, told TOI that the entire dyeing units in Surat were closed for the last three weeks following continuous protests over CAA and NRC. “We could not carry out dyeing process due to the fear that protesters may damage the fabrics,” he said. “I don’t know when the situation would improve,” he added.

Meanwhile, the viscose rayon yarn manufacturers have reduced the yarn rate to avoid stocks in their units.

Secretary of Chithode Power Loom Owners Association (CPOA) K Balasubramani said viscose rayon yarn was sold for Rs 220/kg about a month ago. “It is available for Rs145/kg this week,” he said. Due to sudden drop in the yarn price, the power loom owners are struggling to fix price for their produces.

It will take at least 15 days to get the finished product. If a power loom owner bought one kilo of yarn for Rs 220, he will sell the finished product from that rate for profit. When the yarn rate is being reduced, the cloth buyers will expect the loom owner to sell their produce for cheaper rate instead of higher price.

“We are trying our best to avoid huge loss as every power loom owner will be facing at least Rs 400 loss per day per power loom machine,” Balasubramani added.

Usually, all the power loom units will be busy especially during Diwali and Pongal festivals. But, this year it was not so. “About 90% of the units stopped their production since Monday,” Balasubramani said, adding that remaining 10% of units will be closed in a couple of days as they have Tamil Nadu government’s free dhotis and sari orders.

The shutting down of power loom units have affected thousands of weavers as they have not got their wages for the past two weeks. “We will be paid maximum of Rs 550 per day. But, the unit owners are now ready to pay only Rs 250 as wage, citing their production loss,” A T Kumaresan, a weaver from Lakkapuram, said.

The weavers have been asked not to come to work till they were called for. “Many of our owners have asked us to look for some other jobs,” Kumaresan said, adding that the government should take some step to save the weavers and their families at the earliest.

Title: Party smells scam in naphtha sale
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: Congress on Wednesday alleged that Mormugao Port Trust ( MPT ) officials and urban development minister Milind Naik had colluded to sell 2,400 tonnes of contaminated naphtha to Mumbai-based United Futuristic Trade Impex (UFTI) Pvt Ltd at a price lower than the value of the consignment. United Futuristic purchased the chemical for Rs 36 lakh, the base price set at the auction conducted by MSTC limited (formerly known as Metal Scrap Trade Corporation Limited). State Congress vice-president Sankalp Amonkar called for an investigation into the auction process. “Naphtha worth Rs 15 crore was sold for Rs 36 lakh and this is for selfish interests,” he said, adding that the naphtha aboard Nu Shi Nalini was pure and not contaminated. A letter dated October 25 issued by the office of the commissioner of customs clearly states contaminated naphtha while giving permission for removal of the cargo from Nu-Shi Nalini.

Title: 16 bikes recovered from auto-lifter gang in Roorkee
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Roorkee: Roorkee Police on Wednesday arrested two members of a local auto-lifter gang and recovered 16 stolen motorcycles from them.

According to Gangnahar Police, a team led by sub-inspector Nitesh Sharma was patrolling on Tuesday night when it came across two motorcycles approaching the Saliyar check post in Roorkee. When the bikes were stopped, the pillion rider on one of the two-wheelers got off and fled.

In-charge of Gangnahar police station Rajesh Sah said, “The rest of the men on the bikes failed to show their documents. We brought them to the police station, where they confessed to being auto lifters.” The criminals are masons by profession and have been stealing bike for the last one year, said police. “The accused used to target ‘Splendor’ model of Hero bikes, as the locks of these are easy to break. Out of the 16 stolen bikes (that were recovered), 15 are of the Hero company,” said Sah.

Title: Will ban on single-use plastic items end up being a farce?
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Merchants were seen using banned plastic carry bags on Wednesday

KOCHI: On paper, single-use plastic has been banned from January 1. But on the ground, shopkeepers across the city sold items in plastic carry bags, all below 50 microns, on the first day. And buyers had no reluctance in carrying these plastic bags.

This is mainly because Kochi corporation is yet to take stringent action to ensure proper enforcement of the ban . “We had given strict instructions to the corporation officials to take stringent action against those selling plastic carry bags below 50 microns. We had instructed the corporation secretary to delegate the powers to slap fine on the violators a week ago. Still, the order delegating the powers of the secretary, to slap fine on the offenders, to the health inspectors is yet to be issued,” said corporation health standing committee chairperson Prathibha Anzari. Had the powers been delegated to the health inspectors, they would be able to complete the procedures during the drive against banned plastic. Once a person is caught red-handed, a health inspector can slap fine on him or her immediately. Otherwise, the order to slap fine should be signed by the top official who are stationed in the corporation office. This will cause a delay of at least a week to issue notice to the offender.

According to corporation officials, the draft of the order delegating secretary’s powers to fine the offenders is ready. “We will be issuing the final order on Friday. The order will be sent as WhatsApp message to all the health inspectors,” an official with the corporation said. “The drive against banned plastic objects will soon be intensified,” the official said. The corporation is planning to deploy three officials in each of the 21 circles of the local body to conduct checks.

The corporation had plans to conduct roadshows and walkathon for creating awareness among the public regarding the ban. “Health standing committee had decided to conduct roadshows. Though we requested mayor Soumini Jain to take measures to conduct the roadshow, she insisted that such programmes can be organized only after getting the approval of the council. But, the mayor hasn’t convened council meeting after December 13,” Anzari said. “Similarly, the committee had recommended the conduct of a walkathon. But the mayor said the local body would be organizing a marathon for creating awareness on the ban,” she said. The mayor and corporation secretary Anu R S were not available for comment.

Some of the textile shops in the city have started giving cotton bags to customers. “For the past six months on, we have been giving cotton bags to our customers. So, we don’t have any issue due to the ban,” an employee with a textile shop on MG Road said. At the same time, many other shops are yet to switch over to cloth bags. “All our shops in Tamil Nadu are using cotton bags. We would switch over to cotton bags if the situation warrants so. Now, we give reusable plastic bags to our customers,” said a staff of another textile shop. Banned plastic carry bags and other items are being used by grocery shops, vegetable shops, bakery shops, etc. Plates with wrapper of plastic sheets on them are used by wayside eateries to serve food.

Title: At 502 on Swachh Survekshan, Hyderabad has steep ladder to climb ahead of final list
Content:
The highest ranked city from Telangana in the overall list is Boduppal (341) in Medchal district, followed by ... Read More

HYDERABAD: The city ranked a not-so-impressive 502 in the Swachh Survekshan League 2020 (SS League 2020-Quarter 1) from a total of 3,971 municipalities across the country. However, this is not the final ranking.A total of 25% weightage of the quarterly assessments will be included in the annual survey scheduled to commence from January 4 and end on January 31, 2020. SS League 2020 is being conducted in three quarters —April-June, July-September and October-December 2019. The city was ranked was based on the first quarter.The highest ranked city from Telangana in the overall list is Boduppal (341) in Medchal district, followed by Sircilla in Karimnagar (362).Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MoHUA), government of India introduced the league with the objective of sustaining the on-ground performance of cities along with continuous monitoring of service level performance pertaining to sanitation.The ranks were rolled out on Monday based on the documents uploaded. Documents related to sanitation activities including door-to-door collection, source segregation, sweeping of residential, public and commercial areas (twice a day), litter bins at every 50 to 100 metres in all commercial and public places and on-site composting were uploaded.Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) also uploaded the penalties imposed on people who were littering the city and found using banned plastic bags (below 50 microns thickness).Unlike earlier, where cities were assessed for 5,000 marks, this year the cities will be assessed for 6,000 marks. Citizen’s feedback, direct observation, service level progress and certification are the four components which carry 1,500 marks. As a part of Citizen’s feedback, GOI officials will randomly call citizens on their mobile or they will directly ask questions related to sanitation. As a part of direct observation, GOI officials shall observe ground reality to rate the city. The marks bagged in the service level progress component is based on documents uploaded by GHMC pertaining to sanitation activities taken by the corporation.

Title: Woman claims to be daughter of famous singer
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: A 45-year-old woman residing in the city has made a claim that she is the daughter of famous Bollywood singer Anuradha Paudwal. The woman, Karmala Modex , also told the reporters here on Wednesday that she has filed a petition before the District Family Court here to legally establish this fact.She has also sought claim of a share of her ancestral property she was entitled to get and also a compensation of Rs 50 crore for the actions of her biological parents that cost her a better childhood, teenage and youth.Addressing the news conference, Karmala said her biological parents Anuradha and Arun Paudwal got married in the year 1969 and Karmala was born in 1974.Her parents gave her up to her foster parents Ponnachan and Agnes as the singer’s busy schedule made it difficult for them to find time to raise her. Ponnachan and Agnes were family friends of Anuradha’s family.Karmala’s advocate M Anil Prasad who accompanied her to the Press Club on Wednesday said a legal notice has been sent to Anuradha Paudwal to attend a hearing of the case on January 27 along with her children Aditya Paudwal and Kavita Paudwal.“I was raised as one of the four children of Ponnachan and Agnes,’’ Karmala said, adding that Ponnachan revealed the truth about her life three years ago in his death bed. Though she tried to reach out to the singer, she was denied permission to meet her every time.Karmala said since Ponnachan and Agnes had difficulty in raising four children, she could only pursue her education till Class X.The court will take up her case for hearing on January 27.Despite several attempts, TOI’s efforts to reach the singer on phone did not materialize.In Video: Woman claims to be singer Anuradha Paudwal's daughter, seeks share in ancestral property

Title: IPS reshuffle in Bihar, Upendra Sharma new Patna SSP
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In a major reshuffle on the first day of the year, the state government on Wednesday transferred 20 IPS officers, including Patna SSP and SPs of four other districts.

ADG (railways) Amit Kumar will be ADG (law and order) while East Champaran SP Upendra Sharma has replaced Garima Malik as Patna SSP. Garima has been promoted to the rank of DIG and posted in CID.

IG (Mithila range) Pankaj Kumar Darad has been appointed as ADG (railways) in Patna after his promotion. IG (CID) Ajitabh Kumar will replace Darad. IG (operation) Sushil M Khopde, after promotion, has been made ADG (operation) after upgrading the post. He would also hold the additional charge of ADG, anti-terrorism squad (ATS), a post also upgraded.

IG (Magadh range) Paras Nath will be IG (budget, appeal and welfare) in Patna with additional charge of IG, Bihar Military Police (BMP).

IG (prohibition) Ratan Sanjay Katiyar has been shifted to weaker section in CID. He was replaced by Amrit Raj, who will also hold additional charge of IG, special vigilance unit (SVU) in place of Katiyar.

DIG (Shahabad range) Rakesh Rathi has been made IG, Magadh range. He has been replaced by P Kannan, who was earlier posted as DIG (BMP).

DIG (eastern range) Vikash Vaibhav has been made DIG (ATS) in Patna. He was replaced by Sujeet Kumar, who was promoted to the rank of DIG. Kumar was SP (railways) in Patna.

CID SP (weaker section and women cell) A Ransingh Sahu has been made DIG (wireless and technical services) after promotion.

State Crime Records Bureau (SCRB) SP Siddharth Mohan Jain has been posted as DIG (administration) after promotion. He would also hold additional charge of DIG (BMP).

Vigilance investigation bureau SP S Premlatha will be DIG in Lokayukta office after promotion.

Siwan SP Naveen Chandra Jha has been shifted to East Champaran. City SP (west) Abhinav Kumar replaced Jha in Siwan.

Munger SP Gaurav Mangla has been shifted to Vaishali. He replaced J Jalaraddi who has been appointed at Patna rail SP.

Barh SDPO Lipi Singh replaced Mangla in Munger. Danapur SDPO Ashok Mishra has been made City SP (west) of Patna.

Title: Chennai: Metro rail plans 20-storey building above Wimco Nagar elevated depot
Content: Chennai Metro Rail Limited is planning to build a 20-storey structure above the elevated depot cum station ... Read More CHENNAI: Picture this. It is 2030 and an elevator takes the visitor to a sea-view apartment on the 23rd floor at Wimco Nagar near Thiruvottiyur. The same elevator will bring the visitor to level five where she can enter the platform and board a metro train to airport.In a bid to integrate real estate and transport and generate non-ticketing revenue, Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) is planning to build a 20-storey structure above the elevated depot cum station at Wimco Nagar, now a calm locality near Thiruvottiyur and 600m away from the beach. Besides the tower, there will be a four-level parking space below the stabling lines. The depot is likely to be ready by December 2020.“It could either be a residential or an office space depending on the demand after the extension line is opened and the area develops. But it’s going to be like a satellite city. We don’t have a design for the structure yet, but we are laying the foundation for the structure now for future development,” a metro rail official said. “Right now, Koyembedu depot can handle all our 52 trains. We will need this second depot only when the trains get older and require frequent maintenance,” the official said.CMRL plans to build the high rise above the elevated depot as the need arises to generate additional revenue. Similar structures are planned in the elevated depots to come up at Madhavaram and Poonamallee as part of the 118.9km three-corridor phase-2.Wimco Nagar depot is part of the phase-1 extension line from Washermenpet to Wimco Nagar with nine stations. It is likely to open in mid-2020. Since, it is an extension of the phase-1 corridor Washermenpet to Airport via Anna Salai, commuters could travel from Wimco Nagar all the way up to airport in one go without a break in journey.“People think it’s far away and don’t like settling in these localities because of the lack of access through a proper transport system. With metro, we are going to give a comfortable and a faster access. We are sure the area will develop rapidly,” an official said.The elevated depot, with 16 lines and spread over 15,500sqm is taking shape at a height of 12m. It rests on 1,161 foundation pile columns built underground and connected with a 1.8-metre-thick concrete raft above which 324 columns of varying thickness have been constructed. Provisions have been made in these columns to build four level car parking space below the depot.“It was a challenge building the foundation as the water table was as high as 2m. We had to drain it out,” an official at the construction site said. “The foundation can hold a 60m tall structure, which is about 15 to 20 floors. We are also constructing other facilities that can be used in the future when the high-rise is built,” said an official.At the depot level, there will be a small station, training facility and other amenities for the depot staff and train operators. The station, which is separate from the Wimco Nagar elevated station less than a kilometre away, could also be used by the occupants in the property developed in the future.The 16 lines at the depot, including one line for the station, are linked to the mainline proceeding towards Wimco Nagar elevated station through a 600m link corridor. A 7.5m wide internal road around the depot, storm water drains and a water tank with a capacity of six lakh litres will also be built. Another 10,000sqm area near the depot will be used to build amenities such as parking space depending on the requirement. This apart, a 1055sqm auto coach washing plant will have three-levels for property development.“We will require funds to develop these facilities. May be in the future, we will construct them on a PPP-mode as the demand goes up. We will generate revenue in the form of rents,” an official said.

Title: Absence of specialist docs plagues Indira Gandhi hospital
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bhopal: The Supreme Court Monitoring Committee, set up by the apex court to keep a watch on medical facilities being provided to survivors of the 1984 Bhopal Gas Disaster, while referring to its visit to Indira Gandhi Women and Children Hospital on Sultania Road, presented a report before the Madhya Pradesh high court on December 18, 2019.

The monitoring committee said, “11 posts of medical officers and six posts of specialists, including that of radiologist, pathologist, medical and surgical specialists and blood bank officers were recommended to be filled up”. It was also recommended that posts as sanctioned should be filled up by regular channel.

It was not only a large number of vacancies of medical officers and specialists that the monitoring committee took note of, but also the fact that beds and bed sheets were also not available for indoor patients in the hospital.

The monitoring committee further recommended that the indoor patient department (IPD) be furnished by providing necessary cots/beds and the repair of damaged and useless cots/beds should be undertaken on an urgent basis. It also stated that lockers, benches and sufficient number of bed sheets be also provided.

The committee also recommended that a separate medicine distribution counter for specially-abled and senior citizens should also be opened in the hospital premises.

Following a visit to Jawaharlal Nehru Hospital, which is the first gas relief hospital in Bhopal, the monitoring committee once again underlined the need to urgently fill up the posts of specialists/ medical officers and pointed out that if the gas relief department adopted the service rules of public health and family welfare in letter and spirit, it could be done with ease.

“Service rules of the public health and family welfare department have been adopted by the department of gas relief and rehabilitation. They should be implemented in letter and spirit and necessary steps for filling up the vacant posts of doctors and staff by regular channel should be taken up with urgency”, said the committee headed by retired high court judge Justice V K Agrawal.

The monitoring committee further recommended that the posts in the hospital scrapped by the gas relief department should also be restored.

The committee also recommended bio-metric attendance of doctors and stated that staff should ensure action is taken for non-compliance.

The monitoring committee also took note that C-arm table, digital X-ray and ultra-sonography machines were not available and recommended that they should be made available to the hospital opened as far back as 1985 for medical care of gas disaster survivors.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Village puts off celebration after local hero’s death
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Akesh’s father (left) and relatives. Akesh (inset).

CHENNAI: As the world ushered in the new year with revelry, Kondanchery village in Tiruvallur district , 50km from Chennai, silently saluted the courage of a local hero who died on Christmas night trying to save a woman from her abductors.

T Akesh, who died in a hospital on December 27, two days after being run over by an autorikshaw in which the woman was abducted. The 22-year old was with his five friends at New Colony when they heard the cries of a woman in a passing auto. Even as they took off on their motorbikes, the woman jumped out of the autorikshaw. Akesh and another friend continued to chase the autorickshaw. After a couple of kilometers, when Akesh tried to block the way of the autorickshaw, the vehicle knocked him off a causeway . Akesh had suffered head injuries.

Kodanchery villagers had only good things to talk about Akesh, “the youth with no vices”. He worked as a driver and took care of his parents. The villagers did not allow any vehicle on Kondanchery Road on his funeral day. “This village has never come together like this for anyone. Everything — Christmas, New year, local body elections — took a backseat. Nothing mattered to us for the past few days,” said N Mohan, a neighbour.

Akesh lived in one of the quarters occupied by scheduled castes who lived in a cluster within the village. But people across castes poured into the hospital when Akesh was undergoing treatment and offered financial and emotional support to his parents.

The youngest of three siblings, Akesh dropped out after Class X to support his parents Thiyagaraj and Padmavathi who are farm labourers. He took up a job as a helper in a machinery company and later became a driver there.

His employer, E D Munuswaamy said the relationship they shared was more than professional. “I treated him like my son. His integrity at a young age surprised me. We retained him on our payroll even when we had to shut down our company for a brief period,” Munuswaamy said.

For the first time in several years, Christmas and New Year celebration at the TELC Church in Kondanchery were low-key affairs. In the village, there was no drunk revelry, no clashes.

Title: Anti-CAA protest violence: Rs 2 cr collected to help victims’ families
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Containing the fire: File picture of anti CAA protests in Mangaluru recently

Mangaluru: Two weeks after the violence that killed two people and resulted in several others sustaining injuries during anti CAA/NRC protests in Mangaluru, associations and individuals have collected more than Rs 2 crore to help the victims ’ families .

Highly placed sources from the police department told TOI that funds were collected through various channels like bank transfers and others, to give compensation to the victims’ families a few days after the violence.

The collection of funds increased after chief minister B S Yediyurappa withdrew ex-gratia of Rs 10 lakh each from the the victims’ families. In the December 19 violence, Nauseen Kudroli, 49, and Jaleel Bengre, 23, were killed in police firing.

A dozen people were injured in the violence, and some of them are still recuperating in the hospital.

“As per our observation, more than Rs 2 crore has been collected to help victims. The people who have taken the lead in making the donations have decided that out of total amount collected, Rs 25 lakh each will go to Nauseen and Jaleel’s families and the rest will be distributed among the injured . We are not aware when it will be distributed to them,” said a senior police officer, on condition of anonymity.

Another source said the victims families, whose breadwinners were killed, had raised objections when fund raising associations decided to hand over money to injured victims. However, they were convinced about the same after intervention of community leaders. So far, two families, whose members have been killed, were given compensation by former chief ministers H D Kumaraswamy and Siddaramaiah.

A few days ago, a Trinamool Congress delegation from West Bengal announced compensation of Rs 5 lakh each to the families.

When contacted, B A Mohiuddeen Bava, who is also one among many actively involved in collection of funds, refused to divulge of total amount collected and said: “It is not the right time rto eveal about the total amount of funds collected. Even if we do, there is uncertainty that more funds will not come in. We are trying to help the shooting victims’ families and the injured, who are facing financial difficulties due to the recent violence.”

Title: Man accused of killing minor breaks leg fleeing from police
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: The 24-year-old man accused of killing a three-year-old girl at Karattumedu here last May suffered a fracture in the right leg when he attempted to flee from police on Tuesday evening.

The Saravanampatti police had taken Tamil of Kovilpalayam under custody after he surrendered at the office of the village administrative officer (VAO) at Karattumedu on Tuesday morning.

After conducting inquiries, police took him to the Karattumedu Government Elementary School, where the girl was allegedly murdered. “He tried to escape and jumped over the compound wall of the school, only to injure himself,” a police officer said.

Tamil is undergoing treatment in the prison ward of the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH).

The body of Devasree, daughter of P Rubini and Paulraj of Velliankadu near Karamadai, was recovered from near a temple at Karattumedu on May 26 after the mother filed a missing complaint. Postmortem revealed that she was poisoned to death. The Saravanampatti police registered a case under Section 302 (murder) of Indian Penal Code (IPC) and launched an investigation.

During the inquiry, it was revealed that Rubini had separated from Paulraj and was in a relationship with Tamil, who was working as a location manager for Tamil movies. “Fearing that the child may cause hindrance to their relationship, they decided to kill her. The duo fed the girl biscuits laced with poison and dumped her body near the temple,” the officer added.

After arresting Rubini on May 27, police were on the lookout for Tamil. A special police team had visited Karnataka several times after receiving information that he was hiding there.

Title: New Year begins on a bright note for Attapur kids
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Hyderabad: The New Year began on a good note for the children of Attapur slum as they were treated to new clothes by a city-based NGO. In addition to the 200 pairs of clothes that were distributed among the kids, over 40 children was adjoining slums were treated to an elaborate buffet.

Organized by Youngistaan Foundation, the lunch was followed by cultural activities and interactive sessions with 15 volunteers.

Ramesh from Attapur who received new clothes said, “I didn’t buy any clothes this year and wanted a few pairs. I am glad someone got me these clothes.”

K Rani who was present at the lunch said, “I was so happy dancing with all the volunteers here. This is the first time I ate so much food.

Arun Daniel Yellamaty, founder of the NGO said, “The greatest happiness is when we see others happy and smile. It’s always good to start your year by giving to people in need. This is our routine every year on December 31 and January.1 Let us be a giving society and look for opportunities to give back to the community.”

The organization also runs programs on food and nutrition, menstrual hygiene management, child sexual abuse.

Title: When Tomorrow Comes ...
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Standing from left: Sarthak Sarwate, Shubhangi Kumari, Kevin Tudu, Sweekriti Shahi, Samuel Tayde, Krittika Upp... Read More

Nagpur: For a year riddled with legal battles over temple and mosque to crimes against women, 2019 was a mixed bag that rounded off with a fairly mellowed down Christmas celebration. Asked to rate the same, Krittika Uppal of Centre Point School felt it was a good one for her personally and gave it a grand 9 out of 10, but the class 6 student was disturbed how the country suffered on account of the protests that arose from the CAA and NRC amendments. Samuel Tayde of Kids World School seconded and called the ‘fights’ that happened uncalled for and wished people would have talked to each other before.

For Kevin Tudu of Centre Point School, personally the year fared at a decent 8 and he also praised the government for bringing in the Metro and for the country he rated it a good 9. Kids World’s Sweekriti Shahi was disheartened by how since August, social and communal issues plagued the country, starting from Kashmir to the CAA-NRC protests that even saw many deaths.

Expecting a turn for the better, Shubhangi Kumari of Delhi Public School, Kamptee, wanted people to resolve their fights and live in harmony. As for a personal aspiration, the class 7 student wished she would play less and study more, something she realized is a little difficult to achieve.

Chinmayee Vidhale of Jain International School agreed and took it a notch higher as the youngster opined that to err is human and even though we wish to do right for others and not fight with them, it is difficult since people cannot function as always is expected of a utopian society. Asked the reason for the violence that raged across the country, Krittika said it was because people have lost the patience nowadays to really listen to each other about the issues they debate upon.

The discussion took a more serious turn when the panellists believed that the city and the society at a larger level is not taking enough responsibility to preserve nature and it is resulting in climate changes and causing irreversible damage. Sareena Jiwani of Jain International School wished for people to adhere to rules when it comes to waste management and segregation so that it makes it easier for NMC to take it up from there. Pollution was also a serious cause for concern as Chinmayee believed there should be strict rules for those who violate public spaces for smoking.

Uses of modern gadgets have been a concerning factor for most parents and the panellists too echoed the same. Calvin Wilfred, who was among the few youngsters present to have a personal mobile phone, admitted to being pulled up for using it too often. He, however, believed that it is a necessity today and its restricted use should help.

Anmol Bansal of Centre Point School agreed and said earlier, phones were only used for contacting in case of emergency but now, they have become a distraction with so many applications and curious minds are not shying away from using them for entertainment which divides their concentration. Sarthak Sarwate of Delhi Public School, Kamptee, though wished for strict intelligence against hackers and wanted cyber crimes to be checked.

Personal achievements scored big ground for the panellists as they listed quite a few efforts they undertook that earned them a pat on the back. Shubham Kumar of Delhi Public School won a trophy for a mathematics quiz and Sareena too was praised for scoring good marks in the tests. Shubhangi too won gold for participating in the Mathematics Olympiad. The youngster frequently sits for the exam and has previously won gold and bronze medals.

The discussion then veered towards their school curriculum and faculty teaching styles. Sareena said that she finds mathematics all right, but “the problems are too hard” for her. Shubhangi enjoys participating in class, answering her teachers’ questions and writing them on the blackboard too.

A part of the panel, however, yearned for a more casual and free-flowing relationship with the teachers. “While some teachers are friendly, there are others who just teach their subjects and leave,” said Calvin.

Chinmayee felt that some of the teachers did not stay true to their words in class. “They encourage us to get our doubts clarified during lectures, but when we do ask them something, they are quick to point out that they just explained that concept a while back,” she said.

For many, the issue of “not practising what they preach” extended to their parents as well. “My mother asks me to be covered from head to toe, and always wear thick jackets in winters, but she herself just dons a thin shawl in the chill,” Krittika complained. “They always promise to take us for outings, but do not fulfil them very often,” lamented Anmol.

The panel had extremely diverse career aspirations — ranging from politics to science research — but for most of them, being successful boiled down to working hard and staying grounded.

Then there were the ones whose idea of success was about comforting the afflicted. “With so many people dying of hunger in India every year, I want to open a shelter for the homeless and offer free food to them,” said Sweekriti. Shubhangi, who wants to be a doctor, wanted to devote one day a week for providing free health care to all those who walk into her clinic, especially those who cannot afford to get treated elsewhere.

Being a good human being also meant different things to different panellists, but there was broad consensus on having empathy for those in pain and saying no to discrimination . When asked to choose between being successful and a good human being, the panel unanimously picked the latter. Shubhangi summed up everyone’s sentiments by saying, “What is the point of achieving all that success if one is not a good human being?”

To bring about equality, Sareena said it is important to “share your thoughts and education with others”. For Krittika, it all starts with treating everyone equally, while Sweekriti wanted people to “not be judged for being rich or poor, but for their innate qualities”.

To ensure more peace in India, Samuel wanted people to try and cultivate “warm relationships with everyone”. Small actions could make a big impact, many felt. For instance, if India wins in a sports encounter, Shubhangi said we must not insult the losing team.

“Eventually, we are all going to die, so might as well learn to live peacefully and not keep quarrelling all the time,” Anmol signed off.

Title: Anti-CAA protest paralyses Kochi
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The crowd at the MG Road Metro station on Wednesday

KOCHI: The rally carried out by Muslim outfits against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) paralysed the city on Wednesday evening. There was heavy traffic block in the city for almost four to five hours, forcing many of the shops in the city to down shutters by noon in anticipation of the traffic block.

Banerji Road, through which one of the rallies passed to the protest venue at Marine Drive, along Jawaharlal Nehru International Stadium-High Court stretch was fully occupied by the protesters. They were seen walking across the footpaths as well. All the vehicles, including private buses, kept off the road leaving commuters in the lurch. Metro came to the rescue of commuters. The Metro ridership reached more than one lakh at 8pm. All the Metro stations were crowded. In the routes where there are no Metro services, passengers had a tough time.

A KSRTC bus was stuck amidst the crowd for almost an hour, while many had to wait for hours on end to get out of a theatre complex in the city as Banerji Road was fully occupied by the protesters. “We have to go to Vypeen side. So, we have to take a U-turn. But we are unable to move an inch even forward, let along the U-turn. We have been trapped here for more than an hour,” said a passenger on the KSRTC bus.

With motorists taking other roads like MG Road following the blockade on Banerji Road, traffic bottlenecks extended to all across the city centre. Even ambulances got trapped in traffic snarls. With police focusing on the venue at Marine Drive and Shanmugham Road , there was nobody to regulate the traffic on MG Road and Chittoor Road .

Title: New Year celebrations: Hyderabad swings in Rs 210 crore liquor
Content:
A cop conducts a drunk driving check on New Year’s Eve

HYDERABAD: Liquor literally flowed in Hyderabad as tipplers spent a whopping Rs 210 crore on various brands as they bade goodbye to 2019 on Tuesday night and ushered in New Year . The total value of liquor sales in Telangana on December 31 night was around Rs 350 crore, market experts said.Across the state, 1,91,323 cases of beer and 2,11,515 cases of Indian-made foreign liquor were sold on Tuesday night alone. “With Hyderabad alone catering to 60% of the sales, Rs 210 crore worth beer and other liquor brands were lapped up by the guzzlers in the city,” a trader explained.Curiously, the total sales value remained the same when compared to the last year despite the increase in the prices recently. On December 31, 2018, 2,18,007 cases of beer and 2,00,051 cases of IMFL were sold across the state. “There was a slight dip in the number of cases sold when compared to the last year. But, increase in the prices made up for the total sale value remaining intact,” sources in the liquor trade averred.Meanwhile, some liquor shops, in their bid to woo tipplers, came up with innovative ideas to increase sales on December 31 night. For instance, in Mahabubabad, a shop owner announced a lucky draw scheme. Those who made a purchase of above Rs 2,000 was given an opportunity to participate in the lucky draw. The first prize winner would get an LCD TV, second prize winner a smart phone and third prize winner would get silver coins.Many liquor lovers fell for the bait and stood in a long queue to buy liquor.

Title: 6 booked for drunk driving during NYE
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Mangaluru: Six persons were booked for drunk driving on New Year’s Eve on Tuesday night.

Manjunath Shetty, ACP (traffic), said cases this year are considerably less as compared to last year when 16 persons were booked.

Cases booked after 1am

“We witnessed thin crowd across city limits and they dispersed by 12.30am. All the drunk driving cases were booked after 1am. No accidents due to drinking were reported,” he added. The city which witnessed violence a few days ago turned a fortress on Tuesday with hundreds of police keeping tabs on revellers. All the celebrations were stopped at stroke of midnight.

Senior police officials said that celebrations were peaceful and no untoward incidents were reported.

Title: Falling prices of drumstick fail to attract customers
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: When Gowri S, a resident of R S Puram, sends her daughter to buy vegetables for the week, she has only two instructions for her: “Don’t bother buying drumstick. We can buy and eat it next month. And don’t buy more than 2kg of small onions.”

Though drumstick prices have fallen from Rs 400 per kg to Rs 200 per kg, households still find it too expensive.

“Drumstick is mainly used to make a side dish or poriyal served at lunch, it is also used to make a specific ‘kolambu’ or gravy and in sambhar,” said Geetha T, a resident of Meena Estate. “We can do without it. We rather spend that excess money on onions, which is essential,” she added.

Onion and shallot prices, which had shot up to Rs 140 to Rs 180 per kg, have fallen to around Rs 90 per kg, giving households a measure of relief. “Onions are more important because it is there in nearly every dish we prepare,” Geetha said. “You can reduce it but not replace it,” she added.

Onion prices have begun decreasing when imported stocks from Egypt and Turkey began entering the market. Though the public gave them a cold shoulder, some arrivals from Maharashtra have begun helping prices come down. “The onions were a dark pink and a few were too large, so people did not seem to prefer the imported onions and some hoteliers claimed that their gravy colours were changing when those onions were used,” said C Dorairaj of Kovai Pazhamudhir Nilayam. “However, prices of our usual onions have dropped after arrivals have begun from Maharashtra,” he added.

Drumstick, which is usually bought from the Oddanchatram vegetable market had seen its prices increase to Rs 350 per kg in the wholesale market and Rs 400 per kg in the retail market. “The rapid price increase was due to lack of arrivals from north India, which is reeling under a cold wave and a cyclone earlier,” Jothi, a wholesale vegetable trader, said. “Earlier we used to get at least four tonnes of drumstick a day from north Indian states. But now we hardly get one to two tonnes a day. There were even days when we hardly got 50 large sacks a day,” he said.

However, the market has begun receiving drumstick from Gujarat and Andhra Pradesh. “ We have begun receiving drumsticks from Gujarat and Andhra, so prices will further fall to around Rs 100 per kg in a fortnight, but for it to return to Rs 40 per kg, it will happen only in February,” the trasder said.

Title: Students of varsities pledge not to show proof of citizenship
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Scores of students from Osmania University, University of Hyderabad, Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu), English and Foreign Languages University (Eflu), Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS) among others pledged to defend the Constitution at Arts College on Osmania University campus as part of their protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) on Wednesday.

Students who participated in the programme organised under the aegis of Young India National Coordination Committee -- Hyderabad Chapter in the city also resolved to not show any documents to prove their citizenship.

“Today, we took a pledge to defend our Constitution and to not show any documents to prove our citizenship. We will also campaign and convince others in the city to not give any information sought in the name of proving our citizenship,” said Faizan Sarwar, national joint secretary of All India Students Association.

Armed with placards that read ‘Reject CAA, Boycott NRC’, ‘We reject NRC’ and ‘KCR Stop NPR’, students read out the Preamble and the draft resolution created against CAA, NRC and NPR along with students across the country, who also organised mass pledges at various universities.

“We, today on January 1 2020, reiterate our resolve to give ourselves a society that will be free of oppressors and take an oath to not show any document to prove our citizenship and we will observe and propagate complete non-cooperation with anti-constitution and anti-India forces,” read the draft resolution framed by the students.

“We, the people of India, are sovereign as we give ourselves the Constitution. No government elected by us on the basis of this Constitution has the right to turn around and ask the people to prove our citizenship on the basis of a divisive diabolical agenda trampling upon the very core of our Constitution.”

They said that they will be participating in ‘million march’ on January 4 and trade union protest on January 8.

“To make the trade union protests successful, all varsities in the state will remain closed on January 8,” said Janardhan G, state general secretary, Democratic Students’ Union (DSU).

Protesting students were joined by members of 20 organisations and people from different walks of life.

Title: West Bengal: Accidents kill two since New Year’s Eve
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The car and one of the bikes involved in the Vidyasagar Setu accident

KOLKATA: Two persons were killed and two injured in accidents since New Year’s Eve.

Ashique Seikh (22), a resident of Domjur in Howrah, along with his friends Sk Taaz (20) from Bankra and Suraj, was headed for Park Street around 11.40pm on Tuesday. The three were on two bikes, Seikh on one, and Suraj and Taaz on the other. They were on Vidyasagar Setu, when a truck hit a car, which in turn rammed the two bikes. Seikh and Taaz fell on the ground and were taken to SSKM Hospital, where Seikh died. Taaz is fighting for his life.

A few hours later around 4am, a Haridevpur resident, Donald Sebastion (28), was run over by a heavy goods vehicle on JM Avenue. He was admitted to RG Kar Hospital with received multiple injuries but died there. A 65-year-old woman was injured on her right leg when she fell while trying to board a bus on Strand Road near Howrah bridge around 2pm on Wednesday.

Title: Kolkata: Theatre groups slam politics of division, preach harmony and unity
Content:
Jayant Kripalani performs at the theatre fest on Wednesday
