KOLKATA: It’s not just the streets of the city that are reverberating with protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act. The protests are now echoing in the creative corridors too. The city saw a high-profile English theatre festival over the last weekend, where the artists talked about “disgust and exasperation at the slicing or artificial divide” that the amended Act has been alleged of bringing in.It saw some of the city’s best-known names in the circuit speak out against the Centre’s initiative. They said that since the early 19th century the country’s intellectuals have been speaking out against communalism and rabid fundamentalism and the trend continues even today.The three-day fest started on Friday and celebrated the golden jubilee of ‘The Red Curtain’, the oldest surviving amateur theatre group in the city. It was formed in 1969 by undergraduates of Loreto and St Xavier’s colleges. At the fest, a narrative written and read out by theatre scholar and critic Ananda Lal focused on the history of English theatre in the city since 1831 when the first English play, ‘The Persecuted’, was written by a 19-year-old Krishnamohan Banerjee. The play was a reaction to conservative Hindus who had forbidden him and his friends from the Young Bengal Movement from consuming beef roast and had thrown him out of the house.Failing to stage the play despite his best efforts, he converted to Christianity and became a priest. A few years later, Michael Madhusudan Dutt wrote ‘Rizia’ and tried to persuade Keshub Chandra Ganguly, a leading actor in Belgachia Theatre, to get the Rajas of Paikpara and Jyotindramohan Tagore for sponsorship/approval. The play, however, was never staged.“What you see around you is nothing new. Intellectuals have always fought such divisive urges,” Lal said. A book tracing such history — ‘Indian Drama in English : The Beginnings’ — was launched during the course of the festival.The festival saw a solo act by Jayant Kripalani, ‘An Evening with Mr Tagore’. It was based on Tagore’s prose, poetry and philosophy on inclusiveness and plurality against sectarian divisive politics. Incidentally, Kripalani has been walking in almost every anti-CAA/NRC protest rallies in the city. “I hope to do everything in my power to rubbish the new act. I think it negates everything that India stands for,” Kripalani said.Rustom Bharucha, faculty of theatre at JNU, spoke about the necessity of plurality in India. There were pop-up acts from seminal plays — such as Girish Karnad’s Tal-e-Danda, Mahesh Dattani’s The Final Solution and Manjula Padmanabhan’s Hidden Fires — that spoke against communal violence and tyranny by the state. Actors like Dhritiman Chatterjee, Vinay Sharma, Anubha Fatepuria, Nibedita Bhattacharjee, Mira Kakkar and Nupur Ghosh were seen in these plays.

Title: Gas burden gets heavier, LPG rate up by Rs 21 in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The New Year didn’t bring much cheer for homemakers as LPG cylinder price in Hyderabad saw a jump of Rs 21. The rates for a cylinder on the first day of the year were the highest among all the metro cities in the country. A 14.2kg LPG cylinder cost consumers Rs 769 on Wednesday. On December 31, its price was Rs 748.

The commercial cylinder, weighing 19 kg, also served a New Year shocker as its price had gone up to Rs 1,400 from Rs 1,368 — a jump of Rs 32 — in a matter of 24 hours. This cylinder is mostly used in the hotel industry and hostels.

Consumers were upset with the price hike . “As if the high price of onions, tomatoes and potatoes wasn’t enough, we are now forced to shell out more on a cylinder. There is no respite for middle class people,” complained SL Pragati, a housewife from Ameerpet.

Expressing dismay at the increase of Rs 21 on each cylinder, some consumers said running a family with the prices of essential commodities at an all-time high was not a joke. “It is as if we are hit from all sides and the government seems to do nothing about it,” rued M Vanajakshi, a techie from Madhapur .

Market experts said the price of the commercial cylinder in Hyderabad when compared to other metros was also steep. “The rates in the districts will be higher than Hyderabad as the state-run fuel retailers will add the transportation costs also,” an expert explained. The fuel retailers change LPG cylinder price every month based on the international rate.

Hyderabad has an added advantage as the Charlapalli plant is located close to the city. But, consumers in districts like Jangaon, Adilabad and Nizamabad are not so lucky as they will have to bear the transportation costs. “The difference will be more than Rs 7-10 from what is charged in Hyderabad,” said Sai Reddy, a gas dealer.

Gas dealers said though rates had gone up, there was no shortage of gas supply in the city and districts. “Refill cylinders are being delivered within two days once a booking is done,” a gas dealer said.

The dealers acknowledged that Wednesday’s was the highest hike when compared to recent hikes. “The price of a cylinder had touched Rs 1,000 in April-May 2019. In that sense, the latest jump is not beyond the reach of consumers,” a dealer remarked.

Presently, the government ensures delivery of 12 cylinders to each household in a year and the subsidy provided by the government on the quota of 12 cylinders varies from one month to another. “Factors like changes in the average international LPG price and foreign exchange rates determine the subsidy component,” a gas dealer said.

Title: Nine prisoners serving extra jail terms released on New Year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: As a goodwill gesture on new year, the district jail administration on Wednesday released nine prisoners , who were serving extra time as they were not able to pay the penalty imposed on them.

A local businessman and social worker Pravendra Yadav paid the total penalty amount of over Rs 61,000 for their release.

Jail superintendent Shashikant Mishra said, “Most of the prisoners released on Wednesday had committed crimes under the Railways Act (theft of property belonging to the railways) and are first-time offenders. They have promised not to repeat their crimes.” “Despite having completed their jail terms, they were not released as they were not able to pay the penalty imposed on them. With inspiration from senior officials, we regularly approach social workers and philanthropists to help them pay this and avoid extra term,” he added.

According to the prison records, the nine prisoners released on Wednesday are in the age group of 18 to 40 years.

In the past two years as superintendent of the Agra district jail, Mishra has managed to arrange for payment of penalties of over 300 prisoners serving extended jail terms. Last year, he was awarded a commemoration medal by the inspector general (prisons).

Title: Villagers to get entrepreneurship training soon
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: Villagers in five talukas of Goa – Pernem, Quepem, Canacona, Bardez and Bicholim – have been selected under the start-up village entrepreneurship program (SVEP) in Goa, to take up skill-building activities.

“Most of these villagers are farmers who engage in cultivation of crops only during the peak agriculture months. During the other months, they engage in small plantation activities. These activities will be converted into sustainable enterprise, for which we provide them with handholding support,” said Raaj Naik, project manager at the Agnel Institute.

The SVEP scheme which aims to support entrepreneurs in rural areas to set up local enterprises is a sub component of the Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana – National Rural Livelihoods Mission of the Union ministry of rural development.

“The scheme is aimed at the creation of rural entrepreneurs by developing a sustainable model for village entrepreneurship promotion through tools for training and capacity-building in Goa over a span of four years,” Naik said.

“We are preparing a detailed project report to start this scheme. After it is submitted, we will start the activity in these villages. We are likely to launch the scheme in April,” Naik added.

The state district rural development agency is helping the institute identify rural belts and reach out to locals for the programme.

Title: HC notice to Narottam over poll affidavit anomaly
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bhopal/Jabalpur: Madhya Pradesh high court on Monday issued notice to former BJP minister Narottam Mishra while calling for records from the special court set up in Bhopal for trial of state politicians in response to a criminal revision petition filed by former Congress MLA Rajendra Bharti.

Bharti had alleged in a complaint before court of chief judicial magistrate (CJM), Datia that while contesting the 2008 assembly polls, Mishra had concealed information regarding ownership of a vehicle and urged the court to order for registering a criminal case and also a case under Representation of Peoples’ Act.

The case was transferred to special court in Bhopal which dismissed Bharti’s complaint earlier this year. Subsequently, Bharti moved an appeal before the high court.

The petitioner alleged in his petition that on November 4, 2008, when Narottam Mishra filed the affidavit for contesting assembly polls, he owned a vehicle with registration number HRB-37-B-1282, but this information was not provided in the affidavit.

Later, the same vehicle was seized at Jigna police station for violation of Motor Vehicles’ Act on November 27, 2008. On November 28, 2008, Mishra through his counsel had made representation before court for handing over the vehicle to him as he is the registered owner of the said vehicle, alleged the petitioner.

Later, on December 1, 2008 the vehicle was handed over to Mishra by court on surety of Rs 3 lakh, considering him to the registered owner of the vehicle, the petitioner alleged.

But Mishra had said that the vehicle was not in his name, Bharti alleged in the petition.

Title: Involve private hospitals to control swine flu: Telangana High Court
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana High Court has directed the state government to involve private hospitals and diagnostic labs in the state in its fight against swine flu that is likely to spread its tentacles during the winter season.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy said this while hearing two public interest petitions filed by Dr M Karuna and advocate Rapolu Bhaskar, questioning the negligence of the officials of medical and health department, and also the civic authorities in taking steps to control the spread of swine flu, dengue and other diseases.

The bench went through the affidavits filed by the state’s chief secretary SK Joshi and director of public health Dr G Srinivas Rao, both of whom were silent on the aspect of involving private hospitals in both diagnosis and treatment of these viral fevers. The bench sought information from them as to what they have done in this regard by Jan 3.

Advocate general BS Prasad has informed the court that since vaccination meant for swine flu is fraught with certain side effects, people are preferring to consume medicines in the form of tablets and syrups. “Hence, we have kept sufficient stocks of the same at all primary health centres all over the state, and our doctors are ready to deal with any likely spread of swine flu,” the AG said.

“We need permission from National Centre for Disease Control to set up diagnostic labs,” public health director, G Srinivas Rao, said in his affidavit. “We thought of setting up 10 labs in various towns and cities of the state, but as the permission is yet to arrive, we could not set them up so far,” he said.

The bench directed the state to sensitise the district medical and health officers (DMHOs) all over the state and also the existing diagnostic labs about the looming danger of swine flu spreading during the coming winter months.

Title: Filling of explosives to begin tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The IOC has started placing sandbags in four layers above the pipeline passing in front of Holy Faith H2O to e... Read More

KOCHI: The filling of explosives to facilitate the demolition of four illegal apartment complexes at Maradu will begin on Friday. Explosives will be filled up in holes made at Holy Faith H2O from 6am on Friday. The explosives will be transported to the site in an explosive van from the storage facility at Angamaly at 5am.

Explosives will be filled in other buildings that are to be demolished after that. It will take minimum one week to fill up the holes with explosives in each building. More police personnel will be deployed in the area once the filling of explosives starts to check people from encroaching into the building compound.

Meanwhile, the two demolition agencies — Edifice Engineering and Vijay Steels and Explosives — have prepared disaster management plan for each building and submitted it to sub-collector Snehil Kumar Singh. District collector will have to approve the plan.

The plan will be discussed at a meeting on Friday that will be attended by the city police commissioner and others senior officials. Deployment of police personnel on around 200m radius of each building, map of the area and traffic diversion plans will be discussed at the meeting.

Around 600 people, who reside in nearby buildings, will have to be evacuated during the demolition of the four buildings on January 11 and 12. The residents will be lodged in Sacred Heart college at Thevara and Kerala University of Fisheries and Ocean Studies at Panangad.

The residents will be evacuated two hours prior to the demolition. A control room will be set up to monitor the demolition proceedings on the day. Alfa Serene and Holy Faith H2O will be demolished on January 11, and the control room will function from Maradu municipality office that day. On January 12, when Jains Coral Cove and Golden Kayaloram will be razed, the control room will be set up outside 200m radius of the buildings.

Meanwhile, Maradu municipality remitted premium of around Rs 89 lakh to National Insurance company towards the insurance amount of Rs 95 crore. A municipality official said the demolition agencies will repair the cracks developed in nearby structures, before the actual demolition takes place. “If any damage is reported during or after the demolition, it will be covered in the insurance. Municipality paid the amount five days ago,” said the official.

Petroleum and Explosives Safety Organisation (Peso) on Wednesday night gave permit to Vijay Steels and Explosives to undertake explosive works at Alfa Serene, under 25 conditions. Explosives for the demolition of Alfa serene will reach Perumbavoor on Sunday or Monday and the filling up of holes will start by Tuesday.

Action council of residents near Alfa Serene started an indefinite hunger strike on Wednesday seeking protection to their lives and properties. The action council took out a proclamation march, which was inaugurated by retired sub-judge M R Sasi. Local self-government minister A C Moideen has convened a meeting of officials and action council members on Thursday.

Title: ED hit the jackpot in 2019, attached assets worth over Rs 1,000 crore
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

HYDERABAD: From a paltry Rs 50 lakh worth of assets attached in 2018-19, Enforcement Directorate ( ED ), Hyderabad, came a long way in financial year 2019-20, with attachments totalling Rs 1,065 crore involving properties of companies and individuals for money laundering as well as other frauds.

On New Year’s eve, ED attached Rs 51.45 crore in IDBI Bank fraud case in Visakhapatnam relating to issuance of loans for pisciculture farmers. Prime accused Kumar Pappu Singh had acted as an aggregator and obtained loans in the names of 87 marginal farmers. He took Rs 70 crore loans fraudulently from IDBI Bank, an official said. ED found that Singh had utilised the money for personal investments.

In scams involving entities such as Musaddilal, Heera Group, Future Maker Life Care (FMLC), eBIZ.com and Q City, the enforcement agency attached close to Rs 200 crore worth properties. Sources said cases of attachment of properties under Prevention of Money Laundering Act saw a spurt after the change of guard at ED, Hyderabad.

In the Musaddilal scam, seizures pertain to a money laundering case in which group MD Kailash Chand Gupta and his two sons — Nitin Gupta and Nikhil Gupta — along with other accused allegedly created forged documents and fraudulently exchanged over Rs 110 crore demonetised cash soon after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced demonetisation in November 2016.

The accused showed purchases by 5,200 customers within a span of about four hours from 8.30 pm to 12 midnight (soon after the demonetisation was announced). ED confiscated Rs 85 crore worth of properties of the accused.

In the Heera Group scam, accused Nowhera Shaik is alleged to have duped thousands of investors promising high returns from deposits in gold scheme. ED attached Rs 300 crore worth of their properties.

In two cases of multi-level marketing , ED confiscated huge properties. In FMLC pyramid scam Rs 261 crore was attached and in eBIZ.com case Rs 278 crore assets were seized. In FEMA violation case, Rs 86 crore assets of Q City Tech Park were attached in Hyderabad.

In individual bank loan fraud cases, ED attached properties of Ganne Srinivas worth Rs 2.42 crore and in a disproportionate assets case involving a tahsildar Rs 1.08 crore worth properties were attached.

Title: Madras high court stays hiring of temporary teaching staff by Anna university
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court has stayed the process begun by Anna University to hire guest lecturers and visiting fellows for its affiliate colleges across the state on a temporary and hourly basis.

Vacation judge Justice V Parthiban passed the interim order on the plea moved by G Arutperumjyothi – a temporary teaching fellow of the university challenging the recruitment.

According to the petitioner, the registrar of the university issued an advertisement dated December 19, 2019 calling for applications to the posts of guest lecturers and visiting fellows on hourly basis.

“While there are already 518 such temporary faculties employed by the university for its affiliate colleges for several years, the university has called for applications for fresh appointments without regularising the existing temporary staff,” the petitioner said. He said the university engaged faculties on temporary basis with impunity and without any approval in total violation of established principles of law enunciated by the Supreme Court and the high courts.

“Time and again courts have come down heavily upon engagement of faculties on temporary basis without identifying the actual workforce required for teaching. Besides this, there is no category of appointment as teaching fellows in the UGC Regulations, 2010,” he said.

Relying on the AICTE regulations, the petitioner said the rules were very clear that there shall be only three designations in respect of teachers — assistant professors, associate professors and professors. There is no other nomenclature for appointment as teaching fellows/ visiting fellows/guest lecturers.

The petitioner said that only 10% of the teaching staff are employed on regular basis by the university for its constituent colleges. All other teaching faculties are engaged only on temporary basis.

Title: Clean-up time: Secunderabad Cantonment Board hits bottom in Swachh League 2020 ranking
Content:
Residents claim that the SCB’s ranking has been affected due to its failure in collecting garbage, not providi... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: The second largest cantonment of the country, Secunderabad , was ranked as the worst performer among all 62 cantonment boards surveyed in the Centre’s Swachh Survekshan League 2020 (SS League 2020) rankings.The ministry of housing and urban affairs released results of the last two quarters beginning April in New Delhi.The SS League 2020, which monitors cleanliness in cities/cantonment boards, allotted 2,000 marks for each quarter. According to the results, the Secunderabad Cantonment Board ( SCB ) secured 136.83 marks in the first quarter and 10.61 marks in the second quarter, thereby ending in the last spot in both quarters.With 1187.39 marks, the St. Thomas Mount cantonment in Tamil Nadu secured the first spot in the first quarter and Delhi cantonment stood at the top by securing 1368.55 marks in the second quarter. The evaluation was done based on services provided, observation and citizen feedback through outbound phone calls.With a 42-square kilometre area and population of nearly four lakh residents, the SCB is the second largest cantonment in the country. However, it failed to compete with other cantonments which are significantly smaller with predominant army presence.Dehu road in Pune, Nainital, Wellington, Shimla are among those who have emerged among the top 20 cantonments in the country in the SS League 2020.Residents claim that the SCB’s ranking has been affected due to its failure in collecting garbage, not providing adequate public toilets and poor solid waste management.“Even today, many colonies in SCB wards don’t have public bins, forcing people to throw garbage on roads. This garbage is often not picked up by the SCB cleaners. Apart from this, there are insufficient public toilets,” said Sudha Konidela, a resident of Vasavi Nagar Colony.Residents blamed SCB for not making enough efforts in taking up developmental works in the areas under its limits. “For years, the SCB has been crying over shortage of funds. Basic issues related to road repair, water and cleanliness have not been addressed due to shortage of funds. The rankings look poorly on the cantonment,” said Jeetendra Surana, secretary of All Cantonments Citizens Welfare Association.Admitting its inability to perform well in the rankings, the SCB authorities passed the buck to the Centre over its failure in clearing dues. “Since we are yet to receive Rs 550 crore from the Centre, we are unable to meet even basic needs of the residents. We are unable to pay our contractors, sweepers. Therefore, we are falling back in terms of cleanliness,” said J Ramakrishna, SCB vice-president.Ramakrishna said paucity of funds forced the board to seek help. “So far, we were self-sustaining. However, for the first time in the history, we were forced to go for aided board as the gap between residents’ needs and availability of funds is only increasing by the day. The Centre should distribute funds proportionately to enable us to perform our basic civic activities,” said Ramakrishna.The performance of cities in SS League 2020 is crucial to their ranking in Swachh Survekshan 2020 due to the 25% weightage of the quarterly assessment to be included in the annual survey scheduled to commence from January 4 till January 31, 2020.

Title: Sanathnagar was most polluted area of Hyderabad last year
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Residents in Sanathnagar breathed the most polluted air in the city during in 2019, shows data available with the Central Pollution Control Board.Particulate matter 2.5 (PM2.5) levels in the area were the highest in 2019 on December 6 with a recording of 278 ug/m3 representing a 24-hour average. PM2.5 refers to atmospheric particulate matter (PM) that has a diameter of less than 2.5 microns, which is even lesser than pollen.The data was collated from the six Continuous Ambient Air Quality Monitoring Stations in the city.The reading on December 6 fell under the ‘poor’ category, which is between 201 ug/m3 and 300 ug/m3. As per CPCB standards, people with prolonged exposure in the area develop breathing difficulties. On November 6, the station in Sanathnagar recorded its second highest figure of the year of PM2.5 (274 ug/m3).The last two months of the year were the worst for residents, data shows. While there were 12 ‘poor’ days in November, nine were recorded in December. The readings are higher than any other part if the city.Other stations did not record any data falling under the ‘poor’ category through the year. The station at Zoo park recorded a high of 173 ug/m3 on December 18.Unregulated industrial units as well as the high density of population in Sanathnagar are to blame for the pollution levels, say activists and residents.“There are so many small industries and workers, including those involved in activities like welding, who are located in and around Sanathnagar area,” said Rani Pasumarti, a local. The teacher said it is worrying that pollution levels are this high and this would have long-term effect on the health of children.Suresh Reddy , also a local, said, “The proximity to the Mumbai highway may be also be behind the high pollution levels.” He said that even opening one’s windows during peak traffic hours has become difficult because of the amount of vehicular emissions.Speaking to TOI, scientist Babu Rao, said the PM2.5 data was very high in the area. “Authorities must clearly mention what measures are being taken to combat this,” he said.

Title: Agra to get 45 new roadways buses this year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) is planning to add 45 more buses to its fleet in A... Read More

AGRA: The Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) is planning to add 45 more buses to its fleet in Agra region in the new year.

In the first phase, 15 BS-4 engine-equipped buses would be delivered by March-end.

The addition to the fleet is part of the state government’s plan to provide 45 more buses to each of the 19 divisions of UPSRTC. Initially, Dr Ram Manohar Lohia central workshop in Kanpur has been given the task of preparing the body of 300 buses. The chassis of these buses have already been supplied to the workshop.

At present, UPSRTC, Agra region, maintains a fleet of 593 buses. Some of the buses are in a poor condition and need to be replaced.

Agra region service manager SP Singh said, “The supply of new buses is likely to start by month-end.”

Meanwhile, UPSRTC Agra region has set up a control room at the regional manager’s office to address work-related problems of bus drivers and conductors. All drivers and conductors would be able to register their grievances on 0562-2225573 from 10:00 am to 5 pm daily. The issues would be resolved by senior officials the same day.

Title: I feel at home, says Telugu-origin Canada minister on Vizag visit
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: The Jason Kenney-led United Conservative Party’s landmark victory over the New Democratic Party in Alberta, in the spring of 2019, wasn’t one of the biggest political news of the year for Canada alone. Back home too, it marked a historic moment with two people of Telugu-origin, making it to the cabinet — Prasad Panda , minister of infrastructure and Leela Sharon Aheer, minister of culture, multiculturalism and status of women.Reportedly, both were first elected to the Legislative Assembly of the Canadian province, Alberta, in 2015. While Panda was born in Guntur’s Sangam Jagarlamudi village, Aheer has her roots in Visakhapatnam.On her recent trip to the city, TOI caught up with the 49-year-old musician-turned-minister, where Aheer spoke about her political journey, which began 14 years ago, and what she aspires to achieve for women in her constituency.“Back then, I used to volunteer for political events but never looked at it as a career option. I was running my private business,” she said, admitting that her friends nudged her to take the plunge, given her interest in it. Following an aggressive campaign, she was elected to the Alberta Assembly in 2015.Now, on her debut run as minister, Aheer has her agenda well chalked out: women’s empowerment, both at home and in society.“One thing that always disturbs me is the way women and children continue to be abused in all societies all over the world. It is time for real talk about the violation of human rights and speak out candidly about honour killings, human trafficking , child marriage and female genital mutilation. We need to engage all ages and genders to have conversations on how we can protect our rights,” said Aheer who declared November 19, 2019 as ‘Women’s Entrepreneurship Day’ in Alberta, at the first-ever Canada-based Women’s Entrepreneurship summit. The day aims to encourage women entrepreneurs and create opportunities for the world to recognise the many ways women contribute to the economy.Persuading women to join politics is also on her to-do list. Incidentally, for the first time, 44% of the contestants in the 2019 elections were women. “Although 51% population of Canada comprises women, until last elections, only a handful of them joined politics. Women felt they are incapable and lacked self-confidence. Last year our aim was to encourage more women to contest,” said Aheer while assuring another thing: unity, collaboration and inclusion within her province.“Be it people who cannot speak English or people who are new to the country, we want them to feel at home and not alienated. I urge the youth who are our future to engage in policy because it is the need of the hour. Wonders can happen if the people and government collaborate and work for a better world to live in,” the minister said appealing to people to break down barriers of religion, caste, economic status and gender.As the conversation veered towards India, Aheer professed her love for the country and sarees, which she said, she loves to wear whenever she gets the opportunity. “India is my second home and I feel my heart beat in India. I feel so close to my family and the people of this country, especially the South. I feel at home because I am home,” Aheer said.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

With the Centre planning to revive 100 lakes in the country including the Kapra, TOI asked readers what should be the salient features of the revival process

As Centre seeks proposals, what should be the key focus of the lake revival project?

would like to congratulate the government on taking important steps to revive the lakes in the country. As a chief environmental engineer (retd) I have dealt with lake remediation to some extent. The primary reason for pollution of the Kapra lake in the inflow of sewage from surrounding colonies into the catchment of the lake. I have also witnessed seen construction material getting dumped near the periphery of the lake. First step in the revival process of the lake should be diversion of drainage and nala water into the lake. Installing STPs in drains do not work because maintenance and over loading of STP makes such the system defunct within a few years. This was what happened during the Hussainsagar lake remediation. The next issue that needs to be addressed is the removal of water hyacinth. It is unlikely that mechanical methods such as dredging will help. Experts must be involved to tackle the issue. If these issues are tackled , Kapra lake can be revived in a sustainable manner and the scientific Laboratory parameters of lake can be brought back to normal.

Arun Kumar

Most of the lakes in the city have been completely destroyed,and the ones that have survived have been encroached upon. Large water bodies have been converted into small pools and ponds. Some of the lakes which are completely destroyed include the Djal Konta, Somajiguda Tank, Mir Jumla Tank, Mount Tagal Konta, Konta Bhawani Das, Nawab Sahib Konta, Afzal Sagar, Naalacanta, Masab Tank etc. Of the thousands of water reservoirs in Hyderabad that existed in the 1970s, very few of them survive today. Most of them have disappeared because of encroachments or have been encroached by private parties. The existing lakes have been used to throw garbage and as an outlet for drainage water. The area of Hussainsagar, the largest lake in Hyderabad, has shrunk by more than 40% in 30 years, from 550 hectares to 349 hectares. The lake was built in 1575 and has not been used as a source for drinking water since 1930. Similarly, the area occupied by the Shamirpet lake has shrunk from 486 hectares in 1989 to 256 hectares in 2006.According to current government rules, no construction is permitted, regardless of ownership of the lake bed. The authorities must look into this matter and ensure that the water bodies of the city are not encroached upon by government agencies or private parties. Lakes are integral parts of the environment, and need to be protected.

Syed Shamsuddin Maghrabi

In 2016, I attended an informal meeting of residents in and around the Kapra area, presided over by officials from the Department of Irrigation. In response to our concerns over depleting depths of the water bodies, we were told that the phenomena was caused due to heavy silting from the water body being. Now this status has to be reviewed by the government, from the standpoint that the land around the water bodies may no longer be agricultural as they have become residential in nature. GHMC should work towards converting the depleting water bodies into healthy lake. The lake's water and land area must be cordoned off to keep out intruders, grabbers and the like. Landscapers, recreational and water sport promoters be encouraged to submit proposals to run the place as public facilities on a commercial basis. The Hussainsagar lake and its peripherals may provide an excellent model to follow. No revival is complete until a safety and security system is put in place. The Kapra lake revival project can be customised to fit in a top-notch security system. Experts must be involved to ensure that all aspects of the revival project is taken care of.

Ravi Sishta

The biggest issue in and around lakes in the city and country is encroachment. All lakes should be fenced and monitored periodically so that encroachment is contained at the very first place. The lakes should be protected to indirectly protect the flora and fauna of the geographic area. Lakes should be well treated and cleared of the hyacinth that multiply rapidly. They should be removed on a regular basis to protect water bodies as well as organisms in the lakes. The lakes should have a walkway all around so that the people can visit the lake and this can be used to promote tourism. Lakes are an integral area of the city that need to be protected, especially in these times of environment degradation

Deepesh Surana

Key focus of the lake revival project must include quick identification of encroached lakes and those water bodies that are vulnerable to encroachments. Stringent action must be taken against corrupt authorities who allowed lakes to be encroached on and gave permits to construct structures in the vicinity of the water bodies. Evacuation of the illegal constructions must be done by giving fair compensation to flat purchasers, but strict action must be taken against builders who constructed these flats. Sewage must not be allowed to flow into water bodies. The flora and fauna in the water bodies must be protected. Industries must not be allowed to toss their water for by products into lakes. Afforestation must be encouraged.

N Srinivasa Rao

Due to laxity of officials and apathy of state governments, many scenic lakes which once served as a recreation were turned either a dumping yard or polluted badly due to let out of untreated dirty water or poisonous chemicals and other substances. In order to save such lakes from total extinction and revive such lakes, the state should come out with a plan of action like getting the entire lake cleaned by removing all weed etc and the fence on all sides to prevent encroachment. Secondly, the entire perimeter of the water body must be planted with different varieties of plants to give aesthetic look to the place. Besides, a garden with cafeteria and provision for games at the entrance to the lake would go a long way in attracting tourists from far and wide to visit the place as part of the tour itinerary. Above all, a notice board detailing the importance of the lake should be installed. Periodical monitoring by authorities is imperative for the lake to be a part of tourist destination.

Srinivasan Ramaswamy

It is an excellent decision by the Central government to revive 100 wetlands across the country. It is good to know that Kapra lake in Hyderabad and Pakhal lake in Warangal have been added to the much-needed list. This was an important move that has been taken up by the Ministry of Environment. Most of the lakes in Hyderabad are highly polluted. The extremely high biochemical oxygen demand of theses water bodies should be controlled and it should be brought down to less than 6 milligram per litre. Chemicals such as mercury, lead, zinc etc have seeped into these water bodies and destroying the entire ecosystem. Therefore, I request the state government to restore all water bodies and clean them on top priority.

Nandikanti Sai Kumar.

Title: Former minister’s son fires shot at Cong leader
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Congress leader Iqbal Khan received a gunshot wound

Bhopal: Panic gripped Govindpura locality on Tuesday night after former home minister late Satyadev Katare’s son — Yogesh Katare — fired a shot with a country-made pistol on a Congress leader over a petty dispute.

The victim sustained severe injury on his finger. Govindpura police reached the spot after getting information and rushed the injured to hospital. A case on charges of attempt to murder has been registered against Yogesh and his accomplices at Govindpura police station and further investigations are underway.

ASP Sanjay Sahu said that victim Iqbal Khan, (52), a resident of Bagh Farhat Afza in Aishbagh, works in a courier company. He is also the district general secretary in Congress party.

Khan told police that he was going to his friend’s house in Kailash Nagar near Shanti Niketan Colony on his bike around 11.30pm to congratulate him on the birth of his granddaughter. While on the way at Shanti Niketan Colony, he spotted that former minister Satyadev Katare’s son and former MLA Hemant Katare’s brother Yogesh along with his friends standing around a bonfire. Khan also stopped for a while and stood around the fire.

ASP Sahu said that Iqbal alleged that Yogesh and his friends were under the influence of alcohol and they manhandled him over a petty argument. Police investigations revealed that Iqbal too was in an inebriated state.

Iqbal said that he left and went to his friend’s house in Kailash Nagar. A few minutes later, Yogesh and his friends also reached the spot.

As Iqbal came out of his friend’s house, Yogesh pointed a pistol on him. The victim grabbed the pistol by his right hand and a shot got fired.

Iqbal’s friend and his neighbours came out hearing the gunshot noise but by that time Yogesh and his accomplices fled the spot. Later, cops reached the spot and rushed him to a nearby hospital from where he was discharged after primary treatment.

ASP Sahu said that cops have registered a case on charges of attempt to murder against Yogesh and his accomplices. Investigations are underway and cops are searching for the accused.

Iqbal said that if he had not grabbed the pistol from Yogesh, he might have killed him on the spot.

Title: AMC fails to meet deadline and make Agra roads pothole free
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

According to civic body officials, a path work has been laid for minor potholes in all the city’s wards.

AGRA: The Agra Municipal Corporation ( AMC ) administration, due to lackadaisical approach of the officials, has failed to meet its December 31 deadline and make the city roads “pothole free”. Worse, even after a month’s delay, repairing work has not been initiated on over a dozen main road stretches. Since November, the deadline had been extended twice.

According to civic body officials, a path work has been laid for minor potholes in all the city’s wards. Some roads are in poor condition and need urgent attention. Work, in this regard, will be initiated in the next few days.

Unhappy residents are also raising questions on the “poor quality” of road repair, which has been a huge inconvenience for the people. Shahganj resident Madan Agarwal said, “The quality of road repairing work is very poor. In my ward, concrete from repaired potholes started coming out within a few days of it being filled up. State government must conduct a technical probe on quality of the work done and the money spent.”

UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath had reportedly ordered all the civic bodies to complete the road repairing work by November end. Unable to complete their work, AMC engineers extended the deadline to December 15 and then to December 31. However, the work is yet to be completed.

Around half of the city roads being maintained by AMC are not in good condition. Roads at Madia Katra, Boghipura, Kailashpuri, Shahganj locality, Paschimpuri, Sikandra Road, Maruti Estate, interior roads of Pratapura locality, Lohamandi Belanganj, Peepal Mandi, Daresi, Heerabagh, Devri Road and Nunihai, are among those in dire need of repair. Roads in Trans-Yamuna locality, Kamla Nagar, Jaipur house, Tajganj also require immediate repair.

Diwakar Sharma, a resident of Kheria crossing, said, “Interior roads of residential areas are in a very poor state. No patch work has taken place in these localities. The pothole-free campaign has become a scope of corruption for civic body officials.”

On Wednesday, AMC chief engineer AK Singh assured, “A majority of small potholes have been filled up across the city. Tender process for repairing major potholes has been completed. The remaining road repairing work will be completed within this month.”

Title: CAA Protest in Kolkata: Bengal finds new protest tool in Kolam
Content:
An anti-NRC Kolam at Trichy, Tamil Nadu

KOLKATA: Kolam protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, are traversing across state borders and will be used in Bengal as well. Social, political and cultural organizations, which have been taking to the streets since the new law was passed, will use Kolam to register their protests.“We felt the need to draw Kolams after a few protesters were arrested in Chennai for painting and writing anti-CAA/NRC slogans on the roads. We shall show solidarity to the movement that will bind the south and the north across communities,” said Tanmoy Ghosh, secretary of Bangla Sanskriti Mancha. The organization, which promotes Bengal’s culture, has planned to draw Kolams on the road during a protest rally from Gariahat to Garia this week.Kolam, which resembles Alpana or Rangoli, is a design made with rice flour, chalk or rock powder. Primarily used during festive seasons, Kolam became a new tool for anti-CAA protest when the DMK president MK Stalin and Lok Sabha member M Kanimozhi tweeted photographs of the patterns outside their houses. In Chennai, several lawyers and anti-CAA activists were arrested after they tried to paint Kolams allegedly without police permission.Collective enthusiasm during political movements in Kolkata started looking for new tools or languages, especially after #Hokkolorob at Jadavpur University, six years ago. The Bangladeshi song got a fresh lease of life when student movement started to galvanize around the two words. “It showed that student movements need new languages and tools to gain a momentum. #HokKolorob was markedly different from the traditional ways of protest as it had contemporary elements,” said Debabrata Roy of No NRC Movement.“Such tools can even be effective in districts where people can register their protest with a small but powerful gesture. These tools work more as sparks during movements and help to integrate mass movements across a country,” said Kamal Sur, one of the conveners of No NRC Movement. “We shall take a call on using Kolam in next few days before we spread the movement in districts,” Sur said.“Kolam can be a powerful tool to protests. Alpana has been a tradition in Bengal and it gels with the state’s ethos. We have tried to fuse newer forms like flash protests and skits to make protests more appealing,” said Suman Sengupta of Sahaman. “We are taking out weekly protests across the city. Skits like Madhusudan Dada have been popular with the protesters. We will now bring in elements of Kolam,” he added.

Title: Army’s Gurpreet hits bull’s eye, bags gold
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bhopal: Army’s Gurpreet Singh bagged the gold medal in the 25m centre fire pistol men’s category at the 63rd National Shooting Championship being held at MP Shooting Academy here on Wednesday.

Gurpreet scored 587-22 points, while Navy’s Yogesh Singh with 587-17 points won the silver medal and Haryana’s Anees bagged the bronze with 585 points. In the team event of the same category, Navy with 1,737 points stood first, Haryana came second with 1,729 points, while Maharashtra stood third with 1,716 points.

In the 25m centre fire pistol men’s category civilian match, Naveen of Kerala finished first with 579 points, Ankur Goyal of Uttarakhand stood second with 575 points and Arpit Goyal of Delhi was third with 574 points. In the team event, Tamil Nadu stood first with 1,697 points, Uttarakhand second with 1,695 points and Delhi finished third with 1,690 points.

In the 25m centre fire pistol veterans match, Prabhat Singh of Uttar Pradesh won the gold with 542 points, Panchal Rohit of Gujarat won silver with 540 points, while Shyam Yadav of Uttar Pradesh earned bronze with 490 points.

In the 25m standard pistol civilians match played earlier, Panchal Rohit from Gujarat scored 521 points, Arun Tiwari from Uttar Pradesh earned silver with 516 points and Shyam Yadav from Uttar Pradesh earned bronze with 451 points. .

ADG Lokayukta Pawan Jain while referring to MP Shooting Academy as world class, said that it is a big gift for shooters. Describing the sports facilities of the shooting academy of international standards, he said that shooters are getting proper sports equipment and high performance training and that is why they are performing well at the national and international level.

Title: Probe team files 1st chargesheet in Koodathayi multiple murders
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kozhikode: The special investigation team (SIT) probing the Koodathayi serial murder case filed its first chargesheet in the case involving the murder of Roy Thomas — the first husband of prime accused Jolly Joseph — before the Thamarassery judicial first class magistrate court on Wednesday.

The 1,800-page chargesheet names Jolly Joseph (47) along with three others as accused. Jolly’s relative and jewellery employee M S Mathew and goldsmith P Prajikumar, who provided sodium cyanide, which was used to murder Roy, has been arraigned as second and third accused.

Former CPM local secretary of the Kattangal unit K Manoj Kumar has also been named as an accused for his alleged role in helping Jolly to forge documents including a fake will to grab family property.

The accused have been charged under 10 sections of the IPC, including murder, criminal conspiracy, forgery and cheating apart from sections 6 (2) of Indian Poison Act.

The chargesheet has named 246 witnesses and also had 322 documents and 22 material objects (thondi). The witnesses consist of 26 officials, including three judicial officials. The chargesheet says the cyanide used for the murder has been recovered from the Ponnamattom house of Jolly.

The case pertained to the murder of Roy Thomas, which was the third in the six killings of family members allegedly by Jolly over a period of 14 years, mostly by poisoning the victims using cyanide. The other victims included Roy’s parents Annamma Thomas and Tom Thomas, Roy’s uncle Mathew Manchadi and wife and two-year-old daughter of Jolly’s second husband Shaju.

According to the chargesheet, Jolly murdered Roy by mixing sodium cyanide in chickpea (kadala curry) and water at their house on September 30, 2011. Roy was found dead in the toilet and it was initially claimed to be due to heart attack. Though the doctor who did the postmortem had raised suspicion of cyanide poisoning which was confirmed later in the postmortem report, the case was not probed further then. Roy is the only person among the six deceased family members on whom a postmortem was done.

The case was investigated by investigation team led by Kozhikode rural SP, K G Simon and Crime Branch DySP R Haridasan.

Simon said the SIT has obtained clear evidence against the accused in the case and has submitted the chargesheet with a sense of pride.

“We have been able to build up a good case and conduct the investigations in a good manner. We have recordical evidence for each and every charges against the accused. Also, we have recorded confessions of six persons, including that of two sons of Jolly, under Section 164,” he added.

The chargesheet says the Jolly plotted and carried out the murder of Roy as she thought that he was of no use to the family as he had no job and had a history of alcohol abuse. Also, there was also the motive to get control of the 38.5 cents of family property.

Simon said there was no need for DNA test results in the Roy case as postmortem certificate and chemical analysis report had revealed the presence of cyanide in the body. Also, the fake will forged by Jolly to get father-in-law’s property is expected to become a crucial evidence in the case

The chargesheet builds up the case by mentioning the earlier murders of Roy’s parents as it is linked with his murder as well. “Jolly began the killings to cover up the pile of lies she had told to family members about her education and other things. First she lied about her education to mother-in-law Annnamma, and to substantiate it she forged certificates and lied further about attending classes and getting job. She first killed Annamma to cover up the lies and when she insisted on her taking up employment. Jolly became emboldened when she found that she could get away with the murders without getting caught,” he added.

The chargesheet says though Jolly was just a pre-degree holder, she had forged certificates of BCom, MCom, UGC-NET certificates and the identity card of NIT-Calicut to substantiate her false claim of being a professor at the national institute. “We have included copies of the forged educational certificates and photograph of the NIT-C identity card as evidence,” Simon added.

Though probing the Roy murder case which was closed years back was a challenging one, the investigation focused on profiling of the accused, victimology, crime scene examination, previous and subsequent behaviour of the accused and how the crime was organised.

Title: Bathing ban in Kodiveri dam leaves tourists disappointed
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Erode: The district administration has banned bathing, fishing and coracle riding in the Kodiveri dam near Gobichettipalayam following the release of water from the Bhavanisagar dam. Visitors who came to the dam to celebrate New Year on Wednesday had to return disappointed.

The Kodiveri dam has been seeing a huge water flow after the public works department started releasing 3,000 cusecs of surplus water from the Bhavanisagar dam into the Bhavani river. “The river water has completely submerged the dam,” a PWD official said.

Considering the huge water flow, the PWD banned coracle riding, bathing and fishing activities in the dam on January 1. Many people from Gobichettipalayam, Erode and Sathyamangalam, who did not know about the ban, thronged to the dam with their children and family members.

“The officials refused to allow us near the dam,” M Matheswaran, one of the visitors, said. He lamented that he would have gone to the Bhavanisagar dam or some other tourist spots, if he had known about the ban.

Petty shopowners too were a dejected lot due to the lost business. “We have stocked goods for the New Year sale, excepting hundreds of visitors. But there was no business on Wednesday,” K Vijaya, a snack and fish stall owner, said.

The PWD said they would lift the ban once the water started receding.

Water from the Kodiveri dam is used for long-term crop cultivation in Gobichettipalayam and its surrounding villages. When the dam brims, water would be released for a period of 133 days benefitting 39,000 acres. About 24,504 acres of fertile lands in Thadapalli, Arakkankottai and its surrounding villages and another 15,000 acres of land lying across the Kalingarayan canal would be benefitted from the water release.

Title: AMU indefinitely extends its winter vacation
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University

AGRA: In the wake of the ongoing protests against the amended Citizenship Act, the authorities of Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) have indefinitely extended the winter vacation for its students. Even though the university was scheduled to reopen on January 6, the administration has announced on Wednesday that a fresh date will be released later.

According to the university administration, the decision to further extend the vacation was taken after a consultative meeting of the deans of faculties, principals of colleges and polytechnics, and other functionaries of the university under the chairmanship of AMU vice-chancellor Tariq Mansoor.

According to controller of examinations Mujib Ullah Zuberi, a detailed schedule for opening the university in a phased manner would be notified in due course of time. He said that the examinations that could not be held in December would also be announced soon, adding that students should regularly visit the university website for updates.

Meanwhile, student leader Faizul Hasan appealed to his fellow students to return to the university. He said that the identity of the university is not about its administration but its students. “It is the fundamental right of students to fight against issues like CAA or NRC. Even though a majority of students have already made their return booking, the administration has now extended the vacation with an aim to quell protests,” he added.

Title: C Rly introduces fog safe devices
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: For the first time, Central Railway has introduced fog safe device (FSD) in the interest of safety of passengers in Nagpur division.

In the last month, many passenger trains were rescheduled due to foggy weather conditions, especially in the northern parts. Several north-south trains have been arriving at least 5-15 hours late every day.

“These devices were introduced by Indian Railways in the north last year. Nagpur Central Railway has brought in 240 such portable fog safe devices for mail/express trains. Each unit costs Rs40,000 and has been to the specifications of Railways Design & Standards Organisation (RDSO),” said a senior traction operation (TRO) department official.

“FSD is a GPS-based hand-held portable device placed in the driver’s cabin. It serves as an aid for the crew during foggy weather through audio visual alarm, whenever any landmark comes within the geo-fence range, which is 500 metres ahead of the signal,” he said.

“We have introduced the device in the Nagpur-Amla-Itarsi section. Location of stations, warning boards, signals, level crossing gates and whistle for level crossing (W/L) boards in the section is fed in the equipment. It displays speed of the locomotive, distance and time to reach landmarks and is carried by the loco pilots,” said the official.

The official added that these devices are being used only in those zones of Indian Railways where the trains pass through fog-affected region. Over 7,000 FSDs have been provided to zonal railways in the north.

Title: Benaulim locals pin their hopes on govt report
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Margao: Villagers of Benaulim , who have been demanding that the stretch of Western bypass passing through their village be built on stilts, are pinning their hopes on the report of the inspection conducted by the Goa State Biodiversity Board (GSBB), water resources department (WRD), agriculture department, town and country planning department and the directorate of settlement and land records, which they believe will validate their concerns.

Following a petition to environment minister Nilesh Cabral by former sarpanch Royla Fernandes, the joint inspection was conducted to examine the environmental concerns raised by her and assess the imminent damage. The GSBB will submit the comprehensive report to Cabral.

Villagers have opposed the filling of agricultural lands to build the bypass. They apprehend flooding of their village on account of the destruction of water catchment areas.

The former sarpanch told TOI that in the absence of any study of the floodplains of Benaulim and the probable effects of new flood levels post reclamation of the land, the destruction could only be catastrophic.

Title: New Year Celebration in Bangalore: BBMP officer led drive to clear tonnes of trash from party hub before Bengaluru woke up
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Junior health inspector Santosh Raj M and his team collected over ten tonnes of trash on Wednesday

BENGALURU: Bengaluru’s hub of New Year celebrations — Brigade Road-MG Road-Church Street loop — is usually dotted with tonnes of waste, including empty liquor bottles, metal cans and food packets, on January 1. But the dawn of 2020 painted a different picture and a very pleasant one indeed. The entire area was cleaned up in such a way that none could visualise it being stomped by a massive crowd barely a few hours ago.

The drive by Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike ( BBMP ) — undertaken on the lines of how normalcy is restored at New York’s Times Square after NY revelry — saw collection of over ten tonnes of trash. “Nobody would want to believe that we cleaned up the area after the big party, but the reality is that we did,” said mayor Goutham Kumar M. The drive was undertaken by 50 workers between 3am and 7am. The trash collected included over 500-600 liquor bottles, around 150 pairs of slippers and shoes, cigarette butts and some five tonnes of plastic and paper waste.

In fact, the champion of the clean-up operation was Shantalanagar (ward number 111) junior health inspector Santosh Raj M. Santosh took it up as a challenge to clean the entire stretch before the city woke up after the celebrations. Raj, 32, told TOI: “Usually, on January 1 morning, motorists on MG Road , Brigade Road and Church Street are put off by all the filth around. They start the New Year by blaming the civic agency for messed-up roads. But this time, I wanted to surprise all.”

Raj requested special commissioner (solid waste management) Randeep D to allow him to undertake a special clean-up drive on these roads. “I requested for one compactor, eight private autorickshaws and private daily wage labourers as pourakarmikas cannot come for work that early,” he said. On getting the green signal, Raj came to the spot along with his team at 2:30am, but had to wait as revellers continued to mill around. The civic team got down to action around 3am after police personnel ensured all revellers had left.

In fact, when The Ugly Indian (TUI), a citizen-volunteer group landed in front of the Metro station entrance on Church Street around 10am to commence TrashURE Hunt (wherein volunteers were to locate trash and photograph the same), they were in for a pleasant surprise. They volunteers managed to gather less than eight kg of trash, most of it dumped by three roadside tea shops in the morning. The BBMP promptly imposed a fine of Rs 3,000 on the three defaulters.

“It was very surprising to see the civic body had cleared out all the trash and ensured the most happening part of Bengaluru was sparkly clean,” said a volunteer of TUI.

“This is a great effort by our officials. But this does not mean people will keep polluting and we keep cleaning. They need to be responsible and keep their surroundings clean,” said Randeep.

Title: Bengaluru: Car-borne gang loots government staff of gold, cash
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 30-year-old government employee was allegedly held hostage and robbed of 25-grams of gold and Rs 1,300 by unidentified car-borne criminals on Sunday midnight near Rajkumar memorial on Outer ring road.

Sunil Kumar BM, a first division assistant with horticulture department, told cops that he and his 17-year-old relative were waiting for the BMTC bus near Goraguntepalya when a white sedan stopped before them.

“We had come from Hassan that night and were waiting for a bus when a white car stopped and the driver asked us where we wanted to go. When answered, he agreed to drop us. We sat in the back seat. After moving a little, the driver and his friend sitting next to him threatened us at knife point and robbed the gold chain and cash from me,” he said.

Earlier this week, two car-borne men had assaulted and robbed a 25-year-old businessman of Rs 11 lakh cash at Kadabagere Cross, off Tumakuru Road.

Title: Punjab minister orders probe into jail assault on farm activist
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Punjab jail minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa. (Photo credit: @Sukhjinder_INC)

BATHINDA: Punjab jails minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa has ordered an investigation into the December 30 assault on a farmer union’s vice-president in Faridkot jail. Randhawa said he had asked ADGP (jails) to find how a gangster and his henchmen beat up the inmate, Kirti Kisan Union vice president Rajinder Singh. An officer of the rank of deputy inspector general of police (DIG) has been asked to inquire into the matter and fix responsibility of the jail staff. Speaking to TOI, Randhawa said, “I had taken up the matter with ADGP (jails) and asked him to get the matter probed. The ADGP has deputed a DIG-level officer to investigate by concentrating on talking to the inmate who was beaten up and those who were around. We will reach to the bottom of the matter and anyone found guilty of dereliction of duty will be taken to task.” Rajinder was attacked in the jail on December 30 evening. With blunt injuries on the body, he was admitted to Guru Gobind Singh Medical College, Faridkot. Nishan Singh, who is serving a life sentence for abducting and raping a minor girl, is behind the attack. A case has been registered against Nishan and 17 others. Farmer organisation activists KKU president Nirbhay Singh Dhudike and BKU (Ekta Ugrahan) general secretary Sukhdev Singh Kokri said it was a matter of serious concern how Nishan and his accomplices were allowed to go near Rajinder, who had been fighting for justice all through his life. While he was the president of a faction of Punjab Students Union, Rajinder was at the forefront of protests against abduction and rape of a minor girl in Faridkot by Nishan in 2012. Due to the sustained struggle by him and other activists, police had arrested Nishan from Goa along with the girl. He was sentenced to life imprisonment in May 2013. Late,r Nishan and his mother were made to pay a compensation of Rs 90 lakh to the survivor’s family as damages. PSU activists claimed that Nishan wanted to take revenge from Rajinder for the role he played in the struggle. Meanwhile, a four-member team of the Democratic Lawyers Association (DLA) on Wednesday met Faridkot jail superintendent and made investigations. Association member Rajiv Lohatbaddi alleged it seemed some jail officials were hand in glove with Nishan. “We have tried to make assessment after meeting the jail superintendent and will hand over our report to the chief justice of Punjab and Haryana high court,” he said.

Title: Chennai: No masks, no gloves, they fight filth with bare hands
Content:
Conservancy workers across the city said they did not get gloves, footwear, caps and masks — the basic protect... Read More

CHENNAI: The stench was unbearable, but Dhanam M, a conservancy worker in Royapettah, emptied garbage from the dustbin into her cart every day. She had no mask, footwear or gloves. “What glove? I did not get any. I was told to wear a jacket every day. I do it,” she said.Conservancy workers across the city said they did not get gloves, footwear, caps and masks — the basic protective gear to be worn while handling garbage.But the dangers do not deter the likes of Mariyamma who drags herself to work every day so that her children can go to school. “I don’t have to money for food. I can’t buy safety gears for myself,” she said.Greater Chennai Corporation has nearly 19,000 conservancy workers who collect 3,600 tonnes of garbage every day. Solid Waste Management rules say that the corporation should ensure safety and hygiene of its conservancy staff and they should get uniforms, fluorescent jackets, gloves, raincoats, appropriate footwear and masks.A superintending engineer from the waste management department said “all conservancy workers are given safety gears”. “Many do not wear them saying that they are not comfortable. We have told them about the hazards but many don’t care,” he added.Prohibition of employment as manual scavengers and their rehabilitation rules mandate health camps for sanitation workers. In Tamil Nadu, these camps were instituted as part of Tamil Nadu Urban Sanitation Support Programme in 2015. The National Urban Health Mission under the National Health Mission had issued a directive in 2017 to all urban local bodies to organise health checkups for sanitation workers and ragpickers but this has not been implemented.Although many workers said they had health insurance, they have never attended health camps. Dhamodaran*, a worker near KK Nagar said, “I haven’t heard of health camps. Even if we are ill, we have to come to work to earn.”(*Name changed)

Title: Firozabad violent anti-CAA protests: Cancer patient, shop owner’s nephew prime accused, says FIR
Content:
Faraz Khan

Rashid Kamal of Hajipura had shot a video which shows the attack on the shop where Faraz was present.

AGRA: The 52-year-old oral cancer patient Ahmad Nabi and 19-year-old Faraz Khan, nephew of the wood shop owner whose outlet was vandalised and set on fire by an unruly group of men in front of heavy police force, are the prime accused in the case registered in connection with the violent anti-CAA protests that broke out on December 20, according to a copy of the FIR copy filed by Nalband police outpost in-charge Rajeev Kumar Chitransh. Though video footage available with TOI contradicts with police narratives.The FIR states that a mob of nearly 2,000 men, led by Ahmad and Faraz, gathered around 2.45pm and started threatening to kill or die claiming that the new citizenship law was passed to force a particular community to leave India.According to the FIR, "The two men along with others were shouting anti-BJP slogans. When I attempted to stop them and tried to explain that section 144 of CrPC is in place in the area, the mob got agitated and a scuffle broke out. They manhandled us, after which I called the SHO and sought backup force."A total of six men were booked in the FIR — Ahmad Nabi, Faraz Khan, Mohammad Hashim, Aamir, Adil and Aamir.In the FIR, sub-inspector Chitransh further claimed, "During interrogation, the accused accepted the charges and claimed that they, under the leadership of Faraz and Ahmad, decided to attack policemen with an intention to kill them in order to protest against CAA ."However, relatives of Ahmad and Faraz vehemently denied the allegations and claimed that police are concocting a fake story to hide their brutal action. Ahmad's brother Vakeel Nabi said, "I never heard about Faraz Khan or any other men being mentioned in the FIR along with my elder brother."Similarly, Faraz’s uncle Azad Khan said, "No one in our family knows about Ahmad Nabi. Police want to frame our child and other men. We have video evidence to prove that a group of 15-20 people backed by heavy police force barged inside our woodshop located near Shikohabad Adda Road close to Nalband Chouraha and vandalised our property, set it on fire and assaulted me, Faraz and our employee Gulshan Sharma along with other customers.""The group looted Rs 1.85 lakh cash and destroyed CCTV DVR in front of policemen while we begged for mercy. They later dragged out my nephew Faraz and Gulshan Sharma out of the shop and handed them over to police. Later, Gulshan was released after his parents showed his identification card and proved that he is a Hindu," he added.The video of the attack on wood shop was shot by Rashid Kamal of Hajipura, who had come to Shikohabad Adda to attend his niece Sumera’s wedding. Kamal said, "I was merely 40 feet away standing on my brother’s house’s roof while shooting the video. I saw policemen and other people barge inside the wood shop after breaking the door. They set a bike on fire in the presence of police. They later dragged out Azad Khan and his nephew Faraz Khan from the shop and rained kicks and punches in front of police. Later, they took Faraz and their employee, Gulshan Sharma, to the station".Dakshin station house officer Dinesh Kumar Singh, under whose jurisdiction Nalband police outpost falls, said, "Our sub-inspector has lodged an FIR. Whatever is mentioned in it, is the truth."

Title: 1,644 banned vehicles found plying in Kolkata in November
Content:
99% of such banned vehicles are diesel-run and are potential health hazards for residents of Kolkata

TimesView Phasing out polluting vehicles is an essential part of controlling the air-quality index. The sooner we can achieve the NGT-set target, the healthier will it be for the city.

KOLKATA: Although 15-year-old commercial vehicles had been banned from plying in the Kolkata metropolitan area by Calcutta High Court way back in 2008, the state transport department’s digital checkposts detected as many as 1,644 such vehicles plying in the city in November 2019. Significantly, 99% of such banned vehicles are diesel-run and are potential health hazards for residents of Kolkata.This came to light in an affidavit filed by the Bengal chief secretary (CS), Rajiva Sinha, to National Green Tribunal. The affidavit was submitted in connection to a case filed by environment crusader Subhas Datta concrning the city’s degrading air quality and remedial measures. The affidavit stated that 67 digital checkposts fitted with high-resolution automatic number plate recognition cameras at strategic locations in the city and the different entry points to the city detected the vehicles. The affidavit said that legal action had been initiated against those vehicles.“This is irrefutable proof that a large number of highly polluting vehicles are still plying in the city. This is only the tip of an iceberg. If this was the figure for just November, the total number of vehicles plying illegally within the city must be much more. The impact of the dirty fumes on the ambient air is far worse,” Datta said.In the affidavit, the CS also stated that the E-Vahan system has been programmed to lock all commercial vehicles when they crossed 15 years. So far, fitness certificates for 3,09,201 vehicles have been locked, or marked for non-renewal of permits and issuance of certificate of fitness (CF), since 2016.However, the mere system-locking has not proved foolproof. Many of these vehicles are plying in the city without valid documents. “Either they managed to skip the scrutiny of police and motor vehicle inspectors or they managed their way by greasing the palm of the personnel,” Datta said.Earlier, the ministry of road transport and highways had informed the NGT that 2,19,137 commercial vehicles exceeding 15 years are plying in the city. However, the transport department picked holes in the claim and said that such a huge number was not plausible.“We shall keep using the digital checkposts and analysing the data with our vehicle database to zero-in on the non-compliant vehicles. They will be seized the moment they pass any of the entry-exit points of the city,” said a transport department official. Last year, the transport department detected 15,000 such vehicles at these digital check posts.

Title: Jolly planned killing meticulously: Cops
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

KOZHIKODE: The chargesheet filed in the Roy Thomas murder case reveals the chilling details of the meticulous planning which prime accused Jolly Joseph carried out to kill her husband by lacing his food with sodium cyanide .

Jolly mixed cyanide in the chikpea (kadala) curry and as a backup added cyanide to the water she had kept for Roy in case he skipped dinner. “On the night of the murder, she laced kadala curry with cyanide and also added it to Roy’s water in case he skipped dinner as he had a habit of drinking a glass of water on returning home, Kozikode rural SP K G Simon said.

He said that to ensure that the children do not consume the poisoned food, she took them upstairs early and put them to sleep.

Jolly had also washed the dishes before she called the relatives to inform about Roy’s death and told them that he had suffered a heart attack, Simon said. He said that she had told only one witness that Roy had eaten dinner at home. “She had told all others that Roy didn’t take dinner and that she was cooking eggs for him,” Simon said.

The SP said that she didn’t inform the children on their father’s death in the night. It was only in the next morning when the children asked about the pandal being erected outside the house that she told them about Roy’s death.

Simon said that Jolly had also tried to stop the exhumation of the bodies of the six deceased.

“The first thing that we checked was her claim that she was a professor at NIT. When we found that it was fake, we sensed that things were not right,” the SP added. Police have collected evidence of bank transactions, fabricated educational degrees and details of how fake ID card of NIT-C to sustain the web of lies and deception in her life.

Title: Tricksters sell sr citizen’s plot using her fake death certificate
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: A 72-year-old woman was duped of Rs 21.75 lakh by four persons, including a trickster posing as her son, who sold her plot by using her fake death certificate between December 2016 and February 2018.

Wathoda police registered a case of fraud and forgery against four persons on Tuesday following a complaint from Bhavna Kulkarni, a resident of Jai Prakash Nagar .

The accused have been identified as Bhimrao Wagde, Ashwin Wanjari, Vikas Choure and one unidentified person who posed as Rajesh Kulkarni, Bhavna’s son.

Police said Bhavna’s husband Sudhakar owned a plot, the market value of which is around Rs21.75 lakh, at Wathoda. After Sudhakar’s death, Bhavna owned the police as the couple does not have any children.

In December 2016, Rajesh made a fake death certificate of Bhavna and presented it before the government official making himself owner of the plot.

Rajesh later gave power of attorney of the plot to Wagde and also sold the plot to him. While selling the plot, Wanjari and Choure were the witnesses. Wagde later sold the same plot to Wanjari, who later sold it to another person.

In February 2018, when Bhavna went to see her plot, she found that some person is constructing a house on it. When she inquired, Bhavna came to know that her plot has been sold.

She later approached Wathoda police station where a case was registered after primary inquiry. Police are yet to make any arrests in the case.

It is learnt that cops are now focusing on arresting Wagde, Wanjari and Choure as it will help them identify Rajesh.

Title: Govt plans to set up 3000 cow sheds this year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bhopal: The state government is keen to set up 3000 cowsheds in 2020. After chief minister Kamal Nath gave this target to animal husbandry department, the officials are working overtime to accomplish the tas. The animal husbandry minister Lakhan Singh Yadav said that as per the CM’s instructions, 3000 cow sheds would be constructed this year and the process to identify the places has already begun. The work would start after bhoomi pujan in the next one or two months, he said.

The cowsheds are being set up to fulfill the party’s poll promise. When asked how many cow sheds have been opened in the state so far, the minister said that over 500 have been opened and the figure is set to cross the 700 hundred mark in the next two months.

The state government on Wednesday announced that 78 cow shelters will be set up through forest committees. The fund of Rs 15 crore for 50 cow shelters to be constructed at the rate of Rs 30 lakh per cow shelter and Rs 8.4 crore for remaining 28 cow shelters has already been earmarked from the dividend amount payable to Laghu Vanopaj Sangh and forest protection committees respectively, officials said, adding that proper forest areas are being selected for fodder production in collaboration with the joint forest management committees.

The government has come up with a ‘sustainability model’ for cow sheds, where it aims to make over 100 products from cow produce to meet routine expenditure of gaushalas. Most of the products would be from cow dung like hawan items, flower pots, manure, incense sticks and other items of daily use. The proceeds will take care of the expenses of food, medication and maintenance, said an official.

However, there are still a few major issues that need to be dealt with by the government. Though a year has elapsed since coming to power, the state government has not been able to come up with a land allotment policy for cow shelters in the state. As per the proposed gaushala land allotment policy which would be tabled in cabinet soon, the amount of land allotted would depend upon money invested. Investors would have to open cow shelters with capacity of at least 2,000 cows to get government land.

Corporates that have showed interest to take up cattle breeding and cowshed projects are reluctant to invest in the absence of clarity on land allotment policy and government’s assistance for the project. Officials said the process has gained pace after the CM’s directive to open 3000 cow sheds this year. Districts authorities have also been directed to get the land identifying process completed soon so that work can be started, officials said.

Title: Punjab: Government schools in border districts fail to make it to state’s merit list
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Government schools in border areas have failed to impress in grading by the Punjab education department with only a few featuring in the top 10 in different categories.In the grading, which is part of government’s efforts to improve the quality of education, not even a single school from border districts of Tarn Taran , Ferozepur and Pathankot featured in the top 10 list of senior secondary, high and middle schools. Amritsar and Gurdaspur just had one school each at ninth spot in the middle school category and fifth in high school category, respectively. Many schools failed to score above 50%.Each school was graded out of a score of 100 — 50 marks for academic performance, 20 for infrastructure, and 10 each for co-curricular activities, public contribution and student attendance.
