The evaluation was done based on data submitted by the schools online.Sources in the department cited shortage of staff as one of the key reasons for poor show by schools in these districts. The department is hopeful of better performance in next grading as corrective measures have already been taken by overcoming shortage of staff in these schools and other infrastructure.Fazilka, another border district, stands out in the lot with Government High School, Hira Wali, from the district securing top position in high school category with a score of 87.3, highest in all categories, while government high school, Himmatpura, attained the third spot by securing a score of 85.56. Government High School, Shergarh, finished seventh. Government High School, Babarpur, Ludhiana finished third in the category.In the senior secondary category, Government Senior Secondary School (GSSS), Karandi, in Mansa district attained the top position with a score of 86.99. It was followed by GSSS, Menru Garden, in the second place with a score of 86.27. GSSS, Manakpur, in Patiala scored 86.24 and was third.Government School, Rattoke, secured the top position by securing 85.83 score in the middle school category. Goverm,emy Middle School, Khular, in Ludhiana and Government Middle School, Bhangal Khurd, in Nawanshahr finished second and third with scores of 85.22 and 84.83, respectively.Punjab education secretary Krishan Kumar said corrective measures had been taken and schools in border districts would perform better in next year’s grading. “The sole purpose of grading schools is to identify grey areas and take corrective steps, so that quality of education can improve,” said Kumar. He said schools have shown improvement and the department is committed to work in this direction.The state government has been making efforts to improve the quality of education for which several initiatives have been taken in two years. The state secured second spot in the human resource development ranking in the recently released good governance index (GGI). Quality of education was one of the key components of the ranking.

Title: Govt to tweak EWS quota rules in state, says min
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Public Relation Minister PC Sharma addressing press conference at PCC in Bhopal on Tuesday. pics A Moeed Faruq... Read More

Bhopal: State public relations minister P C Sharma said on Wednesday that the Congress government will work in ‘20-20 style’ (alluding to a cricket format).

“In one year, we have proved our intention of fulfilling what had promised to the public. The Kamal Nath-led government will work in 20-20 style during the entire year beginning today. Good governance and development will be the main objective of the government,” said Sharma.

The minister also said that the chief minister will hold one-to-one meetings with officials Kanal Nath on January 3 to chalk out plan for the year. It will be followed by a cabinet meeting on January 4, he added.

The government plans to tweak the rules for 10% reservation to economically weaker sections (EWS) from the general category in the state.

“For the poor from general category, the government has decided to relax all norms, barring the minimum annual income criteria of Rs8 lakh. The prospective beneficiaries will only be required to submit their income certificate and the other conditions will be scrapped,” said Sharma, adding that the government has taken up several welfare initiatives for poor, which have proved extremely successful.

As of now, a candidate wanting to avail reservation benefits should not own agricultural land more than five acres or 1,200 sq ft plot under municipal corporation limits; 1,500 sq ft plot under municipality limits; or a house or more than 1,800 sq ft plot under panchayat limits. Various certificates are also required.

The general administration department (GAD) has drafted a proposal, which has been forwarded to the chief minister’s office to get the official consent. The new reservation rules will come into force soon, said sources.

The BJP, however, took a dig at the government’s plans.

“It was PM Narendra Modi-led Central government, which passed the bill for EWS reservation in Parliament and executed the same. The Congress’s one-year rule in MP is good enough to show how people of the state are suffering the consequences of poor development,” said BJP state spokesperson, Deepak Vijayavargiya.

Title: ‘Kerala governor misquoted Gandhi to insult Muslims’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Irfan Habib said that the governor was wrongly attributing statements to Maulana Azad and Gandhiji to claim th... Read More

AGRA: Amid his stand-off with Kerala governor Arif Mohammad Khan over the developments at the Indian History Congress in Kannur recently, eminent historian Irfan Habib on Wednesday said that he had interrupted the former’s speech as he was misquoting Mahatma Gandhi and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and attributing words to them to insult the Muslim community.

Habib said that the governor was wrongly attributing statements to Azad and Gandhiji to claim that they said such things. He added that, as a historian, he knew that the leaders never made such remarks. He further added that he would have reacted in the same manner had anybody made such “inappropriate remarks” against the community.

The historian said, “I only stopped the governor from abusing the sacrifices of these great leaders. Even the audience raised objection to the same.”

On being asked about breaking protocol, Habib said that police should not have been deployed in the room in the first place as per the rules of IHC .

When asked about the allegations that the historian tried to physically push the governor, he said, “I just pushed the guards back and walked towards him.”

However, Habib admitted that he asked the governor to quote Nathuram Godse as he was not ready to stop speaking about Maulana Azad and Mahatma Gandhi.

Title: Minimum temperature drops to 3.9 degrees Celsius in Agra
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Over a dozen trains, including Gatimaan Express and Shatabdi Express, were running behind schedule on Wednesda... Read More

AGRA: The minimum temperature level in Agra on Wednesday was recorded at 3.9 degrees Celsius which was one degree Celsius less than Tuesday. Cold winds blew at a speed of 20 km per hour causing shiver during the day. There was a slight respite for people in the afternoon with mild sunshine spreading some warmth.

The maximum temperature level was recorded three degrees Celsius below normal. It remained 17.4 degrees Celsius. In the evening, visibility level decreased below 500 metres. Moderate fog was witnessed in the morning.

Besides Agra, cold wave condition swept across Firozabad , Mathura, Etah , Aligarh and Mainpuri. The entire region remained in the grip of cold wave. People preferred to stay indoors. Few people went to government offices and could be seen out sightseeing at monuments.

Over a dozen trains, including Gatimaan Express and Shatabdi Express, were running behind schedule on Wednesday.

To help people who stay outdoors from cold wave, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has installed gas heaters and operating them in evening at over a dozen places around the city. Besides, people set up bonfire at different places.

On Wednesday evening, mayor Naveen Jain and municipal commissioner Arun Prakash distributed woollen blankets to people staying at a shelter home on Rajamandi railway station road.

According to the meteorological department, there is a possibility of rain in the first week of January.

Meanwhile, Wednesday’s air quality index in Agra was recorded in moderate category at 178. According to central pollution control board (CPCB), particulate matter 2.5 remained the prominent pollutant.

Title: Punjab: Show original ownership in revenue records, says panel
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Encroachments on govt land are a serious issue in Punjab

CHANDIGARH: Noticing that possession of waste lands, riverbeds and fallow lands across Punjab continued to be shown in ‘ khasra girdawari ’ on the name of a person “surreptitiously”, the Punjab revenue commission has recommended that possession should be recorded in favour of the original owner like the municipal corporations, municipal councils, nagar councils or village panchayats.

Illegal encroachment of government land has been a serious issue in Punjab. Even forest and wildlife minister Sadhu Singh Dharamsot had in April 2018 claimed that 28,600 acres of forest land was under illegal possession of “politically influential persons” across the state.

“It has generally been noticed that when a person other than the owner is in occupation of land in some capacity or the other like tenant or unauthorised occupation, his possession continues to be shown in ‘khasra girdwari’ even though the general rule is that ‘possession follows title’,” observed the commission headed by Justice S S Saron (retired).

The commission added it affects proprietary rights of owners which include even the state government, municipal corporations, municipal councils, nagar councils and gram panchayats particularly in respect of ‘shamlat deh’ land.

Khasra girdawari is a revenue document in which the patwari (revenue officer), on the basis of harvest inspection done twice a year, makes entries like name of land owner, land cultivator, land or khasra number, area of land, nature of land like cultivated or non-cultivated, source of irrigation, crop sown and revenue rate.

The revenue commission said the Supreme Court has held in ‘ Gurunath Manohar Pavaskar vs Nagesh Siddapa Navalgund’ case, “a revenue record is not a document of title. It merely raises a presumption in regard to possession. Presumption of possession and/or continuity thereof, both forward and backward, can also be raised under Section 110 of the Evidence Act”.

In another case, Nair Service Society Ltd Vs KC Alexander, the Supreme Court held: “Possession may prima facie raise a presumption of title no one can deny but this presumption can hardly arise when the facts are known. When the facts disclose no title in either party, possession alone decides.”

The apex court had also made the law clear in “Chief Conservator of Forests vs Collector”, holding that it certainly does not mean that because a man (or government body) has title over some land, he necessarily is in possession of it. It in fact means that if at any time a man with title was in possession of the said property, the law allows the presumption that such possession was in continuation of the title vested in him. Therefore, the revenue commission has recommended to the Punjab government, “In respect of fallow lands or lands where no cultivation is done, the possession should invariably be recorded in favour of the owner as shown in the revenue record.”

Title: How rural panchayats can take giant strides for development
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The story of Odanthurai panchayat in Coimbatore has now become sort of folklore in rural development. Located 40km from the urban agglomeration, it has a windmill generating eight lakh units of power every year. The green power is enough and more for the village with a population of about 10,000. The surplus is sold to Tangedco.

Closer to Coimbatore, Kurudampalayam panchayat had set new benchmarks in solid waste management, much before the country woke up to the Swachh Bharat mission. Down south in Theni, a former woman panchayat president has made everyone pay tax.

These panchayats have become case studies of self-governance and attract teams of civic body chiefs, government officials and NGOs looking for possible emulation of the model. Much of the credit for the making of these rural role models goes to the visionary panchayat chiefs who have shown what local governance means and what panchayat presidents are capable of in nation building.

"Developing a village is not a tough task. All it takes for a panchayat president is honesty and strong will. The constitution provides us everything else," says R Shanmugam. When he took over as panchayat president in 1996, the tax revenue of Odanthurai was just Rs20,000. Within a year, he increased it to Rs1.45 lakh by making everyone comply with taxes. By the end of his second term in 2001, the village had a corpus of Rs1.5 crore with which a windmill was installed. By that time the panchayat had also turned into a hutless one with pucca houses on either side of neatly laid roads.

Chandra Pichai, former panchayat president of Thirali in Madurai district, managed to make the panchayat 100% tax compliant. Chandra who took over in 2011, shortly after the state suffered a severe power crisis, installed solar streetlights across the village.

Despite the significance of grassroots governance, political parties are seemingly apathetic to rural local body elections. While some parties view the polls as a means to gain strength ahead of assembly elections, some like Makkal Needhi Maiam (MNM), which spoke about the importance of grama sabhas, are staying away from the civic polls. MNM founder Kamal Haasan justified the boycott saying corruption would come into play in civic polls leaving them devoid of a level playing field. But the DMK too does not seem keen in the contest.

Panchayat raj expert and Gandhigram University professor G Palanithurai says both the DMK and the AIADMK are aware of the significance of rural local bodies. "But this time the elections are different," he says. The parties are more concerned about assembly elections and have adopted different strategies. "The AIADMK wants to put a party man in every village ahead of assembly elections. The DMK’s approach is to keep the protest momentum alive till the assembly elections and win the polls. Once they form the government, local body chiefs irrespective of their political affiliation have to fall in line with the ruling party," he says.

Experts, however, say it is time panchayat presidents are given enough autonomy granted to them by law. Political and bureaucratic interference in the functioning of panchayat presidents is a norm rather than an exception. And the first casualty of such political interference is clean local governance. Panchayat presidents also face non-cooperation from the community, particularly in villages with deep-rooted caste hegemony.

Palanithurai says the primary function of the panchayat chief is to work for economic development of the village. Second, to administer social justice, then democratizing community and finally involving the community in governance. "But this is easier said than done," he says.

Not always are panchayat chiefs efficient. From managing funds disbursed by the state and Union finance commissions along with the village’s self-generated revenue and funds allotted for specific schemes, to preparing plan documents, the responsibilities of a panchayat president are vast. "He should be a people’s person and at the same time should be able to interact with the MLAs, MPs and senior bureaucrats," says Shanmugam.

Experts say the government should begin training panchayat presidents. "Nowhere are panchayat presidents trained. The powers bestowed on them are ample and so are the responsibilities. They need training in rules, regulations, fund management and administration,’’ says S Singarayar, programme leader of Madurai-based Dhan foundation, who has conducted training for women panchayat chiefs.

Title: Syro-Malabar Synod may take up liturgy alteration; laity meet today
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kochi: The age-old debate over liturgy in Syro-Malabar Church has become active again with reports about the Synod of the Church, set to be held from January 7 to 15 here, having liturgy as an item in its agenda.

Ernakulam-Angamaly archdiocese has constituted a special liturgical committee and would hold a meeting at Kaloor Renewal Centre on Thursday to discuss the issue with the laity, sources said.

The issue pertains to the difference in conducting masses in dioceses under the Syro-Malabar Church (SMC). In Ernakulam-Angamaly archdiocese (and most other dioceses to the north of Ernakulam), the celebrant faces the laity during the mass.

However, Changanassery Archdiocese (and most dioceses to the south of Ernakulam) has the celebrant facing the altar during the service.

“What we understand now is that one among the detail in the agenda of the upcoming synod is to create a uniform liturgy. The text of the liturgy is the same for all under the SMC. Some of the options in the text are being used by dioceses like the Ernakulam-Angamaly archdiocese to conduct the service facing the public, just like the global Catholic Church. We want to continue with this. If at all there is a need for uniformity, then it is better for the other dioceses to also adopt our way,” said a priest of the Ernakulam-Angamaly archdiocese. In Malankara Syrian churches (Jacobite and Orthodox), the celebrant faces the altar while the Latin catholic church has the celebrants facing the laity.

Official sources with the Syro-Malabar Church said the agenda of the synod is yet to be released. “They (Ernakulam-Angamaly priests) might have got a hint about it (agenda) from discussions held at respective dioceses ahead of the synod. However, it is too early to comment on it as even the agenda is not out,” said an official source.

Meanwhile, Almaya Munnettam (laity uprising), an organization of the laity at Ernakulam Angamaly archdiocese, said in a communiqué that the liturgy reformation is to hide the delay in restitution in connection with the losses incurred by the archdiocese in the controversial land deals.

The group demanded a continuation of the liturgy presently in place in the archdiocese and immediate implementation of restitution.

Title: Hyderabad: Woman succumbs to burns, partner booked
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 37-year-old woman from Chennai, who set herself ablaze outside Panjagutta police station on Tuesday, succumbed to burns on Wednesday while undergoing treatment at Osmania General Hospital. She had suffered 78% burns

Following the death of Lokeshwari, police altered the case from Section 309 (attempt to commit suicide ) to sections 417 and 420 (cheating) and 306 (abetting the commission of suicide) of the IPC. A case was booked against Praveen Kumar, the city-based businessman, and her partner. Police teams went to his house in Warasiguda but it was locked.

On Tuesday night, Lokeshwari’s dying declaration was recorded by a magistrate at the hospital. Before setting herself on fire, Lokeshwari wrote a petition addressing Panjagutta police. “She stated that Praveen had duped her. Lokeshwari alleged that Praveen exploited her by promising to marry her,” Panjagutta ACP Tirupatanna said.

Lokeshwari married Srinivas in 2000. He deserted her a few years later. In 2012, she met Praveen, a mining businessman. In 2013, Praveen set up a jewellery store in Somajiguda and appointed Lokeshwari as its manager. In 2014, Praveen lodged a complaint against Lokeshwari alleging that she stole 23.5 tola gold from the shop. Lokeshwari was arrested and later they made a compromise at the Lok Adalat.

“In the petition, Lokeshwari claimed that Praveen had promised to give Rs 7.5 lakh to her as he had lodged a false theft case against her and got her personal jewellery worth Rs 7.5 lakh. As Praveen was avoiding her, Lokeshwari got vexed and ended her life,” the ACP said.

Title: Punjab: LIP’s Bains says will challenge state’s proposal for land banks
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

LIP MLA Simrajit Singh Bain in Patiala on Wednesday

PATIALA: As the state cabinet recently gave an in-principle approval to amend the Punjab Village Common Land (Regulation) Rules, 1964, to create land banks in rural areas to boost industrial development, Lok Insaaf Party (LIP) MLA Simarjit Singh Bains on Wednesday said his party would fight the amendments as it was an attempt to grab village common land.

Interacting with media here, Bains said 18,000 industrial units in Punjab were lying shut and no effort was being made to revive these.

“If the government is serious about industrialisation, it should acquire land as per the existing policy,” the MLA said.

He said land was being grabbed in the name of industrialisation, while the fact remained that politicians were now eying village common lands even as the Punjab Village Common Land (Regulation) Rules, 1964, clearly stated that common land could not be transferred in the name of an individual. “LIP will soon file a contempt petition in the high court,” he said.

Bains added that LIP had decided to launch a statewide campaign against theproposal.

Title: Vigilance attached properties worth Rs 101.6cr last year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Chandigarh: The Punjab vigilance bureau attached Rs 101.64 crore worth properties of offenders in corruption cases and arrested 165 accused red-handed in 2019, said an official on Wednesday.

The chief director of the vigilance bureau, ADGP B K Uppal, said of the 165 people arrested, 147 were govermment empoyees and 18 civilians. They were booked in 129 trap cases during 2019. The vigilance bureau had nabbed 13 gazetted officers and 134 non-gazetted officials from January 1 to December 31, 2018. The arrests were made in 129 cases. Among the arrested government employees, 63 were personnel of Punjab Police, 28 of revenue department, 13 of power department, seven of health department and six of local bodies.

The vigilance bureau also registered 27 cases against 57 accused during 2019 and launched 42 vigilance inquires to probe corruption complaints. Three cases of disproportionate assets were also registered against a gazetted officer and two non-gazetted officers. The bureau had been able to conclude 50 vigilance inquiries during the year. Various special courts have sentenced 42 accused in 29 cases under Prevention of Corruption Act while imposing a fine amounting to Rs 14.96 lakh.

He said the bureau had launched a social audit scheme to reveal detailed information of projects to the public in order to check corruption in engineering and development projects. Uppal added under this scheme, ‘citizen information boards’ would be installed by the chief vigilance officers of the respective departments under which information about the projects will be written in English and Punjabi.

Title: Amit Shah to visit MP on Jan 12 for CAA awareness
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

New Delhi, Dec 29 (ANI): Union Home Minister Amit Shah addresses during the foundation laying ceremony of Dire... Read More

Bhopal: In the ongoing campaign to mobilise support for the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), BJP national president and Union home minister, Amit Shah will visit the state on January 12. Shah will address a public meeting and also interact with people to create awareness on CAA and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

The party will also urge the protesters to shun violence in the name of anti-CAA demonstrations.

“Congress and other opposition parties are spreading canard on Citizenship Amendment Act, but the BJP has decided to counter it by bringing out the truth. BJP national president Amit Shah is arriving in Jabalpur on January 12 to address a public meeting and also to interact with the people of Jabalpur and Mahakaushal on this issue,” said BJP state president Rakesh Singh on Wednesday.

Besides, Shah is also likely to give a message to the party workers that Rakesh Singh would continue as the state chief.

Singh said that Shah’s visit coincides with the party's state-wide campaign against the failures of Congress-ruled state. “Shah is likely to give a message on behalf of Prime Minister Narendra Modi that the NDA government is committed to the welfare and development of the public. The objective is to secure the country's border and to safeguard the country's honour,” said Singh.

The BJP is all set to launch a series of events across the state to support CAA and NRC from January 3. Party leaders said that apart from awareness campaign, outreach programme to connect people, discussions with the common man and intellectuals, signature campaign in favour of CAA, foot march, rallies and felicitation programmes will be held throughout the month, said Singh.

“Apart from awareness campaign, the BJP will also urge the demonstrators who were damaging public and private property in the name of protest, to shun violence and resort to peace to extend moral support against the atrocities committed against the minority Hindus residing in neighbouring states,” disclosed a senior BJP state functionary.

BJP has plans to connect 3 crore people under the campaign for which 10 lakh workers and leaders have been assigned the task. By January end, details of the campaign, its effect and feedback will be collected by the national leadership.

The party will also prepare videos of refugees and minority people who had come to India from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh and their sufferings during their stay under government torture. The workers have also been asked to contact social media groups with more than one lakh followers or subscription, said sources.

Title: Stay in Pakistan to understand pain of Hindus: UP BJP chief
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Swatantra Dev Singh

AGRA: Hitting out at Akhilesh Yadav for opposing NPR and NRC, Uttar Pradesh BJP president Swatantra Dev Singh on Wednesday said that the Samajwadi Party chief should go and stay in Pakistan for some time to understand the atrocities faced by Hindus there.

Singh also asserted that the amended Citizenship Act was not against the poor and accused Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi Vadra of misguiding people on the law.

State BJP chief said, “Akhilesh should stay in Pakistan for a month and pray in Hindu temples. Then he will have first-hand experience of atrocities committed on Hindus there.” He added that the SP chief should also read about CAA and NPR in depth. “He is unnecessarily protesting against the Act.”

Singh’s remarks came after Yadav on December 29 said that the National Population Register (NPR) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) were against the poor and minorities of the country, while asserting that he will not fill up the NPR form.

Talking to mediapersons in Vrindavan , Singh said that there is nothing wrong in NPR as it provides simple options like presentation of Aadhaar card or driving licence to confirm that a person is a bonafide resident of the area. He also accused Akhilesh of ignoring his party's workers and promoting his family members.

Attacking Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi for her visit to riot victims’ houses, Singh said that her aim was to misguide them and create a ruckus. He added that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah are only trying to provide a respectable life to people affected by atrocities in Pakistan through the new citizenship law. He also urged parties and students to go through the details of CAA well before protesting against the Act.

Title: CBI lauds police officer’s role in conman’s arrest
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Mangaluru: The Central Bureau of Investigation has in a letter lauded the role played by a Mangaluru East police station inspector in the arrest of a notorious fraudster wanted by Interpol–Sam Peter.

A routine police check by Maruti S V, sub-inspector, and his team, had helped to nab eight members of the notorious inter-state gang, who posed as officials of the National Crime Investigation Bureau, involved in cheating and extortion from vulnerable people. T Sam Peter, 53, a resident of Koyilad in Kerala, and currently staying at End Point in Manipal, was the mastermind behind the gang. Peter, who was under the Interpol and CBI scanner, had committed 14 major offences, which are registered in more than six states including Karnataka. In Maharashtra he was a proclaimed offender of the state. Sam Peter had come to Mangaluru over two issues. One among them was to target a Goud Saraswat Brahmin pontiff.

In the letter, Raguramarahan A, head of branch, CBI, stated that Sam Peter also knows as Rajesh Robinson or Rahul Peter, was declared as a proclaimed offender by the CBI court in a special case. “With dedicated efforts you have arrested Sam Peter in a criminal case and further traced his involvement in a CBI case and informed the same to the CBI for necessary action. Searching for his name in other cases and informing CBI of the same is the epitome of dedication of a police officer. Your zeal and enthusiasm is a source of motivation for others and highly appreciable,” the letter read.

The central agency was on the lookout for Sam Peter from the past 18 years. His alias Rahul Peter is listed in the most wanted Interpol list from 2001, and a red corner notice was issued against him.

Title: She had met police twice in December
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

During inquiry, police found that Lokeshwari had visited Punjagutta police station on December 26 and asked police for her Aadhar card that she had produced during investigation in the 2014 case. “As they could not find the Aadhar card, police asked her to come back on December 27. She gave a petition against Praveen Kumar stating that he had duped her. SI Vijay Bhaskar Reddy called Praveen and the latter said that the allegation was fake as only part of his lost jewellery was found. The SI told Lokeshwari that he will inquire further once Praveen returns to the city from Bangalore. The general diary entry of the petition was made on December 27,” said west zone DCP AR Srinivas. tnn

Title: Hyderabad: Film producer’s son pushes cops, booked
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Panjagutta police booked a case against film producer Natti Kumar’s son , Kranthi, for allegedly obstructing police from performing their duties.

According to the police, at 11.30pm on December 31, a patrolling team of Panjagutta PS received a dial 100 complaint from Kranthi. “Our staff attended the complaint and met Kranthi. While the constables were talking to him, Kranthi behaved rudely and created nuisance. Constables Samiuddin and Anjaneyulu requested him to behave properly, but Kranthi did not listen to them and pushed them,” Panjagutta police said.

SI Vijaya Bhaskar Reddy and inspector Karunakar Reddy, who were present at the spot brought him to the police station for enquiry. Panjagutta ACP, Tirupatanna, said: “Kranthi’s father, Natti Kumar, and his family came to the police station and they too behaved rudely. We registered a case against Kranthi.”

Title: Lawyers slam PM Modi & Amit Shah, call CAA anti-Hindu
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Lawyers stood in solidarity against CAA, NRC and NPR for over an hour

NAGPUR: After a break of about a week, a protest against citizenship law was held in the city with around 30 to 40 lawyers standing in solidarity with the nationwide opponents of the legislation outside the Nyay Mandir in Civil Lines on Wednesday.

Demanding scrapping of the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), the lawyers said the law is as much anti-Hindu as it is against the Muslims.

They slammed Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah for creating rift among communities to hide their failure in tackling core issues of price rise, faltering economy, lack of jobs and ensuring safety of women.

They said people were being misled but the government but it can't “fool” them as they know the law.

Akshay Samarth said if government troubles the minorities here, “our people outside the country will face problems”. “This is an act of polarization. We are a secular nation having unity in diversity. The Act is violation of Article 5. We won’t tolerate this and won't allow this to happen,” he said.

Tarun Parmar said the BJP wants to take away the rights of real voters as they don’t have any. “An artificial wave was created to make Modi the PM. Their success is based on EVM tampering. They are doing this to ensure they always remain in power,” he said.

Ravi Gavai said ultimately poor people will stand in queues to prove citizenship. “The Act is not just anti-Muslim but also anti-Hindu. Look at Assam how 15 lakh Hindus brothers were harassed. This will cause problems for those who migrated, married women the most. Since we know the law, we understand what the problem is,” he said.

SB Meshram said crime rate is increasing but the government is behaving as if this (illegal immigrants) is the only problem. “There are many important issues where government must focus to improve lives. What about other neighbouring countries who are not included in the Act,” he asked.

Title: Administration disrupting stir, claim AMU students
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aligarh Muslim University

AGRA: Students of the Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) have accused the university administration of disrupting their ongoing protest against CAA on campus by allegedly hiding their amplifier, speaker and mike.

AMU students’ co-ordination committee has filed a police complaint about the missing speaker, amplifier and sound system.

Former students’ union president Faizul Hasan said that when the proctor team refused to comment on the missing equipment and denieed the CCTV footage too.

“On one hand, the VC himself writes to students that he has no issues with peaceful protests. The he sends his administrative officials to disrupt the protest,” alleged Hassan.

When contacted, proctor Asifullah Khan said that he was not aware of any equipment missing from the campus. He added that the equipment must be with the students only.

Title: Bhopal: After three months, Boulevard Street thrown open to public
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The Boulevard Street which connects New Market to Mata Mandir

BHOPAL: Boulevard street , connecting one end of smart city development to another, was opened for public transport here on Wednesday. The project lays the foundation of civil infrastructure work for the core area of Bhopal ’s smart city development in TT Nagar.

MP minister for public relations and MLA from Bhopal Dakshin-Pashmin, PC Sharma, opened the road for the public once again. It had been closed for public movement for about three months.

“Smart city construction, which was delayed, has gathered pace. The fast-paced construction of Boulevard street is an example. Some distress caused by the development has been well worth the wait. The government will fully support completion of smart city development in time,” said Sharma.

Traffic connecting Mata Mandir to New Market has been closed for over three months as the underground duct for services was to be constructed.

The street will connect TT Nagar to Jawahar Chowk and then via a small turn will connect to smart road to Polytechnic Square.

“The underground duct has been laid. About 70% of the project has been completed. About 200 metre of construction work is to be completed out of 1,600 metres,” said Bhopal Smart City Development Corporation Limited (BSCDCL) city engineer, OP Bhardwaj.

Recognising the need to limit vehicle use and promote non-motorized transport (NMT). Boulevard Street will also have a cycle track of about 1.73 km. The concept is to segregate slow and fast-moving vehicles and providing designated safe spaces for pedestrians in the form of footpaths.

Street vendors, trees and street lights are all carefully placed along the roadside to create the feel of a ‘boulevard’, thus effectively separating motorised and non-motorized traffic, he added.

Title: Villagers help leprosy-affected octogenarian get pension
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Vellore: Within hours of a video of an octogenarian differently-abled woman afflicted with leprosy seeking the Tirupattur collector’s intervention to get her monthly old age pension (OAP) approved was taken to his knowledge, collector M P Sivanarul ensured she got her sanction order delivered at home in Arpandakuppam near Vaniyambadi in the district by Tuesday afternoon.

Mohan, 40, a resident of Arpandakuppam, who helped the woman get monthly financial assistance, said, “Hamsa, 85, was born with locomotor disorder and was a spinster. Her sister-in-law, who was taking care of her after receiving the OAP for the past two decades, abandoned her when she was diagnosed with leprosy five years ago. She was undergoing treatment in Chennai for more than two years and her OAP was cancelled. She was leading a miserable life without food and medical assistance as she didn’t get her monthly financial assistance.”

Kumar, 54, another villager said, “Appalled after seeing Hamsa’s condition, the villagers under the guidance of Mohan decided to help her and took efforts to get her the OAP. However, officials at the Tirupattur social welfare department rejected our petitions, demanding that we bring the applicant (Hamsa) in person.

As a final attempt, Mohan on Tuesday recorded a 20-second video asking Hamsa to make a direct plea for her monthly assistance and forwarded it to collector Sivanarul and revenue officials in the social welfare department. Officials, including the collector, who were troubled on seeing the video, directed Mahalakhsmi, Vaniyambadi social welfare department tahsildar, to sanction her the OAP.”

Speaking to TOI Mahalakshmi said, “The villagers came with a new petition around 11am on Tuesday, and from the office they forwarded Hamsa’s video to the collector. Sivanarul, responding to the WhatsApp video, directed us to sanction Hamsa the OAP and the order was handed over to her at her house before 1pm. As we knew that Hamsa was struggling without even a change of clothes, we gave her a saree and presented her sweets and a cake box ahead of the New Year.”

The humanitarian act of the villagers and the tahsildar was widely appreciated on social media.

Title: ‘Net subscribers rose, agri production fell in 2019’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Chandigarh: Even as Punjab has slipped overall two places in Niti Aayog’s ‘Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Index 2019-20’ report, the number of internet subscribers in Punjab grew from 52.6 to 84.1 (per hundred population) over the previous year in 2019.

However, mobile tele density in the state has gone down from 124.4 to 122.79 (per hundred population) in this period. Punjab’s overall rank fell from 10th to 12th in 2019.

Besides, the annual production of rice, wheat and coarse cereals (kg/ha) fell from 4,297.73 to 4,169.67. The gross value added (GVA) in agriculture for 2019 was 2.4. The value for 2018 was not available in the report.

“In terms of agricultural productivity, India produces 2,516.67 kg of agricultural produce of rice, wheat, and coarse cereals from one Ha of land annually. The target is to double this by 2030 to 5,033.34 kg/ Ha. While no state has achieved this target yet, Punjab and Andhra Pradesh are nearing the targeted productivity with current levels at 4,169.67 kg/Ha and 3,917.50 kg/ha, respectively,” says the report.

Other indicators in which the state’s performance declined included employment under MGNREGA (%), which fell from 81.63 to 76.12; sex ratio at birth, which decreased from 893 to 886; and cognizable crimes against children (per 1 lakh population), which rose from 21 to 24.3.

The report further stated that Punjab improved its score for districts verified to open defecation free (ODF) (%) improved from 40.91 to 90.91, internet subscribers (per hundred population) grew from 52.67 to 84.1, homes completed under PMAY (%) improved from 0.74 to 28.12, wards with 100% door-to-door waste collection(%) went up from 65.82 to 97.45, children under age 5 years stunted (%) declined from 25.7 to 24.3, and average annual dropout rate at secondary level (%) came down from 8.86 to 8.6.

Title: 4-man train robbery gang from Assam arrested
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Vellore: A special team of the Jolarpet Government Railway Police ( GRP ), investigating back-to-back robberies on moving trains, on Wednesday arrested a four-member gang from Assam in connection with the incidents.

A senior police officer identified the accused as Deepjothi, 21, R Sanjurai, 26, K Kishor, 23, and S Amarjothibora, 23, all from Assam.

The team, after arresting the accused in the wee hours, seized about 10 sovereigns of gold jewels, eight mobile phones and Rs 30,000 from them.

Government Railway Police DSP Babu said that two weeks ago, two sovereigns of gold jewels were snatched from Mageshwari, a passenger on Nilgiri express plying between Chennai and Coimbatore when the train was crossing Jolarpet railway station . Similarly, a three-sovereign gold chain was snatched from Rohini of Bengaluru when she was travelling in an express when the train was crossing Pachur railway station. A week ago, Rs 2,500 and a cellphone were snatched from Mani of Bengaluru when he was travelling in Cauvery express. Following the series of robberies, three special teams were formed to nab the culprits.”

On Tuesday evening, when the Jolarpet GRP were conducting patrolling on platform 2 in Jolarpet railway station, they spotted Deepjothi and Sanjurai loitering in a suspicious manner. Police took them to the Jolarpet GRP station for inquiry and based on their confession, arrested two more of their associates.

Title: Phoolka wants gurdwaras to run ‘medicine langar’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Amritsar: Noted lawyer and former AAP MLA H S Phoolka has sought intervention of the acting jathedar of Akal Takht to issue directions to every gurdwara in Punjab to begin a weekly medicine langar to provide basic health services at doorstep in every village.

Phoolka, who won from Dakha assembly constituency in January 2017 before resigning in October 2018, handed over a memorandum at the Akal Takht secretariat on Wednesday.

Later, talking to media, Phoolka said his organisation Gyan Sewa Trust had been successfully running a mobile dispensary in 20 villages in Dakha and covered four villages every day.

“Around 300 patients converge to gurdwaras to take medicines from the mobile dispensary, which visits every gurdwara once in a week,” he said.

Phoolka claimed that 75% villages of Punjab didn’t have government dispensaries and they was always a shortage of medicines or doctors in the rest.

“We have observed that a majority of patients had issues of high blood pressure, diabetes, vitamin D deficiency etc. But, due to abject poverty, they can’t even afford medical treatment,” he added.

He said he did not expect the Punjab government to provide primary medical care at the grassroots. He appealed to religious personalities to intervene and encourage communities to come forward to help provide medical facilities where governments had failed to do so. “I have urged the jathedar of Akal Takht to issue directions to every gurdwara to begin a weekly medicine langar and ask doctors to provide free medical services once in a week,” said he.

Quoting his trust’s experience, he said the monthly expenses on medicine langar comes to around Rs 20,000 . “People from almost every village have gone abroad and they wouldn’t mind extending a help of $300 a month, which will also take the financial burden off gurdwaras,” he said.

Title: Students start year with anti-CAA, NRC protests
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bathinda: Protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) continued on the first day of 2020 as activists of Punjab Students Union, Naujawan Bharat Sabha and Aam Aadmi Party’s student wing Chhatra Yuva Sangharsh Samiti (CYSS) held demonstrations in colleges across Punjab under the banner ‘Young India campaign against NRC, NPR, CAA’.

Protests were held at Nehru Memorial College, Mansa; industrial training institute (ITI), Guru Har Sahai in Ferozepur; and government colleges in Malerkotla and Sangrur.

A protest was also held at Mastuana Sahib in Sangrur. In Bathinda, All India Students Association (AISA) held protests at Government Rajindra College and ITI. Activists of Inquilabi Naujawan Sabha and Dr Ambedkar Library and Club also participated in protests at Bathinda.

Students are demanding the rollback of CAA and scrapping of National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Rashpinder Jimmy, president of one wing of PSU, said the act is unacceptable since it is against the spirit of the Indian Constitution. “It discriminates against a particular religion. Our Constitution clearly mentions equality on the basis of class, caste, creed and religion, but the NDA government is trying to divide the country,” he said, adding that students would hold a protest at Malerkotla on January 3 and give a call for boycotting exams in all colleges of Punjab on January 8.

AISA activist Sukhjit Ramanandi said CAA was discriminatory in nature and would divide the country on religious lines. “Students of the country will never tolerate it and will continue holding protests till the Centre agrees to withdraw it,” he said.

Title: Andhra RTC workers are now govt employees
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

APSRTC employees perform abhishekam to the portrait of AP chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, in Vijayawada on... Read More

ViJAYAWADA: In a first step in the merger process of Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation ( APSRTC ) merger with the state government, more than 50,000 workers became state government employees.

In a New Year gift to workers, the government has notified the absorption of employees into the government from Wednesday.

Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy had promised RTC workers that he would merge them into the state government if voted to power. Soon after he came to power, Jaganmohan constituted an expert committee headed by former vice-chairman and managing director (VC&MD) of APSRTC, C Anjaneya Reddy to study various aspects of the merger and suggest ways to make APSRTC economically sustainable.

The Anjaneya Reddy committee submitted its report to the government on September 3, 2019. The state government in the following cabinet meeting accepted the committee report to merge the employees into the government. Subsequently, another committee was formed with the higher officials to chalk out the merger process.

On November 1, 2019, the board of APSRTC passed a resolution authorising the state government to take over the corporation’s establishment in “as-is-where-is” condition so as to facilitate the merger process.

The state government has created a new department called ‘Public Transport Department ’ (PTD) by making necessary legislative amendments. The PTD will be under the administrative control of the Transport, Roads and Buildings Department. The government has notified that the PTD will come into existence from January 1, 2020 and all the workers of APSRTC will become government employees under PTD.

The APSRTC workers have held a thanksgiving ceremony at all 128 depots across the state on Wednesday. Transport minister Perni Venkatramaiah (Nani) participated in ‘Thank You CM’ programme held at Vijayawada . He said the YSRC government has kept its promise of merging APSRTC into the government within the shortest possible time. The state government is having many plans to make APSRTC sustainable by reducing debts and by introducing technology enabled services in the future he said. “Our aim is to make APSRTC as role model in the country offering best services to people without compromising on the welfare of employees” he said.

Title: Swachh Survekshan League ranking: Bathinda only Punjab city in top 20
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

Title: ‘Youths are the powerhouse of the country’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Mysuru: The youths should always think about the good of society and they are the real asset of the nation, said zilla panchayat CEO K Jyothi at the Yuvajanothsava here on Wednesday.

Speaking at the inaugural function of the day-long district-level youth cultural festival at Maharani’s Arts College , she said: “The youths are the powerhouse of this country and hence its future. The progress of the nation depends on youths. Hence I request them to work for the progress of the nation by cultivating and practicing good habits. This is also the age where youths tend to take everything for granted and there are chances of getting deviated. Hence there are parents, teachers and friends to guide you and get back to you on the track.”

Mayor Pushpalatha Jagannath, delivering her inaugural address, said: ‘During our student days, we didn’t have much opportunity to showcase our talent which is not the case now. The parents, even though it is difficult for them to afford, still sacrifice everything to fulfil the demands of their wards. Hence I request all of you to utilise this platform to the maximum extent to showcase your talent.”

The mayor also made use of the platform to create awareness about cleanliness and Swachh Abhiyan. “Last year, Mysuru city stood third place in the cleanest city cateogry in the country. This year, we want to make it to number one. Hence we need your support. If each school tries to keep four roads clean in their surroundings, it will do a lot of good for maintaining cleanliness in city,” she said.

In the day-long Yuvajanothsava, students and those affiliated to the department of youth empowerment and sports in the age group of 15 to 29 years are taking part. The participants will be taking part in nine different events—classical dance, classical instruments, harmonium, guitar, classical singing, debate, mono act, folk songs and folk dance. Those who secure first place in the respective event will qualify to take part in the state-level Yuvajanothsava which will be held at Shivamogga from January 3 to 5.

BOX

Rachana Varsha’s drum beats enthral all

Those who had come for the district-level Yuvajanothsava competition were dumb struck with the drum performance of Rachana Varsha. In front of her mentor Raghavendra, she presented a nearly 10-minute drum performance. The rotating drum stick in her hands was a real treat to watch.

Title: NY gift from greens to officials, district reps
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Sustainability: Sahyadri Sanchaya and Rotaract Mangaluru members gift a sapling to P S Harsha, police commissi... Read More

Mangaluru: Instead of celebrating the New Year in grandeur, a group of like-minded people led by members of Sahyadri Sanchaya and Rotaract Mangaluru City visited the offices of district representatives and officials with a gift on Wednesday.

The gift included water in a mud pot , a sapling and a cloth bag . This is to convey to the peoples representatives and officials that New Year’s should not be restricted to celebrations only, but it is the time to introspect and ponder about measures to be implemented to protect the environment.

Dinesh Holla, convener, Sahyadri Sanchaya, working for the protection of Western Ghats, told TOI, “We can expect one of the worst water crises this year. Apart from celebrating the New Year, it is also time for the officials and peoples’ representatives to plan and prevent disasters. Last monsoon was marked by landslides and destruction of the Western Ghats. We cannot afford another similar disaster. Ambient temperatures are rising and water in the river Netravati, the lifeline of Dakshina Kannada, is drying up. We expect the administration to protect the environment. This is the time for the administration to wake up and take up water conservation measures. People continue to use plastic bags, which has to be controlled.”

The delegation met deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh, city police commissioner P S Harsha and Mangaluru City Corporation commissioner Shanady Ajith Kumar Hedge, and also visited the offices of MLA Mangaluru City South D Vedavyas Kamath, MP Nalin Kumar Kateel and Mangaluru South police station. They will be meeting the MLA and district minister Kota Shrinivas Poojari soon. Every gift selected had a message. The sapling stressed on the need to plant more trees and emphasised on the need for a green city. Water is to indicate that the district is heading towards one of its worst water crises and a cloth bag to request the district administration for a complete ban on the use of plastic. The saplings were provided by green crusader Madhav Ullal, who told officials that he was also willing to plant them.

“For a secure future, it is important that every individual takes up the responsibility to protect the environment,” said Holla.

Title: Bronze travellers huge draw at Mysuru station
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Mysuru: The city railway station , already a talking point for its cleanliness, is turning into a crowd-puller with the recent addition of life-size bronze sculptures in its portico, depicting the romance of rail travel.

The statuary comes about four months after a glow-in the-dark “I love Mysuru” structure was installed at the station. Both are now popular selfie points for commuters, drawing rave reviews on social media as well.

The sculpture – ‘Life is a Journey’ – depicts two men, two women and a boy and a girl in various poses, with luggage, tickets and a camera, capturing the scene at a railway station.

“‘Life is a journey’ is a celebration of the spirit of travel. We saw the redevelopment of the railway station as an opportunity to showcase the talent and vibrant art and culture of Mysuru,” said Aparna Garg, DRM of Mysuru division of South Western Railway. The statues are the work of city-based sculptor Arun Yogiraj, who also made the life-size statue of Jayachamaraja Wadiyar at Hardinge Circle and Paramahamsa at Ramakrishnanagar.

“I have made hundreds of sculptures but this was a different ball game because I had to depict the common man and travellers and needed to capture the nuances of each of them, be it adults or the children,” Yogiraj told TOI. “I studied each character in detail and carefully observed commuters for each pose. These are realistic sculptures which are seen more in foreign countries.”

Over four months, Yogiraj studied postures and gestures, built true armatures (structures for sculptures) and clay models with detailed human anatomy. After fibre modelling to get a fine finish, the statues were cast in bronze.

“Mysuru railway station looks very appealing now,” said Ramesh, a manager in a private firm in the city and a frequent traveller. “Thanks to the initiative of the railway authorities and the talented artists, the station is no less than a tourist spot.”

Title: Both misleading people, misusing mandate given to them: Cong
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Dehradun: The opposition Congress on Wednesday launched a scathing attack on BJP’s Jhabreda MLA Deshraj Karanwal and independent lawmaker of Khanpur Kunwar Pranav Singh Champion and accused them of “making a mockery of democracy.” The senior Congress members were of the view that strict action was required against the two “as they had leveled serious allegations against each other, which need to be thoroughly probed.”

Senior Congress member Suryakant Dhasmana told TOI, “Both knew that they had landed in an awkward situation as Champion had challenged the SC certificate of Karanwal and the latter had accused the Khanpur legislator of using castiest remarks against him. Both feared that a thorough probe would find them guilty, so after creating much confusion, which included knocking the doors of high court, they decided to bury the hatchet.” Dhasmana said that by making truce, the “crime or illegal act performed by them did not end. The allegations need to be probed and strict action is required if charges are found genuine.”

He did not fail to mention that approaching the police or the high court is “not a joke. When matters are out of control or extremely serious, people make police complaint or raise the matter before the court. They are not common men. By striking a compromise, they are hushing the issue.”

Another senior Congress member and former state spokesperson Mathura Dutt Joshi said that “If the charges were found true, they do not deserve to sit in the state assembly. This compromise reflects that Karanwal is scared of getting caught, whereas Champion wants to make a ghar-vapasi in the BJP. The Congress wants that both allegations should be thoroughly probed to bring out the truth before the people.”

Title: Fate of Mee Seva owners, employees hangs in balance
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: One hundred and twenty five owners and around 500 employees of Mee Seva Kendras in the district, along with their families, are spending sleepless nights as the fate of such centres remains uncertain. On December 30 Sri Hari, a differently abled Mee Seva employee dashed off a voice message, addressing it to chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy, claiming that he would commit suicide inside his Wombay Colony office. Fortunately, his friends received the message on time and rushed to the office to rescue him.

So far although the government has not made any formal announcement about the Mee Seva Kendras, they fear that the centres might be closed as the government has decided to recruit digital assistant-rank officers in the grama sachivalayams. The role of digital assistants at Mee Seva Kendras are similar to that of the digital assistant-rank officers in the grama sachivalayams in rural areas and in ward offices in city limits. Moreover, these digital assistants have begun their operations from Wednesday and that too free of cost.

“We are not sure about the fate of our business. Even if the government does not officially shut it down, the decision to make fresh recruits would affect our business considerably. Anyway the income from this business is not high,” KVD Prasad, owner of one such centres told TOI.

There are 125 Mee Seva Kendras in Visakhapatnam districts, that have around 500 employees. In Andhra Pradesh there are around 9,000 Mee Seva Kendras with around 30,000 employees.

“If we have to shut down our business what would we do? Most of the owners or employees of these centres are undergraduates and many of them are more than 40 years old. How would they find an alternative profession?” said Nagaraju, secretary of Mee Seva Operators’ Association.

Officials of all the Mee Seva Kendres called an indefinite strike from December 22 and since then all the Mee Seva Centres have been closed.

On April 11, 2011 Mee Seva Kendres were introduced in Andhra Pradesh during N Chandrababu Naidu’s regime. The TDP government introduced such services to facilitate local residents to pay government bills like house/property tax, water tax and electricity bills and to generate employments as well.

Title: Minister launches Kavalan app at Tirupattur SP office
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Vellore: As part of the Tamil Nadu police department’s initiative to extend instant help to people, particularly women, children and elders, K C Veeramani, state commercial tax department minister, on Tuesday launched Kavalan mobile app at the Tirupattur superintendent of police’s office .

Tirupattur collector M P Sivanarul, Tirupattur superintendent of police’ P Vijayakumar, Tirupattur constituency legislator A Nallathambi and various political party men, district administration and police officers took part in the programme.

Speaking on the occasion, Veeramani said, “The Tamil Nadu police department led by our erstwhile leader Amma (J Jayalalithaa) is witnessing various developments every year. Kavalan app , which focuses on the safety of women, children and elders, can be ‘a security ring’ to college-going girls and working women.”

“The app downloaded on android phones should be registered with their mobile phone number, including the details of emergency contact numbers, address and other personal details. On pressing the SOS button during emergencies, an alert will be sent to the police control room with their present location and simultaneously the GPS location will be forwarded to the local patrol unit for speedy police action,” he said.

Addressing the media, Veeramani said the newly carved Tirupattur district is on the road to speedy development. “All departments will get a new own building at the earliest,” he said.

Title: YSRC rejigs strategies ahead of local body polls
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: YSRC is keen to wind up the local body elections even before the nitty-gritty of the capital city relocation are finalised as the party has set its focus on political management in key districts.

While it is hopeful of reaping rich dividends in Grater Visakha Municipal Corporation (GVMC) elections following chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy’s decision to make the city executive capital, the party has started reworking its strategies in Krishna, Guntur and Prakasam districts where it might find the going difficult. Although, the chief minister is determined to complete the process of setting up three capitals through a resolution in the assembly by the end of January, the YSRC strategists are suspecting the process might get delayed if it had to face legal scrutiny.

Hence, the YSRC leadership wants to hold local body elections before the formalities of the three capital cities are finished. Sources said that the decision to let TDP MLA from Guntur West Maddali Giridhar to meet the CM and extend support to YSRC was with an eye on the upcoming elections to Guntur Municipal Corporation (GMC).

Although, YSRC has its legislator Mustafa in Guntur East, the switchover of Giridhar is expected to bolster the prospects of the party as he belongs to Vysya community which has a sizeable population in the city. Although, the party enjoyed the support of majority among the minorities, BC, SC and Christians in the last elections, it is worried about losing base among these sections as the working class has been hit due to shortage of sand and slowdown in construction activity in the last six months.

In this context, the party strategists have decided to consolidate its strength among the upper-class sections in urban areas by roping in key functionaries from rival camps.

The decision to admit TDP youth leader Devineni Avinash into the party and make him the city east segment in-charge was taken with an eye on civic body elections. The party also appointed Kamma leader Boppana Bhavakumar as city party chief as part of its measures to placate Kammas. With minister Vellampalli Srinivas (Vysya) and central legislator Malladi Vishnu (Brahmin) are representing two dominant sections, YSRC is looking for a strong face from Muslim and Kapu communities to expand its footprint.

The party might also be required to promote a strong functionary from the SCs to make a visible presence among these sections in the city.

According to sources, YSRC is holding negotiations with key TDP functionaries in Prakasam district. Meanwhile, the state government has almost finalized reservations to the posts of panchayats in all the districts. Collectors have finalized the reservations and sent the lists to the government.

The state government might advance the municipal elections in case the high court did not give its green signal for increased quota for the BCs in panchayaths.

Title: Long-time foes Champion, Karanwal ‘bury hatchet’ in new yr
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Dehradun: Long-time warring colleagues, Deshraj Karanwal and Kunwar Pranav Singh Champion, have called it a truce on the first day of new year and are now “friends forever”.

Burying their hatchet at a joint press conference in Dehradun on Wednesday, Jhabreda BJP legislator Karanwal and expelled Khanpur MLA Champion, who were fighting legal battles which often spilled over on to public arena, said they have decided to iron out their differences and “withdraw all the cases”.

“All the misunderstandings between us have been sorted out,” Champion said, amid the newly-found bonhomie. Champion was expelled from the BJP last July after a video of him dancing with guns was widely circulated.

Champion, who has now vowed to be friends with Karanwal and withdraw all the cases filed against each other, has been trying to stage a comeback in the BJP. But, sources said the police case registered against him by Karnwal had made his return difficult.

BJP sources said that Champion had sought CM’s help in resolving his differences with Karanwal which seems to have worked, at least for now, with the two men addressing the media together. Karanwal even said, “I will withdraw the cases, including the one registered under the SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, and Champion will withdraw cases filed against me. Now, we are friends forever.”Champion had filed cases against Karanwal mainly raising questions on the validity of his SC certificates and contesting from a reserved constituency.

“He now regrets filing the cases and has promised to work constructively,” added Karanwal.

Notably, there has been “truce” in the past, too, which didn’t last for long. “The two had announced a truce at the CM’s residence last year. But, things soon fell apart. After today’s joint press conference it looks like the party wants both the legislators to work together,” said a senior BJP leader.

Title: Nepal consignments contribute to growth of Vizag Port in ’19
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Imports to the land-locked Himalayan country of Nepal played a pivotal role in the growth of Visakhapatnam port in 2019. Among the around 1,78,000 consignments imported through the port, 33, 647 of them were bound for Nepal.

“Growth at container terminal has consistently compounded at an annual growth rate of 22% since inception. The year on year growth from FY15 to FY19 has been impressive too, at 16%. Thanks to container movements to Nepal that played a pivotal role in the increase in import ,” said a senior official from Visakha Container Terminal, the sole agency responsible for handling the container terminal of Visakhapatnam Port.

Officials said, traditionally, Nepal used to import essential commodities through the Kolkata Port. It was in 2017 that customs granted permission to Nepal to import via Visakhapatnam as well. And, gradually, in 2019 the Visakhapatnam Port actually handled more imports to Nepal than Kolkata Port.

“Being a riverine port the turnaround time at the Kolkata Port is three to four days. On the other hand at the container terminal in Visakhapatnam import goods get cleared within four hours. So Nepal started importing through Visakhapatnam in 2017 and in 2019 we actually handled 52% of Nepal imports through India,” the official added.

Nepal mostly imports food products, pulses, electronic goods and machineries. A major part of these imports are from the United States of America.

“To facilitate imports to Nepal, shipping line major Maersk initiated a dedicated service in 2018 to transfer the imported commodities from Visakhapatnam to Birgunj in Nepal by train. In Birgunj the goods are handed over to Nepalese importers,” stated an official.

In fact, to provide safety and security to the goods bound for Nepal, Indian customs had introduced radio-frequency identification (RFID) technology early in 2019. All containers carrying the imported goods are fitted with this technology. It helps customs officials to locate the containers in transit wherever they are in India. “Going by the figure till December 2019, this fiscal the container terminal in Visakhapatnam is all set to cross the 0.5 million TEU mark and it goes beyond doubt that imports to Nepal played a significant role in the growth,” said an official.

Title: High spirits and tradition define celebrations as city greets 2020...
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Vijayawada: Residents of the city rang in the new year in style with special parties and events organised by hotels on Tuesday night. Large numbers of youth visited Mahatma Gandhi Road, which wore a festive look.

St Paul’s Lutheran Church and other churches organised a special mass to welcome the new year while some youth marked the occasion by distributing sweets and blankets to the destitute.

At Sai Baba temples near Mutyalampadu and Stella College, devotees lined up late on Tuesday night, waiting for darshan. Temple committees organised special prayers for peace and prosperity in 2020. Special prayers, however, were stalled at the Dasanjaneya Swamy temple in Machavaram where temple authorities provided ‘seeghra darshan’ to clear the rush of devotees.

“Visiting the temple on the first day of the new year and offering prayers is an old tradition. We have performed a special ‘abhishekam’ for Sai Baba and made a special offering,” said Madhava Sharma, a priest at Gunadala Saibaba Temple.

Meanwhile, city police filed 55 cases of drunk driving . Checks were held between 11 pm and 4 am at 13 major junctions and 32 two-wheelers, one autorickshaw and three cars were seized. Police also set up barricades and medians on busy roads to control rash driving.

Deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Nagaraju monitored special checks across the city.

Title: Mayor Gama inaugurates DMCs helpline service
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Dehradun: Mayor Sunil Uniyal Gama inaugurated Dehradun Municipal Corporation’s (DMC’s) helpline service on Wednesday. The 24x7 helpline service has been launched to help city residents inform DMC officials about the civic issues in their areas. The residents can register complaints and get them addressed without visiting the DMC office. The complaints will be addressed in a time-bound manner, say civic officials. Proper time frames have been set for addressing particular type of civic issues, they added.

“The helpline service will make sure that the residents can easily register their complaints which will be solved within a short period of time. We will also be focusing on improving services in all 100 wards of the city. And by the end of this year, there will be 10 Smart Vending Zones running in Dehradun. The DMC will achieve far greater success in 2020,” said Gama.

Title: ‘Save AP’ rangolis come up in capital region
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Vijayawada: While merrymaking marked new year festivities in the city, residents of the 29 villages in the Amaravati capital region painted rangolis with a ‘save Amaravati, save Andhra Pradesh’ to welcome 2020.

Farmers in the capital region skipped new year celebrations as a mark of protest against the three capital cities proposal, and instead opted to express their grievances through rangolis.

A rangoli competition with a ‘save Amaravati, save Andhra Pradesh’ theme was conducted at BRTS road by Amaravati Pari Rakshana Samithi (APRS) and Helping Hands NGO. Thirty participants from the city made rangolis highlighting the problems of farmers in the region.

“Amaravati doesn’t belong to a single community or a religion. It is the spirit of the public of the 13 districts of Andhra Pradesh. While the idea of decentralisation is appreciable, shifting the capital out of Amaravati is not acceptable. Farmers of this region sacrificed their land for the sake of the capital and have now lost their means of livelihood. I have tried to depict this through my rangoli,” said Yalamanchali Vijayalakshmi, who won a prize in the competition.

Meanwhile, Andhra Pradesh Congress vice-president and APRS functionary Sunkara Padmasri said they are conducting a series of protests and programmes to explain the plight of farmers in the Amaravati capital region.

“The state government is meting out injustice to the Amaravati region in the name of decentralisation. Proposal for three capitals is baseless and we will continue our agitation till the government withdraws its proposal,” Padmasri said.

Title: Women empowerment top priority for Canadian minister with roots in Vizag
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Jason Kenney-led United Conservative Party’s landmark victory over the New Democratic Party in Alberta, in the spring of 2019, wasn’t one of the biggest political news of the year for Canada alone. Back home too, it marked a historic moment with two people of Telugu-origin, making it to the cabinet — Prasad Panda , minister of infrastructure and Leela Sharon Aheer , minister of culture, multiculturalism and status of women.

Reportedly, both were first elected to the legislative assembly of the Canadian province, Alberta, in 2015. While Panda was born in Guntur’s Sangam Jagarlamudi village, Aheer has her roots in Visakhapatnam .

On her recent trip to the city, TOI caught up with the 49-year-old Aheer who spoke about her political journey, which began 14 years ago.

“Back then, I used to volunteer for political events but never looked at it as a career option. I was running my private business,” she said, admitting that her friends nudged her to take the plunge, given her interest in it. Following an aggressive campaign, she was elected to the Alberta assembly in 2015.

Now, on her debut run as minister, Aheer has her agenda well chalked out: women’s empowerment, both at home and in society.

“One thing that always disturbs me is the way women and children continue to be abused all over the world. It is time for real talk about the violation of human rights and speak out candidly about honour killings, human trafficking, child marriage and female genital mutilation. We need to engage all ages and genders to have conversations on how we can protect our rights,” said Aheer who declared November 19, 2019 as ‘Women’s Entrepreneurship Day’ in Alberta, at the first-ever Canada-based Women’s Entrepreneurship summit. The day aims to encourage women entrepreneurs and create opportunities for the world to recognise the many ways women contribute to the economy.

Persuading women to join politics is also on her to-do list. Incidentally, for the first time, 44% of the contestants in the 2019 elections were women. “Although 51% population of Canada comprises women, until last elections, only a handful of them joined politics. Women felt they are incapable and lacked self-confidence. Last year our aim was to encourage more women to contest,” said Aheer while assuring unity, collaboration and inclusion within her province. “Be it people who cannot speak English or are new to the country, we want them to feel at home and not alienated. I urge the youth who are our future to engage in policy because it is the need of the hour. Wonders can happen if the people and government collaborate and work for a better world to live in,” the minister said appealing to people to break down barriers of religion, caste, economic status and gender.

As the conversation veered towards India, Aheer said, “India is my second home and I feel my heart beat in India. I feel so close to my family and the people of this country, especially the South. I feel at home because I am home,” Aheer said.

Title: 55 drunk driving cases in Vijayawada, 12 die across AP
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Despite cops issuing warnings to people ahead of the New Year and conducting a special drive from Tuesday evening till Wednesday morning, 12 persons died in road accidents across the state and 794 cases were registered for drunk driving .

A total of 72 accidents were reported—fatal (11), non-fatal (19) and 30 people suffered injuries.

In Vijayawada, 55 cases were registered. Drives were conducted in places such as MG Road, Eluru Road, One-Town, Prakasam Barrage, Ramavarrapadu, Benz Circle and NTR Circle in Vijayawada. Cops targeted highways at both entry and exit points against drunk driving.

In all, 794 vehicles were seized for the offence. The injured persons due to various mishaps were rushed to respective local government hospitals for treatment.

Not surprisingly, the least number of drunk driving cases were registered in Tirupati where alcohol is banned, particularly on Tirumala hill. Officials said that they would recommend suspension of licenses for habitual offenders and imprisonment.

The highest number of cases were registered in Vizag city—237, followed by 83 in Guntur city . According to police sources, they conducted special drives across all 18 district police units.

The fatal mishaps that took place during the New Year’s Eve were at Vizag city, East Godavari, Rajahmundry, West Godavari, Guntur urban, Guntur rural, Prakasam, Kadapa, Anantapur and Chittoor police units. Maximum non-fatal mishaps took places in East Godavari and Vizag rural police units. Cops said they had cracked down on illegal sale of liquor at various places in the state after midnight.

Title: Centre releases Rs 267cr to build roads, bridges in Maoist strongholds in Andhra
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The central government has released Rs 267 crore to build infrastructure in Maoists strongholds. The work will be taken up under the Road Connectivity Project for Left Wing Extremism Affected Area (RCPLWE) and the funds were released through the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana.

The funds will be used to lay 44 roads , around 400 km, and two bridges . The project is set to be taken up in phases and completed by the end of this year. While tenders have been finalised for a few roads, the remaining would be finalised in a month or two.

The central government has chalked out plans to provide road connectivity in Maoist affected areas in seven states to curb Maoist menace. As part of it, in Andhra Pradesh the project will be taken up mainly in East Godavari and Visakhapatnam.

According to sources, more than 1,500 villages or hamlets, which are Maoist strongholds, lack road, in the Visakha Agency lack proper roads.

Presently, the second phase of work has been taken up that includes 35 roads, around 165 km, with an estimated cost of around Rs 120 crore. The third phase will include laying of 410 km of roads and the remaining roads will be laid after the remaining funds are released by the end of August, sources said.

Title: Three dead, including 7-year-old, in Chittoor tractor mishap
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Two women and a seven-year-old child died on the spot while 15 others suffered injuries after a tractor lost control near Modalapalli village under Tavanapalli mandal in Chittoor district on Wednesday.

The deceased were identified as Bujjamma (49), Lokamma (45) and Gautam (7). According to cops, the incident happened in the afternoon when the tractor was heading towards Siddeswara Swamy Temple. Cops said the tractor overturned while turning at a hairpin bend.

Locals rushed to their aid and managed to rescue some of the injured who were stuck under the vehicle. Upon information, cops reached the spot and rushed the injured to a government hospital for treatment. A case under section 304A of the IPC (causing death due to negligence) has been registered. All three bodies were sent for postmortem .

Title: SRR College alumni reunite after over 40 years
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: Nostalgia marked the meeting of 40 alumni of Sri Raja Rangayya Apparao and Chunduru Venket Reddy (SRR&CVR) College who came together again four decades after they left the college campus.
