Alumni of the BCom (English medium) batch of 1978, now working in various professions, had not met after they graduating from college. The idea to reunite at the college came about after former batchmates YV Krishnaiah, Y Ramesh and KJN Gupta started to trace their other classmates. After five years, they had managed to trace 56 out of 75 batchmates.

Following two futile attempts to organise an alumni meet, the three succeeded the third time around with 40 alumni from across the country, the United States and Canada recently gathering on the college premises.

Speaking to TOI, Krishnaiah said, “Coming from a commerce background, most of our batchmates worked in public sector banks. Two of them even worked for the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) and retired in high positions.”

The alumni spent a day on campus with two lecturers, P Krishna Murthy and K Govardan Rao, who were felicitated at the meet.

G Ramasubramanyam, an alumnus, organised a book exhibition with old textbooks.

Principal Velaga Joshi, also an alumnus of the college spoke about the developments in the college over the last four decades. Alumni members donated Rs 1 lakh to the college for the ‘Gorumuddha’ programme under which breakfast is provided to students from economically weaker sections. They also felicitated veteran librarian of the college, Lakshmaiah.

Title: AP fishermen in Pak jail may be released by Sankranti festival
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The New Year is likely to bring some happy news for the 22 fishermen from Andhra Pradesh, who were arrested by the Pakistan marine security agency on November 22, 2018 and have been languishing in a Karachi jail since then. In all probability, they would reach home by Sankranti, which falls on January 15.

North Andhra fishermen’s association confirmed the development on Tuesday after meeting officials of Union home ministry in New Delhi.

“The ministry officials informed us that as part of an exchange programme, India and Pakistan would release a few prisoners who are held up in the jails of the two countries. Both countries have prepared a list of prisoners to be released. The names of the 22 fishermen from the state is in the list prepared by Pakistan,” AP Matsyakara Samakhya president Vasupalli Janakiram told TOI.

The 22 fishermen hailing from the coastal belt of north Andhra — 17 from Matyalesa village in Srikakulam district and five from Bhogapuram in Pusapatirega mandal of Vizianagram district — had gone to Gujarat were they were hired by a fishing company based in Veraval, near Porbandar.

They had ventured into the seas in November 2018 when their boat reportedly drifted into Pakistani waters where they were apprehended by a team from the Pakistan marine security agency. They were later taken to Karachi and lodged in a jail there on charges of trespassing.

“They are expected to be released by the second week of January 2020. However, the specific dates are yet to be confirmed. They would be handed over to Indian authorities at Wagah border,” added Janakiram.

It was the first time that any fishermen from AP had been arrested by a neighbouring country for trespassing into their waters. In October last year, eight other fishermen, hailing from Thippalavalasa village in Pusapatirega mandal of Vizianagaram district, were arrested by the Bangladesh coast guard for entering their territorial waters.

Every year fishermen from the coastal districts of the state migrate to Gujarat in September and return in March as the catch is very low in the Bay of Bengal during that time of the year.

Title: Only Parliament can take final call on location of state’s capital: Legal experts
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Amaravati: A debate is on about powers of the state and Union governments in deciding the capital city of a state after chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy proposed setting up three capitals based on an expert panel’s report.

Legal experts and political parties are divided on the issue. The legal experts say only Parliament has the authority to notify the boundaries of the state as well as the capital city. They noted that the assembly could only make an appeal to the Centre on the issue of the capital city through a resolution and it is the Centre’s prerogative to take the final call.

Article 2 and Article 3 of the Constitution of India confer exclusive and plenary powers upon Parliament to form or establish or completely alter and destroy the identity of the existing states. A state legislature, as per Clause (e) of Article 3 of the Constitution, cannot even change the name of the state. It is within the exclusive domain of Parliament to form any state, set boundaries, and name a state in the Union as defined in Article 1 of the Constitution.

“The power to establish a state’s capital is inherent to, and inseparable from, the power conferred upon Parliament under Articles 2, Article 3 and Article 4 of the Constitution,” said advocate and peasant rights activist Mallela Seshagiri Rao.

The matter of establishing a capital of a new state formed by Parliament by law is not covered by any Entry in List-II of the Schedule-VII of the Constitution. It is specifically because the capital of a state shall foster the needs of all sections/strata’s of the society/residents of the state without any political discrimination as to the development of a particular region/part of such state, he explained. Therefore, only Parliament can, by law, establish the capital of a newly reconstituted state, which after reconstitution and reorganisation by enacting a law, under Article 3(a)(c)(d) of the Constitution, said Rao.

Interestingly, Parliament has not passed any legislation making Amaravati as capital city of Andhra Pradesh after the bifurcation. In fact, neither the Centre nor the state government has issued a gazette notifying the capital city of the state resulting in confusion.

The state assembly had only passed a resolution when N Chandrababu Naidu was chief minister declaring Amaravati as the capital city. Subsequently, the TDP government failed to get it cleared by Parliament in the past five years giving scope for Jaganmohan Reddy to make new plans.

Legal expert and TDP MP Kanakamedala Ravindra Kumar said the state has no say in shifting the capital city.

Meanwhile, minister Botcha Satyanarayana said the government was not shifting the capital city but plans were only to decentralize development across the state in an even manner.

Title: BJP questions YSRC move to shift capital city
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

AMARAVATI: Kanna Lakshminarayana , president of the state unit of BJP , on Wednesday questioned how chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy could take a unilateral decision to shift the capital city without consulting all stakeholders.

He said Amaravati was declared as the capital city by consensus in the assembly to which BJP is also a party. He recalled that TDP, YSRC and BJP had voted in favour of the resolution. He also added that it was Prime Minister Narendra Modi who had laid the foundation stone for the capital city in Amaravati.

He pointed out that the Centre had released Rs.1500 crore for infrastructure development in the capital city which showed that the Centre was a stakeholder in the project.

Several ministries in the Centre including urban development (Amaravati Smart city, housing for poor, UGD in Guntur and Vijayawada), surface transport (flyovers in Vijayawada city and in principal consent for Amaravati-Ananthapuram NH, civil aviation ( Gannavaram , capital city airport development) had released funds for infrastructure development and new projects to the capital city, he said. He added that all these ministries were stakeholders in the capital city project.

Title: 4 armed robbers tie up, gag yarn trader in Sundar Nagar
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Times News Network

Ludhiana: Four masked miscreants tied up a yarn trader and robbed him at gunpoint in Sundar Nagar on Tuesday evening.

Even as the incident took place around 6.30pm, a scared Kuldeep Singh, 53, a resident of BRS Nagar, informed police at night.

In his police complaint, Kuldeep said, “I was at office with my employee, Gurmeet Singh. As my television set was not working, I asked Gurmeet to fix its cables. Minutes after Gurmeet left, four masked men barged into my office. One of them pointed a pistol at me.”

The four tied Kuldeep up with a chair and taped his mouth.

“After snatching the drawer keys from me, they fled with Rs 80,000. Before making good their escape, they threatened me against informing the police,” he added.

After sometime, when Gurmeet returned, he released Kuldeep. The trader narrated the incident to him and asked him not to call the police.

Daresi police station SHO inspector Vijay Kumar said, “Kuldeep was too frightened to lodge a complaint. After he apprised his family of it, his son called up the police.”

As no CCTV cameras were installed at Kuldeep’s office, cops are scrutinising the ones in the area. “A CCTV has captured the four masked miscreants. They came on two bikes. It is suspected that the accused did a reconnaissance before striking, as they barged in when the trader’s employee left and he was alone in office.”

A case has been registered.

Title: Nara Bhuvaneswari donates gold bangles
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

AMARAVATI: The decision of former chief minister Nara Chandrababu Naidu ’s wife Nara Bhuvaneswari to take part in a public protest programme on Wednesday has raised eyebrows as this is her first appearance in the near four-decade-long political career of her husband.

So far she was never seen at public forums either when her father NT Rama Rao or Naidu served as chief minister of Andhra Pradesh.

Meanwhile Bhuvaneswari said her husband has always put peoples’ interests ahead of his family interests. She donated her gold bangles in support of the farmers’ agitation in the capital city area. She said that she was moved by the plights of the women and decided to take part in the protest to extend moral support to them. She participated in the farmers’ dharna in Yerrabalem village along with Naidu.

Speaking to the gathering, Bhuvaneswari said that Naidu had not even taken proper care of his health as he kept himself busy with overseeing the construction of Amaravati and Polavaram projects. He worked round-the-clock for the state and their family would be with the farmers in times of difficulty.

Title: Andhra Pradesh ranks top in health insurance, clean water & sanitation: SDG 2019
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh finished among the ‘ frontrunner ’ states with a creditable third position in the latest United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals ( SDG 2019) report by Niti Aayog.The state stood no.1 in some of the indicators which include health insurance coverage, clean water and sanitation. Telangana stands at fifth place.Overall, Andhra Pradesh scored 67 out of 100 points which marginally qualifies it as a frontrunning state among all 28 states.AP’s SDG score comparatively stands higher than the national average of 60. The state also improved on its overall score by three points compared to 2018 when it was 64 qualifying it as just a ‘performer’.On the other hand, Telangana scored well in economic growth and decent work while ranking poorly in gender equality. Interestingly, despite being a combined state once, there are certain contrast ratings between both the states as AP still lacks a concrete capital city. Some of the aspects Telangana scored over AP includes: wards with 100% door-to-door waste collection; births registered; and population covered under Aadhaar and households electrified.Of the 16 SDG indicators, AP is graded as a ‘frontrunner’ state in 11 indicators, two categories as ‘performer’ and three cases as ‘aspirant’ which is the lowest grade. AP also stands second place in terms of climate action, life below water — marine ecosystems (compared to nine coastal states in India), after Karnataka . AP stands third in terms of ‘no poverty’ with a score of 69 points.Each indicator has some sub-indicators in which there are contrasting ratings given by the SDG report. Some of the major improvements that the state witnessed under these sub-indicators include: internet subscribers, mobile tele density, habitations connected by all-weather roads under PMGSY, houses completed under PMAY, wards with 100% door-to-door waste collection, waste processed, sex ratio at birth and districts verified to be ODF.In terms of the sub-indicators, AP’s highest score of 96 comes with clean water and sanitation. The second indicator in which AP scored well is affordable clean energy and peace, justice and strong institutions. Conversely, AP stands amongst the worst in ‘zero hunger’ criteria despite standing second in agriculture productivity as food wastage is cited as a ‘major concern' in the report.

Title: Decomposed body of man found at City Centre site
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

SUICIDE SUSPECTED

Times News Network

Ludhiana: The body of an unidentified man was found hanging in the parking lot of City Centre site in SBS Nagar on Wednesday afternoon.

Police said it seemed the man had died almost a month ago as the body was highly decomposed.

Property advisers, who have their offices near the site, called up the police after foul smell started emanating from the spot.

Dugri police station SHO inspector Davinder Sharma said, “When we reached the spot, we found a body hanging with a rope from an iron rod. It bore no injury marks. It seems to be a case of suicide. The body is quite decomposed... the man must have died at least 30 days ago. We, however, are awaiting the autopsy report to confirm the cause of death.”

As no documents were found on the body or near it, police are yet to establish its identity. “The body will be kept at civil hospital for 72 hours. We have informed other police stations and sought details of missing persons so that the man can be identified,” said a cop.

Title: CBI arrests DRI ADG, two businessmen in Rs 3 crore graft case
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The teams went to the residence of ADG located inside Marvel Homes on Ferozepur Road.

LUDHIANA: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) on Wednesday arrested a senior Indian Revenue Service (IRS) officer — who is the additional director general (ADG) of the zonal unit of the Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI), Ludhiana — in a Rs 3-crore bribery case.

Prior to ADG Chandar Shekhar’s arrest, CBI nabbed two businessmen — Rajesh Dhanda of Ludhiana and Anup Joshi of Delhi — on Tuesday afternoon from a five-star hotel in Delhi with Rs 25-lakh cash, which they had allegedly accepted on behalf of the DRI officer. Dhanda is a prominent name in the city’s textile circle and has a huge business interest in Dubai, while Joshi is a customs clearing agent.

A statement issued by the CBI said, “The CBI arrested a DRI, Ludhiana, ADG and two private persons, including a friend of the public servant, in an alleged bribery case of Rs 25 lakh. A case was registered against the accused on a complaint, in which it was alleged that in June 2019, Ludhiana DRI had conducted a search at a private clearing agency, which provides services to various exporters. In this search, some documents pertaining to an exporter were also seized. The complainant, a resident of Delhi, submitted a complaint to the CBI that a clearing house agent and a close friend of the Ludhiana ADG demanded Rs 3 crore on behalf of the public servant for ensuring that he would not be implicated by DRI regarding recovery of his documents. CBI caught both private persons while demanding and accepting Rs 25 lakh from the complainant. During investigation, the public servant was also arrested. Searches are being conducted on the premises, including residence and offices of the accused located at Delhi, Noida and Ludhiana. The accused will be produced before the competent court. Further investigation is continuing.”

A clearing agency gets import and export shipments cleared from different departments.

It was only in the afternoon that the agency sources confirmed the arrest of the ADG, as earlier the CBI officials were maintaining that he was under detention. On Wednesday morning, different teams of the CBI visited Ludhiana along with the arrested officer and reached the office of DRI in Ghumar Mandi. Later, they went to the residence of the ADG at Marvel Homes on Ferozepur Road.

The ADG is among the most powerful postings as he has jurisdiction over Punjab, Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh and Chandigarh. ADG Chander Shekhar has had an illustrious career and was involved in big anti-narcotics operations. In November last, he grabbed national limelight when in two separate operations in Kashmir Valley, the DRI, in a joint operation with Army and other agencies, had seized heroin worth Rs 120 crore along with a huge cache of arms and ammunition from the border fence.

Title: Amaravati had potential to be an economic hub, says Chandrababu Naidu
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu and his wife Bhuvaneswari at Yerrabalem village in Guntur district o... Read More

AMARAVATI: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu and his wife Bhuvaneswari participated in a farmer’s protest in the Amaravati region on Wednesday.

Naidu said chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had turned a conspirator against the state and was working against its development.

He accused the chief minister of ruining the people’s dreams of a world-class capital city for Andhra Pradesh .

Naidu chose to forsake New Year celebrations and extend solidarity to ongoing protests in the region. Addressing a meeting in Krishnayapalem village, he said Jagan was acting against the farmers who had given up their lands for the capital city.

“Jagan does not know anything about governance and is acting against the interests of the state,” rued the former CM.

Claiming that all works in the capital city region had stopped soon after Jagan assumed the post of chief minister, Naidu said the three capital cities proposal was made as Jagan was unable to transform Amaravati into a capital. Naidu added that Jagan should tell the public what he had constructed in the seven months after becoming chief minister instead of questioning the former TDP government.

Naidu explained that his dreams for Amaravati had centred on the city and AP becoming one of the economic hubs of the country but Jagan had driven the farmers of the region to seek permission for mercy killings from the Prime Minister, a mark of the gravity of the situation.

“YS Rajasekhara Reddy at least tried to respect the opposition and take its advice. Jagan does not have respect for the opposition of concern for peoples’ issues,” said Naidu, adding that the chief minister was unable to prove charges of insider trading against him and his party functionaries.

Naidu found fault with the YSRC-led government for attempting to tarnish the image of Amaravati. “First, they branded it a flood-prone area, later they claimed the soil in the region was unsuitable for constructions, and then there were charges of insider trading. They have lied to the people on all occasions,” claimed Naidu.
