Title: 13 travel agents in the soup for defrauding city residents
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Times News Network

Ludhiana: The police on Tuesday booked 13 immigration agents for defrauding city residents.

Shamsher Singh, a resident of Islam Gunj, said in his police complaint, “Vatan Arora of Alwar, Rajasthan, took Rs 50,000 from me on the promise of sending my son to Singapore on work permit.” When Vatan could not arrange the permit, Shamsher sought a refund, but the former refused.

Division 2 police station sub-inspector Sukhwinder Singh said, “Shamsher lodged a complaint in October 2019. The case was registered on Tuesday after a thorough investigation.”

In another case, Sadar police have booked travel agent Narinder Singh of Daad village for duping members of a Gatka (traditional Sikh martial arts) group on the pretext of sending them abroad.

Surjit Singh, a resident of Hambran and member of the group, said in his complaint, “Narinder took Rs 45 lakh from us, saying he will help us go abroad. When he could not arrange our visas, we asked him to refund the money. But of Rs 45 lakh, he returned only Rs 13 lakh.” The complaint was filed in May 2019.

In the third case, Daba police have registered a case against fraud agents Prince Shrivastava, Sushil Kumar, both residents of Nakodar Road, Jalandhar; Rajpreet Kaur, Mandeep Singh and Priya, all three of Amritsar, on the complaint of Bharmeet Singh, a resident of Maha Singh Nagar.

Bharmeet said, “The accused took Rs 5.30 lakh from me for sending me to Cyprus. But instead they sent me to Turkey on an entry visa.”

Focal Point police, too, have registered a case against fraud travel agents on the complaint of Prabhjot Singh of Jeevan Nagar.

Prabhjot told cops, “Shankar and Rajbir of Gobind Nagar, Ludhiana, took Rs 4.40 lakh from my two relatives — Lakhwinder Singh and Avtar Singh — and me for sending us to Armenia on work permit. After we reached Armenia, the accused also took 4500 dollars from us, but failed to arrange jobs for us. And so, we had to return from there.”

In fifth such case, Jamalpur police have booked Raminderdeep Singh of Amritsar for cheating Karamjit Singh of Bhukhri Kalan of Rs 75,000 on the pretext of sending him to Kuwait on a work visa. “Instead of sending me to Kuwait, Raminderdeep sent me to Dubai on a tourist visa,” alleged Karamjit.

Division 5 police have registered cases against three fraud travel agents. “Rupinder Garcha of Gobindpur village has been booked for duping Yogesh Sharma of Kailash Nagar of Rs 1 lakh on the pretext of sending him to Canada. In another case, we have filed an FIR against Jaswinder Singh of RS Nagar for duping Sangrur’s Hardeep Kaur of Rs 1 lakh. He had taken the amount to send her husband and daughter to Canada. And in the third case, we have booked Gurwinder Singh of Feroze Gandhi Market for cheating Anil Kumar of Bhamiyan Road of Rs 1.30 lakh on the promise of sending him to Germany. Gurwinder had also given Anil a fake job offer letter from Germany,” said a cop.

Title: Brrr bar on rise in city: At 0.3, it was coldest January night in decade
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ludhiana: The weather continues to be on a record-breaking spree. The city witnessed the coldest night in January in the past more than 10 years on New Year’s Day.

As per the Chandigarh meteorological department, the minimum (night) temperature in Ludhiana on Wednesday was recorded at 0.3 degrees, which is five degrees below normal and 3.8 degrees less than a day before. The department data for January temperatures since 2009 suggests that second lowest night temperature was recorded at 1.6 degrees on January 11, 2017, January 25, 2011 and January 9, 2009.

Among the main cities of the state, Ludhiana witnessed the coldest night as the minimum temperature in Amritsar, Patiala and Jalandhar was recorded at 2.4, 1.6 and 2.1 degrees, respectively.

The maximum (day) temperature in Ludhiana on Wednesday settled at 17.7 degrees Celsius, which is around normal and 4.1 degrees higher than Tuesday’s.

The fog brought down the visibility to 100 metres at 8.30am. It improved to 1,500 metres at 11.30am, when there was mist in the air. At 2.30pm, even as there was haze in the sky, the visibility improved to 2,500 metres.

The city witnessed frost formation on Wednesday morning as the night temperature dipped.

Rainfall is on the cards from Friday.

“Western disturbance is likely to hit the city on Friday. It may cause light rainfall on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. As a result, the day temperature may fall slightly and night temperature is expected to remain below normal,” said Punjab Agricultural University weather expert Kulwinder Kaur Gill.

The meteorological department website predicts fall in day temperature to 12 degrees till Friday, whereas night temperature is expected to rise to 7 degrees.

The spine-chilling cold made residents helpless. “It was cold beyond our tolerance level on Wednesday night and we had to keep heating systems on till morning,” said Vivek Jain, a businessman from Chandigarh Road.

Year-wise lowest Jan temp

2009: 1.6

2010: 2.2

2011: 1.6

2012: 3.2

2013: 2.7

2014: 3

2015: 2.3

2016: 3.3

2017: 1.6

2018: 3

Colder than hill stations’

Dharamshala: 2.2

Shimla: 1.4

Kangra: 2.8

Bhuntar: 0.5

Comparison with North Indian cities

Jammu: 2.6

New Delhi (SFD): 2.4

Chandigarh: 3.5

Ambala: 2.4

(*Night temperature)

Title: Natasa Stankovic and cricketer Hardik Pandya get engaged; the actress shares the post on her Instagram
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput's death probe is been investigated by the Central Bureau of Investigation. Yesterday, Rhea was snapped with her brother Showik as they arrived at the DRDO guesthouse for the third round of questioning. Recently, a news channel reported that Samuel Miranda who was summoned by the agencies opened up about the late actor. The report further suggested that the ex-house manager revealed these details to the CBI during questioning.

Title: Plastic ban put on hold after firms say will recycle waste
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Panaji: The state environment ministry had decided to impose a complete ban on use of all plastics below 50 micron from January 2020. The state also wanted to ban all items sold in small quantities in plastic and non-recyclable multi-layered packaging like chips packets, satchets, PET bottles below 500ml, etc. Rules were also framed to impose such a ban. However, the state has decided to keep the ban on hold for now.

Environment minister Nilesh Cabral said the plan was changed as manufacturers of such materials have now promised to themselves treat the non-recyclable waste caused from their products.

“The different associations of such packaging manufacturers as well some individual companies like Godrej, Hindustan Unilever, P&G and Tetra among others approached us. We do not want to only impose a ban on plastic, but find a solution,” Cabral told TOI on Wednesday.

“The associations and companies said they want to come on board to collect all types of plastic waste which is even non-recyclable. We had a meeting with them accordingly on December 20. They have said they will tell us how they plan to collect this waste. Therefore, rules for plastic ban have been put on hold for now,” he said.

The December 20 meeting was attended by over 30 associations and representatives of companies manufacturing plastic and multi-layered packaging, he said.

Currently, all such non-recyclable packaging is baled and sent to cement factories where it is used as fuel at very high temperatures. Goa does not have such factories and therefore is dependant on other states.

Cabral said that the manufacturers of the packaging material have been told to involve the unorganised sector like ragpickers in collection of the non-recyclable plastic waste.

“Currently, waste like PET bottles are bought from ragpickers at Rs 8 per piece for recycling and depending on the bottle size the amount paid can go upto Rs 20 a piece. The manufacturers will now ascertain a value to all other types of plastic wastes and involve ragpickers in collection of these too,” the environment minister said.

Earlier, to frame the rules for implementation of a plastic ban, Cabral had involved officials from various departments like directorate of panchayats, municipal administration, Goa state pollution control board and the department of science and technology.

The minister had said that instead of targeting every company that sells products in plastic packaging, the government is looking to target companies which manufacture packaging and distribute it to different companies like Tetra.

Title: First in 37 months, no air-safety violations in December: DGCA
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: The aviation regulator’s recent clampdown on unsafe flying practices seems to be paying off. December 2019 was the first month since October 2016 when not a single instance of SOP violation by an Indian carrier pilot requiring action was reported.“There was no incident or accident last month that required action to be taken against pilot. This was a first in 37 months despite the fleet size of Indian carriers increasing significantly in that time frame,” Directorate General of Civil Aviation ( DGCA ) chief Arun Kumar said.The number of incidents requiring action against pilots had peaked mid-2019 due to a sharp rise in cases of runway incursions and aircraft skidding off runways during monsoon. The regulator then audited airlines which saw maximum number of these incidents and ordered action against many carriers’ operational heads and pilots involved in these cases.Data shows that February to August saw up to 11 cases every month, peaking in July. Violations included not following air traffic control instructions; runway incursions, heavy landing causing damage to aircraft; any procedural violation and non-adherence of SOPs. Following the DGCA cracking the whip after the aviation ministry gave it a free hand to rein in on violators, September, October and November saw two cases requiring action against pilots each month and then the figure dropped to zero in December.Maximum number of incidents requiring action against pilots was reported by SpiceJet . On their part, senior pilots say some airlines had a questionable operational record due to their practices. “The way rostering is being done by certain airlines is leaving pilots very fatigued and a tired pilot can inadvertently make mistakes leading to incidents,” said a pilot.They say fuelling practices of some airlines and maintenance issues need to be probed.

Title: Drunk driving cases go up on New Year’s Eve, 287 booked
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Determined to crack down on the tipsy motorists on the New Year ’s Eve, Vizag traffic police booked cases against 287 motorists for driving while under the influence of liquor on the intervening night of December 31, 2019 and January 1, 2020.

The number of drunk driving cases increased by over 21 per cent on New Year’s Eve when compared to the drunk driving cases at last (2019) New Year’s Eve, when 236 motorists were booked for tipsy driving.

Speaking to TOI, assistant commissioner of police (traffic), MRK Raju said that around 180 drunken driving cases were reported under Zone-I of Vizag Police Commissionerate and 107 tipsy driving cases were reported under Zone-II, he added.

“We have appealed to the Vizagites to not to mix a drink in a drive, and also warned them of strict action if they were caught for tipsy driving. Our appeal seem to have little impact, with the number of motorists caught on the New Year’s Eve slightly increased when compared to previous year, said ADCP (Traffic) M Ramesh Kumar.

However, the strict enforcement of the city traffic police has led to fewer incidents of road accidents on New Year’s Eve. Police said that very few non-fatal accidents and one fatal accident was reported during the intervening night of December 31 and January 1, in which only one person died.

A senior police officer on condition of anonymity said, “We saw that some young revellers opted to be safe and hired cabs, auto-rickshaws, and also the bikes of Ola, Rapido and few others after consuming liquor at New Year parties.”

City police chief RK Meena said, “We didn’t let the tipsy motorists get away easy as our teams with advanced breath analysers changed the location of checkpoints from 9 pm on December 31 to 4 am on January 1.

Sources said that police seized 10 cars, 20 auto-rickshaws and over 250 bikes from tipsy motorists. Majority of the motorists who were caught were youngsters.

Temperatures dipping and the New Year celebrations saw liquor sales increasing in the city on December 30 and 31. Vizagites consumed alcohol worth Rs 5 crore in the last three days of 2019.

Sources said that since liquor shops shut down at 8 pm and bars and restaurants downed their shutters at 10 pm, the consumption of liquor was less as compared to last year.

Title: IIM-V’s digital governance prog set to begin on Jan 6
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Several senior bureaucrats will be sharing the bench at the Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam with their counterparts from the corporate world for the postgraduate programme in digital governance and management (PGP-DGM). A total of 28 professionals from central government, various state governments, public sector undertakings and private organisations from Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Punjab, Kerala, and Rajasthan, to name a few, have enrolled in the PGPDGM, which will lead to the award of MBA in digital governance and management. Among the 28 candidates, 14 participants have more than 10 years’ experience. The batch has four female executives.

The programme is offered under the aegis of the National e-Governance Division (NeGD), ministry of electronics and information technology (MeitY). The 20 participants from the government sector would be funded by MeitY. Ajay Prakash Sawhney, chief secretary, MeitY, will inaugurate the 18-month programme on January 6.

Speaking to TOI, IIM-V director professor M Chandrasekhar said that the courses were designed and developed by IIM-V’s faculty in consultation with leading experts in the domain. “The PGPDGM is meant for experienced officers and professionals who are keen on catalysing the success of digitalisation and digital management initiatives in their respective areas of work. They are expected to lead the change from the front through their contribution to digital governance and management processes,” said prof Chandrasekhar.

Explaining about the course, Prof Chandrasekhar said that the PGPDGM will provide an immersive and active learning experience to the participants. “It will equip them with new knowledge and skill-sets for successfully steering digital governance programmes and projects. In the fourth term, participants will undertake an international immersion programme to gain exposure to best practices in digital governance and management,” said prof Chandrasekhar.

All the participants will be required to carry out a ‘Capstone Project’ of practical importance and with potential for implementation in the digital governance and management space. The project must be identified in consultation with and endorsed by their respective ministries/departments/organisations.

Title: 2 constables’ increment stopped, sr PI gets notice
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: Police commissioner Chiranjeev Prasad has stopped the increment of two constables and issued notice to a senior police inspector of the Vedantnagar police station after an internal inquiry report found them guilty of helping a man recover the money he had lost to a gambler.

“After carrying out an internal probe, two constables were found guilty of misconduct. As a punishment, we have stopped their increment for one year, and have also served a show-cause notice to an inspector,” Prasad told TOI on Wednesday.

The police department was rattled when the two constables were accused of going to a gambling den and assaulting a man before snatching the money he had won in gambling from their friend in the first week of December 2019.

The constables allegedly assaulted the gambler and took back Rs 1.18 lakh, which one of the constable’s friend had lost during gambling. The alleged incident took place in the Kanchanwadi area falling under the limits of Satara area police station.

According to police, the gambling den was being run from a flat. The man who lost money dialled the police constable, who incidentally happened to be at a nearby shopping mall, along with his woman friend. He, along with the woman friend, went to the flat. He was soon joined by two to three more acquaintances, including another police constable.

The group, allegedly led by the constables, assaulted the gambler and took back Rs 1.10 lakh, the lost money, out of which a portion was reportedly transferred on account.

Angered over being snatched of the won money, the alleged gambler approached Satara area police station for lodging a robbery complaint against the constable and others. To counter the complaint, woman accompanying the constable alleged that the gambler tried to outrage her modesty.

According to police sources, the Satara police were considering the pros and cons of registering a cross complaint, including against the police constable, a senior officer from another government department approached them on behalf of the constable to settle things. The cops too realized that registration of offence would only show them in poor light as the gambling den was operating in their jurisdiction.

On learning about it, the city police chief ordered a probe, following which DCP zone-II submitted a default report, indicting the constables, following which punishment was granted to them and show-cause notice served to the senior PI.

Title: Drive to create awareness on single-use plastic begins
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kozhikode: City corporation authorities have commenced shop visits to create awareness among shop owners to garner their support to impose ban on single-use plastic items in the corporation limits.

Health standing committee chairman K V Baburaj along with the health inspectors visited the shops at Oasis compound at SM Street and Palayam vegetable market on Wednesday to detail about the ban which will be imposed strictly by the civic body in its limits from January 15 onwards.

The single-use plastic ban has not been made compulsory in the limits of corporation due to the favourable court order obtained by the traders from high court against imposing penalty till January 15.

The corporation authorities have formed squads at the 18 health circles and three zonal offices of Cheruvannur-Nallalam, Beypore and Elathur and they will inspect shops to create awareness till January 15 and encourage the traders to switch over to eco-friendly cloth and paper carry bags. The same squad will conduct inspections covering shops and commercial establishments to check violations of ban after January 15.

Only a few shops selling essential commodities, grocery items and fish vendors have started using degradable carry bags and newspapers to wrap the commodities and fish varieties.

Corporation secretary issued an order to schools informing them of the fine fixed to be levied on them on detection of using single-use plastic items to serve food items to students at the time of holding functions at the schools. The health inspectors will impose fine of Rs 10,000 in the initial phase. The fine will be increased to Rs 25,000 and Rs 50,000 in case the officials detects the violations for the second and third time at the same schools.

The civic body has set up more than 100 kudumbashree cloth bag manufacturing units to supply the bulk orders of cloth carry bags in various sizes to shops, malls, markets to meet the demands of customers. It has also set up units to provide steel plates, glass and cutlery items on rental basis to serve food at the time of holding public and private functions to curb the use of disposable plates and glasses.

K Devaraj, owner of Kurungody store selling grocery items at West Hill said that it’s difficult to comply with the ban due to the absence of viable alternatives to the plastic carry bags. “We are using newspapers to wrap the grocery items. Some of the customers have started bringing cloth bags along with them,” he said.

Title: Road near Visakha Valley School to be widened
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority launched the construction works of the master plan road passing through Visakha Valley School , on Wednesday. VMRDA chairperson Dronamraju Srinivasa Rao and metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao launched the works.

Speaking on the occasion, Srinivasa Rao said that chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy laid a foundation stone for the master plan road works on December 28 and they would invite the CM againafter completing the works.

The project would affect a part of the wall and classrooms of the Visakha Valley School, Food Crafts Institute, Kuchipudi Kalakshetram and others. The VMRDA would build the damaged structures for these institutions at the cost of Rs 2.41 crore apart from spending Rs 5.93 crore on the road works. The 1.6-km road connects the national highway and the Vizag-Bheemili road. The VMRDA identified a land pocket near Gudilova to compensate the forest land needed for the road project.

The existing 20-feet road would be expanded to 60 feet. With ever-increasing traffic on both sides of this stretch—which connects national highway and beach road—the narrow road had turned into a traffic gridlock. The traffic from Visakha Valley School also contributes to a good part of traffic on this road. The Visakha Valley School Parents’ Association has long been demanding the government complete the road-widening project considering their daily travails on this stretch, which allows only one four-wheeler at a time.

Title: Steel sector showing signs of revival: RINL head
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Vijayawada: The steel industry, which has been moribund for some time now, is showing signs of revival with the introduction of the central government’s initiatives to boost spending on infrastructure, construction and the automobile sector, said PK Rath, chairman and managing director of Rashtriya Ispat Nigam Ltd--Visakhapatnam Steel Plant, on Wednesday.

Rath pointed out that many steel companies in the world were under severe stress in 2019 and the rise in raw material prices, like coking coal and iron ore, severely impacted the industry’s bottomline. tnn

Title: Admissions at IGNOU open till January 20
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Admissions are in full swing for various academic programmes being offered by Indira Gandhi National Open University ( IGNOU ), Visakhapatnam centre for the January 2020 session, according to regional director Dr S Raja Rao. The last date for submission of admission applications online is January 20.

“Interested applicants from the five districts of northern and coastal Andhra Pradesh, under the jurisdiction of the Visakhapatnam Regional Centre, are advised to utilise the opportunity to take admission into their desired programmes. The link for submission of online admission forms is available in the IGNOU website; https://ignouadmission.samarth.edu.in/. For more details, interested candidates can contact the IGNOU Regional Centre at VUDA Complex, Ushodaya Junction, MVP Colony, Visakhapatnam. The phone number is 0891-2511 200/300 and the email is rcvisakhapatnam@ignou.ac.in,” said Dr Raja Rao.

Srikakulam, Vizianagaram, Visakhapatnam, East Godavari and West Godavari districts fall into the jurisdiction of the Regional Centre, Visakhapatnam.

Title: Man bludgeons wife to death with pestle
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: A drunk man, Kacharla Sobhan Raju (55), bludgeoned his wife to death with a pestle at Chekkanagar in the district on Tuesday midnight. The woman, identified as Kancharla M Kamalakshmi (48), was a government teacher.

Preliminary investigations revealed that Raju often picked fights with his wife doubting her fidelity. These were common especially after he used to return home drunk. On Tuesday night, as usual, after drinking Raju had an argument with his wife that ended with him hitting Kamalakshmi with a pestle on her. He then fled from the spot.

Locals later found a severely injured Kamalakshmi in a pool of blood and shifted her to a government hospital in Payakaraopeta that advised them to shift her to King George Hospital in the city. But by the times she was taken to KGH she had succumbed to her injuries.

Police have registered a case against Raju under Section 302 of IPC and launched a manhunt for him.

Title: Soil tests begin for hanging bridge project
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Malappuram: L&T Infrastructure, the agency which was appointed to prepare a detailed project report (DPR) for the proposed suspension bridge project across Bharathappuzha in Ponnani has started soil investigation for the construction of the 4.8km bridge.

The soil investigation process is aiming to assess the material for the construction works and feasibility of the project in the proposed location.

L&T has already prepared primary-level design of the multi-crore project and it has started the process of analyzing the traffic through Kozhikode-Ernakulam highway including a number of heavy vehicles through the route, to prepare the DPR.

Office of assembly speaker P Sreeramakrishnan, who is local MLA has informed that the DPR would be submitted soon after completing the soil investigation process to finalize the location of the bridge.

As per the proposed design, the bridge will start from MES College premises and it will end at a location 800m away from Padinjarekkara. The suspension area of the bridge is 400m. Among the four lanes of the bridge, two lines would be used for vehicle traffic and other two lanes would be used as cycle tracks and viewpoints. Entertainment parks also would be set up on the banks of river in Padinjarekkara and Ponnani. A bridge café would also be set up.

Kerala Infrastructure Investment Fund Board (KIIFB) has sanctioned Rs 236 crore for the project which would be a part of the proposed coastal highway connecting Thiruvananthapuram with Kasaragod. The bridge would be first of its kind in the state and it would be modelled after the Howrah suspension bridge in Kolkata. The four-lanes would be completely used for vehicle traffic when the coastal highway develops into four lanes.

The total estimated cost of the project, which is to come up across the river at the estuary where Bharathappuzha and Ponnani river converge with Arabian sea, is Rs 236 crore. The project is being jointly implemented by harbour, fisheries, PWD and national highway departments.

Government is planning to appoint E Sreedharan, as chief coordinator of the project. TNN

Title: Vizagites call for massive public events to be moved away from the beach
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Citizens and environmentally conscious netizens are taking to social media to protest against the conducting of Visakha Utsav and such fests on the Beach and the adjacent Beach Road. They have appealed to the city administration to not conduct every event on the beach and make sure some events are conducted at venues in others parts of Vizag too.

Apart from severely inconveniencing the residents in these areas and crippling traffic movement, such fests are also adding a lot of trash to the seas and beach, a resident said.

Environmentalist and long-time resident of Pandurangapuram, Sohan Hatangadi said, “Visakha Utsav is conducted at a huge expenditure. It is more of a political propaganda with little impact on inbound tourism. Why can’t we have Vizag Utsav in places like Pendurthi, Anandapuram, Gajuwaka or Malkapuram? It was shameful to see that all the food stalls set up during the utsav left the leftover food and plastic cutlery strewn across the beach and didn’t take any responsibility of cleaning it.”

“Ecologically-sensitive sites like the sea get ravaged during such events. Tonnes of plastic and garbage end up in the sea and on the beaches. Marine life including fish and turtle are impacted. It blocks traffic on all approach roads, even obstructs ambulances. Residents have to put up with constant honking and high exhaust emission levels,” Hatangadi added.

Retired vice chancellor of Nagarjuna University prof V Balamohandas said, “During the Visakha Utsav, it took me around half an hour by car to reach Vuda Children’s Arena from Circuit House, (a distance of less than 500 metres) because the police stopped the traffic to enable convoys of ministers to reach the beach. The government should pass a GO stating that the police should not obstruct the traffic for ministers.”

A top bureaucrat, with several years of experience of working in Vizag, also remarked that planning and better traffic management needs a lot of improvement for the city to be able to host such fests and events.

Citizens like Pratap Singh Tomer pointed out that such fests can be held at multiple locations so that all Vizagites and tourists from elsewhere can visit without having to go through the traffic nightmare. Trade and business all over the city can benefit.

In fact, according to reliable sources, a commander from the Indian Navy had advised the traffic department regarding managing the traffic. The naval officer had suggested parking be done the way the Eastern Naval Command (ENC) does during Navy Day. But his advice was ignored.

Title: Hingoli’s ZP school built of dry grass and sticks
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: In a time where schools have adequate facilities with proper buildings, Mumsajinagar village of Sengaon tehsil in Hingoli district has a zilla parishad school which is a shack made up of dry grass.

This school is the only school in the vicinity of the village which has a predominant tribal population of 350. The other school are relatively well-built which is in Ghordari village, about 4km from the Mumsajinagar.

Most of the essential facilities, including toilets, are not available in the school. Thus, forcing the children to urinate and excrete in open.

Residents question on how the students can be taught about ‘Swachta Abhiyan’.

The residents are upset as despite donating 5,000 square feet land from the agricultural land they received from the government, for the construction of the school, the education department gas failed to do the needful.

An education department official said they require at least 15,000 square feet of land for construction of a school.

This primary school, which was started a few years back, currently has a strength of 17 students studying in Classes I to V with two teachers including a headmaster (HM), who teaches all the subjects.

Gajanan Khillare teaches all subjects to the students of Class III, IV and V, while the HM teaches students of Class I and II.

To make matters worse, the shack has only one blackboard.

The students get confused between their and classes of other students. The teachers, with the help of the residents, have arranged for tin shade where students of Class III, IV and V students will be shifted.

Sanjay Chillarge, a resident, told TOI, “It is very difficult for the children to walk 8km daily, to and from the school in Ghordari village, so we are forced to send our children to this school.”

The residents said that the administration just granted permission for the school and deployed two teachers, while they had to prepare the shack with dry grass and sticks. “We have crowd funded and arranged some bench and tables for the students,” said Ashok Fupate, another resident.

When contacted, ZP CEO HP Tummod said, “The land in the village is owned by the people of the scheduled tribe and as per the laid down norms, there are limitations in acquiring their land. The other lands in and around the village belongs to the forest department, which can neither be acquired for school nor is it feasible to have school on forest land.”

The official assured to send a team from the education department to the village to check for land for the construction of a school.

Title: Rythu bazaars to sell onions at Rs 15
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: To provide relief from onion woes, the government has decided to supply subsidised onions at Rs 15 from January 4 or January 5.

The district administration is expecting stock from Krishnapuram (KP) onions in next couple of days.

It can be recalled that the district administration had stopped the subsidised onions for the past few days due to lack of stock. Generally, the port city needs around 35 metric tonnes of onions per day, but around 25 metric tonnes of material was expected every day.

The price of onions at the rythu bazaars is between Rs 75 and Rs 77. Onions continue to cost as much as Rs 100 in the general markets. Damaged crop due to heavy rains and floods as well as a shortfall of rain in some areas caused the scarcity of onions across the country.

Generally, Vizag gets onions from Kurnool and Karnataka. Since rains damaged the crop in Karnataka , the city is now dependant on Sholapur, Kurnool, KP onions and others.

The state government supplied subsidised onions for Rs 25, initially. But the price of the Krishnapuram (Maidukuru) onions decided as Rs 50 a kilo after subsidy. When people opposed the decision, the price was reduced to Rs 25. The government even brought loads from foreign countries to cater to the needs of the public.

Marketing department officials said that KP onions may reach the city by January 4 and they would available in all rythu bazaars. Not just KP onions, the bazaars would also stock onions from countries like Egypt and Turkey .

A senior official in the marketing department said that they would supply 1kg onions for a family.

Title: Accommodation for patients at cancer hospital
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: To redress the problem of accommodation for cancer patients at the Homi Bhabha Cancer Hospital and Research Centre (HBCH & RC) at Aganampudi, a 60-bed patient facility was inaugurated here on Wednesday on the hospital premises. The facility was built with the help of a donation of Rs 23 lakh from philanthropists.

During the inauguration Dr D Raghunath Rao, director, HBCH & RC said, “It is for the convenience of cancer patients who are from villages and small towns who need to travel to city for treatment at our .”

Stating further Dr Rao said, “Bed charges are nominal—Rs 239 per day, which includes food for patients as well as for the accompanying attendant. As the treatment for cancer is lengthy process, people are allowed to stay as long as required. Since the hospital is far away from the railway station, we are also arranging a free bus service for the patients.”

Title: Review meet on land allotment held
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Principal secretary to the chief minister Praveen Prakash held a review meeting with officials of the revenue department here at the office of the district collector in Vizag on Wednesday. He instructed officials to identify government lands in various parts of the district in order to assign land pattas to the poor by Uagadi.

Prakash said that chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had ordered officials to allot lands and construct houses for economically weaker sections. The government has decided to allot 1.5 cents of land to each beneficiary in the district and three lakh beneficiaries have been identified in Vizag district so far, Prakash said.

He also instructed officials not to take over land given to educational institutions, hospitals and religious establishments.

Title: Bird sanctuary to improve tourism sector in Kannur
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kannur: In an effort to improve the tourism sector of Kasaragod, and also to attract the bird and nature enthusiasts to the district, the authorities are planning to set up a bird sanctuary at Kidoor in Kumbala panchayat, as part of the Kasaragod development package.

The place, which is home to over 174 varieties of birds , will be developed by providing the facilities like walkway along the river bank, planting of fruit trees, seating arrangements along with tree guards, solar lamps, toilets and waste treatment facilities, said the authorities. Facilities for bird watching camps would also be put in place.

The Prabhakaran Commission Report, as part of Kasaragod development package, had recommended the development of rural development project in Kumbala, and the bird sanctuary is part of that, said district panchayat president AGC Basheer.

The village, believed to be the root of Padmanabhaswamy temple in Thiruvananthapuram, has many interesting places around and this is one of the natural habitats of a variety of birds, including migratory birds, according to him. Kumbala panchayat has already given the land for the development of the infrastructure and the development would be made in an eco-friendly manner.

Once this bird sanctuary becomes a reality, it would become the biggest bird sanctuary in the district, said the district panchayat president, who also represents Kumbala division.

“When this project is implemented, we expect more nature enthusiasts to reach here and it would boost the eco-tourism,” said Basheer, who added that the Rs 2.7-crore project has gotten the administrative sanction and the work would start soon.

The village, through which the Shiriya River flows, has many varieties of birds, mainly thanks to the ecosystem there. The surveys conducted with the support of ornithologists have identified over 174 varieties of birds, which also include 38 types of migratory birds. Around 160 bird varieties from here have been registered in ‘EBirds’, the online database of bird observations said an official release.

In order to promote bird watching, around eight bird watching camps are organized here every year, with the support of Kumbala panchayat, and the development of the bird sanctuary is expected to boost such activities further.

The plan is to complete the works this year and the works would be awarded soon, said the authorities.

Title: Tiger stays near Ajanta caves for 8 days
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: A young male collared tiger from Tipeshwar wildlife sanctuary lived in the area around the world-famous Ajanta Caves and stayed for about eight days before heading towards the Dnyanganga sanctuary in Buldhana district.

The collared tiger C1, moved within a two-km radius of the world heritage site in the Fardapur and Soyegaon areas around Ajanta caves. An alert about its presence was sent to the forest department in Aurangabad by the Wildlife Institute of India (WII). WII, in collaboration with the forest department, has taken up long-term monitoring studies of tigers and in March 2019 had installed radio collars on a couple of them.

Citing information received from WII, forest department officials said the tiger entered the area sometime after December 15 and stayed till December 25, before starting its journey towards Dnyanganga sanctuary on December 26. Deputy forest conservator Satish Wadkar confirmed that the tiger was within a two-km radius of Ajanta caves and Fardapur between mid-December and December 25.

Authorities say they kept the news of C1’s movements under wraps to ensure that no panic-like situation arose since the world heritage monument is visited by many domestic and foreign tourists every day. They also wanted to ensure the wild cat’s safety and security.

Forest officials were relieved to see the three-year-old tiger leave the area without incident. “The tiger preyed only on wild animals in the jungle patches and did not head towards human settlements and farms during his stay here. Any man-animal conflict around the world heritage site would have attracted negative publicity for the wild cat, which we seriously do not want,” said a forest official.

“To ensure that it is not bothered or disturbed, we had decided to keep the development under wraps,” said a senior forest official, who was part of the team that camped in Ajanta at night. As a precautionary measure, teams of the forest department, armed with guns loaded with tranquilizers, were deployed in and around Ajanta and Fardapur jungle to respond to any reports of man-animal conflict.

Forest officials said the tiger originally belongs to Tipeshwar wildlife sanctuary in Pandharkawda of Yavatmal district and since leaving it on June 23, 2019, has travelled well over 1,700 km. From October 19 to 30, C1 was in the Umarkhed forest range under Pusad division of Yavatmal. On October 30, it was captured on camera in the Isapur sanctuary (Nanded-Yavatmal border). It also entered Hingoli division of Marathwada and has briefly forayed into Adilabad district of Telangana.

Title: Two returning from New Year bash die as car falls into well
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: Two men were killed and three others injured when the high-end luxury car they were travelling in fell into a roadside well outside the Daulatabad fort, 17 km from here, at around 2am on Wednesday.

The accident took place when the men were returning home from a New Year party.

The deceased have been identified as Saurabh Vijay Nandapurkar (29) of Rokda Hanuman Colony and Virbhas Kasture (34) of Pundaliknagar. While the injured are Nitin Ravindra Shirshikar (34) of Rokda Hanuman Colony, Pratik Girish Kapadiya (30) of Khara Kunwa and Madhur Pravin Jaiswal (30) of Shahbazar in Chelipura area.

Police suspect the driver lost control of the BMW car and it fell into the roadside well, which did not have a parapet.

The police lauded the presence of mind shown by Mohammed Nazim, a Pune resident, who alerted the police and helped save three lives.

Daulatabad police inspector Rajshri Adhe told TOI, “It was due to alertness shown by Nazim, who was passing along the the road, that we could save three occupants of the car from drowning. He saw the high-end car fall into the well and alerted the police.”

On learning about the accident, senior police officers rushed to the spot. They used ropes to enter the well. The three men, who survived the accident, had managed get out of the car.

The car was slowly drowning in the silt and mud of the well. Police said there was complete darkness and with no space to get a grip, the trio managed to stay afloat by climbing on top of the car.

By the time the fire brigade teams reached the spot, two of the car’s occupants, who could not get out of the car, had drowned.

Fire brigade team said that the abandoned well had considerable amount of silt, which made it almost impossible for the two persons sitting in the front seats to open the door and get out. Those sitting on the rear seats tried to get them out of the car, but failed.

The Daulatabad police have registered a case of accidental death, causing death due to negligence, rash and negligent driving against the car driver, who died in the accident.

Title: Hike in rail fare & LPG price will hurt slump-hit people: Opposition
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NEW DELHI: The opposition led by Congress slammed the BJP government for the hike in rail fares and prices of LPG cylinders and said the decision would further hurt the common man already reeling under the effects of a slowing economy and rising food prices.

Cornering the Modi government on rising unemployment and food inflation, Congress said it had hoped that the government would give some reprieve to the people. However, the two announcements regarding the increase in rail fares and LPG cylinder prices only pushes the common man into a “deeper financial economic crisis”, Congress said.

Asking when the government’s wilfully imposed “travesty” will end, Congress spokesperson Sushmita Dev attacked the government for hiking railway fares. “Coupled with the state of the economy, the rise in unemployment, and the fall in rural consumption, where even ‘daal’ and normal cooking oil is unaffordable, how is the common man going to deal with this injustice,” she said.

Referring to the rise in prices as a cruel New Year gift to the people of India, the Left parties also slammed the government for attacking people’s livelihoods. “Modi government starts the year. After railway passenger fare hikes, another attack on peoples' livelihoods. All this in the wake of sharp job losses, food price inflation and record fall in rural wages,” CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury said on Twitter tagging an article on the increase in LPG prices.

In another tweet, Yechury called the rail fare hike, “New year gift from the Modi government.” The government on January 31, raised train fares by one paise to four paise per kilometre, depending on the travel class . It also hiked LPG cylinder rates by 19 per cylinder.

CPI, however, went a step further and demanded a rollback in the increase, alleging that this was a bid by the government to give a leg up to the privatisation of railway operations. “National Secretariat of CPI expresses its strong opposition to the hike in railway fare just before the budget presentation. This is an unhealthy practice to delink budget from price rise.

The National Secretariat is of the option that this step is being taken to help new private train operators who are being brought by the government to operate trains on private basis,” the CPI said in a statement.

Title: Cops to lay emphasis on streamlining traffic in 2020
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: The city police have chalked out plans for the New Year starting with laying more emphasis on improving vehicular traffic situation.

Senior police officials said that a plan in this regard is ready and will be executed in 2020 so that there are no traffic snarls and accidents in the city, especially busy roads and junctions.

Commissioner of police Vishwas Nangare-Patil said, “Our aim is to ensure that people make more use of public transportation. If more and more people use public transport, the rush of private vehicles on city roads will automatically come down, resulting in lesser traffic snarls and accidents.”

Nangare-Patil said that the traffic police have already swung into action against illegal rickshaws plying on city roads. “Once detained, these rickshaws will not operate in future. We have already eliminated the menace of passengers sitting on front seats in rickshaws and are appealing to the rickshaw drivers to ply by meter or share-seat system only,” he said.

“The result of the continuous drives against motorists driving without a helmet or seat-belts is quite evident. Most two-wheeler drivers are now seen riding riding with a helmet. The next step is to identify spots with maximum traffic congestions and road accidents and address them,” Nangare-Patil said.

Senior police officials said that they recently conducted a meeting with the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) officials to take steps for solving the perennial problem of traffic snarl at the Dwarka junction.

DCP Pournima Chougule said that a decision in this regard has been taken. The plan involves shifting of the existing bus stand and auto-rickshaw stands at Dwarka junction to a different place.

“All the rickshaw stands are located on the corners of Dwarka junction, thus creating impediment in smooth flow of traffic. Thus, it has been decided to relocate these rickshaw stands as well as bus stands to a different spot,” Chougule said.

She said that the police are also taking steps to ensure that heavy vehicles do not pass by the Dwarka junction during peak hours.

Over the last one year, police undertook various drives for the use of helmet and seat belts among motorists. Further, taking front seats or four seats in auto-rickshaws has also come down significantly.

CP Nangare-Patil said that in 2020, the aim would be to prepare such a situation so that more and more people make use of mass transport system.

Nashik city would get a fleet of 400 buses as against the existing 160 city buses from April 2020.The 400 buses would start plying on the city roads in a phased manner.

Title: Women’s empowerment to be priority for rural SP in ’20
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: Empowering women, bridging the gap between people and the police and basic policing will be the priorities for the Aurangabad rural superintendent of police, Mokshada Patil, in 2020.

The SP has roped in career counsellors and woman psychiatrist — to help the victims of domestic violence and women struggling in their personal lives — for the women’s complaint redressal centre.

These professionals would guide women victims in personal lives, apart from guiding and helping them to acquire certain skills that would make them self-sufficient.

SP Patil said that women empowerment is the key to end gender inequality.

In addition to this, a list of villages, under A-grade are being identified, so that police teams visit during weekly markets and interacts with the residents.

SP Patil has also issued an internal communication announcing that the rural police would pay for the higher education of cops’, who did not complete their education after joining the police force.

For getting recruited as constable, the candidates need to be at least HSC pass. Majority of the candidates after getting recruited, do not complete their education. In order to motivate them, the initiative has been taken. “On completion of graduation and with a certain number of years of service, police constables have an opportunity to appear for departmental examinations and become officers,” said SP Patil.

Apart from this, Damini squads have been assigned to reach out to female students travelling in public transport by sharing helpline numbers.

A special squad of tourism police will be trained in basic etiquettes, communication skills before they are deployed at the tourist spot for the safety of the tourists.

Twitter handle and facebook page of the police would be promoted at the airport, bus stands and railway station.

Title: Sena beats BJP to bag 5 of 9 panchayat samiti posts
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: The Shiv Sena in alliance with NCP-Congress on Tuesday defeated BJP by winning five of the nine panchayat samiti elections in the district.

BJP had to remain content with two panchayat samitis, while Congress won one post. An independent won the seat in Kannad with the help of some BJP members.

While admitting to losses in at six panchayat samitis, BJP spokesperson Shirish Boralkar said it was due to manaeuvering by the other parties that the BJP lost at least two panchayat samitis- Gangapur and Sillod, the party has managed to win Khuldabad and Phulambri panchayat samitis, he said.

He also claimed that the independent who won the Kannad panchayat samiti belonged to BJP as he got elected with the support of the party. Boralkar also said that the situation arose because all other parties have joined hands against the BJP, but this has not gone down well with the voters. He also admitted that earlier, six panchayat samitis were being led by the BJP in the district.

Shiv Sena, however, claimed that the BJP was losing ground in the state particularly in rural areas, where the party had made inroads with its support.

Sena’s Rasulbi Osmankhan Pathan won the Soegon panchayat samiti chairman post, while the party’s Sahebrao Gaikwad was chosen as deputy chairman. In Sillod, Kalpana Jamkar and Kakasaheb Rakde of Sena have got elected as chairman and deputy chairman, respectively. Shiv Sena’s Ashok Bhavar and Krushna Bhumre got elected chairman and deputy chairman of Paithan samiti respectively.

In Gangapur, where the BJP was a dominant party, Sena’s Sunita Kere and Sampat Chhajed won as chairman and deputy chairman of the panchayat Samiti. In Vaijapur taluka, Sina Misal of Shiv Sena was elected chairman, while NCP’s Rajendra Magar was elected as vice chairman. In Aurangabad taluka, Congress nominee Chhaya Ghagre got elected as chairman while Shiv Sena’s Malti Padul was elected as her deputy.

BJP managed to win Phulambri where its nominees Savita Phuke and Sanjay Tribhuvan were elected as chairman and deputy chairman of the samiti. The BJP nominees have registered victory in Khuldabad where its candidates Ganesh Adhane and Rekha Chavan have won as chairman and deputy chairman respectively.

In Kannad independent Apprao Ghuge won the chairmanship while the BJP’s Naina Tayade was elected as deputy chairman. Ambadas Danve, the MLC and district unit Shiv Sena president said that these elections have proved that its Sena that rules the roost in the rural parts of the district.

Title: HC quashes FIR against primary teacher
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court recently quashed an FIR registered against a teacher in Latur district who was booked following a complaint by the school’s headmaster for seeking details of income-tax refund.

The assistant teacher, 40-year-old Dhanraj Shivraj Dhumale, then approached the HC challenging the FIR registered with the Chakur police station for offences punishable under sections 294 (obscene act) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of the IPC. He had also sought quashing of the case and the chargesheet.

Rajendra Kure, the 40-year-old headmaster of Lalbahadur Shastri Secondary School, Shastrinagar, had alleged that on October 15, 2016, at 12.40pm, Dhumale, who was working as a primary teacher, came to his office. Dhumale allegedly used abusive language as well as threatened him (Kure) with dire consequences. The headmaster said the petitioner wanted to ask about an income-tax refund. Kure also contended that when Dhumale went to fetch some weapon, like a wooden plank, other employees of the school somehow held him back and saved Kure. He lodged a complaint on October 23, following which, the crime was registered.

The petitioner, however, submitted that he had given representation to the education department, making a complaint against the management on October 19, 2016, alleging that the management and the headmaster, by name of Bavage, were harassing him and in the incident dated October 15, the other headmaster threatened and abused him when he was seeking information about I-T refund. He had also complained to the education officer that the management collected money in the name of contribution toward building fund as well as annual gathering.

The court noted that the petitioner was also not allowed to resume his duty till the high court ordered the management on March 20, 2019, to allow the teacher to resume duty.

The HC had also noted that the petitioner was not paid salary for months.

While allowing the petition, the division bench comprising Justice T V Nalawade and Justice M G Sewlikar, observed: “It appears that the management chose other ways like giving report to police, which is nothing but pressure tactics.” The bench also stated: “Employees who depend fully on the salary face all kinds of problems when management stops giving salary and does not allow the employees to resume duty. If there are some misconduct, then appropriate steps like inquiry can be taken by the management and action can be taken.”

The court also observed: “In view of these circumstances, this Court holds that it will be abuse of process of law if the petitioner is directed to face the trial for the aforesaid offences. The incident took place inside of the campus of the school. Employees, who are interested in getting salary every month do not want to raise dispute with the management and they support the management.”

Title: Review SLC decision on 50 saw licences, APCCF urges govt
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: The state-level committee (SLC), which grants licences to saw mills, is in the dock for its decision to permit 42 inches additional horizontal band saw (AHBS) to 50 saw mills as it is facing opposition from within the department now.

APCCF & state nodal officer Sanjeev Gaur on December 19, 2019, had invited attention of PCCF (HoFF) and chairman of SLC, raising serious objection on the minutes of the SLC meeting held on November 18, 2019.

The copy of the letter has been sent to the state government, which has constituted the committee as well as the regional office of the MoEFCC, which happens to be the appellate authority against the decisions of the SLC.

According to Gaur the decision taken by the SLC on November 18 to grant more such licences instead of reviewing the 50 licences issued earlier is nothing but afterthought on the part of the then PCCF (HoFF) to defend his report to issue licenses, which has already been rejected by the government.

On November 18, SLC, under the chairmanship of UK Agrawal, the then PCCF, took a controversial decision to look afresh into matters of applications of additional cutting machines instead of reviewing 50 AHBS issued on July 23, 2018. Gaur also contended that the decision to grant 50 licences on July 23 was without prescribed quorum.

It was Gaur, who as CCF (territorial), Nagpur, and the member of SLC then, played a whistle-blower and pointed out that the SLC decision was against Supreme Court directives. Based on Gaur’s report, the state government has objected to the SLC decision to grant 50 AHBS licences in Kolhapur circle.

Gaur contended that in the nine-member SLC meeting on November 18, barring the chairman himself and representative of the saw mill owners, all others were new.

The regional office of MoEFCC at Nagpur has already informed PCCF (HoFF) to take necessary action in conformity with Supreme Court order of March 4, 1997 regarding licences granted to 50 applicants for operation of 42-inch AHBS on November 15, 2019.

Gaur also mentioned that the decisions in the meeting held on November 18 tantamount to brushing aside facts and statutory provisions of MFR 2014.

Surprisingly, minutes of the meeting held on November 18 do not bear signature of MoEFCC representative Suresh Kumar Adapa, raising doubts whether SLC decision was in conformity with government of India guidelines.

Gaur also urged present PCCF (HoFF) N Rambabu that entire issue may again be placed before the SLC in a fair and impartial manner without any external influence.

Rambabu has already told TOI that he shall be taking appropriate action, both as chairman of SLC and technical adviser to the government. “Now it is up to him to save the government from embarrassment,” said sources.

As reported by TOI, permission for 50 band saws has been granted without receiving timber assessment report from Institute of Wood Science & Technology (IWST), Bengaluru & Indian Council of Forestry Research & Education (ICFRE), Dehradun. Besides, as per state government, giving permission for installation of additional band saws amounts to increasing cutting capacity of a saw mill and is against SC decision.

“A plain reading of the minutes of November 18, 2019, meeting makes it clear that the entire story is hatched and there is an attempt to cover up the actions of then PCCF, who, by his position as chairman of SLC, must have prevailed over other members,” Gaur’s objection letter states.

CCF (protection) and member-secretary of the SLC SS Dahiwale confirmed that APCCF Gaur has raised objections against the minutes of the meeting of SLC held on November 18.

Title: Delhi trader kills wife, daughter before shooting self
Content:
Police found the body of Neeraj Agarwal (37) on the driver’s seat while all other three members of the family ... Read More

AGRA: A 37-year-old bullion trader allegedly killed himself after shooting his wife and two minor children inside his SUV, parked near Vrindavan exit point on Yamuna Expressway early Wednesday morning. While Neeraj Agarwal, his wife Neha (35) and his daughter Dhanya (6), were found dead, his son Shaurya,10, is battling for life at a Delhi hospital.As per documents accessed by TOI, Agarwal was facing multiple inquiries from Income Tax department, commercial tax department and Economic Offences Wing for Rs 123-crore transactions after demonetisation in November 2016. Police say that the Enforcement Directorate was also on his trail and he was under heavy debt. “These could be likely reasons which pushed him to the brink,” they say.His family, however, claimed that Agarwal was killed at the behest of his business rivals. “Some people had shot at Neeraj two years ago in Govardhan area and a police complaint was filed in this regard. Fortunately, he survived as the bullet nicked just his car,” said his father Dinesh Chandra Agarwal. The family is based in Govindnagar area of Mathura but Neeraj, along with his family, was living in Delhi for the past one year.“Neeraj used to come to Mathura frequently. His wife also hailed from Mathura’s Jaganathpuri area,” his father added. He admitted that some inquiries were going on against him. “But Neeraj had filed an appeal in the cases and this this could not be the reason for his death,” he said.Police said that the incident took place early Wednesday morning. While Neeraj’s body was found on the driver’s seat of Tuscon, all other three members of his family were on the back seat and had gunshot injuries on their head. The car was locked from inside. According to SP (city) AK Meena, Neeraj’s son was found breathing when the police broke the glass of the car and he was immediately rushed to Nayati hospital from where he was shifted to Apollo hospital, Delhi, as his condition was critical.Meena told TOI that a small note was also found inside the car and the it had been sent to forensic wing for checking its authenticity. Though the note was not clear, it had a mention of some issues related to custom and penalties. He said, police found a pistol in Neeraj’s right hand and he had apparently shot himself on his right temple.Neeraj’s brother-in-law, Amit, told TOI that his sister, Neha and her family had dinner with them and they all appeared happy. “They had left late on Tuesday night for Delhi as their daughter’s program was scheduled early Wednesday morning,” he told TOI. Amit has filed a complaint in this matter and an FIR is being lodged at police station.In July 2018, the investigation wing of I-T department had conducted a raid at RS Bullion and Jewellers in Mathura, owned by Neeraj Agarwal and Neha Agarwal, and found large-scale anomalies during the period after demonetisation. According to reports, RS Bullion had alone deposited Rs 123 crore cash in bank accounts during demonetisation.After the raid, the I-T officials had told media persons that Neeraj claimed to have sold gold worth Rs 37 crore in a single day, however, records suggested that his firm converted black money of people into white by taking commission. In return, the trader had provided them receipt of gold purchase. Also, the trader, had claimed that he had taken gold stock from a firm in Mumbai — Vanity Jeweller — but it was closed down in 2012, much before demonetisation announced.

Title: State BJP chief likely from coastal Odisha
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Hectic parleys are on within the BJP as the saffron party looks for a replacement of Basanta Panda as party’s state unit president. Sources said the new state chief will be named within the next few days.

After BJP central observers — Rajya Sabha member Vinay Sahasrabuddhe and national secretary R P Singh —met senior party leaders here on Tuesday and held discussions with them to ensure ‘unanimous’ selection of the new state chief, speculation is rife that the saffron party may be looking for a face in coastal Odisha for the top party position in state.

A BJP insider said considering the party’s remarkable growth in western Odisha in recent years, now it will focus to strengthen its hold in the coastal region. “Selection of the new state chief may be done keeping that in mind,” they said. In the 2019 Lok Sabha election, the party won all the five Lok Sabha seats (Bargarh, Balangir, Sambalpur, Sundargarh and Kalahandi) in western Odisha besides three others, Bhubaneswar in coastal part besides Mayurbhanj and Balasore in the north.

The state BJP presidents have been from western Odisha since 2004 in a row when Jual Oram took over, followed by Suresh Pujari (2006-2009), Jual Oram again (2009-2012), KV Singhdeo (2012-20016) and then Basanta Panda in 2016. Also, the current leader of opposition (Pradipta Naik) is also from western Odisha. The party may try to do a balancing act by choosing someone from the coastal region, a senior BJP leader said.

Going with such a presumption of ‘coastal factor,’ senior leaders Manmohan Samal (Bhadrak) and Sameer Mohanty (Cuttack) emerge as top contenders. Factors against Samal who was party president twice (1999-2000 and 2001-2004) may be his past controversies. He had to resign as revenue minister from the BJP-BJD coalition government in 2008 over his alleged involvement in a sex scandal. Speculation over the name of Sameer, currently party’s vice-president, was also doing the rounds during party chief’s selection in 2016.

However, given that the election of state BJP leader is just a formality and would be decided by party chief Amit Shah, one never knows which factor would finally work, said BJP sources.

Speculation over the names of former Union minister Jual Oram (who did not find a place in Modi II cabinet), Suresh Pujari (currently national secretary) and KV Singhdeo (who lost the 2019 assembly elections), all of whom have held the post in the past, are also doing the rounds as among the contenders.

“Irrespective of region, the new state chief has to be an acceptable face to all in the party rank and files and someone who inspires public confidence. That’s the most important factor,” said a senior BJP leader.

Title: Counters to get back lost articles in autos
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Commissionerate police in association with auto-rickshaw drivers is planning to open lost and found counters in Bhubaneswar where the drivers can keep the lost articles of passengers and inform police. Police sources said the proposed move will be a trust-building exercise by auto-rickshaw drivers.

“We have mooted the idea of opening lost and found counters after coming across some instances where passengers, travelling in auto-rickshaws lost their articles. Last month, a couple from Sagar in Madhya Pradesh lost their bag in an auto-rickshaw. Our team later traced their lost bag and returned it to them,” deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Sagarika Nath said.

Sagarika said details involving location of the proposed lost and found counters and their functionality would be finalized soon. “We will discuss with auto-rickshaw associations and seek their cooperation. The drivers will be sensitized about honesty and integrity so that they immediately take the help of police to return lost articles of passengers,” she said.

Police are likely to discuss the plan with auto-rickshaw drivers in an awareness camp here on Thursday. The traffic police would sensitise 5,000 auto-rickhshaw drivers on traffic and lane discipline among others on Thursday. “Our focus is to streamline the chaotic movement of auto-rickshaws by some unruly drivers. They will be sensitized about lane discipline, good conduct with passengers and usage of auto-rickshaw bays/stands to avoid traffic congestion,” Sagarika said.

Every day over 30,000 auto-rickshaws ply on different routes in the city. In October last year, police identified auto-rickshaw stands and bays near Raj Mahal Square, Kalpana Square and Vani Vihar Square. Each stand can accommodate at least 40 auto-rickshaws. Only five auto-rickshaws are allowed to be ply at the bay at one time. The bays exclusively work as only pick and drop points, police sources said. However, there were allegations about non-compliance by many drivers of the auto-rickshaws stand facilities.

Police said a private auto-rickshaw association has decided to provide uniform and identity cards to drivers in the city. The association is also planning to develop a mobile application to help passengers book auto-rickshaws.

Title: At 423, 2019 accident toll was highest in seven years
Content: Ahmedabad: The year 2019 claimed 423 lives in road accidents across the city, the highest fatality figure since 2013. According to the figures obtained from the city traffic police, 405 fatal accidents were reported in 2019 in which 341 men and 82 women lost their lives.The figures also revealed that the number of women killed in accidents has all but doubled over seven years; 42 women had perished in 2013. Fatalities rose in 2019 though the number of accidents decreased. Traffic police had registered 1,371 accidents last year; 1,610 in 2018; and 1,888 in 2013.“Encroachments have been removed from the roads, opening up more space for drivers,” said joint commissioner of police, traffic, J R Mothalia. “So they tend to drive at high speed and meet with accidents. A few years ago, people suffered because of traffic jams.” He went on to say: “But today, we have ensured that jams do not build up. So people find clear roads and drive recklessly”.On bad road engineering and potholes, Mothalia said that no survey establishes a link between such factors and accidents.Officials said that most deaths were reported on the ring road and a stretch between Narol and Vishala Circle where heavy vehicles are common.

Title: 16 special trains to tackle winter rush
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The Railways will run 16 new special trains passing through the East Coast Railway (ECoR) zone to tackle the heavy rush of passengers during the winter season.

Passengers who are not being able to get confirmed tickets on regular trains can check the special ones. People travel more during the winter months to spend their holidays. Officials said the Railways introduced the special trains keeping the long waiting lists in mind.

Sources said as daily trains didn’t run between popular destinations, the existing trains remained sold out most of the time. The situation worsens during the winter and festival season.

The special trains will be run between January 1 and April 1. However, two trains — Kolkata-Puri special and Visakhapatnam-Araku special, have already started their journey from December 23. The other trains will start within the first week of January.

The Railways have started running Santragachi-Coimbatore special, Sambalpur-Banswadi (Bengaluru) special and Chennai Central-Santragachi special from Wednesday. It will run Bhubaneswar-Secunderabad special from Thursday. Santragachi-Chennai Central special, Puri-Santragachi special fare weekly special, Shalimar-Puri-Santragachi weekly AC special and Hatia-Bangalore Cant special will be functional from Friday.

Similarly, Puducherry-Santragachi special and Kacheguda-Srikakulam Road special will start running from January 4 and 5, respectively. Railways will run Visakhapatnam-Tirupati special and Kacheguda-Tatanagar weekly special train from January 6 and two other trains — Kacheguda-Srikakulam Road special and Visakhapatnam-Secunderabad weekly special — from January 7.

Title: Woman robbed of gold chain in Mhasrool
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: A woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 45,000 in the Mhasrool area on Tuesday afternoon. Police said that they have registered a case of robbery against an unidentified person.
