Title: Telangana government sanctions 164 more SPF staff for hospitals
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana government has announced more Special Protection Force ( SPF ) personnel will be deployed at eight teaching hospitals and two government hospitals in Mahbubnagar and Nizamabad.

The deployment of police personnel has been a long-standing demand for controlling unruly behaviour of relatives of patients and attacks on doctors. As per the government order (GO) issued by the revenue department, posts for 164 SPF personnel have been sanctioned. “The home department has proposed to create 164 posts under control of the Director-General, Telangana State Special Protection Force (TSSPF) for deployment in government teaching hospitals,” the order said. Of the 164 posts, 132 would be of police constables, 20 head constables, eight assistant sub- inspector, three sub-inspector and one inspector.

Government hospitals have recorded several incidents of attacks on doctors and hospital staff, which triggered strikes and protests. “The decision has come after years of strike and protests by medical fraternity. This was a long-standing demand. Let’s hope the financial sanctions will come early and the posts will be filled up soon,” Healthcare Reforms Doctors’ Association president Dr Mahesh Kumar said.

Title: N Uttam Kumar Reddy moves HC, questions poll notification without quota
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

N Uttam Kumar Reddy

HYDERABAD: Telangana Congress president N Uttam Kumar Reddy filed a public interest petition in the high court challenging the poll notification and schedule for municipal polls in the state without determining and notifying the reservations for STs, SCs, BCs and women.

He urged the court to set aside the notification issued by the State Election Commission (SEC). He said SEC should have waited till the reservations were decided in respect of 2,727 wards in 120 municipalities and 385 wards in five municipal corporations which would go to polls on January 22. He sought a stay on the further process because allowing the authorities to go ahead would be ‘contrary to the mandate of the Constitution’. SEC had announced that a notification would be issued on January 7, nominations process taken up between January 8 and 10. Poll result will be out on January 25.

Title: Telangana: Bigger quota likely for BCs in municipal polls
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The population of Scheduled Tribes (STs) is less in urban areas as compared to rural areas in Telangana . So, Backward Classes may get more percentage of reservations in the ensuing municipal polls . The exercise to reserve wards and chairpersons in municipalities and mayors in municipal corporations is almost complete.

Officials said final touches are being given to the quota issue and that the list of reserved wards, chairpersons and mayor posts is likely to be announced on January 4 or 5. BCs enjoyed 23% reservations in the gram panchayat polls.

“The population of SCs and STs in the urban local bodies going to polls is between 17% and 20%. Also, the government is likely to take the state as a unit to finalise reservations. As a result, BCs are likely to get a quota between 30% and 33%,” said an official.

At least three seats of mayor, 30 posts of municipal chairpersons and over 1,300 wards in the urban local bodies would go to BCs if they get over 30% quota. As per the Constitution, reservations for SCs and Scheduled Tribes are given in proportionate to their population which cannot exceed 20% in the ensuing municipal polls, sources said.

Fearing that BC quota may be reduced in the municipal polls, BC welfare associations led by R Krishnaiah submitted a memorandum to state election commissioner V Nagi Reddy to ensure that 34% quota extended to BCs in municipal polls in 2000 should be continued even in the January 22 polls. Krishnaiah told TOI that they would move Supreme Court if BC reservation is reduced in the polls.

Title: Four-year-old girl from Koya tribe raped
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BHUPALAPALLY: A four-year-old Koya tribal girl was allegedly raped at Konampeta in Mahamuttaram mandal on Tuesday night. The incident came to light after the girl was found lying unconscious in the village outskirts on Wednesday. Locals rushed her to a local hospital from where she was moved to MGM Hospital for better treatment. The 40-year-old accused is absconding.

According to the victim’s mother, the accused who is from Nagaram village kidnapped the girl at night while she was sleeping with her inside their house. The mother woke up at midnight and realised that her daughter was missing, following which she woke her neighbours up for help to search for the girl.

The girl’s parents and their neighbours lodged a complaint when they couldn’t find her. She was seen the next day in an open field in the village outskirts.

Kataram DSP Bonala Kishan has set up four special teams to nab the culprit. Police are conducting combing operations in the forest in Bhupalapally.

Title: Two killed, one hurt in road accidents in Pilibhit
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Pilibhit: Two people were killed, while one sustained multiple injuries, in separate road accidents late Tuesday evening under two police station circles in Pilibhit. Police sent the bodies for autopsy and shifted the injured to a hospital.

In first incident that took place on Bareilly-Hardwar national highway 74 near Lalpur village under Jahanabad police station, a 30-year-old plumber, identified as Mewaram, of Kurraiya village was allegedly mowed down by an unidentified vehicle when he was on his way home on his bike. He was shifted to the district hospital, where doctors proclaimed him dead upon arrival. “An FIR will be lodged as soon as we receive a complaint,” said SHO Mani Ram.

The second incident took place near Pansadi village under Deuria kotwali, in which 25-year-old Virendra Kumar of Bichpuri village under Bilsanda police station was killed on the spot after his bike was allegedly hit by an a tractor. The pillion rider, Mukesh Kumar, sustained serious injuries and shifted to the district hospital, but in view of his critical condition, he was referred to a higher medical facility in Bareilly.

Police, meanwhile, impounded the tractor and registered an FIR against the unidentified driver under sections 304A (causing death by negligence), 338 (causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others), 279 (rash driving or riding on public way) and 427 (mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees or upwards), said Shahroz Anwar, SHO, Deuria kotwali.

Title: Nirbhaya squad book 4,000 in city for harassing women
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

(done)

Nashik: The city police’s Nirbhaya squad has taken to task 4,055 men and youths for harassing women, including college and school students, from June 6 last year till December 31, 2019, data available with police shows.

The all-woman squad, comprising four units, swung into action soon after it was formed on June 6 last year and the trouble-makers, mostly youths, were booked under various sections of the Bombay Police Act.

“Those caught by the squad were booked and released with a warning that strict action would be taken against them if they are seen indulging in such activities again,” said a senior officer of the squad on Wednesday.

“The squad is proactive when it comes to spreading awareness among women, especiall female students, and conducted 941 awareness programmes in educational institutions,” said the officer.

Officers said that the squad has been basically formed to provide a safe atmosphere to women and girls, it also challaned 858 motorists for flouting traffic rules during the last seven months.

The officers said that the squad got many distressed calls from women and girls about harassment, following which action was initiated.

An officer said the Nirbhaya squads move around in different parts of the city to check if women or girls are harassed by hooligans near schools, colleges, gardens or at market places and take action against such people.

Given the awareness programmes organised all over the city, most of women and girls studying in schools and colleges have the phone numbers of the squad.

For instance, a college student had left her mobile phone in a rickshaw a couple of months back. When called the number through her friend’s phone, the rickshaw driver demanded Rs 2,000 to return the mobile phone. The student soon contacted the Nirbhaya squad, which caught the driver and booked him.

Only recently, the squad launched a drive in the city and its teams are taking part in sting operations to keep a check on men and youths harassing women at night and nabbed a number of such people.

The women teams of the squad not only conduct awareness programmes for girl students in schools and colleges, but also counsel young girls who are found loitering in gardens after bunking their classes.

Title: Andhra among top states in CSR spending with Rs 2,731 crore, Telangana one of the lowest spenders with Rs 918 crore
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Excluding North East and Union Territories, Telangana is one of the states where the lowest amount of CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility) funds were spent in the last three years, according to the data of the past four years released by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs, while Andhra Pradesh stood among the states where the highest amount of CSR funds were spent.AP, with a CSR expenditure of Rs 2,731 crore, stood third in the country after Maharashtra and Karnataka, whereas Telangana stood 11th in the country with Rs 918 crore despite several MNCs, corporate companies and IT and pharma firms having presence in Hyderabad.A total of Rs 42,536 crore was spent towards CSR by companies in India. The states that spent the lowest towards CSR were Bihar, Punjab, Jharkhand and Kerala. As per section 135 of The Companies Act 2013, every company during each financial year has to spend atleast 2% of its average net profit made during three immediately preceding financial years. Further, it is the company board’s prerogative to take up CSR activities, whereas the government cannot issue directions to corporates to spend on any activity.In Telangana, in 2017-18, around 634 companies had spent around Rs 291 crore mostly on education, rural development and healthcare. Infosys emerged as the biggest spender with Rs 20 crore, followed by Singareni Collieries Company Limited (SCCL) at Rs 19 crore and Divis laboratories at Rs 15 crore. Interestingly, the total amount spent on CSR in Hyderabad was Rs 21 crore.Suresh Chitturi, former president of Confederation of Indian Industries (CII), AP told TOI, “During election year, the CSR expenditure usually falls. It all depends on political will. In AP, from 2014, there was the special interest taken by the government to pursue CSR with corporates, hence expenditure could be more. Also, there are several profit-making PSUs in AP which may have spent CSR funds. Telangana figures are surprising.”Stating that it is difficult for companies to find the right NGOs to fund, he said, “Everyday, several NGOs approach us. We have to check the credibility and fund them. We don’t know how these funds are used. There is greater awareness these days on CSR among firms.”

Title: Canopies outside tunnels for cover from falling boulders
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

SLUG: KASARA GHAT

Nashik: The Railways has decided to raise protective canopies at the entrance of the tunnels between Igatpuri and Kasara stations to prevent a recurrence of boulder falls during monsoon.

The Railways will construct six canopies at entrance of the tunnels so that the trains are able to move in and out freely. Of the six to be constructed, the Railways have already completed the construction of one at T3 terminal while coming from Kasara towards Igatpuri.

“There were several instances of boulders falling in the ghat section during the monsoon of 2019 at the entrance of tunnels. Once a major tragedy was avoided due to the alert loco pilots. In order to cut down on the risk and stress on loco pilots and increase safety, it has been decided to raise canopies of iron mesh at the entrance of the tunnel,” said Shivaji Sutar, chief public relations officer of central railway.

The canopy has been designed in a manner that several iron rods run parallel to each other and can arrest boulders above a particular size from falling on the tracks.

The canopy has been built in a manner that it will catch and divert the boulders falling on it and do not affect the movement of trains. The boulders that fall through the beams will be small and would not hit the rail traffic. The beams have been laid on a strong concrete foundation and are at spots that are likely to witness boulders fall.

The cost of constructing each canopy is around Rs 90 lakh. According to the officials, the work of building the remaining five canopies will be finished before monsoon.

In 2019, heavy rainfall had caused boulders to fall on the tracks in the ghat section on several occasions, but it did not result in any major accident. Alert employees on the trains prevented any accidents. The construction of these canopies, much like the wire mesh on the Mumbai-Pune Expressway, is a preventive measure.

Title: ‘Gold imports to state in 2019 lowest since 2004’
Content: Ahmedabad: Amid an overall slowdown, skyrocketing gold prices and dwindling demand for jewellery, yellow metal imports in Gujarat in 2019 was the lowest since 2004, said market experts.Gold imports stood at 41.6 metric tonnes (MT) according to data by Ahmedabad Air Cargo Complex.“The last time gold imports plunged so low was in 2016 when it was 49.1 MT. The reduction in imports is a result of high gold prices and weakened consumer demand,” said Samir Mankad, CEO, GSEC Limited.The price of gold stood at Rs 40,300 per 10 gram in the Ahmedabad market on Wednesday.“Gold prices have remained high in the international market owing to escalating geopolitical tensions and increased procurement from central banks. Also, the fluctuating rate of Indian currency against the US dollar and increase in basic customs duty on gold kept gold prices on an upward trend most of this year,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).“Gold imports plunged due to various factors. These include stress across most industrial sectors and weakened consumer confidence, which caused a liquidity crisis. All of these factors led to a plunge in demand for most commodities and assets, including gold,” he added.Analysts said that demand for gold remained low-key during the wedding season as well, due to which yellow metal imports were further affected.“High prices of gold was a major deterrent for those looking to buy wedding jewellery. This led to an increase in exchange of old gold against purchase of new jewellery. We hope that after Uttarayan, when the Kamurta period ends, the increase in the number of muhurats will improve the demand,” said Manoj Soni, a city-based jeweller.Jewellers said that gold imports and overall demand has remained muted over the past two months in rural areas due to crop failures triggered by the unseasonal rainfall in October.

Title: Telangana weeds out five lakh bogus ration cards, highest in south India
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana has the highest number of bogus ration cards deleted among all the southern states in the last three years. A total of 1.49 crore ration cards were deleted in the country across states and Union territories and Telangana accounts for 5.21 lakh cards.This was revealed in the parliamentary standing committee’s updated report on food, consumer affairs and public distribution. Among the southern states, Kerala had the least — 3,314 — bogus cards deleted.Telangana made it to the list of top 10 states where maximum number of bogus cards were deleted. Uttar Pradesh stands on top of the charts with 70 lakh bogus cards deleted, followed by Rajasthan at 14.52 lakh cards. Officials said these cards have been deleted on various counts. Digitisation of ration cards, beneficiary records, duplication due to Aadhaar seeding, transfer, migration, death, change in economic status of beneficiaries and implementation of National Food Security Act led to the exercise of weeding out bogus ration cards, an official said.Under the Targeted Public Distribution System (Control) Order, 2015, all the states and Union territories have to issue ration cards to eligible applicants and conduct periodical checking of ration cards to weed out ineligible and bogus ration cards as well as bogus units in ration cards.Last year, Telangana launched the pilot project for the inter-state portability of ration cards between Telangana and Andhra Pradesh and between Maharashtra and Gujarat as part of its ‘One Nation, One Ration Card’ scheme. As the ration cards are issued by state governments generally, beneficiaries can procure foodgrains only from the designated ration shops within the state.

Title: Sarus crane population up by 254 in one year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The number of sarus crane, which is considered as the tallest flying bird in the world, has gone up from 1,867... Read More

BAREILLY: Conservation effort and awareness among local people about the “vulnerable” sarus crane saw the number of Uttar Pradesh ’s state bird increasing by 254 in just one year in Rohilkhand forest zone comprising nine districts of Bareilly and Moradabad divisions.

The number of sarus crane, which is considered as the tallest flying bird in the world, has gone up from 1,867 in 2018 to 2,121 in 2019. Besides, of the total 2,121 birds found in the Rohilkhand forest zone, 401 are juveniles, according to a survey conducted by the forest department.

The bird is listed in Schedule IV (protected) of the Wildlife (Protection) Act 1972 and as vulnerable on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List.

Chief conservator of forests, Rohilkhand zone, Lalit Verma told TOI, “The number of birds has gone up by 254 in a year. The increase in the sarus crane count can be attributed to the conservation effort and awareness among locals. We have been educating locals that sarus does not pose any threat to them if it is found present in their backyard, and thus, they should not disturb the bird.”

The survey elucidates that 1,720 adults and 401 juveniles sarus were found in the Rohilkhand forest zone. However, except Bijnor and Rampur, all other districts falling under the forest zone reported an increase in the sarus count in comparison to 2018. No Sarus was, however, found in Rampur which had eight birds in 2017 and four in 2018, while the count of birds in Bijnor decreased from 112 in 2018 to 102 in 2019.

The forest department had conducted a two-day counting for sarus crane on December 16 and 17. For the purpose, forest teams first conducted a survey of places where sarus were sighted the previous years and also reviewed new locations. Besides, the forest department also constituted teams comprising forest staff, NGOs, farmers and locals, who were present at the possible locations for sighting sarus.

According to officials as sarus birds are found near wetlands, marshy areas and paddy fields, teams were deployed at all selected sites to avoid inaccuracies. The counting was carried out from 7am to 9am and 3pm to 5pm on both days.

According to officials, the height of a standing sarus, which usually found in pairs, is approximately 156 cm (5’2”). The crane builds its nest in June-July in marshy areas using paddy straw, leaves and twigs and their breeding period is August-September. A female crane usually lays two eggs at a time.

Title: Change of guard talk in Telangana Congress
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A day after indicating that he would step down as TPCC president, N Uttam Kumar Reddy on Wednesday said Congress is coming back to power in states where it has been written off.

In an informal chat with mediamen, he said the party leadership has given freedom to local-level leaders to work out winning strategies in the coming municipal elections. He criticised the State Election Commission for giving very little time to select candidates for the January 22 polls.

He lambasted chief minister Kalvakuntla Chandrasekhar Rao for diluting democratic norms.

“Where is the need to arrest Congress leaders who were going to Gandhi Bhavan in a peaceful rally,” he said, referring to police clampdown on the rallyists and detaining them during an anti-CAA protest.

Meanwhile, Uttam’s remarks on change of guard in the TPCC leadership led to a lot of speculations. Sources said MLA D Sridhar Babu and MP A Revanth Reddy were among the frontrunners to succeed Uttam. “With the party set to effect a replacement only after the municipal election results, it will be a testing time for all the aspirants,” a leader said.

Title: Nagpur zone exceeds amnesty estimates for pre-GST regime dues
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: As central goods and services tax (GST) department is running Sabka Vishwas amnesty scheme for defaults of the earlier central excise and service tax regime, Nagpur is among three zones where the response has been beyond the estimates. The scheme was extended for 15 days on December 31, 2019.

The scheme covers tax demands of pre-GST regime that have been held up under litigation. The taxpayers can clear their liability by paying the dues ranging up to 60% of the demand. At the time of launch, estimates were made on the basis of number of long-drawn litigations where it was hoped that the taxpayer may go for a settlement.

Till 2019 end, 1.36 lakh applications for an amount of Rs6,99,770 crore were received by the department from all over the country. Over 7,500 applications have been made in Nagpur zone for an amount of Rs339 crore. This comes to 117% of the estimate. The Nagpur zone covers Nashik and Aurangabad commissionerate too.

The average response comes to 73% of the total estimates drawn for all zones. The other two zones where the actuals have exceeded the estimates are Visakhapatnam and Mumbai.

Source said the better performance in the zones like Nagpur has helped in pulling up the national average to 73%.

If the number has exceeded the estimates, it means that even those assessees whom the department thought may prefer to continue with the litigations have turned up and applied under the scheme. Once an application is made, the amount due to the government if freezed.

Chartered accountant Pritam Mahure says, “Sabka Vishwas scheme has been successful as it has liquidated more than 73% of the pending legacy. The number of applications may even go up further due to the 15-day extension. However, many taxpayers are unable to apply due to severe cash crunch on account of slowdown and thus more extension, say by 2 months, could have been better.”

Title: ‘AMC’s budget spending short of target’
Content: Ahmedabad: In the last six years, the Ahmedabad’s civic body has not been able to mobilize its financial resources for intended civic infrastructure projects in the city. The highest development expenditure was 77% in 2015-16 and the lowest was in 2017-18, when the expenditure was 59%. It is these development expenditures which ensure creation of new civic infrastructure in the city, according to a budget analysis by Pathey Budget Centre, an NGO that analyzes public expenditure.The Pathey analysis claims that the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has never been able to achieve a cent per cent tax collection. the actual revenue collection has only grown from 75% in 2014-15 to 85% in the last budget year. The largest revenue shortfall — worth Rs 1,367 crore — was reported in the 2017-18 budget year. In 2018-19 the AMC has claimed that it collected Rs 4,300 crore against the budget estimates of Rs 5,240 crore. “This is most unlikely as the actual collection will still be less than the revised estimates for 2018-19,” says Mahender Jethmalani, one of the authors of the budget analysis.In 2018-19 the AMC had declared a budget of Rs 8,051 crore, of which it was to spend Rs 4,124 crore on capital works. Of this, Rs 1,747 crore was raised by the AMC itself while the rest was received as grants from the state government.If one were to analyze AMC’s own fund expenditure according to the 2018-19 budget estimates, 16% were reserved for laying new drainage, 11 % were allocated for bridge projects, 9.9% were earmarked for water supply infrastructure, while 9% were directed towards housing. In the same budget year, the AMC was to receive Rs 1,775 crore from the state government of which a mammoth 42.23% was received as grants under the Swarnim Jayanti Mukhya Mantri Shaheri Vikas Yojana (SJMMSVY), 15.25% was provided as grants under the PM Awas Yojana, 14.08% was to be received as a grant under AMRUT — a central government urban renewal scheme. In the last budget year nearly 3.66% of the state government grant was provided for undertaking cleanliness mission under the Swachh Bharat scheme.

Title: Works worth Rs772cr hit as civic chief cuts NMC budget by 25%
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: In an unwelcome development at the beginning of the year, municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar has dropped various works pertaining to basic amenities worth over Rs772 crore approved in the current fiscal due to poor tax recovery by Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), failure to achieve revenue target and finding new income sources. This confirms that the 156-year-old is going through a severe financial crisis.

The works will be dropped as a result of Bangar’s decision to implement 25% cut in the budget presented by standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane in June last year, which is probably happening only for the second time in NMC’s history. Bangar will present the revised budget in February.

The cut will impact cement road, tar road, water supply, sewage, storm drain, LED street light project and other types of infrastructure works. Leaders of BJP, ruling party in NMC, are likely to create pressure on Bangar to take back the decision.

Pohane had presented a budget of Rs3,197.60 crore and approved works of Rs3,197.34 crore, for a balance of Rs25.49 lakh by March 31. Bangar told TOI that based on data compiled for revenue earned between April and November end, and considering experience of last five years, likely revenue between December and March end was calculated.

Against the target of Rs3,197.60 crore, till November end, the NMC could mop up Rs1,882.87 crore (59%), including 2018-19 fiscal’s balance of Rs399.87 crore. Thus, the actual revenue this fiscal so far is Rs1,483 crore.

The income includes state’s grants of Rs1,102 crore, which means NMC collected revenue of only Rs381 crore on its own from property tax, water bill, town planning etc in the last eight months.

“If 25% cut is not implemented, it will create liability on the NMC. Work orders will be restricted up to 75% under all heads, excluding those works approved under fixed priority, for backward class and persons with disabilities,” he said.

The NMC had approved works worth Rs31.20 crore under fixed priority which are used for internal roads, Rs55.37 crore under backward class for works in slum areas and Rs20 crore for welfare of persons with disabilities, for a total of Rs106.57 crore. Thus, the 25% cut will be on works of Rs3,091.03 crore, which means works worth Rs772.75 crore dropped.

The cut is slightly higher than the budget presented by Bangar in March last year. He had presented a Rs2,452.36 crore budget but Pohane increased it by Rs745.24 crore.

Bangar is following a trend set by his predecessors. Against the practice of presenting revised budget in December after analysing situation up to November end, civic chiefs have been presenting them in February or March, that too with a cut. It was done for the first time in 2010-11 by the then municipal commissioner Sanjeev Jaiswal.

The dropped works are either deleted on permanent basis in the revised budget or they create a liability for next fiscal.

Pohane said he would request Bangar to bring down the cut to 15%. “The cut is result of less recovery by NMC officials concerned against whom action will be initiated. Last fiscal, Rs299 crore were received as special funds from the state government to avoid the cut. We will approach the government this time too,” he said.

Condemning the move, Congress corporator Praful Gudadhe said that citizens are being made to suffer due to BJP’s failure. “BJP is either unable to ensure satisfactory recovery and achievement of target or increasing budget by cheating people. We will demand implementation of all works. Civic chief should have sought general body’s approval before taking the decision,” he said.

Title: IMS scam: Two arrested in new case
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Two more persons were arrested in a new case booked in relation to the multi-crore Insurance Medical Services (IMS) fraud on Wednesday. So far, 23 people were held in the IMS scam.

ACB arrested Omni Medi company proprietor K Srihari Babu and Sweden-based pharma company Hemocue’s regional manager T Venkatesh.

Srihari Babu, former IMS director Ch Devika Rani and joint director Padma played a key role in obtaining purchase orders for Legend Enterprises, whose proprietor is his associate Krupasagar Reddy, officials said. Venkatesh, who is Telangana regional manager of Hemocue, had reportedly issued a fake authorisation letter indicating that Legend Enterprises was the authorised distributor of Hemocue’s products in Telangana.

“Using the fake letter, Devika Rani, Padma in collusion with Srihari and Krupasagar Reddy, issued purchase orders for white blood cell cuvettes and blood glucose cuvettes. The accused placed purchase orders for the products, whose original prices were Rs 11,800 and Rs 1,950 per kit for Rs 36,800 and Rs 6,200, quoting over three times the product’s original price. Legend Enterprises supplied 6,291 units of white blood cell cuvettes and 4,500 units of glucose cuvettes in 2017-18 and charged excess amount of Rs 12,84,96,600.

Title: Alcoholic Telangana man beheads wife for complaining against domestic violence
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BHUPALAPALLY: A man chopped off his wife’s head on Tuesday after she complained to village elders about domestic violence, in Gandhinagar of Regonda mandal.

Sampath, an alcoholic, and his wife Sumalatha moved from Lakshmipuram of Parkal mandal in Warangal Rural district to Gandhinagar in search of livelihood. Sampath frequently beat his wife and children after consuming liquor. Unable to bear the torture, Sumalatha approached village elders for help. Sampath, however, refused to change his ways.

He barged into their house in a drunken state on Tuesday night and during a quarrel with his wife, he picked up a sword and chopped off her head. Regonda sub-inspector Krishnaprasad registered a case against the culprit, who is absconding.

Title: Rain catches New Year revellers on wrong foot
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: It was a wet start to 2020.

New Year revellers, who were wrapped in winter clothes on Tuesday, were caught on the wrong foot and with the inappropriate wear as it started raining around midnight. Most didn’t heed the forecast of the Met department which had hit the bull’s eye with its prediction.

Said Sajeena Abraham, “We had just stepped out of the church after the midnight mass and had to take shelter from the rain. It was pelting like it was monsoon. We had planned a little party which got delayed taking the punch out of our revelry.”

According to the data of Regional Meteorological Centre, Nagpur, the city received a total rainfall of 8.3 millimetres. Following showers, the minimum temperature of Nagpur almost rose by double — from 6.5 degrees Celsius it saw a drastic increase of 13.4 degrees Celsius on Wednesday. The maximum temperature recorded was 21.8 degrees Celsius.

Many places in the city were flooded. Motorists, especially two-wheel drivers, had to wage through water making driving a difficult job.

“We had planned a terrace party with family friends in my house,” said residents of Friends Colony. “After it started drizzling we thought it could just be a passing shower. But when the intensity increased, we had no option but to shift indoors.”

As per RMC, the highest rainfall was recorded at Bhandara (28.6mm). The met department has forecast thunderstorm or hailstorm accompanied with lighting for Thursday too. For the coming week, the minimum temperatures of the city are expected to sway between 6-12 degrees Celsius.

As reported by TOI, the region is experiencing unusual rains in winter season as the wind flow is not completely northerly. On December 26, Nagpur received 10mm rains. Due to the unseasonal rains, the city has been witnessing less cold and more humidity.

A compiled data for December shows that in the first five days of the month, the average temperature of the city remained between 20-22 degrees Celsius. In the second week, the minimum mercury levels saw a slight fall and went around 10-11 degrees Celsius. However following rains, the minimum temperatures again went up to 16- 18 degrees Celsius.

From 12.6 degrees Celsius on December 27, Nagpur’s minimum temperature significantly dropped to 5.1 degrees Celsius the following day. This was the third lowest minimum temperature for December in almost a century.

Title: FDCM goes ‘soft’ on tainted staff
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: Instead of taking some action, the Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM) only shifted two of its officials who aided over 250 tractor trolleys in illegal excavation of sand from reserve forest area.

TOI on December 26 had reported how inquiry report nailed ST Meshram, assistant manager (AM) of Jamdi-I (Gondia), and range forest officers (RFOs) KJ Shinde and RN Lambat, under whose jurisdiction large-scale sand smuggling was going on.

The FDCM shifted Meshram to Ballarshah timber depot and Shinde to Kanhargaon in Chandrapur. Both have been given field postings again. Inquiry officer IV Kore has also been shifted to Yavatmal.

The corporation took illegal quarrying lightly and action on the inquiry report was taken two months after it was submitted, only when TOI reported the matter.

The GM of FDCM, who has powers to suspend officials up to the rank of RFOs, has recommended departmental inquiry (DE) against Shinde. It was expected all those involved would be suspended. No action has been recommended against Lambat who also connived with the private contractor for illegal quarrying. FDCM is also silent on recover of loss of royalty over Rs10 lakh from the contractor or from these officers.

Title: Amdavad’s specially abled autorickshawwali!
Content:
Ankita Shah, 35, has been driving a rickshaw for six months. Her father has cancer.

Ankita Shah's father has cancer.

AHMEDABAD: In an age when women are increasingly wading into male-dominated professional sectors to create a space for themselves, Ankita Shah, 35, has shattered the gender stereotype to become Amdavad’s first specially abled rickshawwali! Shunning a desk job as a call-centre executive, Ankita has been driving a rickshaw for six months, to contribute towards her ailing father’s cancer treatment.A BA with Economics, Ankita is the eldest among five siblings, and hails from a family with modest background in Palitana, her native place. She had her right leg amputated due to polio, at an early age. After facing social ostracization over her disability, she moved to Ahmedabad in 2012 and began working at a call centre.“I used to barely make Rs 12,000 working a 12-hour shift at the call centre. Moreover, after my father was diagnosed with intestine cancer, I had to constantly shuttle between Ahmedabad and Surat for his treatment and getting frequent leaves was a problem. The income wasn’t enough. That’s when I decided to call it quits,” she said.Despite appearing for interviews at various private companies, Ankita could not get a job easily as her disability was cited as a concern by most employers. “It wasn’t an easy time. Making ends meet was difficult and I was feeling all the more guilty because I couldn’t contribute anything for my father’s treatment. I finally decided to do something on my own,” she added.The idea of driving an autorickshaw struck her but it was both challenging and raised eyebrows in the family too. But determined to improve her financial condition to be able to pay for her father’s treatment, while finding work-life balance, Ankita embraced it all. “I learnt driving a rickshaw from a friend – Lalji Barot – who is also physically challenged and drives a rickshaw. He not just taught me how to drive, but also helped me get a customized autorickshaw of my own – which has a hand-operated brake,” she said.Today, Ankita ferries her rickshaw for seven to eight hours and makes upto Rs 20,000 every month. “It is much better because there is no work pressure. I can also visit my family and help with my dad’s treatment,” said Ankita, who plans to start her own taxi business in the future.

Title: Nashikites will have to pay R 5 more for short distance train travel
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: The rail fare for second class travel between Nashik and Mumbai, Nashik and Aurangabad and Nashik and Bhusawal has been increased by Rs 5, following the announcement of fare rise by the railways on Tuesday.

According to railway officials, the fare for ordinary train travel to CSMT, Mumbai, or Aurangabad or Bhusawal or Jalgaon from Nashik has increased only by 1 paise per km with the an effective rise being Rs 5 in the tickets.

“The ticket for travel to CSMT, Aurangabad, Bhusawal or Jalgaon will now cost only Rs 5 more. The AC travel, however, will be costlier by Rs 10 on these routes,” sources in the railways said.

The fare for Rajdhani Express between Nashik and New Delhi has increased by Rs 55 for a single journey.

The railway officials said that this was the first fare revision since 2014-15 and that it had little impact on the fare.

“The hike in train fares is nominal because it is still much cheaper than road travel,” Ragini Patil, resident of Nashik and frequent traveller.

Akash Khairnar, a daily passenger, said that the monthly season ticket was not touched and it is the best thing to happen for them.

“Given the rising inflation, the Railways has done the right thing by not overburdening the passengers with steep hike in the fares. The current rise can easily be borne by commuters,” said Khairnar.

Another commuter, Shreekant Kulkarrni, said that the hike at a time when prices of all the commodities were rising is unfortunate. “The fuel prices have increased, and the rise in rail fares would only fuel inflation,” he said.

Title: 3 phone sellers held with fake accessories
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ahmedabad: Three mobile phone shopowners of Ramnagar were booked by Sabarmati police on Tuesday night for violation of Copyright Act and selling counterfeit accessories of tech-giant Apple Inc.

The accused were identified as Kiran Prajapati, 35, resident of Ghatlodia, Rakesh Bishnoi, 21, resident of Chandkheda, and Prakash Harapalani, 34, resident of Sardarnagar.

Police said that officials of Griffin Intellectual Services Private Limited, who are authorized by Apple Inc to act against dealers selling counterfeit products of their brand, had verified the accessories sold at three shops owned by the accused through decoy customers. When they learnt that the accessories were fake, they went to Sabarmati police station with documents and evidences.

On the basis of the information, police raided the three shops at Ramnagar chowk. According to police, the accused did not have any franchise or permit from Apple Inc to sell the accessories. Police found counterfeit accessories worth Rs 9.11 lakh..

Title: Bareilly: Malaria cases up despite dip in temperature in December
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Even as the temperature in Bareilly dropped below 10 degrees Celsius making mosquitoes inactive, the district recorded 683 cases of malaria in December, which in the corresponding month last year was reported to be 578.

District malaria officer DR Singh said, “Due to low temperature, the mosquito becomes inactive. As the density of mosquitoes reduces in December, the number of cases also decreases drastically. However, in September, more than 600 cases were being detected per day. Besides, a few people, who did not follow the full course of treatment, are still carrying the malarial parasite.”

According to health department officials, the number of positive cases is decreasing with the drop in temperature. Last year, Bareilly had reported 6,302 malaria cases in October, but it reduced to 1,912 in September. Officials said malaria cases are at its peak during July to mid-October due to monsoon.

Of the total 683 cases reported, 251 were of “killer” malaria strain plasmodium falciparum (PF), while 428 were of a milder form of malaria caused by plasmodium vivax (PV). However, four people were diagnosed with mixed forms of malaria carrying both PF and PV parasites.

Bareilly district reported nearly 24% increase in malaria cases in 2019 as compared to 2018. A total of 37,482 malaria cases were detected in 2018 in Bareilly, but the number rose to 46,717 in 2019. Of the total 46,717 cases reported in 2019, 11,753 were PF and 34,576 were PV and 388 were carrying both parasites.

As PF cases are still being reported, health department officials said they would conduct active case surveillance in the villages, where PF cases were detected. Under active case surveillance, health department teams hold a camp in a village to test all suspected cases.

The department has categorised 135 villages and two urban wards of Jagatpur and Subhashnagar as sensitive for reporting PF cases.

Of these 135 villages reporting PF cases, maximum numbers of villages are situated in Majhgavan block (62), followed by Bhamora (35), Ramnagar (14), Kyara (11), Fatehganj West (8), Meerganj (3) and Faridpur (1).

Title: MSRTC to set up eight charging ports for e-buses in city
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: To facilitate e-bus services from the city, Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation ( MSRTC ) has decided to raise eight charging ports for buses at the Nashik depot-1.

“Currently we have been asked to initiate the procedure for creating infrastructure for power chargers at Nashik depot. Hence, we are in touch with the state electricity distribution company limited (MSEDCL) requesting it to provide us with the quotations for raising the same,” said a senior officer from MSRTC.

MSRTC is likely to start e-bus services on two additional routes — Nashik-Pune and Nashik-Mumbai — besides the Mumbai-Pune route.

Officials of the Nashik division of MSRTC said that it was likely that the MSRTC launched three buses on Pune route and three buses on Mumbai route. However, officials said that the Mumbai route seems to be the priority.

“Mumbai route could be taken up on priority as we already have Shivshahi air-conditioned buses running on the route and they could be replaced. Mumbai route could also be on the priority since it connects the state capital and contributes towards reducing pollution,” an MSRTC official said.

“The MSRTC will raise eight charging ports at the Nashik depot. The technical specifications required have been shared with the MSEDCL which could be presenting quotation to the MSRTC explaining it over the charges required,” he added.

“Once the quotation is received, we will process it and get the infrastructure ready for the buses,” the officer said.

The MSRTC Nashik-1 depot has eight bays where the maintenance and repairs of 177 busses are carried out. These bays are the ones that fulfill the demand of the MSRTC for taking care of its buses running on diesel. Since the e-buses will have lesser moving parts, their maintenance would also be restricted. However they will be required to be stationed for re-charging which currently is a tedious task that takes at least four hours.

Title: Sena to bag ZP prez post, NCP with VP
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: Shiv Sena is set to elect a party member as the Nashik Zilla Parishad president while the Nationalist Congress Party is likely to walk away with a vice-president’s post as three parties including Congress reached a consensus to keep the BJP at bay.

With the president and vice president completing their terms on December 20, the elections for the same will be held on Thursday. The Zilla Parishad has 73 members of which one seat is vacant. The Shiv Sena leads with 25 members, followed by NCP with 15 and Congress with eight members. The Maha Vikas Aghadi has 48-member strength and enjoys support from independence as well as the Communist Party of India (Marxist).

While the name of Shiv Sena’s Balasaheb Kshirsagar is making rounds for the presidential post, the name for the vice president is yet to come to a consensus among the NCP members, the sources said. “Kshirsagar is running ahead at this point in time for the post of president. The name for the vice-president is still under wraps given that several names from the NCP were vying for the post. However, both the names will be finalized by the respective party chiefs and the decision will be conveyed just before elections to the office,” the sources added.

The election process is scheduled to start from 11.00 am while the election in particular will be conducted at 1.45 pm.

Meanwhile, the election of the president and vice president seats of 15 Panchayat Samiti were held on Monday and the Shiv Sena reigned supreme in seven Samitis across the district. The party got its members elected as president and vice president in Igatpuri, Sinnar, Niphad, Dindori, Peth, Yeola and Nandgoan Panchayat Samitis.

The NCP bagged posts in Deola and Nashik, while the Maha Vikas Aghadi bagged the posts in Baglan Samiti. Kalwan saw an understanding between Congress and NCP, CPI-M to win the bragging rights in Surgana, an independent candidate won in Trimbakeshwar and BJP member in Chandwad Samiti.

Title: Mahagenco’s Bhivkund coal block cancelled
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: The coal ministry has cancelled the allocation of Mahagenco’s Bhivkund coal block located in Chandrapur district for failing to start mining even after passage of over 11 years. The block had proven reserves of 100 million tonnes (MT) and was meant for a new 500MW unit. It is not clear whether the ministry will now allocate it to another company.

The block was allocated to the power generation company in July 2008. Mahagenco was supposed to start coal production from September 2015. However, it failed to obtain the major clearances required for starting mining. It had received several notices from the ministry in this regard but to no avail.

Over a decade ago, Mahagenco had been allocated Macchakatta coal block in Odisha. However, it failed to start mining there too and its allocation was cancelled after Coalgate. In August 2016, it was given the Gare Palma block in Chhattisgarh but the company has failed to get environmental clearance so far.

The company continues to face coal shortage due to its failure to start mining from its captive mines. The allocation of the coal block had raised the hackles of environmentalists. The coal block is named after Bhivkund nullah that lies on the road linking Chandrapur to Ballarpur. Bhivkund forest is very dense and is contiguous to Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) through Lohara jungle. It lies in the tiger corridor.

Chandrapur greens have demanded that now the block should be permanently cancelled so that destruction of the dense forests is prevented and tiger movement is not affected.

The ministry had recently cancelled allocations of six blocks given to state-run power generation companies of Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha and Maharashtra. These coal blocks, with geological reserves of around four billion tonnes, had been allocated to these companies between 2007 and 2010 for future expansion. However, none of these power projects saw the light of the day and no significant development was made to operationalize these mines.

Jharkhand has lost the Moury (225.4 MT) and Kerandari BC (916.5 MT) blocks. The Pindrakhi (421.5 MT) and Puta Parogia (629.2 MT) blocks have been de-allocated from Chhattisgarh and Odisha lost the Bankhui (800 MT) block.

Title: 9 children rescued from garments unit
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ahmedabad: Narol police rescued nine child labourers from a garments unit owned by one Mohan Gavandar in Narol on Tuesday. Police sources said the children were sent to a shelter home and the procedure to take them back to their native places has been initiated.

Police sources said they received intelligence about minors being employed at the unit in JK Estate in Narol through the police control room.

“We formed a team and raided the unit running at shed number 34 in the estate. We found nine minors children working at the unit. They are from states such as Bihar and Uttar Pradesh,” said a police source.

The children in their statements to police said Mohan Gavandar confined them at the workplace. “He used to pay the children, but did not allow them to leave the warehouse,” a police official said.

Police officials said they have booked Gavandar under the Child Labour Act.

Title: Eflu PhD students’ stir enters Day II
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Demanding that the varsity provides alternate accommodation to all pursuing PhD, the students of English and Foreign Languages University ( Eflu ) on Wednesday staged a protest on campus for the second consecutive day.

They said it was not fair on the varsity’s part to extend winter vacation at the fag end and added that this is causing severe inconvenience to students, especially hose doing their PhDs.

“There are no vacations for PhD students. They can’t give us three days’ time and ask us to vacate hostels. Many of us can’t go back to our hometowns owing to financial constraints and unrest in cities among other reasons. They should have at least given us a month’s time,” said a PhD student.

The vice-chancellor, however, said major renovations was underway at the varsity and added that they can’t make alternate arrangements for PhD students as they don’t have separate hostels. “They can’t cite financial constraints as we have already deposited their fellowship amount in their accounts today. We even assured to compensate them for the cancelled tickets as we have announced extension of winter vacation on December 30. We have requested them to book train tickets to leave for their hometowns. If any of their tickets are in waiting list, we will even talk to railway officials and try to get them confirmed,” said E Suresh Kumar, VC, Eflu.

Title: Submit status report in UCO Bank scam: HC asks CBI
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NAGPUR: Expressing acute displeasure over Central Bureau of Investigation’s (CBI) reply regarding Rs25 crore scam in UCO Bank ’s loan disbursal scheme for farmers, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court has directed the agency to submit a status report of its probe into the scam.

While hearing a suo motu criminal petition, a division bench led by justice Zaka Haq directed the premier investigation agency to file a report by January 21.

The UCO bank had floated a scheme to grant loans to the farmers/joint liability groups through industry/mill owners. The latter are required to prepare a list of farmers, who would be cultivating the crop (Soyabean), and they would remain guarantors of their repayment. The loan amount was supposed to be deposited into accounts of farmers/joint liability groups.

The Adilabad-based GS Oil Company in alleged connivance with the bank officers in Wardha and Hinganghat, sought loans of Rs25 crore on the basis of forged documents. After the amount was deposited into farmers’ accounts, it was immediately transferred into company’s account, which revealed that it was the actual beneficiary. After the fraud came to fore, the CBI registered offences against the company’s officials under IPC Sections 420, 468, 471, 34 and Section 13 (1) and 13(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act.

While hearing their anticipatory bail plea, when the court came to know about alleged involvement of the bank officials, it directed the registry to file a suo motu plea and appointed Rajnish Vyas as an amicus curiae .

Pointing out massive misappropriation of public money by the bank officials, the amicus said it was done in collusion with directors of private companies like GS Oil. Further accusing the bank officials of not cooperating with the CBI, he also charged the agency of showing disinterest in the entire case. He prayed for directives to Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to call on all banks and financial institutions to file a suo motu complaint on financial frauds by framing appropriate guidelines and its strict monitoring.

He also demanded CBI to explore implementing Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA) in such financial swindles. He termed the entire incident as a ‘systematic and organized crime’ committed by the bank officials through illegal transactions.

After, HC’s notices to respondents on July 22, 2017, including Wardha police, RBI and CBI, it took over two years for them to reply. Vyas again pointed out that the respondents failed to sufficiently explain the disbursement of huge loans and the transfer of amount farmers’ accounts to the account of oil company.

“The facts on record show that loan was sanctioned in farmers’ names, but there is nothing on record on the basis of which it can be accepted that the persons in whose names loans were sanctioned are farmers. On specific query, the CBI hasn’t been able to point out any material to show that those in whose name loan was disbursed were agriculturist at the relevant time,” the judges said, before adjourning the hearing.

Title: BDA to construct 5-km-long road to connect Ramganga Nagar
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: The Bareilly Development Authority (BDA) has proposed to construct a 5-km-long road connecting Dohra road to Bisapur on the city outskirts. A survey for the project is going on in the area.

According to BDA officials, a wide road will facilitate commuters moving towards Ramganga Nagar Awasya Yojana, as the area currently lacks a connecting road suitable for vehicular movement.

Speaking to TOI, BDA vice-chairperson Divya Mittal said, “We are taking measures to develop BDA’s housing scheme Ramganga Nagar Awasya Yojana popular among the public. However, for increasing the number of visitors, it is important to make the area easily accessible but, at present, the connecting Bisalpur-Dohra road is damaged to the extent that it poses risk to motorists. Thus, for the convenience of commuters/visitors, we are considering to lay a 5-km-long and 42-meter-wide road. A survey is underway and as soon as the project gets approval, the construction work will commence.”

The development authority has been taking up various developmental projects in Ramganga Nagar to attract more and more customers and ensure settlement in its residential projects.

Besides, the BDA has announced to develop a ‘Science Park’ over seven-acre premises with an estimated cost of around Rs 1.7 crore to create awareness among youths about technology, job creation, facilitating start-ups and attracting home buyers to Ramganag Nagar Awasya Yojana, which is spread over 269 hectares.

Apart from this, the development authority has also proposed to develop a ‘Forest City’ (a semblance of forest) over 81,000 sq metres within the housing scheme at a cost of around Rs 20 crore with facilities such as open gym, children play area, garden, walkway, etc.

Title: State forms NRG committee
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Gandhinagar: The state government has formed a non-resident Gujarati (NRG) community co-ordination committee, to reach out and help Gujaratis living in other parts of the country. Pradipsihn Jadeja, minister of state, NRG division, said, “The purpose of the NRG community coordination committee is to reach out to Gujaratis living in different parts of the country and help them in all possible ways. The committee will be chaired by the chief minister and the purpose of the committee will be to create a sense of belonging in Gujaratis living in other states. The committee will meet twice a year and discuss issues faced by the community and activities to increase engagement of the state with Gujaratis living in other parts of the country.”

Title: Mercury drops to 10.3 C, records season’s lowest temp
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: The city recorded the season’s the lowest temperature on the first day of the New Year with the mercury dropping to 10.3 degree Celsius on Wednesday.

The previous lowest temperature was recorded on December 28 with the city witnessing an 11.4 degree Celsius.

On Tuesday, the minimum temperature was recorded at 12.2 degrees C as compared to 10.3 on Wednesday.

According to IMD officials, the climate will be dry for the next four days and the minimum temperature is expected to drop to 9 degree C. “It has been very cold for the past seven days, particularly from last Thursday. This is really a pleasant climate in the district. I along with my friends had planned a small trip to Igatpuri in the district. We felt as if we were in a hill station,” said Vinay Jagtap, an engineering student.

“The Nashik city climate is very pleasant during the last few days of December. I had come to Nashik to visit a winery for new year celebrations. I have been here for the past three days with my family. The city is so cool and I enjoyed the new year in a winery near Gangapur village in the city,” said Manish Sharma, a tourist from Hyderabad.

Niphad tehsil town, which is a major grape-growing belt in the district, recorded a minimum temperature at 9 degree C on Wednesday. The maximum temperature of the city was recorded at 27.8 degree C on Wednesday. The minimum temperature of the town is 1.3 degree C lower than minimum temperature in Nashik city.

“This is for the second time I celebrated New Year here in a winery. I had come here for the first time to celebrate New Year in a winery around two years back,” he added.

The grape harvest season is expected to begin from the second half of January. “The vineyards are affected only if the minimum temperature goes below 5 degree C. The grapefruits develop cracks if the minimum temperature is below that,” said Manik Patil, a senior member of Maharashtra Rajya Draksha Bagayatdar Sangh.

Title: NMC drive to spot fine shops, hawkers starts
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: From Thursday, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) will fine road and footpath encroachers on the spot.

On Wednesday, the civic body launched an intensive drive to free footpaths and roads from encroachments.

The decision was taken by mayor Sandip Joshi and municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar.

As per directives of Joshi, the committee headed by BJP corporator Dayashankar Tiwari finalized a spot fine of Rs 1,000 for hawkers. The fine will be triple (Rs 3,000) in case of a second violation. The seized material will be returned to hawkers after recovering 25% of its value. The fine will be Rs 500 in case the value of seized materials is below Rs 500. The NMC is recovering these charges since the past few years and will continue doing the same along with the newly introduced spot fine.

In the third instance, material seized from hawkers will not be returned. It will be auctioned by the NMC. The police department will initiate action according to section 102 of the Bombay Police Act. Violators will have to pay this fine in court.

In case of encroachments by shopkeepers, the spot fine will be Rs 5,000. It will be Rs 10,000 in case of a second violation. Material seized will not be returned in case of a third violation. It will be auctioned by the NMC along with police action. In this case, material will not be returned in the first two instances if the shopkeeper in question has not paid property tax.

The NMC will recover the spot fine similar to that of shopkeepers from leasehold shopkeepers. In this case, lease will be cancelled if any leaseholder encroaches footpath or roads or any public place for the third time.

Joshi had already announced a spot fine and stringent action to make footpaths walkable and roads free for motorists. He also announced development of Smart Kiosks to rehabilitate hawkers.

NMC implemented the spot fine and action as per the new policy which will be later approved by the standing panel and general body.

The NMC launched the drive in seven out of the ten zones on Wednesday. Three zones — Dhantoli, Nehru Nagar and Ashi Nagar — failed to launch the drive for reasons best known to them.

There was tension in Mahal Zone during the drive. Despite 60-70 hawkers opposing the move, the NMC successfully removed encroachments in Mahal market. Encroachments were cleared on the stretch between Narsing Talkies and Ghate Hotel, Kotwali police station and Kalyaneshwar Mandir and Zenda Square and Ladkika pul. In all, 75 encroachments were cleared.

In Laxmi Nagar Zone, the drive was conducted on West High Court (WHC) Road from Laxmi Nagar Zone to Khamla Square. Items of a tipper were seized.

Drive was conducted on WHC Road between Law College Square and Shankar Nagar Square and also on footpaths in Gokulpeth market.

Similarly, the drive was undertaken in various places in Satranjipura, Lakadganj, Hanuman Nagar and Mangalwari Zone.

Assistant commissioner (enforcement department) Ashok Patil, Sanjay Kamble and engineers of zones were present. Surprisingly, the nuisance detection squad (NDS) levied a fine of Rs400 on hawkers in some zones. The fine was not related to encroachments but for creating unhygienic conditions.

IN A NUTSHELL

Earlier System: NMC used to seize materials of hawkers and shopkeepers and take them to its godown. NMC used to return materials after recovering 25% of the total value of seized goods. There were no provisions for spot fine

New Policy: Spot fine introduced for the first time

Hawkers — Fine of Rs1,000 for first time, Rs3,000 for second instance. In first two instances, materials seized will be released to hawkers after recovering charges of 25% of total value of seized materials. Materials will be auctioned in case of third violation along with action from police as per section 102 of Bombay Police Act in which the hawker will have to pay the fine in court

Encroachments by shopkeepers in front of shops: A fine of Rs5,000. It will increase to Rs10,000 in case of a second violation. Material seized will not be returned in case of third instance and auctioned by the NMC along with police action. In this case, material will not be returned in the first two instances if the shopkeeper in question has not paid property tax

NMC leasehold shops: Fine similar to that of shopkeepers. In this case, lease will be cancelled if any leaseholder encroaches footpaths or roads or any public place for the third time

More Fine: Nuisance detection squad will levy a fine of Rs400 if waste or garbage is dumped by hawkers or shopkeepers on footpaths, roads or public places

Title: With 230 babies, ‘Jiyo Parsi’ brings cheers
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Karmin and Yazad Gandhi with their children Zaisha and Rayaan.

NEW DELHI: “230 and counting…” – that is the number of children born to Parsi couples since 2014, who benefitted from the Centre's ‘Jiyo Parsi’ scheme, aimed at arresting a sharp decline in the community's numbers. The scheme took off in 2013-14 as an urgent response to the 2011 census data that pitched the Parsi population at just 57,264- a steep drop from 1,14,000 in 1941.

A scheme to spur the mating instinct may have seemed esoteric, but it would seem some gains have been made. The data of 230 children pertains to those couples who benefited from medical reimbursements offered under ‘Jiyo Parsi’ for medical interventions like fertility treatments, Assisted Reproductive Technologies and counselling— all intended to preserve a community, which despite its small numbers, played a disproportionate role in national life, producing stellar cricketers, exceptional scientists and trail-blazing industrialists.

The good news is that the Parsi story is witnessing a turnaround of sorts with younger couples choosing to have not one, but two children. The 2021 census will be an important milestone that will reflect how far the community has been able to slow down the trend. Studies conducted in the past to assess the reasons for the decline pitched a worrisome picture of there being an average of one child below the age of 10 in nine families.

With Maharashtra being home to most Parsis followed by Gujarat , Mumbai-based Karmin and Yazad Gandhi’s story reflects the changing mindset. This year Christmas was special as it was Rayaan - their second born’s first big festival. He completes three months on December 30 and has an elder sister Zaisha who is 2.

The family is a beneficiary of the ‘health for community’ component of Jiyo Parsi, which includes financial assistance of Rs 4,000 for crèche support per child up to the age of 8 to couples who fall within a certain income bracket.

Professionals in the tourism industry, Karmin and Yazad, are candid that the crèche support for their first child helped them plan their second. Yazad, who was 28 when he got married, says, “I was a single child but I was clear about marrying early and having children so that I could grow with them. The advocacy at community events does motivate young people,” he shared.

A review of the Jiyo Parsi scheme of the ministry of minority affairs (MoMA) is set out in great detail in a report of the parliamentary standing committee on social justice. The committee, led by Rama Devi, has emphasised the need for a separate census for the Parsi community.

Recognising the importance of numbers to assess the changes on ground over the last decade, Shernaz Cama, Director UNESCO Parzor and National Director Jiyo Parsi Programme, said they have already started planning on the outreach to ensure that when the enumeration exercise for census 2021 starts next year, the community is ready to come forward to be counted.

TOI search of Jiyo Parsi community posts on social media platforms found that marriages and child birth make for big news. In one post, a mother shares a poem along with her baby’s photograph and speaks of her dream of having a child being the biggest joy of the world.

“Low rate of marriage, delayed marriage and the largest numbers of those never married till age of 40 has led to a decrease in the number of babies born. Therefore, it is important to change both marriage patterns as well as treat infertility which is a socio- psychological problem," the ministry said in a reply to the committee.

It has been found that because of the very large proportion of elders in the community, a younger couple often bears the responsibility of several elders.

The Jiyo Parsi scheme therefore also provides for a senior citizen honorarium of Rs 3000 for childcare per child per month up to the age of 10 years. Assistance of Rs 4,000 per month per person after the age of 60 years is also provided.

Title: Inter-state highway robbery gang busted by crime branch, six arrested
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A crime branch team of Bareilly police busted an inter-state highway robbery gang and arrested six of its members with Rs 4 lakh cash and seized looted articles from their possession on Tuesday midnight.

The robbers belong to western UP districts and used to commit robberies in Bareilly, Lakhimpur Kheri, Unnao and Shahjahanpur districts, said police.

Police said they would carry the stolen material in a mini-truck and sell the items with the help of a fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) dealer in Ghaziabad, identified as Kapil Tyagi. One of their members was earlier working with an FMCG production unit and he would provide the information about dispatched goods to the gang members, said police.

In Bareilly, the accused had stolen a truck carrying shampoo from Rudrapur in Uttarakhand to Bhamora area in Gujarat on December 8.

The accused were arrested after an encounter on Bhamora-Aonla state highway when they were on their way to Lucknow for delivering the looted items.

According to police, when they signalled the driver of the mini-truck to stop, he tried to run them over. The accused, then, opened fire at the crime branch team in a bid to evade their arrest.

However, in the ensuing gun battle, six of them surrendered before police while two escaped, said police. The accused were identified as Shahil alias Mushrat, Azeem and Sajid from Meerut, Anil Singh, Kapil Tyagi and Parvez from Ghaziabad district. The remaining two accused Sher Mohammed and Waseem alias Pradhan are absconding and police are searching for them, said police.

Giving details about their modus operandi, Bareilly SSP Shailesh Pandey told TOI, “The accused used to target FMCG consignments, which are easy to sell. having worked with FMCG companies in Rudrapur, Sher Mohammed is well aware of the information about products dispatch. The accused used to commit robberies using mini-truck of Waseem, while Kapil used to supply looted goods to small dealers at discounted rates. The gang has looted a shampoo consignment in Bareilly, biscuits in Shahjahanpur, chyawanprash in Unnao and Maggi in Kheri districts. We have booked them under IPC sections 395 (dacoity), 307 (attempt to murder) and under relevant sections of the Arms Act.”

Title: Sangli ZP: BJP making efforts to bounce back
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: In a desperate attempt to retain power in Sangli zilla parishad (ZP), the BJP is riding its hopes on the differences among the functionaries of Congress, NCP, and Shiv Sena.

The ZP election for the post of president is set to be conducted on Thursday.

BJP state unit president Chandrakant Patil has expressed confidence that the party would win the election this time around. Mahavikas Aaghadi comprising of Congress, NCP and Shiv Sena has also shown its confidence to capture power by defeating BJP in the election.

Sangli MP Sanjay Patil is said to be upset over the selection of candidates for the post of president and vice-president. In reply, his four supporters were absent at the party meeting. But top functionaries have managed in convincing Patil about power-sharing.

The saffron party is also trying to capitalise on the difference of local Sena and NCP functionaries. Some BJP officials are in touch with Anil Babar and Ait Ghorpade, who have supporters in ZP as well as long-time detractors of NCP’s Jayant Patil.

Sources in the party said that Patil is expected to take a lead bringing together all anti-BJP forces but he is yet to take any initiative in that direction. Few independent members, who have an alliance with a local outfit, have not taken any decision yet. BJP in total has a strength of 28 members while NCP and Congress have 22 members.

Title: Encroachments near Sarangpur Bridge razed
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ahmedabad: After almost 40 years, demolition has begun to remove a string of encroachments at the foot of the Sarangpur Bridge. Close to a 100 structures today encroach on the road. Because of this, the BRT corridor could not expand owing to frequent stays by civil courts and the high court. The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has demolished 17 major structures. The space was allotted to some refugees in the early 1950s to build temporary wooden cabins. “The shopowners did not produce valid documents. Notices were issued in 2012 and at regular intervals after 2014,” said an AMC official. TNN

Title: Over 55k tourists visit Nashik wineries in 10 days
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The year ended on a high for the wineries in Nashik.

Over 55,000 tourists from across the country visited the wineries in Nashik during the last 10 days of the year. Nashik has become wine capital of the country and wineries here have become an attraction for tourists.

Sula Vineyards, the country’s largest vinery, recorded footfall of around 35,000 tourists between December 21 and 31.

“There has been good response from tourists during the second half of December. Usually, the number of tourists at the wineries is around 2,000 a day. The number increased two-and a half times during last 10 days of December,” said an office-bearer of All India Wine Producers Associations (AIWPA).

Last year, around 50,000 tourists had visited different wineries during the same period. “There has been a marginal rise (10%) in footfall during the festive period of Christmas and New Year,” the office-bearer added.

Though there are several wineries in the district, Sula Vineyards has become an international brand and bags most attraction among tourists.

“We had very good response throughout December when around 45,000 tourists visited. Of which, around 75% of tourists visited during last 10 days of December,” said an official from Sula Vineyards.

Apart from Sula, other wineries like Soma Vineyards, York, Vallonnie, Grover Zampa, Soma, Renaissance, Good Drops, are the major wineries where tourists visit at large. “Usually, around 5,000 tourists come every month, but response was very good during last 10 days of December. Over 10,000 tourists visited our winery in past 10 days,” said Pradeep Pachpatil, chairman and managing director of Soma Vineyards.

He added that apart from visiting the winery, tourists also get to indulge in some wine tasting. In addition to the wineries, Nashik hoteliers also had their cash registers ringing.

“Almost all the city hotels had 100% occupancy in the last seven days of December in view of Chirstmas and New Year celebrations,” said Sanjay Chavan, president, Association of Hotels, Bars and Restaurants (ABHAR), Nashik.

Title: Official attached to secretariat following graft charges
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Dehradun: Education secretary R Meenakshi Sundaram attached a joint secretary rank officer to the secretariat on Wednesday. The move comes two days after an audio clip went viral on social media platforms. In the clip, the officer can purportedly be heard seeking bribe from a school owner for issuing a No Objection Certificate for CBSE board affiliation.

Late on Tuesday night, a government order was issued for action against the accused official which said that "such acts tarnish the image of the department and government”. Sundaram has also recommended suitable departmental action against the official, if he is found guilty.

In the two audio clips that went viral on social media, the official can purportedly be heard telling the principal of a private school that it’s not easy to get the affiliation as there are too many middlemen who have to be pleased to get the file cleared.

In the first audio clip, a man can be heard saying — “Pachaas tak to dena hi padega. Babu se le ke sab koi mangta hai (One has to shell out at least 50.. From a clerk to others, everyone demands).”

Responding to the demand, the school’s principal can be heard asking if the education minister will also be taking a share.

In the second audio clip, the official can purportedly be heard asking the school’s principal if he has made up his mind to pay the bribe or not.

“We have attached the official to the secretariat and have forwarded the matter to additional chief secretary Radha Raturi for further action as officials of joint secretary level are governed by secretariat administration, which is headed by her,” said R Meenakshi Sundaram.

Meanwhile, the official refused to talk on the issue saying that this is a conspiracy against him.

Title: On first day of year, Rajpur Road sees massive traffic snarls
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

yyyyyyyyyyyy

Dehradun: A long stretch of Rajpur Road witnessed traffic holdovers on Wednesday with a large number of tourist vehicles (from Delhi, Haryana, and Uttar Pradesh) contributing to the jam as many people who had come to hill stations like Mussoorie and Dhanaulti for New Year celebrations were returning home on the day.

As the Dehradun railway station has been shut for a few months for repair and reconstruction works, most of the tourists had driven to the hill state in their cars. The large number of four-wheelers prolonged the jam, with traffic moving at a snail’s pace for many hours.

When compared to previous years, the number of buses, cars and two-wheelers was significantly higher this year. As per sources, in the last few days of 2018, a total of 3,800 tourist vehicles had entered the hill stations near Doon. In 2019, the number went up to 4,500. Rajvir Pundhir, who was heading towards Nehru Colony on Wednesday afternoon, told TOI, “I had expected a light traffic jam as I knew that tourists would be returning home. However, the traffic jam was huge. Despite efforts by police and traffic personnel, the holdover was visible on almost the entire stretch of Rajpur Road.”

Meanwhile, police officials claimed that no traffic blockades were caused and that there was proper traffic management.

An official who did not wish to be named told TOI that a meeting was held with hotel owners before the start of New Year celebrations.“In the meeting, hotel owners were asked to provide parking slots to their customers. They were also told to request their customers to not use private vehicles for intra-city movement so as to avoid traffic jams.” As reported by TOI earlier, several tourists had flocked to popular tourist destinations across the state to welcome the New Year and majority of the hotels, resorts, and guest houses in hill stations like Mussoorie, Nainital, Mukteshwar, Auli, and Chakrata were packed to their capacity on December 31.

Title: Man found dead, police suspect accidental death
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Police during inspection on Wednesday

Dehradun: A 41-year-old man, identified as Kapil Dev Arora, was found dead near his residence in city’s Karanpur area on Wednesday morning. While his family members and friends did not rule out the possibility of murder, police, on the basis of the CCTV footage, claimed that it was “not a murder but an accidental death.”

Arora’s family friend Nilay Mishra told TOI, “Kapil was a computer expert and was extremely fond of electronic gadgets. He had done MCA and used to run a cyber cafe on the ground floor of his house. In the last few years, many hostels have come up in the area and the students living in those often created nuisance and argued with locals.”
