Mishra added that Kapil had an argument with a few hostel residents some time before his death.

“His family and friends strongly believe that his death may be a case of planned murder,” he added.

However after going through the footage of CCTV cameras of a neighbour’s residence, police said that Kapil might have died after falling from the first floor of a hostel.

SP City Shewta Choubey said, “The CCTV footage shows that he was trying to climb on to the first floor of a hostel situated next to his residence. During his attempt, the boundary grill broke and he fell on it.”

According to police, Kapil had an argument with some people in the late night hours of Tuesday and police constables, who were on the spot, had dropped him home. “The constables had handed over Kapil to his father Arjun Dev. Subsequently, Kapil was locked in a room by his father, but he managed to come out through the window of the room. Prima facie, it appears to be a case of accidental death but we are probing other aspects as well,” Choubey said.

Title: ‘Scrap exemption for PhD holders from NET/SET’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NAGPUR: Several city teachers, under the banner of All India NET/SET Teachers Organization and National Forum for Quality Education, have urged Kasturirangan Committee, tasked with drafting National Education Policy (NEP), to make National Eligibility Test (NET) and State Eligibility Test (SET) as recruitment exam.

They also demanded that PhD holders shouldn’t be given any exemption during recruitment and they be asked to clear the two entrances.

Presently, the NET and SET are treated as only eligibility test while recruitment is 100% based on personal interview of the candidates.

Through 2018 regulation, University Grants Commission (UGC) had exempted PhD holders from appearing in NET/SET for their appointment as teachers.

Though teachers’ bodies had opposed the move then, UGC refused to heed the concern. “The NET/SET exemption was not only unfair to 8 lakh qualified candidates across India but also led to dilution of research standards,” the teachers had claimed.

Even as the NEP is being framed, the UGC recently wrote to all universities asking them to make its ‘Research and Publication Ethics’ credit course compulsory for all PhD students as part of pre-registration course work.

“Introducing these two courses on Publication Ethics and misconduct is mere farce and an attempt to legalize the temporary exemption to PhD holders from mandatory NET /SET examinations,” said Ramesh N Zade, president, National Forum for Quality Education.

“If PhD is removed as eligibility for teaching positions and promotions, its ethics, standard and quality will certainly improve,” said Kushal M Mude, convener, All India NET SET Teachers Organization.

In their suggestions and feedback to the NEP draft committee, both the bodies have pointed out the importance of NET/SET upheld by different committees between 1983 and 2016.

Mehrotra Committee, comprising 18 members, was constituted in 1983 and after comprehensive survey and deliberations it had prescribed qualifying in NET as an essential condition for recruitment for the post of lecturer in any university or college throughout the country. This qualification was not to be relaxed even in the case of candidates possessing MPhil and PhD at the time of recruitment. These recommendations were introduced in NEP 1986 after discussion in the Parliament.

In 2007, Mungekar Committee in its final report removed exemptions to MPhil and PhD.

TSR Subramanian Committee, comprising five members, had submitted its report on ‘Evolution of New Education Policy’ in April 2016 and had recommended NET/SET as mandatory for teachers in higher education. The committee noted that there has been improvement in the quality of candidates joining higher education institutions as teachers as a result of NET.

Title: Irrigation project cost jumps 21 times & work is yet to start
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: The Lower Painganga dam being built in farm suicide-hit Yavatmal district may soon turn out to be another white elephant surpassing even Gosikhurd dam in terms of burgeoning cost.

Approved in 1997 at an initial cost of Rs1,402 crore in Ghatanji tehsil of Yavatmal district, even the basic construction work is yet to begin and it may now take Rs29,000 crore to finish the project.

In 2009, the first escalation taking the cost to Rs10,400 crore was approved. Now, another estimate of Rs29,000 crore has been drawn for the project and approval is awaited. As against this, the yearly fund allocation for the works has been in couple of crores only.

In comparison to that, current approved cost of Gosikhurd dam, which has been in the limelight for alleged irrigation scam, stands at Rs18,400 crore. The targeted irrigation potential for Lower Painganga is almost close to that of Gosikhurd at 2.27 lakh hectare.

In Gosikhurd, nearly half of the target of creating irrigation potential for 2.5 lakh hectare has been achieved. On the other hand, work on the Lower Painganga dam has been shelved since 2012 by Vidarbha Irrigation Development Corporation (VIDC).

A change in the design will now take the cost of Lower Painganga to Rs29,000 crore. A latest proposal has been put up before the state government over a year ago. All the VIDC has done so far is acquisition of 900 hectare forest land and over 700 hectare private holding.

As the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court disposed off a PIL seeking early completion of the project, it also directed the beneficiary states — Maharashtra and Telangana — to seek central assistance for expediting funds and pitch for making it a national project like Gosikhurd. The PIL was disposed off in 2017.

Maharashtra government had informed the HC that it had extended the deadline for the project completion to 2044, following fund crunch.

The main reason for the VIDC to have stopped the work is poor fund allocation. The VIDC has ended up spending a mere Rs330 crore in the last 22 years, which comes to Rs15 crore a year. For the 2019-20, the allocation for Lower Painganga is as low as Rs2.75 crore.

There is opposition from the locals to land acquisition which has also pushed back the work. VIDC needs to take over more than 19,000 hectare land for the project. Locals were against acquisition probably due to the low rates offered at that time. Now, five-fold hiked price has to be given under the new land acquisition law. However, even if the locals may find the deal lucrative, the VIDC does not have enough funds for buying the land, said a source. For land acquisition alone, the VIDC needs Rs4,700 crore.

The stopping of the work has also a political colour. Congress leaders in Yavatmal have blamed Devendra Fadnavis-led BJP government for deliberately neglecting the project.

Former MPCC president Manikrao Thakre said, “It’s a huge project that would have changed the fortunes of Yavatmal and adjoining areas where highest number of farm suicides have taken place. The last government under Fadnavis unfortunately put the project on the back burner following stiff opposition by BJP legislators, who were opposing land acquisition for the project from their respective constituencies. Now, we would raise the issue with concerned ministers in our government for early completion of the mega project. Allocation is the major problem and we will convince the government to seek central funds for it, as directed by the high court.”

Title: Mahavikas Aaghadi falls in Solapur ZP elections
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: The Mahavikas Aaghadi suffered a major setback in the Solapur zilla parishad (ZP) election as six members of Congress, NCP and Shiv Sena rebelled against the party decided to vote for BJP-led alliance.

BJP’s Aniruddha Kambale was elected as the president by bagging a total of 37 votes. Dilip Chavan secured 35 votes to be appointed as a new vice-president. The election had garnered interest in political circles as NCP had made it a prestigious issue after its debacle in the Lok Sabha election.

Mahavikas Aaghadi — the ruiling alliance of NCP, Congress, and Shiv Sena — was strong on paper with Karmala MLA Sanjay Shinde taking a keen interest in the election on the instruction from deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar.

However, Mahavaikas Aaghadi failed to capture power as four Sena members decided to join hands with BJP instead of Congress and NCP. Four Sena members are supporters of former Sena MLA Narayan Patil, who was denied ticket in the 2019 Assembly elections. The four members had contested the election on Sena symbol but defied party decision. Patil was expelled from Sena in the election as he had rebelled against official candidate Rashmi Bagal, who eventually lost the Karmala seat.

The Solapur the outcome is considered as an eye-opener for Mahavikas Aaghadi as senior leaders like deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar, Sanjay Shinde, and Baban Shinde, both MLAs Ganpatrao Deshmukh and Dilip Sopal have come together to keep BJP at bay.

BJP functionaries managed to keep its members united as influential leaders like Vijaysinh Mohite-Patil, Samadhan Autade, and Prashant Paricharak continued their support for BJP. All these leaders had come together in 2019 Lok Sabha elections, because of which Congress and NCP lost two seats in the Solapur district.

In the last election, Sanjay Shinde, now with NCP, had become president with the help of BJP. Shinde resigned from the membership after he got elected as MLA. BJP managed to attract four Sena members by offering them ZP president post and ensuring anti-BJP parties do not come into power

(With inputs from Suryakant Asbe)

Title: Swachh Survekshan 2020: Nashik features in top 10 list
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: Nashik city has featured among the top 10 cities (in more than 10 lakh population category) in the Swachh Survekshan League 2020 (Quarter 1 and Quarter 2).

Swachh Survekshan was introduced with the objective of sustaining the on-ground performance of cities along with continuous monitoring of service level performance in terms of cleanliness.

SS League 2020 is being conducted in three quarters, i.e. April-June, July-September and October-December 2019. The survey allots 2,000 marks for each quarter and is evaluated on the basis of monthly updation of details by cities along with citizen’s validation on the 12-service level progress indicators through outbound calls.

Union ministry of housing and urban development on Tuesday declared the ranks of top 20 cities. In the first quarter assessment, Nashik secured 4th rank in the country while it slipped to the 7th rank in the second quarter assessment.

Nashik is the first city in the state to be featured in the top 10 list. In the second quarter, it secured the second spot with Navi Mumbai being the first.

Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) officials are optimistic that the city will rank better than last yer in the final Swachh Survekshan results as 25% weightage of the quarterly assessments would be included in the annual survey scheduled to commence from 4 January till 31 January 2020.

The performance of cities in Swachh Survekshan League 2020 is crucial to their ranking in the survey due to the 25% weightage of the quarterly assessments to be included in the annual survey.

“Nashik has improved its ranking considerably from 63rd position to among top ten clean cities in the country. This is because of the joint efforts of officials, citizens, corporators and other institutions. We are confident that Nashik will emerge top clean cities in the country in Swachh Survekshan 2020,” said municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game.

“In Swachh Survekshan 2020, there are around 40 different indicators such as garbage lifting, garbage segregation, waste composting, cleanliness drive, public toilets, cleanliness of roads and markets etc. We tried to perform well in all segments, resulting in the city’s improved ranking in the first two quarters,” added Game.

“If citizens, corporators and officials work together, I am confident that Nashik will secure the first rank in the survey,” said Game.

Nashik city failed to perform well in Swachh Survekshan 2019 as its ranking among 425 cities had dropped from 63 in 2018 to 67 in 2019.

Citizens’ feedback accounts for 35 percent of the marks in the survey that is at the threshold. According to the data compiled by union ministry of housing and urban affairs, there had been poor response from citizens about their feedback related to cleanliness and sanitation status in their cities.

Title: Last date for registration under ‘easy installment scheme’ is now January 31
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Power consumers can now get registered under the ‘easy installment scheme’ till January 31.

The Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Ltd (UPPCL) had launched easy installment scheme in November under which domestic power consumers in urban areas with up to 4KW load were able to pay their dues in 12 easy installments while rural consumers can pay pending bills in 24 installments after registration. The last date has been extended from December 31 to January 31.

Speaking to TOI on Wednesday, Madhyanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (MVVNL) superintending engineer, rural, Tariq Jalil said, “The special scheme was launched hardly a month ago. December 31 which was the earlier deadline was too short to make power consumers aware and for them to avail it on time. Therefore, the last date has been extended till January 31, for the convenience of consumers. Around 21,000 rural power consumers in Bareilly district have so far got registered under the scheme since November.”

Sub-divisional officer (SDO), Bareilly, Sathyarth Gangwar said, “Around 3,800 urban power consumers have availed to the scheme and registrations are under process. To ensure that maximum power consumers avail the scheme, state government has extended the registration period by a month. We have been sensitizing people through media while consumers visiting power department offices are also being made aware about it.”

UP energy minister Shrikant Sharma had introduced the easy installment scheme in November 2019, with an aim to tackle the problem of power dues which is a major issue in UP. Under the scheme, LMV-1 (domestic/residential) category electricity consumers in urban and rural areas (having a load of up to 4 KW) can avail the scheme by simply paying 5% of the dues or minimum Rs 1,500 (whichever is higher)as first installment.

Domestic consumers of urban areas will get the benefit to pay entire dues in 12 monthly installments and domestic consumers of rural areas will get the benefit to pay entire dues in 24 monthly installments and during the period, late payment surcharge penalty on the dues till October 31 will be waived.

Title: Naik Sawant loses his life in cross fire
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: Naik Sandeep Raghunath Sawant lost his life on Wednesday morning while fighting against infiltrators in Naushera sector, Jammu and Kashmir.

Mortal remains of Sandeep Sawant is expected to arrive at Pune airport on Thursday.

The 25-year-old martyr hails from Munde village in Karad taluka of Satara district. He is survived by his father, mother, wife and two-month-old daughter.

Maratha Light Infantry Naik spotted few infiltrators, who were trying to cross the border. Sandeep was accompanied by Arjun Thapa Magar of Gorkha Rifles. Both of them opened fire at the infiltrators. Indian army cordoned the area from where the infiltrators were trying to cross the border. However, Sawant and Thapa were seriously injured in the cross firing and later succumbed to their injuries.

According to the official communication from Defence Ministry, the last rites will take place in Munde village on Thursday.

Title: On New Year’s Eve, youth hacked to death by 5
Content: Ahmedabad: Five persons, including a minor, barged into the home of Paras Katheria of Bhargav Road, Meghaninagar, on Tuesday night, and hacked him to death with swords and knives.Katheria, who ran a sewing factory, was readying to welcome the New Year with his friends when the incident took place.Police have arrested the minor while the other four are on the run, said inspector D J Chudasama of Meghaninagar police station. Police said all five accused were inebriated when they committed the murder at about 10pm on Tuesday.“The accused persons on the run are Sandeep Gupta, Ajay Barot, Ravi Limbachia and Deepak Gupta,” Chudasama said.Police sources said the accused had fallen out with Katheria after a scuffle over drinking seven months ago. One of the accused, Deepak Gupta, had been injured in that fight.“Deepak and his friends were looking for revenge, and chose New Year’s Eve for their attack, knowing that Katheria will be at home for celebrations,” said a police official.“Katheria was rushed to a nearby hospital, but he was declared dead on reaching there. We have registered a murder case,” Chudasama said.

Title: Purse with valuables snatched
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: The Shahupuri police have registered an FIR against an unidentified person for snatching the purse of a woman while she was boarding a Ratnagiri-bound bus from the Central Bus Stand in the city on Monday afternoon.

Police said that the purse contained valuables worth Rs 2.27, including Rs 30,000 cash and gold jewellery.

The complainant — Utkarsha Uday Nagale — is a resident of Charweli of Ratnagiri district. She had come to the city for some work when the incident took place.

Jewellery shop burgled, valuables stolen

Kolhapur: Unidentified men broke open the shutter of a jewellery shop in Sarud village of the Shahuwadi taluka and decamped with silver ornaments worth Rs 45,000.

A complaint in this regard has been registered with the Shahuwadi police station.

Police said that they are investigating the case in details.

Title: Avg wholesale onion price crashes by Rs 1,000 in a day
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: The average wholesale onion price crashed by Rs 1,000 per quintal — from Rs 4,500 per quintal on Tuesday to Rs 3,500 per quintal on Wednesday — at Lasalgaon APMC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market.

The increase in the supply of onions has led to the drop in the average wholesale price.

In Nashik retail markets, onions were being sold for Rs 45-60 per kg on Wednesday. The drop in wholesale prices are expected to reflect in the retail markets in the next couple of days. The retail onion prices are expected to drop to below Rs 50 a kg soon.

The supply of fresh kharif onions has increased over the past few days. The daily supply at the Lasalgaon APMC has increased to about 22,000 quintals a day. A fortnight ago, it was receiving just about 12,000 quintals every day. This increase in supply has helped bring down the average wholesale onion price, said APMC officials.

On Wednesday, the minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices at Lasalgaon were recorded at Rs 2,000 and Rs 4,551 per quintal, respectively.

We expect the trend of wholesale onion prices to be downward now. The supply will further increase once the arrival of kharif onions becomes regular by the second half of January. The average wholesale onion prices are expected to drop to Rs 2,000 per quintal in the next 10-12 days, said APMC officials.

Usually, the arrival of fresh kharif onions begins by mid-October, but the unseasonal rain had badly affected the kharif crop across Maharashtra this time. Around 75% of the onion plantations were damaged. This created scarcity of onions that shot up the average wholesale onion prices, added the officials.

But the acreage of late kharif onions has increased in the district to around 45,000 hectares. Now, the harvest of late kharif onions is expected to gather momentum.

Title: Six more anti-CAA protesters arrested in Rampur
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

RAMPUR: At least six more protesters — all aged between 25 and 30 years — were arrested in Rampur on Wednesday after they were “identified from video footage” during a protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act which turned violent at Hati Khana Chauraha on December 21. These protesters were allegedly involved in pelting stones at police personnel, vandalising property and setting ablaze police jeep and bikes.

Rampur superintendent of police (SP), Ajay Pal Sharma, said the arrests were made only after a thorough probe, while family members of the arrested claimed they were innocent. The arrested persons appeared in video footage collected from the protest site, police said. All the arrested persons were presented before the court of the chief judicial magistrate and sent to jail under heavy police escort on Wednesday. Earlier, 18 protesters were reportedly arrested and sent to jail.

Police had also allegedly recovered a .32 caliber bore pistol and two live cartridges from the possession of one of the arrested protesters, identified as Nadeem. Rampur SP told TOI that initial probe indicated that the pistol recovered was used in firing during the protests. “We are investigating the presence of pistol at the protest site and will also seek police custody remand (PCR) of Nadeem for further questioning,” the SP added.

Police arrested the protesters under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapons ), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object), 307 (attempt to murder), 302 (murder), 333 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 353 (assault or criminal force) and under sections 3 and 4 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act 1984. Section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act has also been invoked against the anti-CAA protesters.

The six arrested persons have been identified as Shimmi, Nadeem, Qayam Mian, Amir Ali, Nazim and Zahid. They were picked up by the Kothwali Sadar police officers.

Meanwhile, Nadeem’s family members said that he owns a grocery shop near the Hati Khana Chauraha. His elder brother Sharief said, “When police arrested Nadeem, we approached senior police officers, and they showed a video footage where Nadeem was purportedly seen. He was seen speaking on his mobile phone. Now, we will approach the court for his bail.”

Another protester was identified as 27-year-old Nazim, a city-based truck driver. Nazim’s elder brother Asif, who runs a paan shop at Pharai gate locality, said, “Nazim is the lone breadwinner. He has four children. He is innocent. But, police officers told us that he was involved in the protest and they have video clips. Now, we’ll approach the court.”

The family members of Shimmi, Qayam, Amir and Zahid have all claimed that they were not involved in the December 21 violent protests and police are concocting stories, mainly, for damage claims.

Rampur district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh had earlier ordered a magisterial probe into the death of 27-year-old Faiz Khan, an alleged protester.

Title: Bhujbal disapproves of NMC’s city bus project
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nashik: State cabinet minister Chhagan Bhujbal on Wednesday expressed his reservations about the civic body’s decision to take over the city bus service from the ailing Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation ( MSRTC ) and roll out swanky vehicles.

Talking to reporters, Bhujbal said this new bus service would add a financial burden of around Rs 100 crore on the cash-strapped Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC).

The NMC will incur an expenditure of over Rs 100 crore and this will also put an additional tax burden on residents. Therefore, instead of running the city buses itself, the NMC should provide some funds to the MSRTC to enable it to operate the service effectively, Bhujbal said.

The NMC’s preparations are already in the final stages of taking over the service from MSRTC.

Bhujbal’s statement comes when NMC is in the final stages of rolling out the city bus service. The bus service is to be operated on GCC (gross cutting contract) system for a period of 10 years. This includes the purchase of new buses, maintenance of buses, employing drivers, purchasing fuel, etc. The municipal corporation will pay charges to private agencies on a km basis. NMC has already finalised three agencies to operate all 400 buses in the city, including 200 CNG, 150 electric and 50 diesel buses. It has given letters of intent to the three agencies.

Two of the three agencies have also deposited the necessary bank guarantee to the civic body, while the third agency is expected to do so in the next few days.

NMC officials said they are planning to sign an agreement with these three agencies in a week or two. As per norms, each agency will have to deploy at least 50 buses within three months from the date of signing the agreement.

Title: Kolhapur: Congress office-bearers threaten to resign over ministerial berths
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Supporters of P N Patil claimed that he had been with the party for 40 years, yet he was ignored during the ca... Read More

KOLHAPUR: Several office-bearers of Kolhapur district Congress have announced that they would resign as MLA P N Patil has been denied a ministerial berth.

Patil recently got elected as the MLA from Karvir assembly constituency. He was district Congress president for 20 years and was made state deputy president before the assembly elections. The supporters of P N Patil claimed that he has been with the party for last 40 years and yet was ignored during the cabinet expansion.

The supporters want Patil to resign from Congress and subsequently as MLA. His supporters had gathered at a multi-purpose hall in Phulewadi to express their disgruntlement.

One of his supporters, who was at the meeting, said, “Patil has been with the party during its good times and tough days. We were expecting him to be appointed minister in 2004 itself. Despite being denied the ministerial berth, he remained loyal to the party and worked as district president. Now, we want him to tender his resignation.”

The chiefs of three taluka units of Congress, a district woman president and several other office-bearers attended the meeting and agreed to resign soon. Patil was not available for his comment.

However, one of his close aides said he will talk to the supporters and then finalise his stand and future course of action in three to four days. “He has not met the supporters yet. He will form his opinion after that and in next three to four days he will speak in public,” the aide said.

In the meeting, district women head of Congress Supriya Salokeh, Karvir tehsil president Shankarrao Patil, Radhanagari tehsil president Hindurao Chougale, Ajara tehsil president Namdeo Narvekar, party co-ordinator for Radhanagari assembly constituency Sushil Patil-Kavlavkar and Seva Dal president Subhash Patil Sirsekar decided to tender their resignations to district Congress president Satej Patil . Also, several students leader vowed to support P N Patil and they too will resign from the student’s wing-National Students Union of India.

The district Congress party is divided into factions. The factions led by P N Patil and Satej Patil are major factions. Satej Patil is credited for the spectacular performance of the party in recent assembly election.

Title: Cops brave rain to nab 592 revellers
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NAGPUR: Despite the post midnight downpour presenting challenge before police personnel deployed to check drunk driving on New Year’s Eve, they managed to nab 592 revellers who were driving under the influence of alcohol between 9pm on Tuesday and 6am on Wednesday. The action was taken at 50 nakabandi points at different locations set up by city police, including traffic cops and police station staff.

Rain also helped in a way as many revellers stayed indoors, bringing down the number of drunk driving case this year by almost half as compared to last year. Last year, city police had registered 1,069 drunk driving cases on New Year’s Eve.

DCP traffic Chinmay Pandit said, “It’s because of our arrangements the New Year night passed off without any major incident or accident. The bandobast started in the evening but heavy rain created complications for the cops during nakabandi. Had there been no rain, the number of drunk driving cases would have increased. Our staff did not leave their position and kept vigil on revellers.”

Among the 10 traffic zones, the maximum drunk driving cases were detected at Indora and Kamptee with 80 and 85 revellers getting caught respectively. At Sonegaon, which is the entry point for traffic coming from Wardha Road where several dhabas are located, registered the least number of cases — 43.

Till 9pm on Tuesday, cops had registered 103 drunk driving cases. With time the number increased. Around 110 cases were detected between 11pm and midnight. The most number of drunk drivers, 176, were nabbed between midnight and 2am on Wednesday.

Ahead of New Year’s Eve, the traffic department under DCP Pandit had launched crack down against drunk driving. Cops had also identified several sensitive points to avoid accidents and kept tight police bandobast throughout the night.

Title: KMC reduces supply as water level declines in barrage
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: The water supply department of the civic administration has reduced the water supply in some of the areas due to the decline of the water level at Shinganapur barrage .

The water is pumped from Shinganapur barrage located along the Panchganga river.

The water level is currently at 534.70 feet, which is below the required water level.

The water supply department has reduced the water supply and changed the timings in certain areas. For instance, Shahunagar, on Wednesday, received water one hour late and it lasted for two hours. Usually, the water supply to most of the areas is for at least three hours once in a day.

A senior water department official, on the condition of anonymity, said, “There is a major leakage in the barrage. We are going to carry out the repair work soon. The water level at the barrage has gone down. We have requested the water resources department to release more water from the upstream dams to maintain an adequate level. We have reduced the water supply in some areas which receive water twice a day for more than three hours.”

The water resources department (WRD) asked the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) to repair the leakages immediately and has not taken any decision yet to release more water from the dams. The WRD officials said that the water in the dams is meant for crisis situations such in summer when the demand for both drinking and irrigation are high.

The corporators are upset over reducing the supply of the water. Chhaya Powar, Congress corporator said, “Without consulting the local corporators, the decision was taken along with changing the timings of water supply. If there is any crisis, then the administration should inform us so that we can do something.”

The corporators complained to the standing committee chairman Sharangdhar Deshmukh. “I have scheduled a special meeting to discuss the issues related to water supply on Saturday. We have faced similar situations before. We will get the plan ready from the water supply department to address the water scarcity that is likely to occur in summer,” said Deshmukh.

The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has issued the tenders for appointing a firm for the repair work of the barrage. The KMC has set the deadline of May end to complete the task.

Title: Voting for ZP top posts to put focus on MVA and BJP today
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: The election for the post of president and deputy president of Kolhapur Zilla Parishad have piqued interest considering the changed political equations in the state and the denial of minister berth to senior Congress MLA P N Patil.

The BJP-led alliance has held the posts for the last two-and-half years but the new Mahavikas Aghadi could prove a hurdle in retaining the position.

The voting for the two posts will take place on Thursday afternoon. The nominations for the posts will have to be filed before 2 pm. The election proceeding will be video-graphed.

Members of ZP have been taken to undisclosed location and they will be bought back by late night or early morning of Thursday. Senior office-bearers of the parties will be meeting the members before they cast their vote.

To win the posts, the parties must be at least 34 votes. Congress and NCP, which are in the opposition, on Wednesday claimed to have the support of 35 members, while a similar claim has been made by BJP-led alliance.

All eyes are on the stand to be adopted by the supporters of Congress MLA P N Patil, who was not made a minister in the state government. Several of the ZP members are unhappy with the Patil’s exclusion and may abstain from voting. At least five members are known supporters of Patil and could prove a worry for Cong-NCP alliance.

The BJP-led alliance has power in the ZP since last two and half years but the five Congress members are in touch with the BJP. Minister of state Satej Patil, who is from Kolhapur, is making all the efforts to convince them to vote for Congress nominee.

According to the sources, a meeting was held between the leaders of Cong-NCP alliance and Shiv Sena on Wednesday evening. Shiv Sena members led by former MLA Chandradip Narke have decided to support Cong-NCP alliance.

BJP state president Chandrakant Patil and several leaders of Tararani Aghadi, led by Mahadevrao Mahadik, are ensuring their members do not support Congress-NCP alliance. Sources in BJP claimed that they have got the support of two members of Swabhimani Paksha led by former MP Raju Shetti, who is unhappy with Congress and NCP.

Title: Valuables worth Rs 5.47L stolen in house break-in
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: Unidentified men broke open a flat located in Kadamwaid area of the city and decamped with valuables worth Rs 5.47 lakh.

According to the Shahupuri police, the complainant identified as Pratap Vishnu Puranik (70, resident of Kadamwadi) lodged a complaint in this regard. “Puranik owns a flat in a building in Kadamwadi area. On December 26, he had gone out for some work and when he returned home the next day, he found the locks of door broken. After entering the house, he found the material from house thrown on the floor. when he checked the cupboard where he had kept the valuables, he found the lock of the cupboard broken and the valuables kept in it stolen. The stolen valuables include gold and silver jewellery, expensive watches and cash Rs 1000, all amounting to Rs 5.47 lakh,” said an officer.

Title: Swimming pools, tennis courts in offing for Jodhpur
Content: Ahmedabad: A civic bonanza in the new year is planned for Jodhpur residents. At least seven major projects involving sports and recreation have been lined up this year. The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has planned a fully air-conditioned gymnasium near Jodhpur civic centre, along with an air-conditioned library and reading room. This is not all, near Rathi hospital the open AMC plot will host an exclusive volleyball court. Near Setu Bungalows, after Jodhpur residents suggested sports infrastructure built in the open plot, the AMC is preparing plans for a swimming pool and a tennis court. Another large swimming pool based on dimensions suggested by the Sports Authority of India (SAI) will come up on an open plot towards Shakti Vidyalaya. A second tennis court is also being planned and a few plots have been identified for the purpose.“The demand for swimming pools and tennis courts was made by many residential societies here,” said a senior AMC official.

Title: Karnataka groups crowdfund Rs 2 crore for victims’ families
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Protest in Mangaluru against CAA (file photo)

MANGALURU: Two weeks after violent protests against CAA left two protesters dead in Mangaluru, various organisations and individuals have contributed over Rs 2 crore to help their families and those who were injured in the clashes.

“Funds started pouring in after Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa rolled back Rs 10 lakh compensation to the families of each victim that he had announced after the violence,” said a police officer who is probing the violence.

Former MLA BA Mohiuddeen Bava is among those who are involved in collecting the funds. However, he refused to divulge details about the money collected so far. “Contributions may stop if we reveal this information. We are trying to help the victims’ families and the injured. They are facing financial difficulties after the recent violence,” he said.

On December 19, anti-CAA protests turned violent and a mob allegedly tried to attack a police station. Nauseen Kudroli, 49, and Jaleel Bengre, 23, were killed when Mangaluru police opened fire to control the protesters. Sources said that over 12 people, who were injured during the protests, are still being treated at various hospitals in the coastal city.

“Over Rs 2 crore has been collected to help the victims. Contributors have decided that Rs 25 lakh each will be given to Kudroli and Bengre’s families. The rest will be given to the injured protesters. We don’t know when the funds will be handed over to them,” a senior police officer told TOI.

Former CMs Siddaramaiah and HD Kumaraswamy have already announced compensation to the victims’ families. West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee recently announced Rs 5 lakh each for the two families.

Title: 43 motorists booked for drunk driving on New Year’s Eve
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Kolhapur: City police have booked 43 motorists for driving under influence (DUI) on the New Year’s Eve. The figure is much less compared to 2018 when 60 motorists were booked on the night of December 31.

Vasant Babar, police inspector in-charge of city traffic department, said, “The drive was launched by city traffic department as well as police staff from various police stations in the city. Equipped with six breath analysers, traffic police were deployed at major chowks in the city. They fined 16 motorists driving under influence of liquor on the New Year’s Eve. More cases have been registered with various police stations and accordingly action was taken against rule violators.”

“A total of 43 motorists were booked by four police stations and the city traffic department. We have issued instructions to the regional transport office (RTO) asking them to take strict action against them as per law and suspend their driving licence,” said a senior police officer.

The traffic department, however, did not come across rash drivers or triple seat riders.“The celebrations were peaceful and the bikers did not resort to rash driving,” said Babar.

Maximum cases of drunk driving were registered in the jurisdiction of Shahupuri police station followed by Laxmipuri police station. 18 cases were registered with the Shahupuri police station while 7 were filed with the Laxmipuri police.

Title: In five days, tiger injures third person in Kheri district
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

BAREILLY: A 55-year-old farmer was injured by a tiger in Kaanp Tanda village which falls in Kishanpur Wildlife Sanctuary of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve on Wednesday.

The farmer received injuries on both of his hands and right leg and was admitted to a community health centre in Bheera. This is the third such tiger-human encounter in Kheri district since Saturday — leaving one dead and wounding three persons at different locations in Lakhimpur Kheri district.

The latest victim of tiger attack was identified as Paragu Bihari, a resident of Kaamp Tanda village. He was walking towards his field when a tiger suddenly appeared in front of him from a cane field and pounced on him. Paragu immediately screamed for help and a few villagers working at a nearby field rushed to rescue him.

There has been a significant rise in the total census of tigers in the state with maximum number of tigers, nearly 100, present in Kheri district. The earlier records show that the tiger attacks were found to be higher in winter season. Tigers usually move out of forest area to sugarcane fields in search of their prey. Many tigers take shelter inside sugarcane fields for months and hunt wild boars and Nilgai with much ease. Forest department has already alerted all the outlining villages to refrain from entering the forest area and move in groups, especially near sugarcane fields.

Speaking to TOI, divisional forest officer (buffer) Anil Patel said, “We have already alerted the residents of the villages located on forest outskirts. They were advised to move in groups, especially near forest area, but still they move alone and ignore our warnings. We have also offered the villagers in Kaamp Tanda village to relocate outside the forest area with a decent compensation but they are yet to agree on the proposal. Fortunately, the victim of today’s tiger attack is stable and he will be released from the hospital soon.”

Title: After partying, many spend New Year Day outside court
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NAGPUR: Many who partied hard as well as those preferring to go about as usual, spent the New Year Day waiting in long queues outside the Motor Vehicle Court on the premises of Nyay Mandir in Civil Lines after they and their vehicles were caught in drunk driving cases.

Probably for the first time, the offenders included people whose vehicles were used at the time by revellers in a state of inebriation. Generally, owners of vehicle caught while driven by minors were booked in such a fashion.

Traffic cops, who conducted on spot breathanaylser test, clubbed Sections 184 and 185 with 180 of the Motor Vechile Act (MVA) to fix responsibility on vehicle owners too.

While Sections 184 and 185 pertain to rash driving under influence of alcohol, 180 holds an individual accountable for permitting unauthorized persons to drive vehicles. Vehicle owners are levied a fine of Rs1,000 while it is Rs3,000 for first-time drunk drivers and Rs4,000 for repeat offenders. Rs500 too was imposed on several offenders for driving without licenses taking the total penalty to Rs4,500 to Rs5,000.

A woman doctor, whose compounder was caught drunk by cops, was penalized Rs1,000 beside having to wait all day in the serpentine queue.

She said she had given her scooterette to the employee to get a water can for the hospital but the man went for a drink on Umred Road. She coughed up a total fine of Rs4,500 as she had to pay for her employee as well.

Several youths too were imposed a cost of Rs3,000 each for drunk driving and Rs500 in absence of license.

This brought a windfall for small time lawyers who made a quick buck. The lawyers and their agents were seen outside the JMFC court luring gullible citizens. The lawyers charged Rs300 for assistance till the case is heard and settled. Agents charged 50% of the lawyers fee for bringing clients though the cases don’t need legal assistance.

Adv Suresh Shinde said he got seven cases while other days he there are just one or two.

Adv Sanjay Takode said people can do it on their own but they don’t want to take any risk of missing any documents which will entail coming again. “The registration certificate had to be presented before the judge with identification documents and valid license. First time offenders are not much aware of all these formalities,” he said.

Both, Shinde and Takode, said there is no way lawyers can get the penalty waived off once a drunk driving case in filed but people feel comfortable having a counsel by their side.

Adv Vihang Sakhare said the New Year celebration period is bringing good income for not just lawyers but also the government. “Over 500 cases have been made. The per day collection goes up to Rs3lakh to Rs 5lakh for the government,” he said.

Title: ‘Organic waste is black gold’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

I am a resident of Civil Lines, and have been preparing compost for the last 8 to 10 years. I read an article in The Economic Times about using kitchen waste in home gardens, and it inspired me to take up this green practice.

I had to partake in a number of trial and error methods to check which one was suitable for me, on the basis of availability of time and other resources. I started watching videos and undertook comprehensive research to adopt a sustainable system.

I collect vegetable and fruit scraps, and discard them in the flower bed. This mixes with the soil and improves the moisture content. The flowers grow in full bloom, owing to the enriched soil. When I started this process, I faced the problem of rodents creating a menace. Upon looking for other options, I found one that made use of old earthen pots.

I dispose of the overcooked and leftover food in the earthen pot, which has a hole at its bottom. Once the remains are drained out, it can be used as compost, too. I have used this organic waste mixed with soil in saplings to present as a gift to near and dear ones.

The earth gives us several resources in abundance, but we don’t know how to manage them. We don’t have the patience, and expect everything to be ready-made. Even after studying science in school, many people do not understand the value of this organic matter. We are facing many problems, and it is important to wake up right now and act on it.

I hope that citizens read up about various methods of putting their waste to use, and embrace them to play their part in saving the environment from mounting garbage heaps. Organic waste is black gold , and we must find the right way to utilize it to its full potential.

Title: December 31 drunk driving cases up 71% in Mumbai
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Drunk driving cases in Mumbai were up 71% this New Year’s Eve from the previous December 31. Nearly 780 cases of drunk driving were recorded between Tuesday night and early on Wednesday, 35% of the offenders being motorcyclists. By comparison, last New Year’s Eve, a total of 455 cases were recorded in the city.A higher number of motorists from Navi Mumbai, too, were caught drunk driving, though their numbers were much lower than Mumbai’s. Nearly 390 motorists were booked for drunk driving on New Year's Eve —up 9% from the previous year. Palghar motorists were the worst; 163 cases were recorded on New Year's Eve, more than double the figure in the previous year. Thane motorists, though, appeared to have sobered up with drunk driving cases down 19% to 1,673 from 2,071.Overall, 3,047 cases of drunk driving were recorded in Mumbai Metropolitan Region—a minor variation from the previous year.“We had made it clear that anti-drunk driving checks would be strict in Mumbai. At certain locations, nakabandis for drunk driving were started as early as 3pm on Tuesday. In most parts of the city, checks began by 9pm and concluded at 6am on Wednesday,” said Madhukar Pandey, joint commissioner, traffic. “Not a single accident was reported,” he added.More than 2,400 traffic policemen were out on the streets across 182 locations in Mumbai. They were armed with 238 breathalyzers and 100 body cameras. The highest number of drunk driving cases at 58 were recorded by Dahisar Chowky. The fewest cases at eight were recorded by the Worli Chowky. Dahisar Chowky also intercepted the highest number of drunk two-wheeler riders at 50 cases.Mumbai traffic police also recorded 601 cases of signal jumping, 258 cases of triple seat and 241 of speeding.In Navi Mumbai, the increase in cases was attributed to more policemen being deployed. “A majority of offenders were motorcyclists aged between 25 to 35 years. Despite Kharghar being a no-liquor zone with no wine shops or permit rooms, we still caught 25 people for drunk driving there. The reason could be tipplers consuming liquor at bars in other areas and returning home to Kharghar,” said Navi Mumbai ACP (traffic) Rajendra Chavan. Kalamboli traffic unit recorded highest number of cases in Navi Mumbai.In Thane, traffic police also booked 188 co-passengers for knowingly travelling in a vehicle steered by a drunk driver.“Thane has shown a dip in drunk driving on New Year's Eve because we had conducted consistant drives two days prior to New Year’s Eve. More than 500 traffic police personnel from 18 units fanned across Thane and were assisted by mobile units in intercepting offenders,” said inspector Mahesh Patil.

Title: RTI activist moves Mumbai top cop for assault FIR against DCP
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

RTI activist Yashwant Shinde

MUMBAI: An RTI activist has lodged a complaint with Mumbai police commissioner seeking immediate registration of an FIR against DCP Abhinash Kumar for allegedly assaulting him without provocation.

Mumbai-based RTI activist Yashwant Shinde was admitted to KEM Hospital six days ago for internal injuries. He was discharged three days later on December 30. Shinde has given a two-day deadline for registration of his FIR or he would approach the Maharashtra State Police Complaint Authority.

Shinde had filed an appeal with Kumar regarding an “unsatisfactory” reply he got from Worli and Byculla police over Right to Information (RTI) Act queries. In December, Shinde had sought details under RTI on Worli police’s seizure of Rs 4 crore cash from a car during the state assembly elections in October.

“I had sought information regarding the seizure of cash as well as a job racket registered at Agripada police where BMC jobs were given on the basis of fake documents. In both cases, Mumbai police gave me evasive replies. Hence, I filed an appeal before DCP Kumar who was to hear me on December 27,” said Shinde.

Shinde had taken along a friend, Jitendra Kataria, to Kumar’s office.

Shinde alleged Kumar was aggressive and within minutes the discussion turned ugly. “I was polite to him and was listening sincerely but Kumar was rude and aggressive. All of a sudden, he got furious and jumped on his table and then pounced on me and began to hit me ruthlessly.” Shinde said when he tried to run, Kumar called his colleagues who pulled him back in the cabin. “They caught me and helped Kumar beat me till I fell unconscious.”

A bleeding Shinde was handed over to Byculla police where cops allegedly told him there was no point in complaining against Kumar, while apologising on his behalf, and advised him to say he fell off a chair. “A few policemen visited me in hospital and tried to convince me to change my mind about filing a complaint.”

Denying the allegation, Kumar said, “Nothing of this sort happened. He got injured after falling off a chair. The complaint is an afterthought as he is in the habit of being rude and of misbehaving. Four diary entries have been made against him for misbehaving with senior policemen. Secondly, the information he had sought under RTI was not relevant to him.”

Title: 409 held drunk or with booze
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ahmedabad: In the commercial capital of dry Gujarat, where the manufacture, sale and consumption of liquor is banned, more than 409 people were arrested for consumption or possession of liquor on New Year’s Eve or the wee hours of Wednesday, police said.

People thronged the Sabarmati riverfront and various lakes in the city around midnight to welcome 2020, a police official said, adding that no untoward incident was reported in the city. Several people were caught drinking or in possession of liquor during the New Year’s celebrations, especially in Sardarnagar, Bapunagar and Meghaninagar areas, the official said.

A police official said that in the city’s Sector 1 police jurisdiction, more than 150 persons were caught for liquor violations, including eight in Sola, four in Gujarat University 4 and eleven in Ellisbridge police station limits.

The figures for Sector 2 were higher, with 108 caught in Sardarnagar alone, 12 in Naroda, 19 in Krishnanagar, 13 in Meghaninagar and 20 in Ramol. Security was stepped-up across the city in anticipation of the late-night parties and celebrations, the official said.

Breath analyser tests were also conducted to check if people were drunk, especially while driving, he said.

“As many as 368 people were arrested for consumption of liquor, while 41 were held for possessing liquor last night,” deputy commissioner of police (control) Vijay Patel said.

Thousands of revellers thronged the Sabarmati riverfront, Vastrapur and Kankaria lakes, and there was a rush at hotels and restaurants late on Tuesday night.

Many residents who stayed home threw parties to welcome the New Year. Residents of Bopal and Satellite celebrated with dazzling fireworks.

Women cops in plain clothes also mingled with the crowds to check eve-teasing, a police official said.

Title: Kerala govt looks at alternatives to plastic
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government has entrusted Kerala State Pollution Control Board (PCB) for testing and notifying alternative materials that can substitute the banned single-use plastic items in the state.

The department of environment has directed PCB to test the suitability of the alternatives for single-use plastic items with the assistance of CSIR-National Institute for Interdisciplinary Science & Technology, Thiruvananthapuram .

Following the ban on single-use plastic items in the state, the demand for alternative materials has risen considerably in the state.

According to officials, many have approached state government with the claim to have discovered alternatives for the banned plastic, that are compostable as well as biodegradable. PCB will be responsible for checking the suitability of the alternative materials and it has to be lab tested and verified before they are brought to the market.

The Union government has identified “compostable plastic” as one of the alternatives to the regular plastic. The rules specify standards/norms for “compostable plastic”. Further, to promote the use of such plastic, the restrictive provision of 50 microns minimum thickness is not applicable to carry bags.

Further, a committee has been constituted by Central Institute of Plastics Engineering & Technology (CIPET) with respect to research and development for compostable/biodegradable technologies on plastic. Plastic Waste Management Rules, 2016 define the norms for compostable plastic as an ecologically sustainable and green alternative of plastic. The rules prohibit the use of plastic bags with thickness less than 50 microns.

As per the reply furnished by Prakash Javadekar, minister for environment, forest and climate change , in Lok Sabha in November 2019, the guidelines suggest jute bags, cloth bags, paper bags as alternatives to plastic carry bags.

The minister has said that sufficient alternatives were available for plastic cutlery such as paper plates and leaf plates, paper/earthen cups and glass, wooden spoons, paper straws, multi-layered (aluminum + paper) pouches in place of container and container lids, wooden trays, stirrers made of wood.

Apart from the traditional material, new material like bagasse-based products, banana stem-based products are widely available in market, the reply pointed out. For the portion of plastic in items like ear buds sticks, balloons sticks, flags, candies, etc, wood/bamboo/paper, etc were suggested as easily available options. The other alternatives presented by Javadekar in Lok Sabha were cloth banner, lightweight textile fabric, wrinkle resistant warp knit, natural fibre-based sandwich board , resin-infused paper and partial boards.

Title: Ahmedabad: Love, like internet, is catching them young
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A teacher at a city school was shocked when she got hold of a note bearing the message “I love you” addressed to a girl. The message was circulating in Class I, at which stage kids are about 6 years old . The girl disavowed the note. The boy, thought to be its author, told the teacher that he liked the girl and for him ‘like’ and ‘love’ were interchangeable terms.A group of Class III girls (about 8 years old) of another school were busy discussing love affiliations and linking each other with the boys. When a teacher stepped in to shoot down the Cupid’s arrows flying around the class, the girls said they were only having fun. For their part, the boys seemed enamoured of only video games and gadgets.In yet another school, a girl in Class VII (about 12 years old) stopped talking after developing a crush on a new boy. She had speech problems and did not want him to notice that.Love, like the internet, is catching them young. Indeed, children are being exposed to the ideas of attraction and love through a host of mediums, primarily the mobile internet. But they seldom get the help of adults to tackle half-formed instincts.Driven perhaps by early hormonal changes or the loneliness that is inevitable in a nuclear family or when being brought up by a single parent, children are seeking solace from peers. But the peers themselves are a confused lot.“I am a homemaker and have all the time in the world to monitor my children,” said Kalpana Parikh, a mother of two teenage daughters. “But it is difficult to keep an eye on their WhatsApp chats. There, no topic is off-limit.” She went on to say: “Recently, I found my daughter, a Class VII student, resolving a tiff between her classmates, who were in a relationship according to her.”Another parent, Tushar Singh, said: “My son is in Class VI, but his friendship with senior girls of Class IX-X often scares me.” Singh added: “Once I found love letters in his school diary; I was disturbed. It took me a lot of time to make him understand things and bring his focus back to studies.”Smita Ghosh, a counsellor, said: “Children confess to being in love, but lack clarity about love.” Ghosh said it is crucial to make children understand that attraction is normal and at times hormone-spurred. “But they should not miss their goals,” she said.Dr Prashant Bhimani, a psychologist, said: “If you make your children understand respectful relationship indirectly, they will apply the principle themselves.”

Title: Thane: Man trapped while trying to sell monkeys to jugglers
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The accused led forest officials to two more monkeys held captive.

THANE: A 28-year-old man was arrested by Thane forest officials for allegedly capturing and trying to sell three rhesus macaque species of monkeys to local jugglers .

Narendra Muthe, range forest officer, Thane, said they were tipped off about a man planning to sell monkeys to jugglers from Kalwa on Monday night. The officials accordingly laid a trap for him.

The officials were waiting at a designated spot in Kalwa East when they spotted a man carrying a plastic basket loitering in the area in a suspicious manner.

Immediately, the officials intercepted him and on questioning, he broke down and admitted to carrying a monkey in the plastic basket. The man then led the officials to his hideout nearby where he had kept two more monkeys captive to be sold to jugglers at a later date. The animals were rescued by forest officials and kept in their custody. The forest officials registered a case against him and presented him before court that later granted him bail.

“We were informed about a man trying to trade monkeys illegally to jugglers. We laid a trap for him and when we interrogated him, he told us he used to trap monkeys from nearby jungles and then sell them to jugglers in the area for Rs 15,000,” said Muthe.

Forest officials said they will be probing the case further to know if the accused has a history of illegally trading animals and to uncover his network.

The rhesus macaque is a most common species of monkeys and is found across a range of habitats.

Title: Patna fourth lowest in first two quarters of Swachh survey
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A mound of garbage near Science College in Patna on Wednesday.

PATNA: The Patna Municipal Corporation was fourth lowest among the cities having population above 10 lakhs in the Swachh Survekshan results for the first two quarters of 2019-20 announced on Tuesday. None of the urban local bodies (ULBs) in state could make it to the top 1,000 ULBs in the first two quarters under the Swachh Survekshan League.

The results were announced by Union minister of state for housing and urban affairs Hardeep Singh Puri on Tuesday. The performance of cities in SS League is crucial to their rankings in the annual Swachh Survekshan 2020 as 25% weightage of the quarterly assessments will be included in the annual survey scheduled to be conducted from January 4 to 31.

As per the results announced on Tuesday, the bottom four cities with population above 10 lakh were Patna (ranked 46), Delhi (47), Howrah (48) and Kolkata (49). But technically, Patna was the second last as none of the West Bengal cities participated in the survey and hence scored zero.

Though Sahebganj ULB in Muzaffarpur was the best in state, but it still ranked 1,388, followed by Muzaffarpur and Danapur with 1,457 and 2,723 ranks respectively. An official with the urban development and housing department said the marks will have slight impact on the final survey starting from January 4. “The entire marks for the survey is 6,000, but SS League 2020 consists of only 1,500 marks and that too only 25% of it will be carried forward. Another 1500 marks each will be on the direct observation, citizens’ feedback and service level programme, which will make to total of 4,500,” he said.

“We do not expect much improvement in the final survey as we lack manpower required for the evaluation,” the official added.

State urban development and housing department minister Suresh Kumar Sharma said the department will now focus on improving the ULBs’ rankings in Bihar . “It is our New Year pledge to perform better from now onwards. We have already bought many equipment for cleanliness and the result can be seen from this month,” said Sharma.

Title: Women’s safety, improving green cover govt’s priorities
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The government has decided to plant around 37 crore tree saplings across the state as part of increasing the green cover , chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said here on Wednesday.

He said that between 2017 and 2019, there has been an increase of 823sqkm of forest in the state and adding greenery is one of the priorities of the government in the rebuilding of the state.

As part of many other initiatives being planned in the new year, the government has decided to replace all the existing street lights with LED lights to save power.

Explaining the plans, Vijayan said that as part of ensuring women safety, the government plans to come up with safe homes for women travelling alone, in all the towns. Along with providing such shelters, the government also will ensure that 12,000 pairs of toilets will be set up across the state for the use of travellers. A pair will consist of one woman-friendly toilet and a gents’ toilet.

In addition, the government is also planning to set up way-side amenities centre which will have multiple facilities like for refuelling, refreshments and toilet facilities.

“The discussions in these regard have begun and the work on them will be launched soon,” Vijayan said. A youth leadership academy to enhance the leadership skills of youths is also in the pipeline, the chief minister said.

He said that by the end of the current calendar year, all the roads in the state, including the national highways, state highways and panchayat roads, will be restored to good condition.

Along with providing infrastructural facilities, the government has also decided to clear all the complaints from the public pending in various offices across the state.

The district collectors will be in charge of conducting adalats for clearing pending complaints in which ministers will also attend, the chief minister said.

Title: Industries in state used 17% more power last year
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Indore: Industries of the state consumed around 17 per cent more electricity in 2018/19 while firms under western region recorded a jump of 22 per cent in power usage as against a year ago led by demand from new units and expansion by existing facilities.

The state supplied 981.1 crore units of electricity to industries having High Tension (HT) connections in 2018/19 of which maximum was consumed under Western Region Power Distribution Company that recorded consumption of 403.4 crore units, showed data from the industry department.

Principal secretary for industry Rajesh Rajora said, “Madhya Pradesh has seen a rise in electricity consumption by industries negating the impact of slowed economy that has affected manufacturing units in the country.”

The increase in electricity consumption is mostly due to demand from new units that have set up facilities in the state while discoms also received proposals for increased usage from already existing units that have undergone expansions.

Under western zone, 165 new HT connections were registered this year while across the state around 302 new units were registered.

Discom MD Vikas Narwal said, “HT connections in western zone constitute about 70 per cent of the total in the state and number of units are regularly going up. We have supplied record number of units this year as demand was high.”

Narwal said, “We are hoping year on year increase in HT consumption looking at the pace of new industries setting up in the region.”

As per discom, besides industries, institutes and establishments also use HT connections and consumption of electricity by all categories of HT users stood at 518 crore units. Last year discom had supplied 413 crore units.

Title: IMC has 3 months to recover Rs 739cr
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Indore: Like transport department, now Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) has a revenue recovery target to chase in current fiscal.

State government has fixed a maximum target of Rs1161 crore for IMC among other civic bodies in state to recover this fiscal through various heads like property tax, water tax, user charges, licence fee and others.

Other civic bodies like Bhopal and Jabalpur also have a revenue recovery target of around Rs700 crore and Rs400 crore to achieve respectively before March 31, 2020.

IMC’s additional commissioner SK Chaitanya said that this is for the first time when civic bodies in state have been given annual revenue recovery targets.

“All civic bodies in state have been given 150 per cent revenue recover target to recover. This includes 50 per cent of the arrear amount and 100 per cent of the current demand amount,” Chaitanya told TOI.

He also said that this target has been set by the government on a logical ground as it would help corporations that are dealing with financial crunch become self-sustainable.

“The amount that we have managed to recover so far is very less as compared to the target set by the government, and we are not sure if we would be able to achieve it. But we still have three months remaining for the closure of the financial year,” he added.

IMC officials and public representatives had been demanding for financial assistance from the state government to ensure proper implementation of development project.

IMC used to get a monthly tax compensation (chungee kshatipoorti) of Rs49 crore from state government which has also been reduced to Rs31 crore for the past four months. And since then, it has become difficult for IMC to manage its monthly expenses such as payment of electricity bills.

The total number of registered property tax accounts in city is 5.41 lakh. In the last financial year, IMC had recovered around Rs418 crore from different heads like property tax, water tax, licence fee, advertisements, building permissions etc. However, this time it has already recovered around Rs422 crore.

Title: Childhood mental disorder high in Bihar: Study
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The prevalence of childhood mental disorder is more in Bihar compared to other states in the country. A recent report published in Lancet Psychiatry stated that Bihar and other states falling in the low Socio Demographic Index (SDI) reported more number of mental disorder cases related to children and adolescent. On the other hand, adult mental disorder is prevalent in states with high SDI, the report said.

As per the report, Disability Adjusted Life Year (DALY) per 1,00,000 population is more in Bihar in the category of autism spectrum disorders, attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and conduct disorder which are related to children.

According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), DALYs for a disease or health condition are calculated as the sum of the Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature mortality in the population and the Years Lost Due to Disability (YLD) for people living with the health condition or its consequences.

Conduct disorder is a condition in which a child becomes hostile or physically violent and may hurt others by pushing or biting during childhood and bullying in adolescence.

Dr Santosh Kumar, associate professor (psychiatry department), Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH), said such children are more likely to become anti-social when they grow up.

Dr Kumar said conduct disorder for Bihar was second highest in the country at 117, while the same for Jharkhand stood at 118. DALY in the category of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (a condition in which child is hyperactive and distractive) for Bihar is 5.3 — which is also second highest in the country. DALY for Himachal Pradesh was 39, the least in the country, he added.

Idiopathic developmental intellectual disability (IDID) in Bihar has been calculated to be 252 — highest in the country — followed by Uttar Pradesh at 215. Dr Pramod Kumar Singh, head of psychiatry department, Patna Medical College and Hospital said IDID in simple terms was mental retardation. It can occur due to some post-natal care or poor health infrastructure.

Autism spectrum for Bihar along with nine other states was 54 which was the highest in the country. However in Bihar, life year lost to death or with disability disorder and anxiety disorder have been found to be 406 and 299 respectively — which is less than several southern states. In Tamil Nadu depressive disorders has been found to be 836, with Andhra Pradesh following next with 793.

Title: 8-year-old boy dies of dengue fever
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Tirupur: An eight-year-old boy from Mangalam here died of dengue fever in the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital on Wednesday.

Hospital sources identified him as Mohamed Pagis, son of Zahir Husain and Hasina Banu, a Class III student. “He was first admitted in the Tirupur Government Hospital with severe fever. Doctors there confirmed that he was affected by dengue and referred him to CMCH four days ago. But his condition did not improve, and he died on Wednesday morning,” an official said.

Meanwhile, the boy’s parents blamed the doctors at the Tirupur GH for his death. “Our house is located close to the Mangalam Primary Health Centre. We do not know how Pagis got infected. Health authorities should have taken preventive steps to stop such infection. He would have recovered if doctors at the GH took good care of him,” Husain told TOI.

A health department official said that they intensified anti-dengue measures in his house and surroundings after Pagis was diagnosed with dengue. “We will continue it on Thursday also,” he said.

With the death of Pagis, four children from the district have died due to dengue fever in the last one month.agencies

Title: 15K autos to stay off roads on January 8
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Coimbatore: Around 15,000 auto rickshaws would stay off roads in the district on January 8 as part of nation-wide strike called to condemn the policies of the central government and press for their demands.

P K Sugumaran, representative of Kovai District Auto Labourers’ Association and general secretary of CITU auto labourers union, said their main demands were to revise meter fares and streamline cab application services.

“We have been asking the state to revise meter fares for long, but it has not been done so far. Similarly, there should be streamlining of cab booking apps. While they say they charge lower fares, they charge more,” he said. TNN

Title: Benefits of core health in everyday life
Content: Core fitness for many is about having amazingly sculpted abdominal muscles but core strength is much more than that. To achieve the feat of having sculpted abs, one needs to drop the overall body fat percentage, however, this article is not about abs but the importance of core strength in everyday life. Your core muscles are basically the connecting bridge between your upper body and lower body. Though we might not notice but we engage our core muscles in every activity. When we walk, exercise, sit or perform basically any activity, our core is engaged and strengthening our core improves our overall health and wellbeing. Here are a few benefits core health has in our everyday life.Healthy backWeak core muscles increase the risk of back ache and injury. The major reason for this is the lack of spinal support. The total weight of our upper body lies on our spinal cord but if we do not maintain healthy core muscles, we deprive our spine of the necessary support. Healthy core muscles can make a vast difference in the long run. Our bones slightly deteriorate with time and a healthy core might come in handy in such situations.On the job tasksWhen we think about the activities engaging our core muscles, we think of lifting, twisting and standing. Well these are the obvious activities but sitting at your work desk for long durations also engages your core. While sitting for long hours, good posture is a must. If you can’t maintain a good posture while doing activities like typing, computer use and similar activities, your back can get quite stiff. A strong core helps you combat such problems.Good postureA good posture eliminates a lot of problems one might suffer. Exercising your core involves an overall strengthening of muscles and also prevents slouching. Good posture helps reduce the wear and tear of the spine and also allows you to breathe better.Improved athletic performanceAll athletic activities involve some or other kind of movement and our core is engaged for long hours during these activities. A strong core helps you achieve enhanced performance and allows you to be at your best for longer durations.Balance and stabilityOur core provides us the balance and stability we need in our everyday lives. It helps to give a centre of gravity while we are resting or moving our limbs. All the body’s movements originate from the core thus strengthening of core becomes essential to provide balance and stability while doing all such activities.

Title: Sharvari’s book offers vivid memories
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: Experiences one takes in formative years play an important role and help shape personality. Sharvari Pethkar, a young writer who loves literature, had many childhood stories to share with the audience at a programme titled ‘Lekhak Tumchya Bhetila’ held at Vidarbha Sahitya Sangh on Monday.

Sharvari, who penned ‘Turtas Khasgi Avedach’ after her tenth board examination was over, said, “My school life was a sensitive journey of emotions and memories.” She said she shared with her mother the happenings of every day after coming from school.

“Looking at my words and expression of thoughts, my mother once asked me to write my emotional outbursts and also happy moments on a piece of paper. I kept on writing my experiences. Later, I decided to write a book,” she said.

Replying to a question about the fears while penning the book, Sharvari said, “It was difficult to write about me and people around. The book doesn’t revolve only around me but has equal space for important people in my life in school, teachers, best friends and soul mates. Writing this book was an experience in itself as it gave me a chance to revisit memory lane.”

Her book gives an insight into her school life, contains various anecdotes and memories that she experienced as a student and learner. It offers glimpses of her curious mind and how she decided to write it.

It is a compilation of her moments of joy, sorrow, love and friendships. Even though she was only sixteen when she completed the book, a reader can experience the maturity of a young girl.

Sharvari’s father Shyam Pethkar, a senior journalist, was present.

Title: Amateurs bloom in theatre contest
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Nagpur: Actors showcased their talent in the plays that tackled as varied subjects as comedy, humanity, social issues and modern-day romance in the 59th State Amateur Theatre Competition hosted by Maharashtra state cultural directorate that concluded at Scientific Society Hall on Wednesday.

The contest concluded with the staging of ‘Bharatiya Rangbhoomiche Aadya’. The competition that commenced on November 18 witnessed quality performances, good direction and stage arrangement which gave amateur artistes a chance to excel. Theatre lovers came in large numbers too to watch new dramas which had innovative themes and young actors.

The preliminary round began with the play ‘Manasicha Shilpakar’, written and directed by Parag Ghonge. This was followed by ‘Kishta Bahar’, ‘Te Bara Taas’, ‘Zhalkari’, ‘Hitler Bootpolish Kartoy’, ‘Natakkar Bhadant Ashwaghosh’, ‘Pahila Prem and Propose’, ‘Neki’, ‘Itthal Itthal Love Love’, ‘Up-Down’, ‘ATS’, ‘Nyayapriya’, ‘Biopic Shri’, ‘Varul’, ‘Sattantar’, ‘Wata Palwata’, ‘Nilambari’, ‘Bewaras’, ‘Golmaal’, ‘Sari Raytri’, ‘Ti, Phone Aani Mrutyu’, ‘The Fear Factor’ and ‘Ramjatra’.

Event coordinator Vaidehi Chawre said, “Each play had young actors making a debut. A total of 25 entries were received. This time, the audience got an opportunity to experience a variety of plays. Each play was unique. This year, many talented youngsters participated and people saw them starting their acting career at the competition.”

Pravin Khapre, writer of ‘Biopic Shri’ said, “The credit for successful completion of the monthlong competition goes to actors, writers and directors whose vision to look at issues from a different perspective helped bring out the best in young actors.

“We practised for over a month as most of the artistes were non-Marathi. It was a task to make them understand the lingo and nitty-gritty of the language,” he added.

Writer and director Parag Ghonge was of the opinion that all the plays had good script and direction. Each play carried a message and acting of budding artistes made it a treat to watch.

“Presenting a good play requires a lot of hard work and team efforts. Everybody worked hard to give their best performances. More than the competition, it was an enjoyable process for the audience and actors,” he said.

Rupali Wande, director of the play ‘Pahila Prem and Propose’, was overwhelmed by the response the spectators gave to various dramas and turned up in large numbers to encourage them.
