She believed the audience enjoyed their play as it had reliability and the power to connect with new-age romance and attraction.

“Our play offered a perfect dose of drama, dance and romance. It was a lighthearted play with a storyline involving college life and the bond of friendship wherein love is an important aspect,” she said.

Director Abhishek Bellarwar chose women empowerment as the theme for his play ‘Neki’. The drama troupe also got reaction of the audience. “We enjoyed our performances. It was the first experience for many actors in the group. We got amazing response from drama lovers. Enthused by the support we got, we are looking forward to the results, to be announced shortly,” he said.

Title: In 3 earlier cases, UP didn’t opt for recovery procedure
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

LUCKNOW: The recovery procedure initiated against those accused of damaging public and private properties during the recent anti-CAA protests has no precedence in Uttar Pradesh .

While the state has witnessed several cases of group violence in the past decade when public property was damaged, no government invoked the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984 or the directives given from time to time by the Supreme Court and the Allahabad high court to make those responsible for damages pay for it.

There have been several protests by farmers for compensation as well as by Jats for job reservation when public property was damaged. Besides, there have been at least three instances since Yogi Adityanath took over as chief minister in March 2017 when public property was damaged during large-scale protests. But the recovery procedure was not initiated in any of these cases.

In April and May 2017, there were violent clashes in Saharanpur between Dalits and Thakurs. While the SSP office was vandalised, a police outpost and a police van were torched in the violence. Besides, around 20 vehicles, including a bus, were set on fire.

Almost a year later, many parts of west UP were affected when ‘ Bharat Bandh ’ backed by BSP on April 2 turned violent. It saw protesters burning a police outpost in Meerut. Besides, half dozen UPSRTC buses, three dozen motorcycles and several police vans were vandalized in the district.

Similarly, a police jeep was torched and a police inspector was killed in Bulandshahr on December 3, 2018. Police named 27 people in the FIR for the murder of the officer and another youth and damages to the public property among other offences. All the accused were arrested and are facing trial, but none of them sent ‘recovery notices’.

“As far as I remember, earlier such recovery notices were not served. That is also because people did not come forward to take claim of their damaged properties. Now that people are coming forward to file claims, we have to recover the money,” said Bijnor DM Ramakant Pandey.

“These recovery notices are being issued only because people are approaching us. The government is not issuing notices for claims on its own but only after people are approaching us,” he added.

Title: BJP names pointsmen to counter opposition’s campaign against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Amit Shah and JP Nadda (file photo)

NEW DELHI: BJP president Amit Shah on Wednesday held a crucial meeting with senior party functionaries, including working president JP Nadda, to take stock of the party’s outreach in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and how effectively it can counter the opposition’s campaign against the new law.

The meeting also reviewed the party’s preparations for the upcoming assembly polls in Delhi, sources said.

Apart from Shah and Nadda, general secretary (organisation) B L Santosh and all other general secretaries of the party were present. The party has assigned responsibilities to its office-bearers to lead the campaign in favour of CAA.

Anil Jain is leading party’s charge in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar — the states which have witnessed major protests against CAA. Avinash Rai has been entrusted with leading and coordinating the outreach programme in Chhattisgarh , Madhya Pradesh, Uttarakhand and Delhi.

Saroj Pandey has been tasked to coordinate in Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Goa and Daman and Diu, while Suresh Bhatt is to lead the programme in Haryana, Punjab, Himachal Pradesh, Chandigarh and Jammu & Kashmir.

For the southern zone, the party has selected Ravindra Raju who will coordinate outreach programmes in Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh , Telangana, Karnataka, the Andamans, Puducherry and Lakshadweep .

For the eastern belt, former Bengal BJP chief Rahul Sinha has been made in-charge of West Bengal , Odisha, Jharkhand and the north-east. He will work in coordination with Assam minister Himanta Biswa Sarma in the northeast.

Title: TN writer held for remarks against Modi
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

MADURAI: Orator and writer ‘Nellai’ Kannan — who was booked for his provocative speech against Prime Minister Narendra Modi , home minister Amit Shah , Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam at an SDPI meeting in Tirunelveli city on Sunday evening — was arrested in Perambalur district around 8.30pm on Wednesday.

Kannan had allegedly instigated Muslims to “finish off” Modi and Shah.

A senior police officer told TOI that Kannan was arrested by the Tirunelveli city police in a guest house in Perambalur district. The officer said he would be taken to the Trichy government hospital to confirm if he was fit to travel to Tirunelveli, where he would be produced before the judicial magistrate. If doctors say he cannot travel, he will be produced before a judicial magistrate in Trichy. “In either case, we will act on the directions of the magistrate. We will hospitalise him or remand him in jail under judicial custody as they say,” he said.

As Kannan was arrested, BJP workers raised slogans against him while SDPI cadres condemned the arrest. When he was taken out of the guest house, some protesters attempted to throw slippers at him.

On Monday night, the Melapalayam police booked him under IPC sections 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), 505(i)(b) (intent to cause, or which is likely to cause, fear or alarm to the public, or to any section of the public whereby any person may be induced to commit an offence against the state or against public tranquillity) and 505 (ii) (statements creating or promoting enmity, hatred or ill-will between classes).

On Tuesday afternoon, Kannan was taken to a private hospital in Tirunelveli as he complained of chest pain. He had to be discharged in an hour as there was a strong protest by BJP cadres on the hospital premises. His family said he would be taken to a hospital in Madurai but maintained confidentiality over the place fearing protest by BJP cadres.

Police said Kannan’s family took him to Madurai on Tuesday and then to Perambalur, where he was arrested due to pressure following the protest by senior BJP functionaries on the Marina on Wednesday evening.

Senior BJP leaders along with 100 party workers were arrested for taking part in the protest on the Marina, demanding the arrest of Kannan.

They had set a 24-hour deadline for the TN Police to arrest Kannan.

Title: Forces keep off politics, work on govt directive: Rawat
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Indian armed forces stay far away from politics and work as per orders of the government in office, said the new CDS General Bipin Rawat on Wednesday, in remarks that follow criticism of his comments on leadership and violent anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protests.

Congress and other opposition parties have not only criticised Rawat for statements with ‘political overtones’, the latest being his stance against the anti-CAA protests, but also questioned the need to have a CDS. The pivotal reform of the CDS post, incidentally, has been hanging fire since the 1999 Kargil conflict.

Asked about allegations that the armed forces were being politicised after he received a tri-service guard of honour on Wednesday, Rawat said, “We stay away, we stay far away from politics. We work on the directives of the government in power.”

Late last month, as the Army chief, Rawat had slammed people instigating protests in the country against the new citizenship law, saying leadership was not about guiding crowds including students to carry out arson and violence.

The remarks had been sharply criticised by opposition leaders. A large section of serving military officers as well as veterans feel there has been an increasing trend in recent years to needlessly politicise the armed forces, from politicians taking credit for cross-border strikes to UP CM Yogi Adityanath dubbing the Indian Army as ‘Modiji ki Sena’ at a poll rally.

During the Lok Sabha election, PM Modi repeatedly referred to the government’s resolve in ordering the air strike on a madarsa in Balakot in Pakistan known for training terrorists, a deci-sion taken after the jihadi attack on CRPF personnel in Pulwama .

The use of armed forces for building bridges, cleaning waste in high-altitude areas, organising events and other sundry tasks also detracts them from their primary role of preparing for war, conducting counter-terrorism operations and guarding the borders, say veterans.

Title: Mumbai: MLA’s school on block for property tax default
Content:
Sunil Rane

Most property tax dues from western suburbs

MUMBAI: The BMC has initiated the process to auction Borivli BJP MLA Sunil Rane’s educational institution, Atharva Education Trust at Malad , for defaulting on property tax amounting to Rs 1.2 crore.The property is one of 228 for which the process has been begun by the civic corporation. Assets of several builders are part of the list for non-payment of property tax worth Rs 581 crore. One of the defaulters, Omkar Realtors, owed the BMC Rs 6.7 crore on its Malad property and another Rs 17 crore on its Worli property.All the properties were attached last year, but few had cleared a part of the dues, prompting the civic body to begin the auction process. On Wednesday, BMC officials submitted details of these defaulters to their publicity department in order to get advertisements issued, with details of defaulters so that the properties could be auctioned.Sunil Rane replaced the sitting MLA Vinod Tawde as the BJP candidate from Borivli in the assembly election in October last year and won by a margin of over 95,000 votes, which was the highest in the city. Rane was not available for comment.Among the other defaulters are several builders whom the BMC termed as “habitual defaulters”. A builder’s representative said that the slowdown in the real estate market has impacted them. “Payment of property tax dues is not a priority for several of them,” an official said. Omkar Realtors’ representative told TOI they would settle their dues in the next few days.Most of the property tax dues are from the western suburbs (Rs 255 crore), mainly the Bandra-Malad belt, followed by the eastern suburbs (Rs 192 crore) and the island city (Rs 133 crore).The BMC’s property tax collection has been dropping in the last few years due to defaults and this year, the figures will drop further as the government, as part of its election promises, has decided to exempt flats measuring below 500 sq ft from payment of property tax.Property tax collection is the biggest revenue source for the BMC ever since octroi was abolished. In the last three quarters, property tax collection showed a 19% deficit compared to last year as the BMC had issued no residential bills amid confusion over a waiver policy for homes under 500 sq ft.All collection has been only from commercial establishments, an official said. The municipal body had not issued property tax bills to residential units as it has not calibrated its software and other systems to exclude units under 500 sq ft while generating the bills. The BMC started to issue the bills on flats size measuring more than 500 sq ft only last month.

Title: Sex chat videos leak: Noida top cop says ‘morphed’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Gautam Buddh Nagar SSP (ANI photo)

NOIDA: Vaibhav Krishna, Noida’s young police chief, found himself in the middle of controversy on Wednesday after at least three videos of an alleged sex chat with a woman were leaked online. Krishna, who is senior superintendent of police, described the videos as morphed and part of “an organised attempt to spoil my image”. The woman isn’t seen in the videos, which are a recording of her phone screen using another device, but the male caller clearly is. Late in the evening, an FIR was registered at Noida’s Sector 20 police station against unknown persons under sections 67 (publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form) of the Information Technology Act. Krishna, who addressed a press conference on the issue on Wednesday evening, warned against the videos being forwarded, saying anyone doing so with “malafide intention” would be booked. “It is my appeal that criminal activity should not be supported that way… Everyone has a right to privacy. How can one produce a morphed video?” the SSP said. Asked about the content of the FIR, Krishna only said there was “conspiracy at work”, leading to morphed videos being circulated. He said the photo in the video was his and he was informed about it by a journalist. “It seems to be a very big conspiracy, a very big attempt to spoil my image in an organised way,” Krishna said. “About one month back, in some matters related to Gautam Budh Nagar and other districts too, a very sensitive administrative report was sent to the CM’s office on which an investigation is on. Besides, over the last one year, the way action is being taken, many nexuses have been broken, criminals who were not being targeted earlier have been targeted and some very big corruption cases have been lodged. It seems some people were angered by this and resorted to such an act,” he added. The investigation into the videos will, however, will be transferred to another district. “A probe will be carried out to get to the bottom of this,” Krishna said. “Where it (the video) has been forwarded from, where it originated from, its source will be checked,” he added. To a question if any politician or government official was named in the report that has been sent to the CM’s office, Krishna declined to comment. The report is sensitive in nature. Investigation is on at the state level,” he said. He, however, confirmed there were names of police officers in the report. Additional chief secretary (home) Awanish Awasthi told TOI on Wednesday evening the videos were fudged. “The officer concerned will lodge an FIR in connection with the incident,” Awasthi said. (With inputs from Lucknow)

Title: Mumbai Air Quality: In 2019, Mumbai breathed cleanest air in four years
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The air quality in Mumbai on the first morning of the year was better compared to previous years. (File photo)

MUMBAI: The city this year might have experienced a lower impact of air pollution as concentration of the harmful pollutant PM 2.5 in 2019 was the lowest since 2016, according to an assessment done by the System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting And Research (SAFAR). The city’s Air Quality Index (AQI) of 175 on January 1 was also the cleanest since 2016.

The city’s annual average for the concentration of particulate matter lesser than 2.5 microns (PM 2.5) was 54 ug/ m3, which is the lowest since 2016 (see box) but continues to breach the permissible limit of 40 ug/m3. “This year the overall concentration of PM 2.5 was lower due to the weather factors including the prolonged monsoon and the cyclones in the Arabian Sea. There has also been more awareness about pollution, and efforts to tackle it that could be showing miniscule results,” said Gufran Beig, project director, SAFAR.

Track the pollution level in your city

PM 10 and PM 2.5, the major components of outdoor air pollution are under the worst carcinogenics to humans (Group 1). While the concentration of PM 2.5 might have dipped, it’s share in the PM 10 composition increased, according to a SAFAR study presented earlier this month. At the annual Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) conclave, Beig showed that Mumbai had a PM 2.5 to PM 10 ratio of 65% and Delhi 45%.

The air quality in the city on the first morning of the year was better compared to previous years. The quality worsened to 204 by the evening, as predicted by SAFAR. Researchers said the reason for an improved air quality on the new year’s morning was weather patterns. “The winds picked up speed in the last 24 hours, allowing the disbursal of pollutants. The humidity was lower on Tuesday as well, which reduces the pollutant carrying capacity of air. The moisture content increased a little during the day and hence the levels moved to the poor category,” said Beig.

In 2018 and 2017, the city recorded an AQI of 253 and 221 respectively, in the poor category. Among the 10 most monitored locations in the city, Malad was the most polluted at

276. The least polluted was Bhandup with an AQI of 88.

AQI levels for PM 2.5 between 0-50 is good, 51-100 is satisfactory, 101-200 is moderate, 201-300 is poor, 30-400 is very poor and above 400 is severe.

Title: Aide kills singer, 3 of his kin over 60,000, insults
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

MEERUT: Police on Wednesday morning found the charred body of a 14-year-old boy from Haryana ’s Panipat town, 40km from west UP’s Shamli district where his father — a ‘ bhajan ’ singer — mother and elder sister were found murdered a day ago.

The accused, Himanshu Saini, an aide of ‘bhajan’ singer Ajay Pathak (45), was arrested by Haryana police. According to Panipat police, Saini was arrested when he was trying to flee after setting ablaze Pathak’s SUV which had his son, Bhagwad’s body in the rear seat. Police have sent the charred body for forensic and post-mortem examination.

It all happened a day after Ajay, his wife Sneha Pathak (42) and daughter Vasundhra Pathak (16) were murdered with a sharp-edged weapon at their Shamli house. Police said during interrogation, Himanshu confessed to have killed the entire family for not returning Rs 60,000 they owed to him. Himanshu alleged that he was insulted by Ajay every time he asked for his money.

During interrogation, the accused confessed to have killed the family with “one of the many swords which were kept at their home”.

Shamli SP Vineet Jaiswal said, “Himanshu had dinner with the family on Monday night, and decided to kill them after he was allegedly humiliated by Ajay for asking for his money.”

“After dinner, as the family was sleeping, he first went to Ajay’s room and attacked him and his wife Sneha with a sword. Then he went to Vasundhra’s room and killed her. He then strangulated 14-year-old Bhagwad to death,” said SP Jaiswal. Police said Himanshu planned to dispose all the bodies. He first took Bhagwad’s body to Panipat. “But, when he got to know that the news of the murders has spread, he set the car on fire,” said Jaiswal.

Title: Pay more for premium housing in Gurugram
Content:
Representative image

GURUGRAM: If you’re planning to invest in premium housing in Gurugram , the new year hasn’t brought good tidings.The Gurugram administration on Monday proposed higher circle rates, which decide how much you pay during registration of properties, in the city. The steepest hikes — more than double the existing rate — will affect those investing in upscale condominiums along Golf Course Road, such as Parsvnath Exotica, The Verandas, Palm Springs, Park Place, Belaire, Camellias, Vipul Belmonte and Central Park, and in DLF 5. In most of these areas, the circle rate may see an increase from the existing Rs 8,000 per sq ft to a maximum of Rs 17,000 per sq ft.The administration has invited objections and suggestions from residents till January 10, following which the circle rates will be finalised and notified.Circle rate is the minimum price at which a property is transferred in government records. Since the government collects stamp duty on the basis of the circle rate, it’s at the registration stage that a buyer will have to cough up a higher amount. So, if a buyer purchases a 4,000 sqft apartment at the current circle rate of Rs 8,000 per sq ft, the total cost comes out to be Rs 3.2 crore. If stamp duty of 7% is levied on the cost, that’s Rs 22 lakh. If the circle rate is hiked to Rs 17,000 per sq ft, the assumed cost of this flat will double, as will stamp duty.Property experts said this would have a negative impact on luxury real estate transactions. The circle rate proposed for group housing societies in Gwal Pahari has also been doubled from the existing Rs 3,000 per sq ft to Rs 7,000 per sq ft. The proposed circle rate for the group housing societies in Sector 15, 27, 28, 30, 31, 32A, 39, 40, 41, 42, 43, 45, 46, 50, 51, 52 , 53, 54, 55, 56 and 57 is also more than double, from the existing Rs 5,000 per sq feet to Rs 12,000 per sq feet.“The circle rate for Huda builder floors and floors in the licensed colonies has been proposed to hike from the existing Rs 5,500 per sq ft to Rs 10,000 per sq ft. This is not at all viable. The circle rates should be in fact reduced by 10%,” said Ramesh Singla, president, Gurugram Home Developers and Plot Holders Association.In Video: Gurugram: Pay more for premium housing

Title: 5 ‘nuisance’ vehicles seized
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The louder a vehicle, the greater the chances of it drawing the cops’ attention. During New Year’s celebrations, some youths hit SG Road with sportsbikes, modified SUVs and a noisy American-made motorcycle. These drew the attention of the cops, who booked them for various offences, such as not having number plates, creating a racket, or because they had modified various parts such as their silencers. PSI M B Viraja of the traffic squad said he impounded five vehicles and sent them to the RTO as their drivers did not have valid documents or licences. He said these five persons will be fined at least Rs 20,000 each.

Title: Hyderabadis partied all night as they rang in 2020
Content: Electrifying music, colourful fireworks and shimmery roads — Hyderabadis celebrated New Year’s Eve amidst much pomp and grandeur as they thronged city hotspots to party the night away.From Begumpet and Jubilee Hills to Gachibowli and Banjara, city clubs were brimming with revellers who were seen shimmying, swaying and head banging as the DJ churned out some peppy beats.Party-goers sure had a wild time as they bid goodbye to a decade and rang in 2020 in style. The roads were jam-packed with vehicles but that didn’t deter mana Hyderabadis from partying it out, even if it meant getting stranded in traffic for a good one hour. Meanwhile, the Film Nagar Cultural Center reverberated with applause as actress Hebah Patel set the stage on fire with her scintillating performance.While the parties at clubs rolled late into the night, hundreds of denizens had their own party at Necklace Road, which was decked up in shiny lights. Pretty sky-lanterns lit up the December sky, as city-folk cut cakes, danced and snapped selfies.“This is my first New Year celebrations in Hyderabad, as I am from Bhopal. It was amazing to party by the Hussain Sagar, looking at the majestic Buddha and the sky lit with lanterns and dotted with hundreds of red balloons. It has been a great start to 2020,” said Pratheek Jain, a city-based techie. Another place which turned into a hotspot for selfies on New Year’s Eve was the newly-launched manicured vertical garden at the Khairatabad junction, which spelt out, ‘I love Hyderabad’. “This is super fun and quirky. I am sure it will be a major attraction in the city for many,” said Soujanya Kumari, a student of Nizam College who also brought in the New Year at Necklace Road with her friends.Even the cops didn’t shy away from having a mini NYE celebration as they cut cakes on their bikes at the Jubilee Hills Check Post and hugged each other, saying ‘Happy New Year!’

Title: P. V. Sindhu: ‘Winning the Olympic gold for India will be a great way to herald the new decade’
Content: From the looks of it, 2020 promises to be a year of reckoning for Pusarla Venkata Sindhu. She has come a long way from being that lanky Hyderabad girl who took everybody by surprise by winning the silver medal at the Rio Olympics back in 2016. This time Sindhu enters the Tokyo Olympics as the reigning world champion. And the 24-year-old knows that all of India will be cheering for her to become first Indian shuttler to win an Olympic gold medal when the 2020 Summer Olympics kicks off in July. “It’s a huge responsibility. Wherever I go, people are speaking about an Olympic medal. I hope I can live up to the expectations people have of me,” says Sindhu, as she settles down for a chat with Hyderabad Times. Excerpts:Yes, I can’t believe it’s 2020 already. The last decade was really good for me and I feel I grew from strength to strength as a player. The biggest high, of course, was winning the gold medal at the World Championships in Basel last year. More than anything else, it is all the love I’ve received from the people of India that has been overwhelming. It feels great to be entering the new decade as the reigning World Champion. I hope I can carry the winning momentum into this decade too and win many more medals for India. Winning the Olympic gold for India will be a great way to herald the new decade.They are going very well; I’m training hard with Gopi sir and Park Tae Sang. I’m back on tour from January 2 itself and will start the year with Malaysia Masters which will begin on January 7. The preparation leading up to Tokyo will be intense. The Olympic qualifiers are also coming up soon so all the focus is on that, everything else will take a backseat.It’s going to be a lot different compared to Rio, because the players are different and the game has evolved so much since. So the strategies are going to be different too. Last time, I was just a promising player going into the Olympics, but this time, I’m the reigning World Champion and the Olympic silver medalist, so expectations are bound to be much higher as people expect a medal from me. That is a huge responsibility and it motivates me to push harder and give my best on court, and hopefully, win the elusive Olympic gold medal for India.Well, I actually enjoyed the tremendous reception I got. It was a much-awaited win and it’s something very important for me. I already had two bronze and two silver medals and I badly wanted the gold. I knew I needed to be on top of my game. It was a great week for me in Basel and I’ve made some priceless memories. Yes, the adulation got a bit overwhelming at times, but I really enjoy it. It’s always nice to see so many people come to me, ask for autographs and selfies. I feel like a real star, and that’s a great feeling. Talking about my performance, yes there were a few ups and downs.In sport, you win some and lose some. But the important thing is to believe in yourself. After the World Championships, I had hit a rough patch where I lost in the first round and pre-quarterfinals in several tournaments. But I didn’t let that bog me down. I always learn from my mistakes, and I think that’s very important.The best way to answer critics is to give your best each time you step on to the court, and that’s what I plan to do. In sport, there are always wins and losses and the only thing I can control is how I play my game. I think it’s important to pick and choose your tournaments as a player, so that you can give your 100 per cent all the time. Because while playing tournaments are important, it’s equally important to stay fit.Yes, everything is fine. There’s nothing to worry about (laughs). I try to strike a balance between skill and endurance in my training. Sometimes, there will be long matches and you get tired, so that’s when you have to find the strength from within to pull through. My fitness regime consists of weight training to improve strength, and a lot of running agility drills to build my endurance and movement on the court.Apart from badminton, fashion is one thing that I really love. It helps take my mind off the game for a while. I enjoy the process of picking an outfit, putting onmake-up and prettying up to go for an event. I really like to dress up, that’s for sure. No matter how tired I’m, I will never step out not feeling good about the way I look. I’m very particular about that. And my look depends on where I go. My fashion funda is to be myself and I like to wear clothes that suit me and in which I feel comfortable.Well, I have a team of stylists but ultimately, I have the final say. Only if I’m fully comfortable and satisfied with my look, will I wear it. As a sportsperson, comfort is most important when it comes to clothes. If your clothes aren’t comfortable, you won’t wear it on the court right? The same applies for me while choosing other outfits as well. But when I dress up, I don’t think I’m a sportsperson. I’m just a girl who wants to look good.At home, I just spend time with my family. My parents are there for me and they motivate me all the time. As they too were sportspersons, they understand the challenges I face. I’m very thankful to them for their support. I also love spending time with my one-and-a-half-year-old nephew, Aryan. We watch movies together and do little fun things. He’s my biggest stressbuster. I love travelling too. Although my overseas trips are usually packed with training and tournaments, I sometimes do take time off to explore the place. Last year, I went to Switzerland and it’s my favourite place by far. Italy and Greece are my dream destinations and hopefully I will get to visit those places in 2020. Obviously, it’s a busy year with the Olympics. Maybe if I win in Tokyo, I’ll go there to celebrate (laughs).

Title: With Asuran remake and F2 sequel in the pipleline, Venky has his hands full
Content: Venkatesh was in his element playing Naga Chaitanya ’s doting uncle in Venky Mama, but his next, the Telugu remake of Dhanush’s Tamil hit Asuran, will showcase his most intense avatar ever, reckons the actor. “I am constantly trying to reinvent myself. Dhanush’s character in Asuran simply blew my mind. It’s such a brooding, psyched out character, something I’ve never seen in Telugu cinema. Set in the 1980s, the film is very raw and intense,” says the actor, who is reuniting with director Srikanth Addala for the movie again after Seethamma Vakitlo Sirimalle Chettu . Talking about his character, Venky goes on to add, “He is like an asuran (demon). His behaviour and expressions and emotions are intense all through. A father of two kids, he goes around killing people to get his revenge. Dhanush did a fabulous job and I knew playing a character like that is going to be a challenge for me.” Venky also confirms that F2 – Fun and Frustration sequel is on the cards. “When we were doing F2 – Fun and Frustration, I was sure that it will make for a great comedy franchise. I have already had a few script discussions with Varun (Tej) and Anil Ravipudi (director). Once we lock in on the plotline, we’ll announce F3. We’re yet to finalise the heroines though, but it will have Varun and me in the lead,” says Venky, signing off.

Title: Centre rejects Bengal’s R-Day tableau on girls scheme
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

NEW DELHI/KOLKATA: West Bengal ’s tableau proposal for this year’s Republic Day parade has been rejected, the defence ministry said on Wednesday.

“The tableau proposal of the government of West Bengal was examined by the expert committee in two rounds of meetings. The proposal was not taken forward for further consideration by the expert committee after deliberations in the second meeting,” a statement from the ministry said.

Bengal was planning to showcase its social welfare project, Kanyashree, on direct cash-transfer for girls that has received international recognition. Bengal officials weren’t invited to two successive meetings convened by the defence ministry’s expert committee to decide on tableau specifications, state government officials said.

This is the second time since 2015 that Bengal’s proposal to showcase Kanyashree at the Republic Day parade has run into rough weather. There was a hitch in 2018 as well, when the state government wanted to make ‘Ekata-i Sampriti’ (unity is brotherhood) the central theme of its tableau. The state went unrepresented at the parade in both years.

It is pertinent to mention that Bengal government’s tableau was shortlisted for participation in Republic Day Parade 2019 as an outcome of the same process. In recent past, Bengal won the first prize in 2014 for a tableau showcasing Chhau dance and in 2016 for its presentation on Baul artistes.

Twenty-two proposals — 16 from states and UTs and six from central ministries — out of a total 56 were short-listed for this year’s parade.

Title: Fast food on wheels set for a comeback in Delhi
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Food trucks dishing out delicacies on the streets are a common feature across the world. However, while this fast food culture has gained popularity in the past decade in satellite towns like Gurgaon and Noida, its growth has been stagnant in Delhi.The scenario, however, is set to change as the city is likely to get more roadside joints in the next few months after a gap of 12 years. While the unified Municipal Corporation of Delhi had stopped issuing new licences for food trucks in 2008 as they were leading to traffic congestion and unhygienic conditions, the deliberative wing of South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) has decided to restart the process.Food trucks were banned in 2008 after a ruckus in North Campus of Delhi University.Kamaljeet Sehrawat, leader of the House in SDMC, said that the process for creating new regulations had been started and licences would be issued after the assembly elections as the model code of conduct is soon expected to come in force. “We will modify the conditions to address the concerns of traffic congestion. We will regularise the food trucks running in violation of norms. In any case, they are active for just 4-5 hours a day,” she added.“Safety norms and traffic concerns will not be compromised. We will review the problems that were faced in 2008 and find a solution. Gurgaon and Noida have already amended their policies to facilitate food trucks,” Sehrawat said.The civic body’s medical relief and public health committee has asked the public health department to reframe rules and start issuing licences. A senior public health official said that apart from permission from the land-owning agency, food trucks have to get a no objection certificate from Delhi Traffic Police to operate.SDMC data shows only around 60 food truck licences are currently valid in areas under its jurisdiction. While west zone has 16 licensees, Najafgarh has 11, south 13 and central 20. Given the low cost, many beginner restaurateurs opt to open food trucks.

Title: Tree count up 11 lakh in decade, says BMC; activists sceptical of claim
Content:
File photo of Aarey Colony

The decade just ended was one in which Mumbaikars went to battle for green cover, as infrastructure projects threatened thousands of trees across the city, especially in the forested Aarey Colony. This was also a decade, according to the official tree census, when the number of trees in the city rose substantially—that is, if you believe the data.Completed in 2018, the census findings were not made public till recently, and met with scepticism. The count pegged the number of trees in Mumbai at 29.75 lakh—10 lakh more than the last census, done in 2008. But almost half of that increase was due to the inclusion of Aarey Colony, which was not part of the last count. Even what remained of the increase seemed at odds with what residents and activists were seeing on the ground: the incessant lopping of trunks for building road and rail, and for redeveloping buildings.Activist Zoru Bhathena said he found the 2018 data unconvincing. “While the BMC through the census had planned to give each tree a unique identification number, this was never done. Nor was any data provided on the BMC’s website,” he said. “Moreover, no one I know saw any officials coming to their neighbourhood for the tree census.”BMC officials say the census data is part of the civic environment report 2018-19. The greenest wards were the ones enclosing the suburbs of Ghatkopar , Malad , Andheri, Vile Parle, Jogeshwari, Vikhroli and Bhandup, some of which are on the periphery of the national park and the Aarey tracts. The least green wards are in south Mumbai, with the Pydhonie-Dhobi Talao area having barely 6,000 trees, and the Dongri-Umarkhadi stretch just about 8,000. It must be mentioned that the areas of the BMC’s administrative wards vary widely.However, census methods have been questioned by experts. Suchandra Dutta, assistant professor of the department of botany , RD National College, Bandra, said the census did not seem to cover educational campuses, many of which have a large number of old trees. “Some historical trees may have been missed out by the census. There is a need to look into this once again,” he said.Others question the delay between the two censuses. The Maharashtra Protection and Preservation of Trees Act 1975 mandates a tree census every five years, noted former BMC tree committee member Niranjan Shetty. “Yet another question is on why certain areas were left out in earlier censuses, especially government land or Aarey Colony,” said Shetty.BMC started the latest tree census in February 2015 from Raj Bhavan, Malabar Hill , finishing only in 2018, at a cost of Rs 3 crore. It was the first time that Geographic Information system (GIS) was used for the exercise.“One reason it doesn’t feel like that the tree cover is increasing,” suggested Dutta, “is that while tree planting efforts have increased, maintenance of those trees is poor.”Ashok Kothari, president of National Society of the Friends of Trees, said BMC has stopped planting trees on pavements. “Instead, space is made for allowing cables to be placed. It could be that some sincere efforts are being made, but there is a need for much more to be done,” he said.Civic officials said they aim to plant 20,000 trees this year. And in yet another bid to increase green cover, BMC has announced plans to develop 100 plots using a Japanese technique of quick afforestation. Will these grand plans help resolve Mumbai’s escalating tree wars?

Title: Delhi Weather: Severe air back in Delhi, light rain likely to occur today
Content:
The AQI is expected to improve to the higher-end of the ‘very poor’ category by January 2 (File photo)

NEW DELHI: At 437, the Air Quality Index in the capital on Wednesday dipped to the ‘severe’ category from Tuesday’s very poor. Long traffic snarls on Tuesday evening and the fireworks post midnight could have added to the deterioration, the agencies said, adding that the meteorological conditions were favourable for pollution on Wednesday.Track the pollution level in your cityThe forecast for the next two days show that the influence of increased surface winds due to an active western disturbance on the air quality is likely to increase. The SAFAR model suggests that, under the influence of approaching western disturbance, increased surface winds and improved ventilation, the AQI is expected to improve to the higher-end of the ‘very poor’ category by January 2.“An additional source of emission through a number of sources like fireworks and vehicles in all likelihood has increased emission levels last night from 8pm onwards, which peaked at midnight to 1am. This has lead to a sudden deterioration in AQI,” said SAFAR.It added that despite high wind speed, a domination of emissions over surface wind has been the driving factor this winter, which has caused the sudden variations in the air quality. Met officials said the wind speed on Wednesday was around 15 km/hr, which was good for the dispersal of pollutants and should increase to 20-25 km/ hr on Thursday, along with a spell of very light rain. Kuldeep Srivastava, scientist at IMD, however, warned that with a drizzle, chances of pollution levels increasing again would be high.In Video: Air quality 'severe' amidst cold wave in Delhi

Title: Miyapur is becoming a Sand Truck den
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

It is a usual sight every day that 100's of sand laden trucks park on the NH from Miyapur X roads to Alwyn X road from 10-11 PM until 7AM next day. These trucks not only causes traffic jams and difficulties for common public, but could pose a serious security threat. There are many residential colonies on both sides of the NH and these trucks park haphazardly blocking the road entries. During the late night and early morning, 100's of trck drivers, labourers and middlemen roam around the area. A large number of IT employees live in this area and they need to travel to and fro to their work places all all hours and their safety is a big concern. Request authorities to look into this seriously and do the needful to end this menace as early as possible.

Title: Inverted Indications
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Pune "Smart City" projects were flagged off with much gusto and fanfare after initially having had waited with baited breath for the much coveted 'smart tag'. In preparation at a short notice, we scrambled to get the requisite infrastructure spread out for display, albeit in a glitzy and tawdry manner. The BRT is still struggling to keep pace with dozens of buses sputtering to a halt and going kaput daily, along with poor planning of the routes causing many unavoidable fatalities. Being a part of this project, cycles, cycle tracks and various display paraphernalia were introduced. But sadly now cycles are gone much like the ones of the olden days; cycle tracks are encroached upon by businesses; and 'Cycle Parking Only' boards have motorised vehicle parkings in its vicinity. Pointlessness.

Title: Free WiFi in Delhi Metro: High-speed Wi-Fi for free on Delhi Metro's Airport Express Line
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

There will be no limitations on download speed or traffic volume (File photo)

NEW DELHI: From Thursday, commuters travelling by Delhi Metro ’s high-speed Airport Express Line will also be able to enjoy free highspeed Wi-Fi services inside the trains.

It will be the first Delhi Metro corridor to have Wi-Fi on-board moving trains and similar services are expected on other corridors in the future.

In July, TOI was the first to report that Airport Express Line will have Wi-Fi onboard in moving trains. The six stations of the high-speed Airport Express Line were the first to provide Wi-Fi connectivity to commuters, in 2016. Next year, Delhi Metro’s Blue Line (Dwarka-Noida City Centre/Vaishali) became the second metro corridor to provide free Wi-Fi facility to its passengers at all the 50 stations of the corridor.

The free Wi-Fi facility in Airport Express Line trains will be launched by Delhi Metro Rail Corporation’s managing director Mangu Singh on Thursday.

According to DMRC officials, the service in Delhi metro will be provided for free and without any limitations on download speed or traffic volume. The target speed will reach up to 300 Mbps per train, they said.

The mechanism through which commuters will be able to access Wi-Fi on-board moving trains will be a two-level network. Firstly, it is a train-to-tunnel (T2T) radio network, which passes signal from base stations inside a tunnel to portable base stations inside head cars. Secondly, the inner-train network that will transmit signal from the Wireless Access Points (WAP) in each car to users’ devices.

According to sources in DMRC, the corporation is planning to deploy a Wi-Fi network at all its corridors, except the Magenta (Janakpuri West-Botanical Garden) and Pink (Majlis Park-Shiv Vihar) Lines.

Stations on the Blue Line, the busiest corridor of Delhi metro network, started providing Wi-Fi facility three years ago. The facility, named “Oui DMRC Free Wi-Fi” is available at all the 50 stations of the Blue Line. Commuters can log in by searching for Wi-Fi options and log into “Oui DMRC Free Wi-Fi” after doing a onetime registration through their mobile phones.

For providing this free Wi-Fi facility, DMRC has tied up with a consortium which is already providing the same facility on all six metro stations of the Airport Express Line from October 2016 and also running India’s first Wi-Fi on train service on the Delhi-Howrah Rajdhani Express.

Title: 5.5 lakh revellers flood Delhi spots as temperature touches 20-day high
Content:
India Gate was choked with visitors from 1pm onwards (PTI photo)

5 metro stations closed to keep crowd in check

NEW DELHI: More than 5.5 lakh New Year revellers, many from other parts of NCR, descended on popular destinations in the capital, causing monster traffic jams in several parts of the city on Wednesday. The massive inflow of people, estimated to be 30% higher than the New Year Day of 2019, prompted police to shut five Metro stations, adding to the woes of commuters.India Gate alone saw footfalls of nearly 3 lakh, police estimated. Visitors also thronged Connaught Place, Delhi zoo, Waste to Wonder Park, the “mall mile” on Press Enclave Road, Akshardham Temple, Bangla Sahib Gurdwara and the Hanuman Temple at Jamuna Bazar.The massive turnout, on a sunny day when temperatures touched a 20-day high, choked almost all arterial roads in east, central and south Delhi for nearly six hours. It followed a bitterly cold morning, when the minimum temperature, at 2.4 degrees C, was the lowest in January in seven years.The crowds were several times more than what police had expected. As the crowds kept swelling, the cops shut down five Metro stations — closing the entry and exit gates of Central Secretariat, Udyog Bhawan, Pragati Maidan, Khan Market and Mandi House stations — to prevent more people from pouring in.The crowd started swelling from 1pm as weather conditions. People heading to the zoo or India Gate caused choke points on Mathura Road as cops had to intermittently stop vehicles to allow pedestrians to cross the road. Apart from this, huge crowds also gathered at the Connaught Place Hanuman temple and Akshardham temple to offer prayers on the first day of the year, leading to major disruptions.The Waste to Wonder Park, which was inaugurated in February 2019, sold 11,000 tickets, its highest for a single day.Visitors had come from as far as Alwar to spend New Year Day in the capital. “I reached Delhi on train as my children wanted to see the National War Memorial. I did not expect such a huge crowd here. We could not enter the war memorial but enjoyed at the India Gate,” said Rama Kanth, a former athlete.Police had deployed 40 teams around the India Gate alone to control the movement of around 70-80 thousand people around afternoon, which soared to a total of three lakh through the day. Police officers say that the crowd suddenly started swelling around 2pm. Even though the cops tried to streamline the movement of the crowd especially around Rajpath and children’s park, the sheer volumes were almost impossible to manage.This choked Chexagon, Mathura Road (near Bapa Nagar) and Ring Road. Almost all roads, from Sarai Kale Khan to Lodhi Colony, became jammed due to the ripple effect of the mayhem. Adding to this, was the crowd at Delhi Zoo and Waste to Wonder Park. Even though the roads around both these places are no-parking zones, visitors parked their vehicles on the stretch, blocking a lane. Amid a maddening craze for selfies with India Gate as the background, nearly the entire road in front of the monument was occupied by visitors.“We had put out a diversion plan that helped us in managing the crowd. Vehicle movement never came to a standstill in any of these areas due to this,” said a police officer.According to an estimate, more than three lakh people had travelled to Delhi from NCR using the newly opened Metro lines and blocked the way for vehicle movements. Press Enclave Road in south Delhi too was teeming with people as revellers thronged the malls there. The police had to stop traffic at intervals to allow pedestrians to cross over. Auto-rickshaws and cabs stopped to pick up passengers, adding to the snarls.Police officers said they sought help from local police to control the crowds. “We could not risk a situation where we could allow pedestrians and vehicles to move at the same time. It would have sparked a law and order problem,” said a senior police officer.“I had presumed that travelling on Barapullah to reach Sarai Kale Khan and then taking Ring Road would be relatively smooth but the snarls on Barapullah stretched on for hours, after which there was a huge jam at India Gate. It took me nearly two hours to cross the stretch,” said Anshul Kalra, heading for Bangla Sahib Gurdwara from south Delhi.At Connaught Place, cops disallowed parking in the Outer Circle after traffic nearly came to a standstill around 5pm. Around the same time, more than 5,000 people had lined up along the road to enter Hanuman temple that blocked one carriageway of Baba Kharak Singh Marg. Police officers say that the situation became better around 8pm when the crowd started dispersing.

Title: Chennai Rain: Chennai may get short, heavy spells of rain
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A brief spell of rain flooded the Nungambakkam vehicular subway on Wednesday.

CHENNAI: In one of the more intense spells of rain in the past few weeks, the city received 1.78cm and the suburbs got 2.83cm of rain on Wednesday. Weathermen have forecast similar spells in the coming days.

The Met department said the sky is likely to be generally cloudy. ‘Light to moderate rain is likely to occur in some areas,” it said. Most parts of the city and its suburbs got a quick and heavy spell of rain early on Wednesday morning. A Met department official said the monsoon has extended and weather conditions continue to be conducive for rain.

Private weather blogger Pradeep John, in a social media post, said: “Chennai January normal rains is 26mm and we have got that rain on the first day itself. The last time Chennai got new year rain is on 2012, but the quantum was not so high.” He added: “On and off rains (and) small spells will be there till January 9 after which rains will reduce.”

The rain and cloudy sky brought down the maximum temperature to 28.3 degrees Celsius in Nungambakkam and 27.6 degrees Celsius in Meenambakkam. Usually the city experiences around 30 degrees Celsius during the day this time of the year. Met department has forecast that the day temperature will remain around 29 degrees Celcius on Thursday.

On Wednesday, OMR received 4cm, Kolapakkam and Chennai airport got 3cm, and Tambaram, Chengalpet and Sriperumbudur got 1cm rain.

Title: Retail demand for cars, SUVs positive from Sept-Nov ‘19
Content:
File photo

CHENNAI: Riding on heavy discounts particularly for BS4 models, retail sales of cars and SUVs have shown an increase for three consecutive months. According to the Vahan vehicle registration data shared by the government, passenger vehicle registrations were up 6.25% in November, 14% in October and 8% in September (see chart). This three-month on-the-trot sales increase comes after five months of continuous sales slump (see chart). The Federation of Automobile Dealers Associations (FADA), the industry apex body for auto dealers, says December too should see positive retail numbers for passenger vehicles though the bloodbath continues for the trucks and buses segment.“In December, dealers are expecting a small increase in sales. October saw positive retail due to festival demand, November the trend continued as the discounts continued and December too should see some uptick. The inventory levels are now very normal at 4 weeks countrywide and around 3 weeks in some markets and the liquidity situation is also improving with banks increasing their working capital and other financing,” said FADA president Ashish Harsharaj Kale. What has helped the situation, he added, are planned production cuts by car companies in the run up to the BS6 shift.“What’s happening is less a turnaround than a bottoming out with passenger vehicle numbers looking stronger month-on-month. The used car trade has also been quite active which is another indicator,” explained Kumar Kandaswami, partner, Deloitte.Used car marketers agree that the sector has been both strong demand and supply right through calendar 2019. “We were expecting a slightly softer December compared to October and November but used vehicle sales continue to be strong,” said Droom founder-CEO Sandeep Aggarwal. Online marketplace Droom, he said, sold used vehicles worth Rs 636 crore in October and Rs 604 crore in November and is looking to close December with around Rs 625 crore worth of business.The total passenger vehicle market (used and new) is currently 9 million units strong (used 5 million units, new 4 million units) and worth $77 billion (new $39 billion and used $38 billion).Auto financiers however say that December retails of some OEMS could be impacted by the production cuts taken to clean up the BS4 stocks. “December has seen some supply issues with a few OEMs that have been discontinuing their BS4 models. The aggressive discounting means customers are interested but in many markets they are not getting the model, variant, colour or powertrain of their choice,” said Vyomesh Kapasi, MD, Kotak Mahindra Prime.

Title: Car sales dip most in two decades in 2019
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Indian auto industry wrapped up one of its most difficult periods in the year 2019 as sales of cars and SUVs went into a free fall, witnessing the biggest decline in over two decades as rising uncertainties, difficult financing, and the economic slump kept buyers away despite heavy discounts. Such had been the pressure that the numbers fell despite the entry of new brands such as Kia Motors and MG Motors, which surprisingly managed a strong opening even in a difficult market.According to numbers sourced from the industry, sales of passenger vehicles — a cumulative of cars, vans and SUVs — fell below the psychological 3-million mark in 2019, after crossing the figure for the first time in 2017. The decline was led by the top brands that included Maruti Suzuki , Hyundai, Mahindra & Mahindra, Tata Motors, Honda and Toyota .The recipe for slowdown has been in the making since the middle of 2018 when numbers had actually started falling. The declines began to get deeper, and sharper, in the coming months and rather got more pronounced in 2019 as economic growth came under pressure and political uncertainties, with relation to the national elections, started growing. And, as liquidity pressures started mounting after the NBFC crisis and issues such as unemployment became severe, the industry started collapsing. Adding to the conundrum was the confusion around the migration to BS6 emission regime from April 2020 from the existing BS4.“It had been a tough year, but now we look forward to the New Year with optimism,” Shashank Srivastava, director (marketing & sales) at Maruti Suzuki , told TOI. Maruti — which also flags rising vehicle prices as a depressant — was able to hold on to its 50% share of the market, but feels that the industry still remains “cautiously optimistic”. Srivastava said that easing of interest rates, and better rural sentiments may help the industry regain numbers.Rajesh Goel, senior vice president and director, sales and marketing, Honda Cars India, said that while the tough period may continue, “The market seems to have bottomed out” for now. “It may still take a few more quarters, at least till the festive period later this year, to fully recover. However, we remain confident.”Ravi Bhatia, India president for analyst firm JATO Dynamics, said that rising congestion in bigger cities and the growing share of ride-hailing apps such as Ola and Uber also contributed to the decline.

Title: Eight die on New Year's Eve in Chennai and Kancheepuram
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A sea of revellers clicking photographs and selfies at Marina beach on Tuesday night.

At least eight people, including a lawyer and a college student, died in separate accidents on the city’s outskirts and in Kancheepuram on Tuesday night and in the early hours of Wednesday when the New Year revelry was at its peak. Police, however, said they were not able to confirm if any of the accidents were directly related to the celebrations.

While hotels and clubs were packed and there were thousands of people on the roads through the night, the biggest party spots, like always, were the Marina and the Elliot’s beach in Besant Nagar. About 15,000 police personnel were deployed across the city and about 75 flyovers were blocked for vehicles from 10pm on Tuesday. There were few untoward incidents.

S Thangavelu, a 20-yearold third year BCom student of a private college and resident of New Perungalathur , died after he rode his two-wheeler into a bus parked by the side of a road near Tambaram. His two friends, who were riding pillion, escaped with injuries. Police said all the three were not wearing helmets. Thangavelu was rushed to the Government Hospital in Chromepet where doctors declared him ‘brought dead’.

Roads in the suburbs were full of merrymakers, either going to events or returning from parties. Ramalingam, a 40-yearold lawyer practising in the Madras high court, was returning home on his two-wheeler after celebrating with friends when he was run over by a truck near Puzhal Central Prison. He died on the spot.

At Irungattukottai on Chennai-Bengaluru National Highway, a car rammed against a lorry, killing two and leaving four others injured. The deceased, who police identified as Kancheepuram residents Vignesh Sha, 24, and Sankar Sha, 26, had celebrated with four others at Kancheepuram and all six were driving to a party in Chennai when the incident occurred.

Near Ennore, Sundar, 48, a fisherman, died after his twowheeler collided with another two-wheeler. The other biker is being treated at a government hospital. While Mohammad, 45, of Porur, who was riding a bicycle, was knocked down by an autorickshaw near Kumanan Chavadi and died on the way to hospital, an unknown vehicle fatally knocked down Krishnakumar, 31, a motorcycle rider, at the Red Hills-Kathirvedu traffic signal.

Rajagopal, a 70-year-old pedestrian, was fatally knocked down by an autorickshaw at Karayanchavadi near Poonamallee on Wednesday morning.

LED-illuminated barricades were put up on arterial roads, particularly Kamarajar Salai, Dr Radhakrishnan Salai, Sardar Patel Road, Anna Salai and Poonamallee High Road, and special teams were deployed on ECR at Neelankarai, Thoraipakkam, Thiruvanmiyur, Outer Ring Road, Maduravoyal Bypass, GST Road and GNT Road to check ‘racing’. Help centres were set up at many places and 25 patrol vehicles were on the roads to help clear crowds and traffic.

Title: Chennai: Man cuts genitals after wife leaves home during quarrel
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Upset after his wife left for her mother’s home following a quarrel, a man cut his genitals at his house in New Washermenpet on Tuesday night.

Police said Babu, 40, of Tsunami Quarters was married to Devi, 35. The couple were childless and would often pick fights over it. The woman also did not like her husband getting sloshed.

Police said Devi sought a divorce from Babu and left for her mother’s home on Monday. However, she returned to celebrate the New Year on Tuesday when a quarrel broke out over Babu consuming liquor. Devi left for her mother’s house again.

Upset, Babu went to the kitchen and cut his genitals with a knife. Hearing his cries, neighbours rushed him to Government Stanley Medical College and Hospital. Police said his condition is critical.

Title: GST evasion: GST evaders set to face stricter scans
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Goods and services tax ( GST ) authorities are going to seek bank account details of businesses to tally with their filings, apart from initiating other measures, as part of fresh efforts to tighten the noose around evaders or those misusing and gaming the system.The revenue department will meet officials from central and state GST wings as well as the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) and the Central Board of Direct Taxes next. The idea is to improve upon the red flags, which have helped the government improve compliance, resulting in filing of the GSTR-3B forms rising over 12% to 81 lakh returns by the December 20 deadline.“Through e-way bills and FASTag, we will be able to check if goods have actually moved. Data from banks will help us check if genuine transactions have taken place or bogus details have been filled up in the returns,” an officer told TOI.Weak compliance, which resulted in less than 70 lakh returns being filed by the deadline just over a year ago, was seen to be one of the reasons for leakages. But over the last few months, the revenue department has started detailed data analysis helping nab those who were under-reporting sales or were claiming excess refund of input tax credit.The Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) along with GST Network, the agency providing the technology backbone, have devised what are commonly referred to as “red flags” that typically add up to around 40,000 a month in a tax base of over one crore. There are four-five parameters based on which alerts are sent out, with key focus being on the two GST returns that are filed.So, there is a “nudge” and a push in case the data in GSTR-1 does not tally with GSTR-3B. If the gap is around Rs 1 lakh, text messages are automatically sent to the company’s directors or the proprietor of a firm, asking them to look into the difference. Officials said, in a lot of cases, this itself is enough to get the entity to “rectify” the problem, which may have been due to oversight.

Title: Chennai: In first year of ban, over 320 tonnes plastic seized
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Corporation officials said some smaller establishments were still using plastics.

CHENNAI: The corporation seized more than 320 tonnes of banned plastic in 2019 from various establishments including manufacturers and wholesale dealers. However, small establishments continue to use plastic bags, which the civic body is confident of phasing out this year.

Plastic ban was enforced in the state since the beginning of 2019. An estimated ₹90 lakh has been collected as fine so far, say officials. While enforcement drive was in full swing in the initial months, monsoon preparedness and other civic infrastructure works put plastic raids on the backseat in the latter end of the year, say officials. Of the total amount of plastic seized, a little over ten tonnes was seized in the past three months. Officials said that while raids are carried out from time to time, only the smaller establishments are found using plastic bags, which they had stocked and hence the seizure seems smaller.

Three weeks ago, extensive raids were conducted in Valasaravakkam Zone (Zone 11), in Nolambur , Poonamalee High Road, Kundrathur Main Road, Porur. As many as 155 establishments- eateries, department stores, street side vendors were surveyed and 10 kg of plastic was seized from about 14 establishments.

A footwear showroom on Kundrathur Main Road, Porur, which was found using banned plastic, was sealed by the authorities.

In all 15 zones in the city, over 3.6 lakh premises have been raided till December 2019, officials said. The highest amount of fine collected is ₹14.9 lakh in Royapuram (Zone 5).

Title: Bengaluru: Gold ornaments worth Rs 3 lakh go missing from star hotel
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A Delhi-based man has lodged a complaint with Bengaluru police stating that gold ornaments worth Rs 3 lakh have gone missing from his room in a star hotel on Kumara Krupa Road. The incident is said to have occurred on December 28 when Kushagra Sharma checked into the hotel along with his wife.

"My wife had placed a 50gm gold chain with two lockets and a rudraksha chain with three lockets on the bedside. While heading to dinner around 9.30pm, I noticed she wasn't wearing the chains. She went near the bed to collect them and was shocked to see them missing. We immediately informed the hotel management and with their help, carefully searched the room again, but in vain. We suspect housekeeping staff may have stolen them," read the complaint.

Police said they have questioned the housekeeping staff. "We were busy with New Year security duties. We will question more staff this week," said police.

Title: Karnataka: Caste quota poses headache for BJP
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

BJP

BENGALURU: Renewed demands for higher reservation in education and employment for Schedule Castes and Scheduled Tribes pose a major headache for BJP ahead of the cabinet expansion.

The issue could give opponents and even disgruntled politicians in the saffron camp ammunition to question BJP’s efforts towards social justice, even as the party tries to shore up its electoral prospects by rebuilding Lingayat-SC/ST alliance in Karnataka.

ST legislators, led by health minister B Sriramulu, have already ramped up pressure on chief minister BS Yediyurappa, threatening to resign en masse if the government doesn’t consider the requests to enhance ST reservation from 3% to 7.5%. SCs have been demanding that their quota be hiked from 15% to 17.5%.

The previous Congress-JD(S) government constituted a commission to look into the demands and asked it to submit a report before December 31, 2019. The commission, headed by justice Nagamohan Das, has now sought time till June to complete its study, much to the annoyance of the Yediyurappa government, which wants to resolve the issue sooner. Panel members said they could not focus on the task because of political stability in the state earlier.

The BJP government has granted an extension, which has further angered ST legislators. “We understand that the commission faced logistical issues during the transition from the coalition government and BJP government, but a delay of six months is not acceptable. We request the commission to speed up the work and submit the report before January 15,” said Sriramulu, who is at the forefront of the quota enhancement campaign.

Yediyurappa faces another problem: there are calls to make Sriramulu and Ramesh Jarkoholi deputy chief ministers. He already has three deputies. Both Sriramulu and Jarkoholi are looking to emerge as undisputable voices of the Valmiki community by bagging the post and leading the quota movement.

The government also faces pressure from religious heads. Valmiki Prasannnanda Swami, the pontiff of Valmiki Peetha in Davanagere district, who had earlier exhorted ST legislators to quit, has convened a meeting of community members on Thursday to discuss preparations for Valmiki Jatre. The issue of reservation is expected to feature and a potential deadline of February 9 might be set for ST MLAs from across parties to resign. There are 15 ST MLAs in the assembly, including nine from BJP. If the nine BJP legislators quit, Yediyurappa’s majority government will be reduced to a minority one.

Title: Haryana: 8-year-old girl raped, killed in Nuh for resisting goat theft
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

AFP photo used for representational purpose only

CHANDIGARH: Nuh police have arrested a man for the rape and murder of an eight-year-old girl, whose body was found in the Aravali hills in Ferozpur Jhirka area on December 26, 2019.

According to police, the accused, who was a drug addict, had tried to steal a goat owned by the girl’s family. As she had resisted the act, the accused had allegedly raped and strangulated her with her dupatta, the police said, quoting the confession statement of the accused.

“We have taken him on police remand to recover the clothes he wore on the day of crime and re-construction of the crime scene,” Firozpur Jhirka station house officer (SHO) Hari Singh said.

The accused’s images with the stolen goat were first captured on the CCTV camera installed in Firozpur Jhirka area. On December 28, he was picked up for questioning. Initially, he tried to mislead the police, but later he confessed about the crime.

Police said in order to arrange money for drugs, the accused had stolen a goat belonging to the victim’s family. As the girl spotted the goat, she approached him and tried to take back the animal.

After murdering the girl, the accused used another route to cross Ferozpur Jhirka. He was apprehended before he could take the goat to New Delhi.

She along with two other girls had gone to the Aravali hills to graze the goats. Two girls had returned, but the victim had remained untraceable. On December 26, villagers launched the search and found her body. Her half-naked body was spotted hanging upside down.

Meanwhile, residents of the village where the victim belonged sought death penalty for the accused and urged the Nuh deputy commissioner to write to the home department for fast track trial in the case.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Nationality certificate row: DC tells RPO to issue passports to Ambala sisters
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ambala: Taking cognizance of the incident in which two Ambala-based sisters Heena (26) and Santosh (29) had been allegedly asked to submit nationality certificates for the issuance of passports, the Ambala deputy commissioner (DC) on Tuesday issued strict instructions and warning to the officials of the Regional Passport Office (RPO), Chandigarh, against such alleged acts. He also instructed the RPO to issue passports to the sisters.

DC Ashok Kumar Sharma said, “The officials in the passport office should not mislead citizens about the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). The main objective of the office is to look at the basic required papers and make passports available to the people concerned on the basis of those documents.”

The DC said a few days ago, Heena had written a letter to Haryana home minister Anil Vij in which she talked about problems in getting the passports. On September 16, 2019, Heena and Santosh were asked to prove their nationality after bringing ‘nationality certificate’ from the Ambala DC office.

Title: Dushyant made foolish move to become Dy CM: Chautala
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Ambala: Former Haryana chief minister and JBT recruitment scam convict Om Prakash Chautala, who is out on 14-day furlough from Tihar jail, termed his grandson and Jannayak Janata Party leader Dushyant Chautala ’s move to become deputy chief minister in the BJP-JJP government a foolish decision.

Addressing a rally of INLD workers at Ambala on Wednesday, Chautala asked them to unite and strengthen the party.

Talking to mediapersons about the present political situation in Haryana, Chautala said, “Before elections, the situations were in favour of INLD and if they had not left our party, we would have received the mandate, and Dushyant would have become the Haryana chief minister.”

“What would be a more foolish decision than this? He left the CM’s post and became a deputy CM. I have no guarantee that for how many days he will remain at that post. What will happen and where will they go? I do not have any hard feelings for anybody,” he added.

Commenting on Haryana home minister Anil Vij, Chautala said, “Today, he has big departments under his control, but everybody knows about his behaviour. If this ruling government falls in Haryana, then the first reason would be Anil Vij and the second reason could be Dushyant Chautala. Both are fighting for the number one spot.”

Answering a question about the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), the INLD supremo said, “This decision was not in favour of the country, but for the ruling party. The situation in the nation is poor, and the irresponsible persons are ruling the government. They take no tension for the nation even when India stands for the communal harmony and people of all the religions have their equal rights.”

The daughter of Congress rebel and former minister Nirmal Singh, Chitra Sarwara, who contested recent Haryana assembly elections against Vij from Ambala cantonment segment also accompanied O P Chautala during his Ambala visit.

Title: 35 of 39 expressway accident fatalities in 2019 on Mumbai-Pune stretch
Content:
Highway Safety Patrol (HSP) officials said 39 people died in accidents on the expressway last year. Of these f... Read More

Most eway fatalities on lanes to Pune

PUNE: Most of the fatal accidents in 2019 on the Pune-Mumbai expressway occurred on the stretch towards the city.Highway Safety Patrol (HSP) officials said 39 people died in accidents on the expressway last year. Of these fatalities, 35 were in the Mumbai to Pune lane.HSP officers cited speeding by motorists beyond the Khandala ghat section of the expressway as the main reason for the accidents on the “Pune corridor”. The HSP refers to the lanes of the expressway towards Pune city from Mumbai as the “Pune corridor”.On December 17, the driver of a car speeding from Mumbai to Pune lost control over the vehicle and it collided with the iron railing of the expressway. Two persons, including the driver, died in the accident. Police said the vehicle was speeding over 120km per hour when the accident occurred.HSP superintendent of police Milind Mohite said, “The stretch from the Amrutanjan bridge in Lonavla to the Kiwale exit of the expressway witnessed most of the accidents in 2019. Speeding beyond the permissible limits was the main reason for these accidents.”The HSP officer said the heavy vehicles mostly moved at a sluggish speed in the Khandala ghat section — from Khopoli to Lonavla — due to the steep gradient. “The lanes are free after the Lonavla exit point of the expressway. From there the heavy vehicles take the side lanes and many cars proceed to Lonavla and its adjoining hill areas,” Mohite said.“The general feeling among the motorists is that they waste a lot of time trailing the heavy vehicles in the ghat section. Once they see the empty lanes after the Lonavla exit point of the expressway, they tend to speed. And in this hurry, many drivers lose control over the wheel and meet with accidents,” he said.The said many accidents have occurred along the shoulder lane of the expressway from Mumbai to Pune. “Many vehicles remain parked on the shoulder lane after developing technical snags. There have been instances of cars speeding and ramming the vehicles parked on the shoulder lane. Vehicles can be parked on the shoulder lane only during an emergency situation or to repair snags,” he said.

Title: Maharashtra: Man held for death of 17-year-old daughter
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Sangli police on Monday arrested a man for allegedly murdering his 17-year-old daughter over an affair.

The police have also arrested another man for allegedly raping the 17-year-old in September last year.

“As per initial investigations, the teenager came in contact with a man from another village who had come to to stay with his relatives in her village,” said a police officer. “There was a relationship between the two and when the girl’s father learnt of it, he warned her to end all communication with the man.”

“As per her father’s statement, on Sunday night when he came home after his duty, he checked the call records on her phone and found the girl was calling the man regularly. This enraged him and he hit her on her head with a wooden stick. She fell to the ground unconscious.”

Man arrested for daughter’s death

The girl’s father’s statement said, “On Monday morning, she succumbed to her injuries on the way to a hospital. The hospital authorities declared her brought dead. A case was registered with our police station and we arrested her father,” the police officer said.

“During the post-mortem, it was found that the victim was three months pregnant. Her mother lodged a complaint and we arrested the suspect for allegedly raping a minor in September 2019. We have invoked section 376 and section 3,4,5, 5(J)(2) and 6 of POCSO against him,” he said.

Title: Drunk driving cases come down in Pune this New Year
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Revellers who were on the streets in their cars and on two-wheelers after downing several pegs found the police waiting for them on Tuesday night.The Pune traffic police registered 460 cases of drunk driving on the night intervening December 31and January 1, this year as against the 873 cases registered last year.In neighbouring Pimpri Chinchwad, the traffic police registered 202 cases of drunk driving across 10 traffic divisions, a small rise against the 124 cases last year.The police had started widespread awareness campaigns and intensified action to check people.The Pune traffic police stationed 130 static, mobile and decoy teams in civil clothes for the special drive against drunk drivers for safe celebrations.The traffic department was on bandobast duty at 52 locations under deputy commissioners of police, three assistant commissioners of police, 23 police inspectors, 34 police sub-inspectors and 648 constables.At another 74 locations, the traffic department with policemen from the local police station conducted drunk-driving tests using breath analyzers.The Pune police said 65 officials and 504 personnel from various branches were deployed to ensure law and order .Among the traffic divisions to register the highest number of drunken driving cases in Pune were Koregaon Park, Warje, Wanowrie, Kondhwa and Sinhagad Road.In Pimpri Chinchwad , the highest cases were recorded at Bhosari, Pimpri, Nigdi and Chinchwad.Police commissioner K Venkatesham said, “We are grateful to Punekars for giving us the opportunity to enter 2020 with zero incidents. I thank all the officers and personnel from Pune police for taking proactive, professional and precise steps so that people can enjoy the New Year with full safety.”Deputy commissioner of police (traffic), Pimpri Chinchwad police, Sudhir Hiremath said action was taken through the night to nab drunk drivers. “We had 15 breath analyzers and had set up nakabandi at 15 points within the areas under our jurisdiction and took action against 202 people,” he said.
