Title: Uttar Pradesh officers to get choppers to mop up tax, CM Yogi Adityanath gives nod
Content:
Yogi Adityanath

LUCKNOW: To raise tax collection in the state, chief minister Yogi Adityanath authorised officials of the rank of additional chief secretary to take state-owned helicopters to visit commissionerates for field visits.Reviewing tax collections in the state during a meeting on Wednesday, the CM said officials responsible for tax collections should carry out regular field visits. He asked the principal secretary, excise, principal secretary, stamp and registration, and principal secretary, power, to visit the 8 divisions. “We have been told to visit two divisions a day. Each division should be reviewed separately. To ensure we are able to complete work on time, the CM has told us to use state helicopters,” said a senior official.The state has about 14 lakh registered traders and the CM directed officials to increase this number to at least 50 lakh since UP is a largely consumer state. Interestingly, despite a slowdown in tax collections across the country, UP’s tax collection has registered an increase. In November, collections were about 12.4% higher than in the same period in 2018.Reviews should begin from January 15, the CM said, and weekly targets should be set for district officials which will be monitored at the headquarters level.

Title: Ordinance to allow Jacobite burials in Orthodox churches, vice versa
Content:
Representative image

Orthodox faction objects to ordinance

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: In a bid to resolve disputes over burial of bodies in churches under the possession of Jacobite and Orthodox factions, the state cabinet on Wednesday approved an ordinance to ensure burial rights for believers in their church cemeteries. The Orthodox faction has condemned the move, saying it is not in accordance with the Supreme Court verdict and is an attempt to bring in parallel administration in churches.The cabinet has sent the ordinance for the consideration of the governor. Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan told reporters that the ordinance would ensure the right of any family of a parish to bury bodies of its family members in the cemetery of the church where their family tomb is situated, irrespective of any objection or dispute. If there is no family tomb, a believer’s body will be buried in the cemetery of his/her parish church.Vijayan said the ordinance would also allow the family of the deceased to conduct the post-death rituals anywhere outside the church or cemetery by a priest of their choice. The provision will allow a family to perform the final rites at a Jacobite church and conduct the burial in an Orthodox church where the family tomb is situated and vice versa.He said the government had to take the decision as the cabinet subcommittee that was formed to resolve the disputes between the Orthodox and Jacobite factions could not succeed in its efforts.“One of the factions refused to even discuss the matter with the sub-committee. There is nothing illegal in the ordinance. The usual custom is that a body should be buried at the earliest and when one section decides not to concede to any solution, the government cannot be a mute spectator. We are also not going against anything ruled by the Supreme Court,” the chief minister said.The Jacobite Church has welcomed the move but Orthodox Church episcopal synod secretary Metropolitan Yuhanon Mar Diascoros said the clause in the ordinance that anyone can cremate the body of a parish member in the cemetery cannot be approved.“The right for getting buried in a cemetery belonging to Orthodox Church is only for those belonging to the parish church. The vicar of the parish is in charge of the cemetery. The clause allowing anyone to enter the cemetery and bury the dead is a violation of the Supreme Court verdict. The Supreme Court had made it clear that it will not allow parallel rule in the cemetery. Burying bodes in the cemetery without the permission of priests who have officially become the vicars through the court judgment will create anarchy,” he said.The cabinet also decided to re-promulgate the Kerala education (amendment) ordinance 2019, the Kerala devaswom recruitment board (amendment) ordinance 2019, the Kerala state goods and services tax (amendment) ordinance and the Kerala minerals ordinance.

Title: Kolkata: New Year party on terrace turns fatal for 29-year-old woman
Content:
Sweetie Sutradhar

Woman’s fatal fall accidental or suicidal, suggest forensic officers

KOLKATA: A 29-year-old woman, celebrating New Year’s Eve with her husband on the terrace of their home in Poddarnagar, south Kolkata, was killed after she fell down four storeys through a narrow shaft between two adjacent buildings in the early hours of Wednesday.Sweetie Sutradhar, who used to work in a call centre, was found in a pool of blood by neighbours at the bottom of the shaft of her neighbouring building after her husband, Kuntal Acharjee, raised the alarm about her being missing. He was detained and being questioned by officers of Kolkata Police’s homicide department till late on Wednesday over certain discrepancies in his statement. Forensic officers indicated, however, that there were signs of the death being accidental.Police said Sweetie and Kuntal had come back to their rented apartment from a party around midnight. At that time, a group of residents of the same building were partying on the rooftop. While the others came down around 12.30am, Kuntal told cops that he and his wife stayed back drinking.“Kuntal said that after some time, he felt tipsy and came back to their third-floor flat and passed out,” said a senior officer of Kolkata Police’s south suburban division. “According to him, he woke up in the morning and noticed his wife wasn’t there, and began a search.”Even as the residents began a search, someone opened a door of the shaft at the ground floor of the neighbouring building and found Sweetie’s body. The residents immediately called officers of Jadavpur police station, who rushed her to MR Bangur Hospital, where she was declared dead.The shaft (circled) between the two adjacent buildings, through which Sweetie (left) fell to her deathResidents have also told cops they heard a muffled cry of a woman sometime between 2.30am and 3am on Wednesday and even called cops to check. “A team of officers from Jadavpur police station visited our apartment and conducted a search, but they could not find anything. Even the noise had ceased when they came,” said an elderly resident of the building.Officers of the forensic and homicide departments went to the spot. While homicide department officers said nothing concrete could immediately be said about how Sweetie had fallen till they received a detailed postmortem report, forensic officials suggested that it looked accidental or suicidal.“Had someone pushed the woman from the terrace, the body would have maintained a certain distance from the wall during the fall. But the fall trajectory doesn’t show any such sign. There are some distinct marks close to the wall throughout the shaft’s outer wall, which can be present only when the victim tries to hold on to something to avert the fall,” said a senior forensic official.He added there were some marks to show the victim spent considerable time on the edge of the shaft before falling down.Cops said Sweetie, who hailed from Asansol, got married to Kuntal, a video editor, a year ago. The couple moved to the Poddarnagar flat four months ago. “We have heard the youth’s family owns a hotel at Tarapith. They seemed peaceful and we have never heard any kind of rift between them,” said Kabita Roy Chowdhury, who lives on the ground floor of the building.The cops said the two adjacent buildings have a common 2.5ft-high parapet, and they were checking whether Sweetie had somehow lost her balance. “As she was new to the building, it is possible she may had tried to cross over to the other terrace by jumping over the parapet. Those not familiar with the place would also not know about the shaft. It is possible she had fallen down accidentally under the influence of liquor. But nothing can be clearly said till we get the postmortem and ante-mortem reports,” said an officer.“We have started a case of unnatural death. We are looking into all angles and are speaking to residents of the building, along with the husband, to find out how the woman could have fallen down,” said an officer.

Title: 600 medical teachers from GMC, MGM Indore resign en mass
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Peeved over the delay in implementation of 7th central pay commission benefits, about 600 medical teachers from Gandhi Medical College, Bhopal and MGM, Indore tendered their resignations on the New Year day on Wednesday.Teaching faculty from all the 13-government medical colleges have threatened to resign if their demands are not met by January 9. Doctors are demanding 7th pay commission benefits for the medical teachers, effective from January 2018. Last year, the Kamal Nath government after coming to power had cleared 7th CPC for them effective from April 2018.On Wednesday, 300 medical teachers from Bhopal’s Gandhi Medical College (GMC) and around 90% of teaching doctors of Indore’s MGM College tendered their resignations to their respective deans. Speaking to TOI over the en masse resignations of medical teachers, medical education minister, Vijaylaxmi Sadho said, “Congress government implemented 7th CPC for medical teachers soon after it came to power. There are budgetary issues and other constraints which are being worked out. Doctors should take that into consideration and not rush into harsh decisions.” There have been three high-level meetings with doctors’ body – Central Medical Teachers Association of MP. The meeting in July, September and last on November 23, have only resulted in assurances and no progress, said, CMTA-MP secretary, Rakesh Malviya. “We are only demanding 7th CPC benefits which have been already been cleared and given to all other government employees,” he said.From January 9, all 3,000, doctors and faculty in 13 government-run medical colleges have threatened to resign. “I am a doctor, too. I understand the condition of medical teachers better than most. However, by threatening to resign, medical ethics cannot be put on the line,” said Sadho.On a conciliatory note, CMTA-MP has offered to the government that it will not demand immediate payment of 7-CPC arrears. It has given the government an option to add it to the doctors EPF or other funds, with an assurance it would be paid out in a defined timeline.A strike by doctors can paralyse medical services across the state. A similar strike, some six months ago brought to a standstill services at Hamidia hospital and other hospitals.

Title: Mangaluru: Citizens collect Rs 2 crore to help victims’ families, injured CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

A file photo of the violence that gripped Mangaluru in the wake of CAA protests

MANGALURU: Two weeks after violent protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act left two protesters dead in Mangaluru , various organisations and citizens have collected over Rs 2 crore to help their families and those who were injured in the clashes.

“Funds started pouring in after Karnataka chief minister BS Yediyurappa rolled back Rs 10 lakh compensation to the families of each victim that he had announced after the violence,” police officials probing the violence said.

Former MLA BA Mohiuddeen Bava is among those who are involved in collecting the funds. However, he refused to divulge details about the money collected so far. “Contributions may stop if we reveal this information. We are trying to help the victims’ families and the injured. They are facing financial difficulties after the recent violence,” he said.

On December 19, anti-CAA protests turned violent and a mob allegedly tried to attack a police station.

Over 12 people being treated in hospitals

Nauseen Kudroli, 49, and Jaleel Bengre, 23, were killed when Mangaluru police opened fire to control the protesters.

Sources said that over 12 people, who were injured during the protests, are still being treated at various hospitals in the coastal city.

“Over Rs 2 crore has been collected to help the victims. Contributors have decided that Rs 25 lakh each will be given to Kudroli and Bengre’s families. The rest will be given to the injured protesters. We don’t know when the funds will be handed over to them,” a senior police officer told TOI.

Former chief ministers Siddaramaiah and HD Kumaraswamy have already announced compensation to the victims’ families. West Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee recently announced Rs 5 lakh each for the two families.

Title: Man held for chain-snatching
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

TRIPUNITHURA: Hill Palace police on Wednesday arrested a 36-year-old man for allegedly snatching a gold chain from an elderly woman on Tuesday.

Identifying the accused as Shehanad (36) of Valapattanam in Kannur , police said that he was a history-sheeter and had committed similar crimes in the past as well. “He used to target elderly women pedestrians at deserted areas. He used to follow them on his two-wheeler, before attacking them from behind. In many cases, the women had even fallen on the ground,” said an official.

On Tuesday’s incident, 83-year-old Kousalya from Eroor, who was on her way to a nearby temple, was attacked.

A team led by Hill Palace inspector P Rajkumar and sub-inspector K R Biju made the arrest. Police identified the accused from CCTV footages from nearby area. He was produced before a magistrate and was remanded in judicial custody for 14 days.

Title: Kota hospital deaths: 9 more kids die in Kota hospital, death toll at 100 in December in 2019
Content:
Representative image

Deaths of kids at J K Lon hosp saw slide since 2014

KOTA/JAIPUR: At least nine more infants have died at Kota’s J K Lon hospital in the last two days, taking the toll to 100 in December 2019.The number of infant deaths in the same hospital in December 2018 was 77, the hospital authorities confirmed on Wednesday.“At least nine newborns and infants have died in J K Lon hospital on December 30 and 31. The number of kids’ deaths in December has reached 100,” the hospital superintendent, Dr Suresh Dulara, said on Wednesday.He added, “On December 30, four kids died and on December 31, five kids died. All of them died mainly due to low birth weight and birth weight hypothesis.”The state government on Tuesday ordered hospitals attached to medical colleges to check the functional status of all medical equipment and send reports.Last week, chief minister Ashok Gehlot and health minister Raghu Sharma had claimed that that most of the children who died were referred to the hospital in critical condition from nearby districts, including regions of neighbouring Madhya Pradesh.The hospital superintendent claimed on Wednesday that the number of infant deaths at the hospital in 2019 was lower than 2018 and the lowest in last six years.“At least 1,005 kids died in 2018 in the hospital, while 963 died in 2019,” said Dulara. The number of infant deaths at J K Lon Hospital has witnessed a constant decline since 2014 when 1,198 deaths were recorded, which was 7.6% of the 15,719 admitted, according to data from Kota district collector Om Kasera and the hospital superintendent. The percentage declined to 7.2% in 2015, 6.6% in 2016, 5.9% in 2017, 6.1% in 2018 and 5.7 %, the lowest, in 2019, the hospital superintendent said.Following the controversy over the high number of infant deaths in December 2019 alone, the hospital has put in efforts for the upgradation and maintenance of its medical equipment, as well as reconstruction of paediatric units and deputations to make up the insufficiency of medical and nursing staff in the hospital.The principal of Medical College Kota, Dr Vijay Sardana, said, “The units of the paediatric department have been subdivided into three units. The HOD’s office will be in J K Lon Hospital and the non teaching unit will be working on the New Medical College Hospital premises.”He added, “A work order for installation of a central oxygen supply line in the hospital has been issued and work would be completed within 15 days. Proposals for new OPD and emergency wards for the paediatric and gynecology departments have been incorporated in the proposed OPD block under the Smart City Project.”Taking serious note of TOI’s report on December 30 headlined “Over 50% of gadgets in Kota hospital where kids died defunct”, the medical education department wrote to the principals and controllers of all medical colleges saying: “An immediate stock-taking of all the equipment should be carried out to make sure that all the gadgets are in use and their annual maintenance contracts (AMCs) are in place.”“For equipment whose AMCs have not been done, the process should be immediately initiated after stock-taking,” wrote Vaibhav Galriya, principal secretary, medical education.While pointing out that some equipment might be lying in hospital stores after purchase, he directed that a physical verification of the stores be done to ensure that such machines are identified and put to use immediately.Galriya has also pulled up doctors while pointing out that hospitals are not properly maintaining IPD bed tickets. “It has also been observed in some hospitals that IPD bed tickets are not being properly maintained. History and clinical notes of the patients are incomplete. All departments and treating doctors must be instructed to make sure that proper recording of patients’ medical information is done after their admission to the IPD,” he said in the circular.Also, proper counselling of patients and their attendants should be done. “They should be briefed regarding the disease and health of the patients,” he wrote.To prevent infection from spreading, he pointed out that microbiological surveillance of operation theatres (OTs) and ICUs must be regularly done at least once a month and samples taken from all relevant portions of OTs and ICUs.The hospitals attached to medical colleges will also ensure that bacteriological reports of the samples should detail the bacteria for which the culture is positive or negative and take curative action. Standard infection control practices, including hand hygiene, should be ensured in all OTs, ICUs, labour and procedure rooms, said Galriya’s directions to all medical colleges.In Video: More children die in Kota hospital, toll rises to 100

Title: Anti-CAA protests: Uttar Pradesh government sets seven-day deadline for response to seizure notices
Content:
Smoke billows out of a burning OB van during a protest against NRC and amended Citizenship Act at Parivartan C... Read More

K’taka, Rlys adopt model

LUCKNOW: Uttar Pradesh government has set a 7-day deadline for response to property attachment notices slapped on those accused of damaging public property during citizenship protests.More than 150 notices have been issued by the Lucknow administration since chief minister Yogi Adityanath declared those who indulged in violence will have to compensate for damages.Reviewing security arrangements in the aftermath of massive protests across the state during anti-CAA protests, the chief minister had directed police and administration to expedite identification of ‘rioters’ through photographs and video footage and swiftly issue notices. “In Lucknow, around 150 notices were issued. The accused will be given a week to present their side, but if the committee is not satisfied, proceedings will begin to extract compensation. If they are not in a position to pay, their properties will be attached and auctioned,” said a senior official in the government.Under fire from National Human Rights Commission for alleged police excesses during the protests, the CM also directed the administration to forward video clips of protestors to NHRC to bolster the government’s position.The government has taken recourse to a 2010 Allahabad high court order which allows the government to claim damages for public property destroyed during protests or riots from those convicted for violence.Even though the CM has drawn flak from Opposition parties, Karnataka chief minister BS Yeddiyurappa declared he too would take similar action against protesters. Yogi’s model is also being followed by the Railways.Meanwhile, the chief minister has said since protests were triggered by rumours and misinformation, police should reach out to the people, especially among the minority community, and tell them CAA will not take away citizenship. For this, help should be taken from the intellectual class, media professionals, professors, doctors and religious leaders.

Title: Asia Pacific drosophila research conference from Jan 6
Content: PUNE: Two Nobel laureates, Eric Wieschaus and Michael Rosbash, will be in the city to attend a conference from January 6 to January 10, 2020. Indian Institute of Science Education and Research Pune will be hosting the 5th Asia Pacific Drosophila Research Conference (APDRC5) and Indian Drosophila Research Conference. The conference will be held at The Westin Pune, Koregaon Park, informed an official from IISER.'Asia Pacific Drosophila Research Conference happens every two years, and this is the first time it is coming to India. This conference will bring together people from all over the world who use the fruitfly Drosophila as a model organism to address basic and applied questions. This year's meeting will see a participation of about 330 Indian and about 100 international participants, including some of the biggest names in fields like neurobiology, cell biology, developmental biology, evolutionary biology and so on,' said the official note.The notification further said, 'We are particularly proud to host two Nobel laureates, Professor Eric Wieschaus and Professor Michael Rosbash who have made seminal contributions to the fields of developmental biology and chronobiology respectively,' said the official notification from IISER, Pune.Registration is compulsory for anyone who wishes to attend the conference.

Title: Umbha violence: Five lax cops fined with 30-day salary cut
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Nearly six months after 11 tribals were killed in indiscriminate firing by the head of Umbha village in Sonbhadra over a land dispute, police authorities on Wednesday penalised five cops with a fine equal to their 30-day salary for lackadaisical attitude which led to violence.Superintendent of police, Sonbhadra, Ashish Srivastava said, “When village head Yagya Dutt tried to forcibly grab a disputed piece of land in 2017, police inspector Shiv Kumar Mishra and his predecessor Mool Chand Chauhan, did not pay heed to complaints by Gond tribals. They handled the matter with a prejudiced approach.”“Three constables – Kanhaiya Lal, Sudhakar Yadav and Pramod Kumar Singh – did not act as per rule of law and followed directions of their senior officers. As a result, 30 days’ salary of these cops will not be given to them for their services,” he added. On July17 last year, a group of villagers belonging to Gond tribe were carrying out farming on disputed land when a group of men, led by gram pradhan Yagya Dutt, reached there to take possession of the land which, they claimed, was purchased by him and his relatives in 2017.This led to violence which left 11 tribals killed and 21 others injured.The government ordered an SIT probe into the incident which is still pending.Sonabahdra district police also launched a probe into the role of cops who had served at Ghorawal police station under whose jurisdiction Umbha village falls. On October 14, police also filed a chargesheet against 51 people.

Title: Workshop on symmetry on Physics and Mathematics organised by CoESME
Content: PUNE: A workshop on symmetry on Physics and Mathematics for Under-Graduate teachers has been organised by Centre of Excellence in Science and Mathematics Education (CoESME), Indian Institute of Science Education and Research, Pune. The workshop will be held from January 14 to January 18, and has been named 'Intertwining Strands in Physics and Mathematics: Symmetry'.The official notification from IISER explaining about the aim of the workshop said, ''While the deep relationship between Physics and Mathematics, where ideas from one have often given very important insights and applications in the other, is very well-appreciated by the experts, this is often not adequately emphasized in the college level teaching of these subjects in India at Bachelor of Science or Master of Science level. The aim of this workshop will be to expose Indian teachers in mathematics and physics to these shared grounds. We will discuss the physical context of mathematical ideas, and vice versa, by taking Symmetries and Groups as an example,'Interested teachers have to apply online via the official website of IISER. There are no registration fees for attending this workshop however candidates will be selected. 'Selected participants will then be provided with local hospitality. Outstation participants will be reimbursed round trip 3-tier train fare (shortest route) from the place of residence. Participants are expected to stay for the full duration of the workshop,' added the notification.The workshop has been designed by Rohini Godbole from Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, Deepak Dhar, IISER Pune and Chandrasheel Bhagwat, IISER Pune.

Title: Pakistani migrant wants to sit for Class XII exam, RBSE says no
Content:
Dami Kohli

Dami Kohli

JAIPUR: A Pakistani Hindu migrant girl’s request to sit for the Class XII board exam this year has been allegedly turned down by the Rajasthan Board of Secondary Education (RBSE) citing technical reasons.Dami Kohli, who migrated from the neighbouring country’s Sindh province and currently settled in Jodhpur , had cleared her Class X board exam from Pakistan and then passed her Class XI exam after migrating to India in August 2018.“I was completely devastated when my form was rejected. We had faced immense problems in Pakistan and are hoping for a better future in India,” said Dami.State education minister Govind Singh Dotasra, who intervened in the matter on Wednesday evening, said the government was thinking of allowing her to sit for the exam and added that they had already sent a letter to the Pakistan high commission seeking details.“We haven’t received any reply from them. We want to know the details of their syllabus and do a comparative analysis. They are yet to reply. Any technical glitch will affect the future of the girl which we are trying to avoid,” said Dotasra.An RBSE official, who did not wish to be named, said whenever a student clears an exam from any other board, the standard is checked. “There are times when the marking system of the other board is lenient than RBSE. In that case, we have to look into whether the student would be able to pass as per our standards. These are the norms that must be followed to avoid any fraud,” said the official.

Title: PV Sindhu: PV Sindhu's Mission 2020: The Olympic gold
Content:
PV Sindhu (Getty Images)

The three big targets this year...

What about All England title? Do you think it has lost its charm?

If you’re asked to choose between 2016 Olympic silver and 2019 World championship title, which one do you like the most?

Do you think 2019 could have been better?

You won only one title (Worlds) last year and lost in the first and second rounds of several tournaments. Your opponents think that you are unpredictable...

How do you suddenly raise your game in big tournaments. It happened in 2013, '14, '16 and '19?

How does leading Hyderabad Hunters help your game?

What are the areas of your game that you’d like to improve?

How do you look at women’s field in 2020?

Your match against Tai is being billed as the match of PBL...

Do you think Tai is no longer a force to reckon with on the circuit?

After the career high of a world crown in 2019, PV Sindhu has turned her attention to Olympic gold this year. While touching upon a lot of topics around her game and targets during an interview with TOI, the 25-year-old believes that unpredictability is her strength.Excerpts:Olympic gold will be the first and most important target. Then to become No.1 in the world and win a few of super series titles.All England is a prestigious tournament. Every tournament is important, but Olympics is the most important and World championships after that. All England is also on my radar and so I said some of the super series titles.Both are different memories. In 2016 nobody thought Sindhu will win in Rio. Then Sindhu was just one good player. But now after that silver, the level of recognition and responsibility is quite high. This world title also no one expected me to win. Both are very different from each other and very good memories.I wanted to win a few more super series titles. But then, I am happy as I won the World championships gold, Indonesia silver. It’s been a good year.Unpredictability is my strength. I feel it is good thing. It depends on the day, the shuttle, surroundings, drift etc. But I never felt bad about my early round losses. Despite first-round losses, the belief that I will play well in the next tournament is very strong. World championship is a very happy moment.I don’t know how I play well in big tournaments. Or if it is a good sign or a bad sign. But I am happy that I play well in big tournaments. So I want it to be like that always. It’s not that I want to lose small tournaments and win only the big ones. Sometimes luck also matters. I lost matches when I had big lead and I also came back from big deficits.It is very helpful. For example, Lionel a senior player used to tell me several important things like I should be more alert on court. I think the advice helped. It is going to be more of fun this year as we know each other. A few new players have joined the team so we will give our best, whatever happens will happen.After the Worlds, a lot of people have been telling me about some aspects of my game. I am working on them. I am working on patience and fitness. All other aspects of my game are good. The most important thing is to play the right stroke at the right time.Now the top 10 to 15 players are of the same standard. They are so many best players from different countries. Tai Tzu (Ying), (Nozomi) Okuhara, the Korean girls, Ratchanok Intanon, Chen Yu Fei, etc. All of them prepare well. On that day we have to give our best. If plan ‘A’ doesn’t work, we have to come up with plan ‘B’. There is no particular strategy.Everyone in PBL are waiting for the match between me and Tai Tzu. It’s definitely going to be a good match. PBL has always been very interesting and exciting because it is a team event. It happens only once in a year and there will be different players and we have to play for the team. The atmosphere is very different, the support we get from the team and the assistance we get from different coaches is all quite different. They will tell their views, point out our mistakes and these small things will add to our game.The Taiwanese player was unbeatable for a long time but now people are able to read her game well. The game is constantly changing. If I play a certain type of game in one tournament, I will play a different game the next time. It is a challenge to steal the point from the opponent. We have to consistently find where the opponent is vulnerable and catch them unawares. It is very important.

Title: Rainfall expected today in Uttar Pradesh: Met
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The relief, however, will be shortlived because western disturbance is expected to cause rains in Lucknow from... Read More

LUCKNOW: A western disturbance that originated from the Mediterranean Sea and hit the Himalayas after crosscrossing from over Iraq, Iran and Pakistan brought relief from severe cold conditions in the city on Wednesday. The relief, however, will be shortlived because western disturbance is expected to cause snow in the hills and rains in UP and Lucknow from Thursday till Saturday.

The minimum temperature on Wednesday was 4 degrees Celsius while the maximum was 20.1degrees Celsius, one unit below normal. “Western disturbance along with a cyclonic circulation over Haryana and easterlies is expected to cause a few spells of light to moderate rain in some parts of UP including Lucknow,” said State Met director JP Gupta. There is also possibility of hail on Friday in isolated places.

Title: Life could have originated in ‘soda lakes’, says study
Content: WASHINGTON: The early Earth may have hosted many carbonate-rich lakes, which contained high enough phosphorus concentrations to get life started on our planet, according to a study.Phosphorus is one of the six main chemical elements of life, and forms the backbone of DNA and RNA molecules. The element acts as the main currency for energy in all cells and anchors the lipids that separate cells from their surrounding environment.“For 50 years, what’s called ‘the phosphate problem’, has plagued studies on the origin of life,” said Jonathan Toner, an assistant professor at the University of Washington (UW) in the US. The problem is that chemical reactions that make the building blocks of living things need a lot of phosphorus, but the element is scarce.The new study, published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, has found an answer to this problem in certain types of lakes. The research focused on lakes rich in carbonate — a salt of carbonic acid — which form in dry environments. Because of high evaporation rates, the lake waters concentrate into salty and alkaline, or high-pH, solutions. Such lakes, also known as alkaline or soda lakes, are found on all seven continents, the researchers said.They first looked at phosphorus measurements in existing carbonate-rich lakes, including Mono Lake in California Lake Magadi in Kenya and Lonar Lake in India. While the exact concentration depends on where the samples were taken, the researchers found that carbonate-rich lakes have up to 50,000 times phosphorus levels found in seawater, rivers and other types of lakes.“The extremely high phosphate levels would have driven reactions that put phosphorus into the molecular building blocks of RNA, proteins, and fats, all of which were needed to get life going,” said David Catling, a professor at UW. The carbon dioxide-rich air some four billion years ago would have been ideal for creating such lakes and allowing them to reach maximum levels of phosphorus, the researchers said.

Title: No cheer: Spurt in tomato, onion & potato prices burns hole in pockets
Content:
Representative image

By: Akshta MishraLUCKNOW: Prices of tomato, onion and potato – staple vegetables in every Indian kitchen – are going out of reach of the common man.After a spike in onion prices in past few months, the cost of tomato and potato is witnessing a sharp rise in the past week, reveals a quick survey carried out by TOI in four major retail vegetable markets of the city – Narhi (Hazratganj), Dandaiya (Aliganj), Bhootnath (Indiranagar) and Mithaiwala crossing (Gomtinagar).Citizens are clueless as prices of these vegetables, used in almost all the preparations, are drilling a deep hole in common man’s pockets.Restaurants and food joints have also increased prices of various dishes accordingly. “Just a week ago, tomato was priced at Rs 20-30 but now it is being sold at Rs 40-60 per kg depending on quality,” said Sameer, a vendor at vegetable market in Dandaiya.Sheela, a homemaker, said: “Grocery prices have gone up. Our food budget has increased by 30-40% a month.”Potato prices have also gone up by 20-100%. Potatoes, which were available at Rs 20 till last week, now cost Rs 25-40 per kg.Suresh, a wholesaler at Dubbaga Mandi, said the prices of tomato and potato had gone up due to reduction in supply following damages to the crop due to extremely cold weather prevailing for about a month in different parts of the country. Onion price continues to hover around Rs 100 per kg. Raju from Naveen Galla Mandi at Sitapur Road said no relief was in sight in near future. Sale of these basic vegetables have gone down by almost 50% collectively as it is significantly hampering household budget.

Title: RGUHS mulls bringing out app for its flagship Jeeva Raksha programme
Content: MANGALURU: Bengaluru-based Rajiv Gandhi University of Health Sciences' (RGUHS) flagship life skills saving programme - Jeeva Raksha will be rolled out as a mobile app. With first batch of around 6000 students trained in this programme set to pass out at the end of current academic year, the university will create their online data base, geo-tag their phones as a precursor to rolling out the app that will endeavour to provide real time help to the needy.Shivanand Kapashi, registrar of RGUHS toldthat the Jeeva Raksha programme launched in 2014 has been made compulsory for graduates undergoing their internship. With the first batch of trained students passing out this year, Kapashi said the university will have to wait for at least two-more years before it can have sizable number of trained first responders who can react to a medical emergency that gets flagged to them via the app.The university is toying with the idea of rolling this App, that is presently at a conceptual stage, on a trial basis in Bengaluru and Mangaluru that has sizable number of medical colleges and will present the perfect pool for trained manpower to roll out this service. The idea is to ensure that a person trained in life saving skills can reach the emergency site within 15 minutes, which in a place like Bengaluru might be a bit hard to achieve, he surmised.With geo-tagging of a trained life saver, the app will flash the emergency on to their cell phones and a person nearest to the site could go over and help the person, he said. The advanced lifesaving course mandatory for medical students and basic lifesaving course that others including those opting for allied health sciences courses study deals with topics such as burns, ingesting poison, snake bites, respiratory issues and cardiopulmonary resuscitation, he said.Dr S Sacchidanand, vice-chancellor, RGUHS said the university spent the first three years in developing around 250 master trainers for this programme who in turn trained teachers of medical colleges in the state. Students are made to study the techniques in simulation labs that are being set up in government medical colleges, he said, adding the union government, NITI Aayog has appreciated the RGUHS model and marked it for replication across India.

Title: Gujarat: Self-taught Porbandar girl wins first prize in shot put
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

21-year-old Rambhi Seeda in a practice session in her farm

RAJKOT: She has proven that Ekalavya is not merely a mythical character defining exemplary discipleship - 21-year-old Rambhi Seeda has shown it in her own life too.

Without the help of any coach, this self-taught woman not only mastered the game of shot put, but even won the first prize of Rs 21,500 in the game in the recent state government organized 'Khel Mahakumbh 2019'.

"I learned various moves and techniques of shot put by watching videos on YouTube on my cellphone. I practised daily both in the morning as well as evening in my farm for months together. I clinched the top spot throwing a five and a half kg iron ball in the Khel Mahakumbh," gushed Rambhi, a resident of Parawada village, some 35 km from Porbandar .

Apart from shot put, Rambhi also learned discus throwing again from the videos. While she had won the second prize in discus throw in 2017 Khel Mahakumbh, she stood third in the game in 2018 and also bagged the first and second prize at the university-level competitions in the same sports.

"I am proud of my daughter. She has been interested in sports, especially, discus throw and shot put, since her childhood. I have always encouraged her in sports. I am glad that an event like Khel Mahakumbh has recognized her achievements," said Rambhi's father, Devsi Seeda.

Title: Habib accuses Kerala Governor of misquoting Gandhi and Azad for insulting Muslims
Content: AGRA: Historian Irfan Habib, on Wednesday, said that he had interrupted Kerala Governor Arif Mohammad Khan’s inaugural address at Indian History Congress (IHC) as he was wrongly quoting Mahatma Gandhi and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and attributing words to them to insult the Muslim community.Quoting the Governor’s address, Irfan Habib said, “the Governor claimed that Azad had said that Muslims are dirty water of Hindustan and Gandhi had given statements against them”. Habib said that this is absolutely incorrect as these leaders had never said such things. “I was present in the meeting, which was being quoted by the Governor,” claimed Prof Habib.He said that he would have reacted in the same manner, if the governor had misquoted anyone else and used “inappropriate” words against any community. He said he stopped the governor as he was “abusing” the sacrifices of these great leaders, even when the audience was objecting to it, he claimed.On being asked about breaking protocol as Governor Khan alleged that Habib went on to the extent of pushing aside his security aides while he was speaking, Prof Habib, said that History Congress also has a protocol that police should not have been deployed at the rostrum, but they were present there.Explaining the series of events of the day, Habib said, that he was stopped by the police on rostrum, when he was going towards Governor and that is against the rules of IHC. He said, “I pushed them back and walked towards him”.He admitted that he asked the Governor to quote Nathuram Godse, when he did not stop speaking against Maulana Azad and Mahatma Gandhi.On December 28, Kerala Governor Arif Mohammed Khan alleged that eminent Habib tried to disrupt his inaugural address at the Indian History Congress and said this "intolerance" towards a different opinion was “undemocratic”. In a series of tweets, the Governor said efforts were made to interrupt his speech on stage and from the audience during the INC at Kannur.

Title: Odisha Govt nod to start teacher recruitment in 4 varsities
Content: BHUBANESWAR: The higher education department on Wednesday asked four state universities under its jurisdiction to start teacher recruitment process. The appointment was stalled for more than a year due to reservation related disputes.The department has accord permission to fill up vacancies in Sambalpur University, Ravenshaw University at Cuttack, North Odisha University at Baripada and Shri Jagannath Sanskrit Vishvavidayalaya at Puri.Ravenshaw University has 179 vacant teaching posts out of 267 sanctioned posts. Shri Jagannath Sanskrit Vishvavidayalaya has 24 vacant teaching posts against the sanctioned posts of 38. Sambalpur University has 52 vacant teacher posts in the place of 153 sanctioned posts and North Odisha University has 74 vacant posts against 115 sanctioned posts.The department has decided to fill up all the vacant posts of these universities. A total of 329 teachers will be recruited in these four universities, said a senior higher education department officer.TOI had published the story 'State varsities hit by shortage of teachers' on December 15 last year highlighting the problems of universities due to lack of teachers. Besides these four universities, other six universities are also facing the same situation.Utkal University has 119 vacant posts against 257 sanctioned teacher posts. Rama Devi Women's University, which was upgraded into an affiliated university on May 30, 2015, has only 33 permanent faculty members against sanctioned posts of 138. Newly created Gangadhar Meher University has only 16 teachers against 144 sanctioned posts. Another new university Khallikote University has 12 vacant posts out of 42 sanctioned posts.Berhampur University, one of the oldest universities of the state, has 72 vacant posts against the sanctioned posts of 153. Fakir Mohan University has only 45 teachers out of the 117 sanctioned posts.On May 27 last year, the department had asked these universities not to proceed with recruitment of teachers till further instruction. But the same department had directed the universities on May 9 last year to start the recruitment process.Official sources said the department had imposed restriction on recruitment process to make the recruitment process seamless, faultless and free from any dispute.

Title: Aide kills singer, three of his kin over Rs 60,000, insults
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

After bhajan singer Ajay Pathak, his wife and daughter were found murdered, police on Wednesday found his son’... Read More

MEERUT: Police on Wednesday found the charred body of a 14-year-old boy from Haryana 's Panipat town, 40km from west UP's Shamli district where his father - a 'bhajan' singer - mother and elder sister were found murdered a day ago.

The accused, Himanshu Saini, an aide of 'bhajan' singer Ajay Pathak (45), was arrested by Haryana police. According to Panipat police, Saini was arrested when he was trying to flee after setting ablaze Pathak's SUV which had his son, Bhagwad's body. Police have sent the charred body for forensic and post-mortem examination.

It all happened a day after Ajay, his wife Sneha Pathak (42) and daughter Vasundhra Pathak (16) were murdered with a sharp-edged weapon at their Shamli house. Police said during interrogation, Himanshu confessed to have killed the entire family for not returning Rs 60,000 they owed to him. Himanshu alleged that he was insulted by Ajay every time he asked for his money .

The accused confessed to have killed the family with "one of the many swords which were kept at their home". Shamli SP Vineet Jaiswal said, "Himanshu had dinner with the family on Monday, and decided to kill them after he was allegedly humiliated by Ajay."

"After dinner, as the family was sleeping, he first went to Ajay's room and attacked him and his wife Sneha with a sword. Then he went to Vasundhra's room and killed her. He then strangulated 14-year-old Bhagwad to death," said SP Jaiswal. Police said Himanshu planned to dispose all the bodies. He first took Bhagwad's body to Panipat. "But, when he got to know that the news of the murders has spread, he set the car on fire," said Jaiswal.

Title: Jaipur night shelters overcrowded as mercury continues its slide
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot distributes blankets at a night shelter in the city on Wednesday.

JAIPUR: As the city is witnessing one of the coldest winters of the last few decades, there has been a rise in the number of people taking refuge in nights shelters.

According to the management of the night shelters , the number of people coming there has seen a steady rise in the last four days. There are 14 shelters with a capacity of 50 to 150 people. People coming to the shelters, however, vary from 70 to 200 per night.

Santosh Gupta, manager of the night shelter near Ram Niwas Bagh, said they had been running out of blankets and mattresses in the last couple of days. “We are facing space crunch. All the slots get filled by 7 pm and we have to ask people to get their own blankets and let them sleep inside. We even ask people to adjust with more people on one mattress or else extra people have to sleep on carpeted floor,” said Santosh.

On Tuesday night, chief minister Ashok Gehlot visited night shelters situated near Ram Niwas Bagh and near JK Lone Hospital. Gehlot distributed blankets to the people and asked for their well being.

Night shelter is divided into two portions - men and women/children. The women portion is separated with a temporary wall and a curtain. Most of the women coming at the shelters are accompanied by men.

As per the norms of the shelter, persons with valid identity cards are allowed inside. Their card is taken for the night and given back to them in the morning. “It is better for the security for the people staying here or else there are chances of theft. At least with this we will be sure who all are staying here,” said Manoj Saini, manager of a night shelter.

Some people have objected to this. Sunita and her family, who live near the JK Lone Hospital, said they were not allowed to live inside the shelter because they didn’t have the documents. “Night shelter is supposed to be for the poor and needy people like us and if identity cards are made a pre-requirement, than the purpose of the shelters is lost,” said Sunita.

Title: Telangana lacks district-wise data on parameters crucial for planning
Content:
Telangana chief minister KCR

HYDERABAD: Even as Telangana is gearing up to carry out the National Population Register ( NPR ) exercise, the state government does not have a proper district-wise data on various parameters, which would be crucial for framing policies and implementing various government schemes.For example, if the government wants to focus on agriculture or irrigation facilities in a particular district, data on the number of operational landholdings and size of the landholding, net area irrigated and other details is a must. With no data available, planning will take a hit.With no district-wise details, the government has not come out with the statistical report in the last two years.The last report published by the directorate of economics and statistics in 2017 (fourth edition) was based on 2015 for some categories and depended on 2016 information for other categories.When contacted, director of economics and statistics department A Sudarshan Reddy said the reports were not published for the last two years. The 2017 report was based partially on 2015 and partially on 2016 information mainly due to non-availability of data from newly-created districts. “We will soon come out with the latest report,” the director said.The government created 21 new districts, which were carved out from 10 districts that existed in October 2016. Two more districts -- Mulugu and Narayanpet — were created in early 2019. Generally, the economics and statistics department collects data from each department, compiles and publishes information in the form of a report every October.Officials said that as many as 28 categories of information pertaining to each district such as demographics and population, health, climate change , livestock, agriculture, education, health, forest, transport, industries, mining, energy, banking, crime and police, industries, tourism and judicial data are compiled in the report.“The revenue department took more than a year to provide boundaries of new districts, mandals and revenue divisions. The government not only created new districts, but also created over 100 new mandals (now 589 mandals). Similarly, revenue divisions were also created. Since transfer of villages happened in the past couple of years, lack of records, staff crunch for compilation and series of elections have led to delay in compilation of the reports,” a senior planning official said. There were allegations that district collectors have not taken interest to send the data to the government.Interestingly, a couple of months ago, the census department wrote to the state government on 460 missing villages in about half a dozen districts after new district were formed and sought a clarification before carrying out Census-2021.

Title: Kolkata Weather: Kolkata gets warmer but chill may return after 2020’s first wet spell
Content:
Even as the temperature climbs, Kolkata is set to receive rain during the later half of Thursday.

KOLKATA: The New Year day turned out to be pleasant in Kolkata, minus the sharp chill that had descended last week.Even as the temperature climbs, Kolkata is set to receive rain during the later half of Thursday. While showers could be moderate, the western districts of the state could be lashed by heavier rain. The rain could continue in Kolkata on Friday, though it could lose intensity and taper off by the weekend. Kolkata recorded a minimum temperature of 12.1°C on Wednesday.A cyclonic circulation over northwest Madhya Pradesh is set to trigger clouds, leading to rain in Bengal, said Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC) director GK Das. “It’s being fed moisture by the easterly winds flowing in from Bay of Bengal. The circulation has been formed partly by a western disturbance that has been moving towards central India from Jammu and Kashmir over the last few days,” said Das.He added the circulation will move closer to Chattisgarh on Thursday and start generating clouds that will float into Bengal. “The impact will be felt by Thursday and the day will remain cloudy. As a result, day temperature will climb down. But the minimum temperature will rise to 14°C degrees and should remain there at least till Friday,” said Das.While the cloud cover is set to pull the maximum temperature down to 20°C, the minimum could fall once the rainy spell ends.An uninterrupted flow of chilly northwesterly winds led to a lowering of temperature across south Bengal last week. Cold-wave conditions prevailed at Purulia, Bankura, Birbhum, Jhargram, West Burdwan, East Burdwan, East and West Midnapore and Murshidabad last Saturday. In Kolkata, the minimum temperature dropped marginally while the maximum, too, remained well below normal on till Wedensday.

Title: Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata Hai update, January 1: Vedika asks Kartik to leave Naira
Content: In the latest episode of Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata Hai Kartik thanks Vedika for agreeing to give her kidney to save Naira 's life. She says it is very difficult for her to live without him as she loves him.Kartik gets angry at Vedika and is in a dilemma when he hears Kairav's shout. He realises that Kairav has reached hospital and he sees his mother unwell.He asks Kartik about Naira, the latter consoles him and says everything will be fine. Kairav asks his father to promise him that nothing will go wrong with his mother.Kartik then agrees to Vedika's demand but asks her to not reveal anything to the family.Everyone is happy to know that Vedika has agreed to donate her kidney. Title: Rajasthan: Librarian exam scrapped after leak, kingpin at large
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The Rajasthan Subordinate and Ministerial Services Selection Board (RSSB) on Wednesday cancelled an exam held earlier this week because of question paper leak. The question paper of the exam, held for the recruitment of librarians on Sunday, was leaked two hours before the exam.

According to RSSB officials, a new date will be announced soon. Around 55,000 candidates appeared for 700 vacancies of Grade-III librarian. The notification was issued in May 2018.

Sources said the new announcement will take at least six months more and the exam will be held a year later. In a joint operation, Jaipur police along with crime branch arrested six persons including two women in conning aspirants by providing them original question papers with answer keys for the post of librarians in government facilities.

Police have recovered the question paper and the answer key. A WhastsApp group was created by the accused named ‘’Jai Shree Krishna’ where they shared the paper and the answer key just two hours before the exam.

The main accused in the case, Sandeep Nehra, who is the owner of a coaching institute, is still absconding. A police constable is said to be involved in leaking the paper. He is said to be absconding as well.

Police officials said, “The accused ran a gang where they would charge candidates by giving them the question papers for various examinations in government jobs. They had made a Whatsapp group and two hours before the librarian exam on Sunday posted the question paper followed by the answer key. We had been keeping a watch on this gang and after receiving information through a source, the accused were arrested from Vidhyadhar Nagar.”

Title: ‘Chhapaak’ actor Deepika Padukone’s 34th birthday plans revealed - details inside
Content: Bollywood actress Deepika Padukone is currently on a promotional spree for her film ‘ Chhapaak ’. The film revolves around Malti who is an acid attack survivor and her battles. This Meghna Gulzar directorial also stars Vikrant Massey The film is releasing just a few days after Deepika’s birthday. The actress will be turning 34 this year and looks like she has some special plans for her birthday. It is being said that she will not be hosting a grand birthday bash but instead celebrate it with acid attack victims.According to Mumbai Mirror, the ‘Piku’ actress will be spending her birthday in Lucknow. She will be travelling to a café which is run by the victims and spend her birthday there. The source also revealed that apart from the café staff, acid attack survivors from neighbouring cities will also be a part of the celebrations. The source says, “Deepika will leave for Delhi later in the day to resume the promotional rounds of Chhapaak.”Meanwhile, Deepika has already impressed the audiences with the trailer of ‘Chhapaak’. It has received an overwhelming response from the people and they just can’t stop praising the actress. The film is slated to release on January 10, 2020. The film will be clashing with Ajay Devgn and Saif Ali Khan ’s ‘Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior’.Apart from this, the actress will be seen with Ranveer Singh in ’83 which is directed by Kabir Khan. The film will release this year in April.

Title: Odisha Govt urges NLUO to reserve 25% seats for state students
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Higher education department secretary Saswat Mishra on Wednesday urged National Law University Odisha (NLUO), Cuttack, to reserve 25 per cent of seats in it's under graduate courses for students of Odisha.Mishra in a letter to the vice chancellor of the university said the students who have passed class XII or equivalent examinations from the state of Odisha shall be eligible for claiming reservation for admission under the state domicile quota."I would request you to work out the necessary modalities so as to enable the students of Odisha to avail 25 per cent domicile reservation for taking admission in the NLUO, Cuttack, from the academic session," said the secretary in the letter.Mishra had also written a letter to vice chancellor of the university on August 2 last year on the issue. He had told the university authorities that the Odisha government has given close to Rs 200 crore to the institute for development of its infrastructure.The higher education department had also written a letter to the university on April 24, 2018, on the same issue. It is also learnt that no reservation has yet been provided to the students of Odisha in the under graduate courses, said a senior officer of the higher education department.

Title: Howrah: Man lynched trying to save 13-year-old boy, six arrested
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

HOWRAH: A middle-aged man was lynched reportedly while trying to intervene and stop youths at an open-air New Year’s Eve party in Howrah from beating up a 13-year-old, whom they accused of theft. The incident took place around 11.45pm near the Daspara locality in Howrah’s Belur on Tuesday. Cops have arrested six youths accused of killing the victim, Debashish Haldar (37).

The accused allegedly struck Haldar with bricks. As he fell on the playground — where two open-air parties were on to usher in the New Year — the attackers started hitting him with bamboo poles. Later, one of them hit him with a brick on his head.

When others tried to lift Haldar, the attackers allegedly tried to stop them. Later, cops from Belur police stationreached the spot and took him to T L Jaiswal State General Hospital where doctors declared him dead. But the accused had fled by then. The victim’s uncle, Bapi Haldar, said: “Youths on the playground were beating up a teenager from Lalababu Sayar locality. When the news of assault reached out neighbourhood, some people, including Debashish, rushed to rescue the boy. He tried to stop the youths from beating up the kid. He also asked them not to drink and play loud music as it was a residential area.” ”

Howrah City Police DC (north) Y Raghubanshi said: “We have arrested six accused, two of whom were identified as Benoy, Abhisekh.”

Title: Why key India players are missing Ranji Trophy ties
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Highlights TOI has learnt that Iyer, Dube and Agarwal were all “advised rest” by the “medical team of the Indian team”

In case of Bumrah, he was first selected to play for Gujarat but then told by BCCI president Sourav Ganguly to pull out

From left, Shreyas Iyer, Shivam Dube and Mayank Agarwal

MUMBAI: A few days back, some of the former cricketers and the media ripped into Shreyas Iyer and Shivam Dube for not turning up for Mumbai’s Ranji Trophy game against the Railways at the Wankhede Stadium on Christmas Day despite no international commitment in that period. Missing them badly, Mumbai suffered a crushing 10-wicket defeat, their first to Railways.

Around the same time, pacer Navdeep Saini too missed Delhi’s Ranji Trophy game against Hyderabad, citing that he had “been asked to rest”. On Tuesday, it emerged that India’s Test opener Mayank Agarwal will miss Karnataka’s Ranji Trophy match against Mumbai, which begins at the MCA BKC Complex from Friday.

TOI has learnt that Iyer, Dube and Agarwal were all “advised rest” by the “medical team of the Indian team,” which comprises physio Nitin Patel and trainer Nick Webb.

“Team India’s medical team of the Indian team monitors the workload of all the players in the side. Iyer and Dube were asked to rest as per its advice. Mayank has played two games so far, but he needs to rest a bit now because then he will leave with the India A team for New Zealand on January 10. Whenever a player is asked to rest from domestic games, skipper Virat Kohli, coach Ravi Shastri and chief selector MSK Prasad are informed about it,” said a reliable source in the board.

“It’s important to manage the workload of all the India players, so that they’re fresh and fit when they play for India. Sometimes, in this period when they’re asked to rest, they’re supposed to just train for a week and not play any cricket. There is so much non-stop cricket these days that workload management is paramount,” he explained. “The medical team maintains a database of all the players, their injuries and matches played.” he added.

However, there is an argument that the India players’ missing the Ranji Trophy despite being available to play devalues India’s biggest domestic tournament. There was also the case of pacer Jasprit Bumrah , first being asked by the selectors to play for Gujarat in the Ranji Trophy against Kerala in Surat but then being told to pull out by BCCI president Sourav Ganguly, a fact that got the attention of the legendary Sunil Gavaskar who wrote in a column that he hoped that it would be an exception.

“It’s not that all India players have stopped playing in the Ranji Trophy. In New Zealand, Mayank will be playing in both the limited-overs and the four-day first-class games. Ajinkya Rahane and Prithvi Shaw are playing for Mumbai. KL Rahul played in both the Vijay Hazare and Mushtaq Ali Trophy for Karnataka. At a time when you have IPL, T20 cricket and the India A tours, you have to give players sufficient time to recuperate and stay fresh,” he stressed.

Title: Chennai: Man who stole lingerie caught on camera, hunt on
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

CCTV camera footage shows the man who allegedly took away lingerie in Adambakkam

CHENNAI: Police have launched a hunt for a man who has been allegedly stealing women's lingerie in Adambakkam area. The man, believed to be in his 40s, would frequent houses looking for the innerwear of women left to dry.

The residents of an apartment complex in New Colony, Adambakkam, found the lingerie of women going missing during nights and checked CCTV camera footage. They were shocked when the footage showed a man hiding his face using a shawl and wearing a lungi entering the complex scaling the compound wall. He was found peeping into the bedrooms of residents and lifting the lingerie. He apparently made sure that the residents were asleep and then went on to steal their clothes.

With the help of surveillance cameras, police found he only stole innerwear from among clothes left to dry outside houses and those hung near windows. Based on the CCTV camera footage, the residents have lodged a complaint with the Adambakkam police.

Police believe the number of victims could be higher. Police sources said that initially residents believed that the lingerie could have gone missing accidentally until more women came up with similar complaints. They suspect that the culprit may have stolen the clothes at irregular times from different areas in the neighbourhood, making his capture difficult.

"So far, we haven't received complaints from residents from other localities," said an investigation officer. As of now, police said that they can't reach a conclusion about the motive for the man stealing the lingerie. "The case is weird," an officer said.

Police said that the culprit's face was not clearly visible in the CCTV footage, though they were confident that his physical appearance could help them crack the case. Police are yet to register any case in connection with the incidents.

Title: ‘Startup policy should give bigger roles to investors’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

JAIPUR: The startup draft policy has laid out an ambitious target of creating 1 lakh jobs and facilitated growth of 2,000 startups. While the industry said the measures will improve the entrepreneurial ecosystem in the state, the government also needs to involve the private sector players as they are better placed to know what works and what does not as they have already invested large sums of money in startups.

In order to empower and handhold startups, the draft policy proposed to waive off conditions like prior experience and turnover so that they can participate in government contracts. The objective of the initiative is to invite solutions for citizen-centric services provided by the government.

While the government has proposed a process for selecting ideas or startups involving IT or e-governance experts and government officials, Mahavir Sharma, chairman of TiE Global Board, said representatives from non-profits in the sector should be involved for identifying better ideas. “Government departments should just be observers. You don’t just need sector specific experts but also real investors who know what else is happening in India and the world in early stage startup ecosystem. Officials from the specific departments which need the solution should be there as has been mentioned but having investors would be very effective,” said Sharma.

The draft also makes provision for a RAJIV fund which can invest up to 25% in SEBI approved Alternative Investment Funds. But Sharma RAJIV fund should co-invest in accredited Angel networks across India. “The early ecosystem needs angel funding and not funding by funds. “The startups in Rajasthan need support at the lower level. By investing in the funds that will invest later might be premature at this stage,” added Sharma.

On the constitution of evaluation and implementation panel, he said academicians and transferable government officials don’t make good evaluators or investors. “People who have invested and succeeded make good evaluators. The government should not be in the process of evaluating actual startups. They should let proven Angel investors or VCs do it and co-invest with them. There should be a committee of all the above to evaluate the co-investor not the startups,” he added.

Title: Rajasthan tells Centre to send new machines to fight locusts
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

File picture of locusts at a field in Jaisalmer.

JAIPUR: The state cabinet on Wednesday urged the Centre to send new machines to Rajasthan to control the menace of locusts.

“This is a matter of concern that farmers had to incur so much losses because of crop damage due to locusts. A central team was in the state to assess the situation and had sent machines to end the menace,” said state health minister Raghu Sharma after the cabinet meeting on Wednesday.

“Now, the Centre has shifted those machines to Gujarat to control the situation in the state. Therefore, we are demanding the Centre to send new machines to Rajasthan so that locust menace could be brought under control,” he added.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot had on Sunday ordered a special girdawari to assess crop damage due to locust attacks.

The CM held a public meeting at Dhanau Panchayat Samiti headquarters on Monday after seeing crop damage caused by locusts in Mithi Nadi village of Dhanau tehsil in Barmer district . He was on a two-day visit to western Rajasthan, which has been badly affected by locust attacks. The cabinet also approved making Nirogi Rajasthan a mass movement. "About 50,000-60,000 Anganwadi workers will be part of the movement. Awarness programmes will be organised in schools for the screening of the children. About 8-9 departments will be clubbed in the entire campaign. The role of various departments were also discussed in the meeting," said Sharma.

Title: Bigg Boss 13: Vishal and Shefali Bagga tell Shehnaz that Sidharth Shukla doesn't prioritise her ever; the latter is in tears
Content: In the upcoming episode of Bigg Boss 13 Vishal Aditya Singh and Shefali Bagga will be seen creating a rift between Shehnaz Gill and Sidharth Shukla. Title: Rajasthan: Girls still on top of tank, exam on schedule
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Two girls who climbed the overhead water tank on Rajasthan University campus remained there for the third day on Wednesday. In the afternoon, they threw a cloth soaked in petrol threatening to immolate themselves if the first grade teachers’ exam was not postponed.

First grade teachers’ exam is on January 3 and the government had already announced that they won’t shift the exam date.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot had announced that 3,000 vacancies for the first grade teachers’ exam would be announced in September. This did not go well with a couple of candidates who are protesting on campus for past few days braving the harsh winter. Police officers, fire tenders and an ambulance have been on alert near the water tank for the last three days. Senior police officers also reached the spot on Wednesday to convince the girls, but they faced students’ ire. A police officer said they were trying to put a safety net around the tank, but were disallwoed by their supporters. “We requested the candidates to let us put safety net but they refused. If a girl falls off accidentally from the tank, her life would be in danger,” said the officer.

BJP MP Kirori Lal Meena, who has been supporting the students, reached the spot and requested the girls to climb down, but left unsuccessfully in the evening.

Meanwhile, candidates who are preparing for the recruitment exam are tensed. A candidate said at a time when the economy is down and unemployment is raising, this protest is putting their future at stake.

Title: Realme ColorOS 6: Realme seems to have learnt from Xiaomi’s ‘pain’
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Chinese smartphone maker Realme has decided to show ads on its phones. This is bad news for many users as they don’t like the clutter of annoying ads on their phone’s UI. But there is a silver lining to the news too, as Realme will also include a provision to disable all the ads with a single tap. And that’s where the former Oppo sub-brand appears to have learnt from its arch-rival Xiaomi , as it is painstakingly difficult to disable ads in MIUI . Realme will roll out the ads in India to all its phones running ColorOS 6 and above with the next update.

Users can recognise the ads by “commercial content recommendation”, a long-winded term coined by Realme. These ads (or commercial content recommendation) will appear in the Phone manager app and Security Check page by default after the update gets installed. To disable them, Realme phone owners can go to Settings > Additional settings > Get recommendations and then switch it off. That’s it. One tap to block every ad. Something like this hasn’t been possible in a Xiaomi phone yet, with users having to disable every single ad one by one manually, even in flagships like the Poco F1 . Realme has been doing really well in the Indian market since its inception in 2018 by targeting the budget and the mid-range smartphone segment and has thus begun to be known for its affordable devices.

Realme’s latest smartphone launch is Realme X2, that comes at a starting price of Rs 16,999. The key features of the handset are 64MP quad AI camera (with ultra wide angle and macro lenses) and the Qualcomm Snapdragon 730G processor, that’s said to enhance the gaming performance of the phone. There is a 32MP AI front camera with a Super Nightscape mode. The device is backed by a 4000mAh battery and comes with 30W VOOC Charge Flash 4.0 that is claimed to charge the phone to 65% in 30 minutes.

Title: No pets allowed in lift: RWA of Zirakpur society removes notice
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The resident welfare association of a society in Zirakpur has removed the notice that directed pet parents to not use lifts for their pets. The resident welfare association had put up the notice last week, which drew a lot of criticism from animal welfare activists.

The notice stated that lifts were meant to be used by the residents only and anyone using them for thier pets will be fined Rs 1,000.

"The lifts installed are meant for residents only. Dogs are not allowed in lifts. It has been observed that almost daily pets urinate in lift cars, which spreads foul smell. All are requested to avoid such type of nuisance. If any resident is caught, he/she will be fined Rs 1,000. Cooperation of all is solicited," the notice read.

Vikas Luthra, an animal rights activist and a resident of the society, had shared the notice, which attracted public irk on social media.

"No resident welfare association can make such a rule. According to a high court ruling, no association can impose such a fine," Luthra said.

The TOI had earlier reported that as per Animal Welfare Board of India (AWBI) no one can restrict movement of any animal. "According to AWBI guidelines, RWAs cannot stop pet owners from using lifts. The RWA might not be aware of these rules," another animal activist said.

Title: 7 years on, Chandigarh railway station awaits its new CCTV cameras
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

The plan proposed installation of cameras at 25 spots, such as entry and exit points, end of platforms, circul... Read More

CHANDIGARH: Shortage of funds has further delayed the seven-year-old proposal of replacing CCTV cameras at the Chandigarh railway station.

As many as 35 CCTV cameras keep an eye on the safety and security of passengers at the railway station. But they have a poor quality of recording. Sources said they are running on outdated technology.

Gurinder Mohan Singh, divisional railway manager, Ambala, said the division is facing a fund crunch. He said the division is aware that CCTV cameras are outdated and need immediate replacement. He said other departments were asked if they could transfer the funds but they have yet to get back.

The station improvement group (SIG) of the security department had drafted a proposal for new CCTV cameras and baggage scanner. The proposal includes metal detectors at entry and exit points on both Chandigarh and Panchkula side of the station. On Chandigarh side, a baggage scanner has been installed.

In 2017, the Ambala division sought a budget for hi-tech CCTV cameras, baggage scanner, lift and accelerators but the railway board did not give nod to the proposal. Later, the RPF on their own prepared a proposal and sought funds from the divisional railway manager, Ambala for installation of CCTV cameras.

Recently, the Northern Railway had told the Ambala division that they should hire a contractor who can install and maintain cameras. Members of the railway protection force (RPF) would be deployed to monitor the premises.

A plan was drafted for the installation of cameras at 25 spots, such as entry and exit points, at the end of platforms, circulating area and near booking counter at the station. But the work is yet to start.

Title: Mumbai: 87 pubs, bars shut in 2019 over lack of fire safety systems
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: As many as 87 pubs, discotheques and orchestra bars across the city were ordered shut by the fire department last year for violating fire safety norms. Last year also saw the fire brigade receiving overall 5,4217 fire calls—at all places, including residential and commercial-—from Mumbai, a rise of nearly 13% compared to 2018.

The fire brigade had inspected 402 drinking establishments with fire NOC and found 115 of them violating the norms. The inspections were part of the special drive launched following the December 2017 Kamala Mills blaze that claimed 14 lives.

Explaining the drive, an official they want to ensure that drinking establishments do not compromise on safety. The fire brigade started compliance units at the local level, with officials conducting frequent inspections of such establishments as well as residential buildings for fire-fighting and other safety systems. If the fire brigade finds violations, they issue notices to the establishment to make their premises fire compliance, failure of which leads to serious action.

A fire officer said, “Such places are normally dark and have high footfalls. In case of a disaster on such premises, casualty can be very high. So, we insist that such places should be fire compliant. They should take precautions for the safety of people or we will not allow them to function.”

The fire department has given NOC to 411 orchestra bars, discotheques and pubs, including those in five star hotels—121 of them are in Bandra-Andheri belt.

About the overall number of fire calls they received, an official said 2019 saw the most calls in the last three years. Last year, fire brigade received 22 serious calls —level III and IV—compared to 20 in 2018. In 2017, the fire brigade received 26 serious calls and one Brigade Call (highest level)—the Kamala Mills case.

This story is from January 2, 2020
