Title: ISRO to set up Regional Academic Center for Space at NIT Karnataka , Surathkal
Content: MANGALURU: Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) is partnering with National Institute of Technology, Karnataka (NITK) to carryout advanced joint research and development activities in the area of space technology applications. This partnership will see ISRO set-up a Regional Academic Centre for Space (RAC-S) at NITK Surathkal and the two agencies are set to sign a MoU in this regard on January 3.The MoU will facilitate advanced research in areas of relevance to future technological and programmatic needs of Indian Space Programme. The centre will act as facilitator for promotion of space technology activities in southern region comprising Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Tamil Nadu, Puducherry, Kerala and Lakshadweep and become an ambassador for capacity building, awareness creation and R&D activities of ISRO.The activities of RAC-S will be directed to maximize the use of the research potential, infrastructure, expertise and experience already existent in ISRO and NITK. The RAC-S will also facilitate and engage other institutes of excellence in the region to take part in capacity building, awareness creation and research and development activities related to space technology, space science and space applications.The RAC-S will consist of faculty members and researchers from NITK and visiting scientists and experts from ISRO. Activities will be guided by a joint policy and management committee (JPMC) consisting of top executives from two organizations. The JPMC will plan the promotional activities including the research programmes of common interest and periodically review such research programmes and related activities.JPMC will also facilitate collaborative activities between the partner institutions of southern states of Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Tamil Nadu, Puducherry, Kerala and Lakshadweep. ISRO will provide necessary annual grant as recommended by the JPMC to the tune of Rs 2 crore per year for the conduct of research and development projects, promotional activities and administrative expenses.The joint research and development activity will actively engage students of NITK and partner institutions. While BTech and MTech students will be engaged in carrying out short term research projects of one year duration, PhD students will be engaged in long term projects of 2-4 years relevant to advancement of space programme. Eligible students will also receive research fellowships during the project period.ISRO and NITK will jointly own the intellectual property generated as part of this research activity. A one day workshop on space technology applications will also be held in NITK after the MoU signing ceremony. Four senior scientists from ISRO will deliver lectures on latest research and development work being conducted in ISRO as part of this workshop. They will also interact with faculty members and students of NITK.

Title: After Mhadei, Prakash Javadekar snubs Goa plea to discuss coastal plan
Content: For the Centre to relax the norms, Javadekar has to hold a meeting of Goa officials with those from the env... Read More ‘State bound by projects as it had cleared them’ PANAJI: After having given a raw deal on the Mhadei issue , Union environment minister Prakash Javadekar has once again ignored Goa’s requests for a meeting to discuss the draft coastal zone management plan (CZMP), 2011.Despite state environment minister Nilesh Cabral sending five letters requesting for an appointment to discuss certain relaxation in norms from the Centre, he has only got acknowledgement of the letters with no sign of a meeting.Goa, which has been given an extension till January 31 by the national green tribunal to submit the coastal plan-—probably the last extension—runs the risk of missing the deadline that can lead to heavy fines and jail term for the state officials.“We have written five letters—the latest was sent on December 24—and I have also met him three times. All we are getting are acknowledgements for our letters,” Cabral said.He said considering Goa’s unique ecosystem, it is necessary for the Centre to make some coastal regulation zone relaxations. “Otherwise, only 257 sq km of the state’s total 3,702 sq km of land will be available for development,” he said.This is because most of the land has already been demarcated under national highways, national parks and wildlife cover, private forests, paddy fields, salt pans, fish farms and other eco-sensitive areas.“Only 257 sq km for development is too little for a population of 15.6 lakh and 80 lakh tourists visiting the state,” Cabral said in his December 24 letter to Javadekar.We want to discuss the pressing and important subject of proposed amendments to the CRZ notification 2011 pertaining to Goa. We have submitted four letters on July 4, October 23 and 31 and again on November 30 in 2019. The latest letter was written on December 24,” said Cabral.For the Centre to relax the norms, Javadekar has to hold a meeting of Goa officials with those from the environment ministry, National Coastal Zone Management Authority and National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management.Cabral said chief minister Pramod Sawant had also briefed Javadekar about the objections raised by the people of Goa to the draft CZMP 2011, during the Union minister’s visit to the state in July 2019.“Goa has granted various clearances prior to the CRZ notification 2011. Based on these clearances, people have invested their hard earned monies to purchase fully approved and developed plots. The Goa Coastal Zone Management Authority (GCZMA) had also given their consent. Post-2011 notification, the high tide line (HTL) has shifted due to breach of bunds, etc, affecting numerous people,” Cabral had written to Javadekar.Breach in the bunds has meant more land inwards has turned saline, now making CRZ regulations applicable here, and making it a no development zone Cabral told Javadekar that since the state government itself had cleared these projects, it is bound by the principle of ‘promissory estoppel’.“Hence, it is proposed that after Clause 3(xiv) an additional clause be inserted stating that ‘CRZ notification of 2011 shall not be applicable to all such projects for which approvals had already been granted for development of plots prior to the CRZ notification 2011 and the line of HTL shall from such closest of the plot permitted for development’,” Cabral wrote.

Title: Bengaluru: Startup fosters design instincts in government school kids
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Students take part in an Inqui-lab session at a government school in Bengaluru

BENGALURU: When his teacher brought some magnets to the class and asked him to use them however he wants, 10-year-old Arif from a nondescript private budget school in Hyderabad designed a shirt with magnetic buttons for his physically handicapped friend. In yet another government school on the outskirts of Bengaluru, a class 7 student designed a solar iron box for his parents, who run a laundry to enable them save on coal.

Both boys were in the classrooms of a startup - Inqui-lab - that works with government schoolchildren in Bengaluru and Hyderabad and helps them design innovative products. The startup is now being incubated by NSRCEL, the entrepreneurship cell at Indian Institute of Management - Bangalore, as part of its Social Cohort Programme 2019.

Founded by three engineers-turned-Teach for India (TFI) fellows in 2017, Inqui-lab works with students from classes 6-9 in Hyderabad and Bengaluru to help government and budget schools turn hubs of creativity and innovation.

"It all started when one of our co-founders, Eshwar Bandi, took some random objects like magnets and solar panels to a TFI classroom. He was amazed to see the ideas students came up with to solve basic problems they faced in their everyday life. Later, we started doing it in other schools and the phenomena was the same everywhere. We wanted to scale up to make it a project for schools to help students develop their problem-solving sk-ills," said Sahithya Anumolu, co-founder, Inqui-lab. Vivek Pidempally is third other co-founder.

Inqui-lab now works with 25 schools, five of which are in Bengaluru. It has a two-year weekly innovation programme that can be adopted by government high schools.

"More than helping students develop and market their products, our focus is on helping them develop these skills and induce creative confidence, design thinking, collaboration and prototyping abilities, which are the future skills," said Sahithya.

"We are teachers first and required help to think like entrepreneurs. The training at NSRCEL helped us have a bigger vision," she added.

The programme is conducted as part of regular classes in these schools. In Bengaluru, the startup has tied up with Mantra4Change, which implements things on the ground.

"Students love the programme as it's for the first time that they get to work with sensors, solar materials, electrical circuits and other stuff. Unlike in other labs, students here have to ideate and come up with projects which can solve simple problems of their lives," said Anu Nayudu, of Mantra4Change.

Title: Mumbai: Former ACP’s daughter duped of Rs 19 lakh in online matrimonial fraud
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The daughter of a retired assistant commissioner of police (ACP) from Mumbai was duped of Rs 19 lakh by a conman whom she had met on a matrimonial website. In his profile, the man had identified himself as Mithilesh and said he was vice-president of an e-commerce company based in Delhi, said the police.

Based on the 40-year-old’s victim complaint filed on Tuesday, the Andheri police registered a case under the Indian Penal Code and the IT sections for impersonation and cheating and are trying to trace the suspect through his email address, IP address and bank account where she transferred the money. The victim had never met the accused in person, said a police officer.

The complainant, who is employed with a private firm as a general manager, told the police that after she uploaded her profile on the matrimonial site, she got an email from Mithilesh in February 2019. A police officer said: “The victim got impressed when he told her that he was VP of an e-commerce firm and drew a monthly salary of Rs 1 crore. After gaining her confidence, the fraudster siphoned off money at regular intervals from February to September 2019.”

The complainant said: “In February, Mithilesh called me on my WhatsApp number and proposed. I accepted his proposal, but did not tell my parents about it. He told me that his company was selling a high-end mobile phone at a cheaper price and asked me to tell my colleagues about this scheme. My colleagues transferred money to my account which I then transferred to his bank account, but the phones were never delivered. I have paid him at least Rs 2.7 lakh every month for this discounted mobile phone scheme.”

The police said he even made her transfer money ranging from Rs 100 to Rs 70,000 giving excuses like he forgot his wallet or credit/ debit cards. “The victim finally realised that she had been duped when her colleagues started demanding their money back as they did not get the discounted phones and he kept making avoiding her,” said an officer. She then disclosed the fraud to her parents and approached the Andheri police on Tuesday.

Title: Hospitals turn hostile to PMKAY, cops bear brunt
Content:
Police

Noble Hospital

Ruby Hall Clinic

Jehangir Hospital

Deenanath Hospital

With the government failing to honour its various health schemes, hospitals have turned averse to entertaining them. After turning the back on patients entitled to Central Government Health Scheme (CGHS) and Ex-servicemen’s Contributory Health Scheme (ECHS), many city hospitals have walked out on the MaharashtraKutumb Aarogya Yojana (MPKAY).Most big hospitals are no longer part of MPKAY’s empanelled list, which has 20 hospitals earmarked in the district. The police department has piled up dues to the tune of Rs 1.94 crore to, Rs 74 lakh to, Rs 38 lakh toand Rs 36 lakh toin the city, forcing them to refuse cashless treatment to MPKAY beneficiaries.The present empanelled hospitals in the district include only three hospitals in the city to cover 10,000 beneficiaries here, besides four in Pimpri-Chinchwad and 13 in rural fringes. The policemen and their kin are feeling the pinch of the big names missing from the list.They complain that being unable to access these better equipped speciality hospitals is affecting the quality of treatment they can avail, especially in the case of critical illnesses. Those who are compelled to pay from their pockets or borrow to get the necessary treatment from the hospitals no longer on the panel, also find themselves scurrying pillar to post to get their reimbursement from the department.Last month, a police constable with Pune police’s anti-encroachment cell, Ganesh Gawde, has in fact pleaded in a letter to the Chief Minister, Governor, Director General of Police, and other officials, seeking the inclusion of the big hospitals in the panel.“The big hospitals are the ones equipped with advanced machinery and specialist doctors. The current 20 hospitals are unable to match up to the quality they offer and are able to handle critical ailments. Many times, these hospitals refer the patients to the bigger hospitals not empanelled, putting us in a quandary. Those hospitals have to be incorporated in our panel in the interest of the thousands of beneficiaries MPKAY have here,” Gawde urged.An assistant sub-inspector, who did not wish to be identified, has been trying to recover the money he spent on his treatment from his own department for a while, in vain. “I underwent open heart surgery a year ago, at a private hospital not empanelled. My family had to borrow to take care of my hospital bill. Now I am running around trying to extract the reimbursement. I am also fending for my monthly medication, while the chase to recover my money has become frustrating,” he complained.Another havildar with the Pune police is struggling to garner appropriate treatment for a family member diagnosed with tumour. “It’s been more than a week that I’ve been trying to identify where my dependent can be treated. The treatment is costly and available at a hospital that has exited the panel. I really don’t know what to do now. We don’t have the kind of money needed for the treatment. Our savings have been exhausted on the initial treatment and screening,” he pointed out.At Noble, which was the latest to exit MPKAY’s panel, the medical director, Dr Dilip Mane, explained, “The dues are huge, so we stopped working for the scheme two months ago. The dues have piled up over two years and the officers seem reluctant to pay up. We would resume if they start clearing the dues.” Bomi Bhote, chief executive officer of Ruby Hall Clinic echoed, “The cops serve the society so hospitals were empathetic and continued to treat them despite delays in payment. We did not bother about low rates fixed for different procedures. But with dues from other schemes also piling up we were left no option but to discontinue our cashless service. If the dues are taken care of we will only be happy to take them in.”The Pune city police commissioner, K Venkatesham, acknowledged the issue was becoming a problem, and said, “We are tabulating the pending dues to various hospitals and are working towards getting them cleared. But the number of hospitals empanelled for MPKAY has only increased.”

Title: NZealand look to salvage pride in smoky Sydney
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Sydney, Jan 2 (AFP) Smoke haze could come into play as New Zealand look to salvage some pride from their miserable tour of Australia in the third and final Test in Sydney this week. With bushfires raging across New South Wales state, day two of the match on Saturday shapes up as the biggest challenge with temperatures forecast to soar and smoggy conditions expected. The issue of smoke is a difficult one for officials, who currently rely on a mix of air quality guidelines from the International Cricket Council, state governments and the Australian Institute of Sport. But there are inconsistencies on what is considered "unsafe", with Cricket Australia and the players' association currently working to develop better protocols around visibility and air quality. It follows a Big Bash League match in Canberra being abandoned this month because of toxic bushfire haze. Currently, it is up to the umpires to decide whether conditions are safe, without any formal framework for that decision. With the first two Tests at Perth and Melbourne ending in heavy defeats inside four days, New Zealand will need all the help they can get. Coach Gary Stead admitted the Black Caps were "beaten up by Australia again" in their 247-run Melbourne thrashing and they have had to go back to the drawing board. "We've got to find some areas where we can keep chipping away, make improvements and put Australia under pressure for longer," he said. "When you get put under pressure for the periods Australia have put us under, then you have to question what we're doing. "Australia have three bowlers at 145 kph and a spinner (Nathan Lyon) that's taken over 300 Test wickets so you're always up against it. You don't get a reprieve and that's the hard thing for us." - No let-up - ============= The bright spot from Melbourne was makeshift opener Tom Blundell's gritty second innings century and he is set to retain the role alongside Tom Latham in Sydney. But there is doubt over skipper Kane Williamson, who has had a poor tour. The New Zealand Herald reported that he missed training Wednesday with flu-like symptoms, with batsman Henry Nicholls suffering similar problems. Jeet Raval is the only specialist batsman waiting in the wings, but he has been out of form and was dropped for Melbourne. Australian captain Tim Paine has made clear his team has no intention of easing up now the series has been won, with New Zealand potentially coming under a five-pronged attack in Sydney, starting Friday. Depending on the pitch, they could play two specialist spinners alongside their fast-bowling machine of Pat Cummins, Mitchell Starc and James Pattinson. Leg-spinner Mitchell Swepson, championed by Shane Warne, has been called up to the squad and is keen to make his debut. "The team's doing really well at the moment and it's going to be a tough team to crack into," he said. "But I'm here and going to be preparing to play. That's the only thing I can do." New Zealand's task has been that much harder with strike bowler Trent Boult ruled out after a Starc bouncer in Melbourne fractured his non-bowling hand. They have turned to off-spinner Will Somerville, who was raised in Australia, as his replacement. "The fact he's played a lot of cricket in Sydney during his career for New South Wales will also be helpful as we prepare for this final Test," said Stead. (AFP) APA APA

Title: Delhi Fire: Building collapses after fire at factory in Delhi's Peera Garhi, people trapped
Content:
A massive fire broke out at a warehouse storing batteries in outer Delhi's Peeragarhi area early on Thursday.

V sad to hear this. Am closely monitoring the situation. Fire personnel trying their best. Praying for the safety o… https://t.co/O23hIXoxPC — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) 1577942063000

NEW DELHI: A massive fire broke out at a warehouse storing batteries in outer Delhi's Peeragarhi area early on Thursday.Three firemen, who had entered the building to douse the flames, got trapped inside after a portion of the building collapsed due to an explosion in the batteries that were stored inside.An operation is underway to rescue the trapped firemen. The fire department has deployed 35 fire tenders to tame the blaze.Fire officials say that the blaze broke out at 4.25am after which seven fire tenders were pressed into service.However, during this, the back portion of the three-storey building suddenly collapsed after an explosion, trapping the firemen inside.DFS chief Atul Garg said that a team from the fire department, police and the Disaster Management Force has been deployed to rescue the men.In Video: Building collapses after massive fire in Delhi's Peeragarhi, 3 fire tenders trapped

Title: New year, new beginnings: Here are some things that change in 2020
Content:
(Representative image)

Cheaper online fund transfers

Buying a ride may get costlier

New year

cheer for customers of State Bank of India

Bad news for users of

Windows

Green new year

GST gets a makeover

Kickstarting a digital payments culture

Passing the buck

Connectivity boon for startups

Incentive hit for exporters

NEW DELHI: From cheaper online fund transfers to GST getting a makeover , there are several changes that will come into effect in 2020. Here's a look at some of the things that you should know.Effective January 1, as a savings bank account holder, you can undertake fund transfers through NEFT without facing any charges from your bank. Make sure you initiate the transaction online via internet banking or the bank’s mobile apps.Top carmakers including Kia, Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, Nissan and Mercedes have said their cars will cost more.For customers of SBI, home loans are set to get cheaper by 25 basis points. Withdrawing cash gets more secure as the bank introduces OTP for ATM transactions above Rs 10,000 withdrawn between 8 PM and 8 AM.If you use WhatsApp on Windows Phone, the app won’t work from January 1, as WhatsApp drops support and won’t provide updates to the OS.Kerala to bid goodbye to single-use plastic as it welcomes the new year.Businesses with an annual turnover of above Rs 500 crore to implement e-invoicing on a voluntary basis.Companies need to stringently monitor whether suppliers are uploading returns on a regular basis as input tax credit will now be restricted to 10% (from 20%) if invoices aren’t reflected in filings. All new dealers enrolling for GST scheme will have to have Aadhaar authentication.Businesses with annual turnover of Rs 50 crore or more in the preceding year cannot insist on cash payments, and will have to compulsorily provide customers options to pay via digital options such as debit cards powered by RuPay, Unified Payments Interface (UPI), BHIM-UPI, UPI Quick Response Code (UPI QR Code), and others.Businesses accepting digital payments through RuPay cards and UPI payments need not pay Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) charges — the fee paid by the merchant to a bank for routing money through their network.Reliance Jio will start providing free cloud and connectivity services to the country’s startups including Azure cloud services that Jio is bringing as part of its alliance with Microsoft.As the new export scheme Remission of Duties or Taxes on Export Products replaces the existing Merchandise Export from India Scheme, an incentive cut from 4% to 2% will hit electronics and textiles among other sectors.

Title: Pune: Indian Army major loses Rs 19,500 in online fraud
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An Indian Army major (35), who wanted to sell his used smartphone online, ended up losing Rs19,500 to a fraudster. The cheat made the officer scan a QR code and siphoned off the amount from his bank account.The officer lodged an FIR with the Sangvi police on Tuesday. The suspect has been booked under sections 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property), 419 (punishment for cheating by personation) of the IPC and the relevant sections of the Information and Technology Act.Sub-inspector Vinod Shendkar of the Sangvi police said the complainant was posted in Jammu and Kashmir and his family resided in Pimple Gurav. The major had come to the city a few days ago for holidays. “He placed an advertisement on an online marketplace to sell his old smartphone in the last week of December 2019,” Shendkar said.The major received a call around 10am on December 26 from a person who wanted to buy the smartphone from him. The fraudster told him he would first transfer 50% of the amount online and give the remaining after the phone was delivered. “The fraudster then told the major he would send him a Quick Response (QR) code and told him to scan it, following which the amount would be transferred to the latter’s account,” the sub-inspector said.When the major scanned the code he found out that the fraudster wasn’t sending him money, but was collecting it from his bank account. Within a few seconds, Rs19,500 was debited from the officer’s account. “The officer blocked his bank account and tried to contact the person but his cellphone was not reachable,” Shendkar said. He said prima facie probe revealed the amount was transferred to two Unified Payment Interface (UPI) ID’s — in Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh. “Tracking these UPI IDs via the mobile number was difficult as the documents used to procure SIM cards are mostly fake,” an officer from the cybercrime branch said.Senior inspector Jayram Paigude of the Pune cybercrime police said cybercrooks could send links via QR codes to cellphones. “As soon as you scan it, they get access to OTPs, SMSs, banking apps and wallets on your cellphone,” he said.

Title: Dimitrov to ease his way back after injury-hit 2019
Content:
This story is from January 2, 2020

Sydney, Jan 2 (AFP) Former world number three Grigor Dimitrov saw his ranking slump last year as he struggled with a shoulder injury, but the Bulgarian Thursday said he won't push himself too hard, too fast to return to the top of tennis. The 28-year-old was laid low early in the season and was far from his best after he returned to action, although he did reach the US Open and Paris Masters semi-finals. Dimitrov said 2019, where he failed to win a title, had been "quite a journey". "It's going to be a year that I remember for the rest of my life," he said in Sydney ahead of the inaugural ATP Cup team event, his warm-up for the Australian Open Grand Slam. "Yeah, the body checks out pretty good right now. I'm still monitoring a lot of my work, a lot that I'm going through. "I kind of pace myself in the right way. I'm not in a rush, which is also a good thing." The shoulder problem was Dimitrov's first major injury and he said he plans to limit the number of tournaments he plays, particularly early in the season. "I'm not going to force myself to play too many tournaments early on and really look after the body. That's the number one thing," said Dimitrov, now ranked 20. "Clearly I haven't competed for almost the past four months of the year, and so that itself brought a lot of doubts, and dropping a lot in the ranking and so on. "But at the same time, I was able to kind of recover as quick as possible, and hopefully now I'm at a place that can only get better. I'm really going to focus on that." He is not only playing for Bulgaria at the ATP Cup, but captaining the team, a new experience that he is relishing. "It's challenging, no doubt about it," he said. "It's always been a dream of mine to always be kind of on the other end, and I think to be a coach is never easy. "I don't know if I'm going to be a good coach. I can only share my experience, my thoughts with the guys." The ATP Cup, which starts Friday, features 24 nations split into six groups across Sydney, Brisbane and Perth, with eight of them emerging from the round-robin to compete in the knockout phase. (AFP) APA APA

Title: 'AdWise' workplace counselling: 'My boss bypasses me and deals directly with juniors'
Content:
(Illustrative image)

Question: I’m a deputy to my superior, who doesn’t like to interact with me. Moreover, he assigns work directly to my subordinates, ignoring me. Often, I face an awkward situation when my juniors approach me for guidance on assignments which I have not been informed about. I am tolerating this unpleasant situation for the last five years. When I took my grievance to my boss, he said he is not answerable to me. The management appears helpless. This is frustrating as my chances of getting promoted are being blocked. What shall I do?

Rituparna Chakraborty replies:

You should attempt the following:

(Rituparna Chakraborty is executive vice-president & co-founder at TeamLease Services)

Talk to us:

adwise@timesgroup.com

This is indeed a difficult spot to be in, and more so because you have been in this position for the last five years. I assume that in these five years, neither you nor your superior have been promoted. Professionally, that is a huge red flag. Before getting into issues which seem to indicate breeding of insecurity, I would be concerned about working under someone who is not progressing in his career. Your acceptance of the situation for five years amounts to professional hara-kiri.The focus should not be around what your superior should or could do, as trying to change his behaviour may not amount to much. What is equally worrisome is that the management seems toothless or lacks a transparent performance mechanism. Is your superior so indispensable that the management has no other option but to look away? Given that both of you seem to be stuck in the same role, it doesn’t seem so.The final issue is around your inability to guide your subordinates, again, on account of your superior.Make an effort to figure out the reason for your superior’s insecurity. Take independent feedback from your superior’s peers and the HR department on what could be possible reasons. Make use of performance management discussions for insights into why your boss is bypassing you.Be self-aware and honest about your performance. Document your achievements or gaps, which might have caused your superior to lose trust in you. Working on these aspects proactively can help approach the situation differently and could elicit a response from your superiors.Apply to internal job postings (if such an option or policy exists), or pitch for a new role under a different leader.Consider this only after options A and B have been exhausted. This will help you explore newer opportunities within the same organisation and give you a chance to grow.If all the options fail, it’s perhaps time to relook at whether you want to continue working in such an organisation. More so because you have given this issue more time than it deserves.However, it would be good to address your inability to help subordinates or guide them, irrespective of the behaviour of your superior towards you. You could continue to command the respect of your team by successfully establishing yourself as a leader whom they can trust and learn from. It would be good to reflect on this and work towards mending ways for the future.Are you dealing with a tough boss? Are your colleagues being mean to you? Title: Miscreants can strike anywhere, anytime in Bengaluru
Content:
amateur photographer

photographing birds

Immanval Ferdinand

Dodda Amani lake

SD card

Bengaluru

I usually visit Hesaraghatta Lake and Magadi Lake for birdwatching. I never go alone. I prefer visiting the lakes with my friends between October and February when the birds visit these lakes. – Udaya Tejasvi Urs, birdwacher from Yelahanka

FIR

.

Anwas attacked by strangers when he went to a lake near Hosakote to take photos of birds that flock thereIf someone told youwould be injurious to health, you would laugh. But, an amateur photographer, can attest to that.On December 28, Ferdinand, an amateur photographer who works at Amazon, went to thenear Hosakote to take photographs of birds that flock to the lake. But instead of coming back from his expedition with afull of photos of birds, Ferdinand, found himself coming to at a hospital.Around 11 am when Ferdinand was clicking photos of birds at the lake bund, he was attacked from behind with a wooden log.“Two unknown people attacked me with a wooden log. They beat me on my head and on my left hand and I fell unconscious on the lake bund. Later, some people found me unconscious and shifted me to a government hospital at Hosakote for treatment. At 6.30 pm, I was shifted to Columbia Asia Hospital infor treatment,’’Immanval Ferdinand said in a statement to Hostakote police.The police have registered a First Information Report () against the two unknown people under Section 324 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) for assaulting Ferdinand with dangerous weapons.“Our policemen patrol the lake during the evening and at night. This unfortunate incident took place during the day. We will send a policeman to the lake bund in the mornings too. We have registered a case and investigations are on,’’ said Hosakote Police Inspector V D Shivaraju.Meanwhile, lake volunteers and birdwatchers have expressed shock over the incident. They have demanded that the police take strict action against the culprits and beef up security around the lake.“It is quite shocking to know about this incident. My nephew Immanval Ferdinand, a resident of Whitefield, visited Dodda Amani Lake near Hosakote to watch birds and take photos. The miscreants attacked him to snatch the camera, lenses and wallet. I want the Hosakote police to act tough with the miscreants,’’ said Lourd Nathan.Stating that the attack on Immanval Ferdinand was the first of its kind on birdwatchers, Udaya Tejasvi Urs, a photographer from Yelahanka, has advised amateur photographers, especially those working in IT companies, not to visit the lake alone but to go in groups.“I usually visit Hesaraghatta Lake and Magadi Lake for birdwatching. I never go alone. I prefer visiting the lakes with my friends between October and February when the birds visit these lakes,’’ said Udaya Tejasvi Urs.Expressing similar opinion, Manju Vikas Sastry, Secretary of Youth Photographic Society has said the birdwatchers have to be cautious while visiting secluded places.“Miscreants target birdwatchers to snatch costly cameras and lenses which they carry along on these expeditions. I would like to advise them to take photos of unknown persons on their mobile phone if they come across such people. It will help the police to nab the culprits in the event of any unfortunate incident,’’ said Manju Vikas Sastry.The volunteers working at Dodda Amani Lake have described the attack on Immanval Ferdinand as unfortunate and shocking.“We want to create awareness among the visitors on the measures to be taken while visiting Dodda Amani Lake. We have submitted a number of letters to Hosakote Municipal authorities to clear weeds on the lake bund but nothing has been done so far,’’ said Swaroop Bharadwaj, a mechanical engineer who also works as a lakevolunteer.
